fields.headline: Scotland give Hendry elbow
fields.trailText: Colin Hendry has been omitted from the Scotland squad to face Poland in Bydgoszcz next Wednesday.
fields.body:
Colin Hendry's international future took a turn for the worse when the Scotland manager Craig Brown decided, after consulting with the player, to omit him from the squad for a friendly match against Poland in Bydgoszcz next Wednesday.

Hendry is anxiously waiting to find out whether Fifa will take action against him over the elbowing incident in a World Cup qualifier last month that led to San Marino's Nicola Albani being detained, as a precaution, in hospital overnight.

There are other absentees from the experimental 20-man squad, which contains three uncapped players, but Brown felt Hendry's absence would "help cool things down" a subtle dilution in the manager's unequivocal support for the player in the immediate wake of the incident, which occurred near the end of Scotland's 4-0 victory in which Hendry scored twice.

Brown said: "There are a number of factors that I had to take into account when considering Colin Hendry for this game. His club commitments are serious with Bolton going for promotion. But there has also been a lot of hype about the incident against San Marino and I felt that leaving him out would help things cool down."

The three uncapped players are Dundee United's Charlie Miller, Hibernian's John O'Neil and the Dundee midfielder Gavin Rae. A surprise call-up was Scott Booth, of the Dutch club Twente Enschede, who won the last of his 17 caps against Morocco at the 1998 World Cup. Injury accounts for Leicester's Matt Elliott, Newcastle's Kevin Gallacher, Derby County's Craig Burley and Leeds United's Dominic Matteo.

The Fifa disciplinary committee meets the day after the Poland match. Added Brown: "I sent a video and a letter to Fifa explaining mitigating circumstances played a part although I'm not excusing what Colin Hendry did.

"They will possibly give him a suspension although the referee and the other officials never reported it so hopefully he will avoid any serious action.

"Immediately after the game I had not seen the tape and I cooperated with the press so that's why I never pointed the finger at Colin. I basically saw what the referee saw, which was a player lying on the deck. The next morning I saw the tape and the way Colin reacted was not on."

Scotland: Douglas (Celtic), Sullivan (Tottenham); Boyd (Celtic), Dailly (West Ham), Davidson (Leicester), McNamara (Celtic), Pressley (Hearts), Weir (Everton), Cameron (Hearts); Ferguson (Rangers), Gemmill (Everton), Lambert (Celtic), Miller (Dundee Utd), O'Neil (Hibernian), Rae (Dundee), Booth (Twente Enschede), Johnston (Rangers); Dickov (Man City), Dodds (Rangers), Hutchison (Sunderland).

webTitle: Greece drop Zagorakis after positive drug test

fields.headline: Greece drop Zagorakis after positive drug test
fields.trailText: Greece have dropped Leicester's former midfielder Theo Zagorakis from their squad to face Croatia on Wednesday after the player tested positive for anabolic steroids.
fields.body:
Greece have dropped Leicester's former midfielder Theo Zagorakis from their squad to face Croatia on Wednesday after the player tested positive for anabolic steroids.

Zagorakis, who tested positive last month after playing for his current club AEK Athens, has been captain and a key figure in the Greece team throughout their World Cup qualifying campaign. The Croatia friendly is preparation for their home qualifier with England on June 6.

The 30-year-old faces a suspension of up to two years after traces of testosterone were discovered in a routine test after a match with Kalamata and then verified in tests on a second sample last Friday. He claims that antibiotics prescribed by the club doctor for a heavy cold were to blame.

Fulham's celebrations at winning the First Division title have been tinged with sadness at the death of their former manager Alec Stock. The 84-year-old, who took the club to the 1975 FA Cup final, died on Monday after a long illness.

Stock also managed Yeovil, Leyton Orient, Arsenal, Roma, QPR, Luton and Bournemouth, winning the 1967 League Cup at QPR, the Third Division South with Orient in 1956 and taking Luton to promotion in 1970.

The Football Conference has signed a four-year deal worth £1.4m with its sponsor for the past three seasons, Nationwide building society.

fields.headline: Bouncing Villa make late point
fields.trailText: Aston Villa maintained their run of late-season form with a comeback last night from 2-0 and 3-2 down to deny Charlton a victory that they were holding on to gallantly with 10 men for almost an hour.
fields.body:
Aston Villa maintained their run of late-season form with a comeback last night from 2-0 and 3-2 down to deny Charlton a victory that they were holding on to gallantly with 10 men for almost an hour.

Five minutes from time, within seconds of Paul Merson hitting the bar from 35 yards, Mark Kinsella broke away and put Charlton ahead. Then in the last minute Lee Hendrie squeezed in a second equaliser.

With quarter-of-an-hour left Darius Vassell, one of two half-time substitutes, weaved down the right, beating two men, cut in and shot past the heroic Sasa Ilic at the near post for Villa's first equaliser. David Ginola, the other substitute, had scored Villa's first goal.

Football's vogue phrase this season among managers has been "on the bounce". John Gregory may have started it, though at the time Villa settled for even one win on the bounce. But they came here unbeaten in seven and sniffing Europe after Ginola, a late substitute, turned Saturday's game for them against Everton.

It was not enough though, to earn the Frenchman a start. The only change was Steve Staunton for the injured Gareth Southgate. It did little to bolster the defence though he could hardly be blamed for Charlton's lead on the quarter hour.

George Boateng lost possession in the centre circle, Shaun Bartlett and Jonatan Johansson exchanged passes and, as Bartlett closed for the tap-in, Boateng did it for him.

Alan Curbishley was looking for a bounce back and got it. After Good Friday's bad result at Bradford he warned his players they had the five remaining games to nail down their positions for next season.

It was looking good for Charlton until 10 minutes before half-time when Richard Rufus, up in attack, lunged late on Mark Delaney and was sent off. It was Graham Poll's ninth red card of the season, maintaining his top billing.

Before Charlton could regroup, Paul Merson struck Ilics's left-hand post and Ian Taylor put the rebound over a gaping goal. Before the interval, though, Charlton had gone two up. As tempers began to fray, Staunton held back Robinson and Claus Jensen converted the penalty.

Not surprisingly Ginola was on for the second half in a double substitution and in 12 minutes he had swept in Hendrie's pass to reduce the lead. By the 65th minute Ilic had brought off two stunning saves, point-blank from Dublin's header and high to his left to Merson's drive and Charlton were hanging on by a thread.

fields.headline: Defoe puts Bournemouth in the frame
fields.trailText: Jermain Defoe, as he has done so often during his six months on loan at Bournemouth, earned his team three points that not only maintain his temporary employer's interest in the Second Division play-offs but condemns sixth-placed Stoke to a nervous last few weeks of the season.
fields.body:
Jermain Defoe, as he has done so often during his six months on loan at Bournemouth, earned his team three points that not only maintain his temporary employer's interest in the Second Division play-offs but condemns sixth-placed Stoke to a nervous last few weeks of the season.

Defoe's value to Bournemouth cannot be underestimated, his steady supply of important goals transforming them from relegation material at the end of October to a team within sight of the play-offs.

West Ham have kept a paternal eye on his progress while he has been on extended loan, Harry Redknapp making frequent trips to his old stamping ground on the south coast.

It was Premiership-calibre opportunism that earned Defoe his 17th goal of the season in the 37th minute, though he should thank a blunder by Stoke's normally dependable goalkeeper Gavin Ward. After a poor opening in which Stoke's greater physical power was evident, Ward raced to the edge of his area to head away a speculative pass but misjudged the bounce and presented Defoe with an open goal.

Stoke attempted to rally in the second half by taking off the former Leeds United and England defender Tony Dorigo and replacing him with Clive Clarke but could not muster a single shot on target in a disappointing opening hour. It was no surprise when a second substitution was made, with Rikhardur Dadason taking over from Ben Petty. But their only tactic was to hit high balls into the Bournemouth half and it was the home side who always looked more likely to add to their lead. They came close again when Wade Elliott's centre was met by Carl Fletcher, whose goal-bound shot struck a team-mate.

fields.headline: Helguson rescues play-off push
fields.trailText: Watford almost threw away thier early two-goal lead but Heidar Helguson scored a last-minute winner with his first touch to seal victory.
fields.body:
It should never have needed a last-minute goal to rescue this match, and with it Watford's season. The game appeared won when, with half an hour gone, the home side found themselves two goals and one man up.

Somehow Wolves recovered to draw level only for Tommy Smith, their chief tormentor, to escape in the final minute and cross for Heidar Helguson to score with his first touch.

It was sure to be an evening which will linger in the memory of all those present, as well as one that carried old memories for the former Wolves manager, Graham Taylor.

Watford still believe they can have a say in the play-off positions - the least of their aspirations given the talent at their disposal.

There can be few more promising youngsters outside the top-flight than Tommy Smith, the young Watford forward who did much to decide this game in the first half.

Twice within the first 15 minutes he was found in space by Gifton Noel-Williams. On the first occasion he ran clear and squared for Tommy Mooney to score. On the second, he ignored Mooney's calls and scored himself from the edge of the area. On both occasions the Wolves defence played as if they couldn't have cared less.

When Smith was released again in the 33rd minute, Sean Connelly decided to assert himself. He pulled the forward's shirt and with the game still awaiting its first booking, was sent off. The game appeared over.

The referee however knew better and, as the half drew to a close, awarded a penalty for Paul Robinson's push on Michael Branch. With Alec Chamberlain static, George Ndah scored from the spot.

Despite this encouragement Wolves made no attempt to add to the goal as the second half began. Instead they were pegged back for 15 minutes in which the home side could have scored two more.

Allan Nielsen, hit the bar with a contortionist's interpretation of a bicycle kick before Noel-Williams drew a fine save from Michael Oakes with a header from Nielsen's centre. Wolves eventually emerged from their shells to gain some kind of foothold in the game, but were fortunate to score from the first real chance of the half. With ten minutes remaining, Ndah nodded down Branch's corner and Adam Proudlock, a second-half substitute, turned to score.

fields.headline: Chelsea keep Europe in sight
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle suffered his first home defeat since becoming Tottenham manager as his ten-men team succumbed to a confident Chelsea side making a late bid for a European place.
fields.byline: Martin Thorpe at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Chelsea moved another step closer to securing a return to Europe last night with an easy victory over the side now managed by the man who started the foreign revolution at Stamford Bridge.

It was ironic that Glenn Hoddle's first league defeat in charge of Tottenham should be inflicted by his old club. But at least he knows the size of his latest rebuilding job.

His patched-up team, hit badly by injuries and reduced to 10 men by Willem Korsten's first-half sending off, struggled to end a jinxed run against their London neighbours, who they last beat in 1990. Only Neil Sullivan and some wayward finishing prevented a rout.

With a large wage bill to feed, Chelsea badly need a money-spinning place in Europe, memories of which were particularly strong last night for it was a year ago that they were contesting the quarter-finals of the Champions League, eventually losing to Barcelona.

At least Claudio Ranieri has managed to get the Chelsea engine purring again. Confidence is high and after this fourth win in a row their chances of claiming the third Champions League spot, or at least a Uefa Cup place, are more than realistic.

The eventual outcome rests on their remaining games against Charlton, Everton and Manchester City - all eminently winnable - but also crucial encounters with Liverpool and Leeds, both away from home.

With the Spurs squad down to the bare bones - Darren Anderton, Steffen Freund, Sol Campbell, Steffen Iversen and Les Ferdinand were among those missing - last night's team was packed with youngsters and a number of players employed out of position.

So it did not take a genius to work out that Tottenham were up against it. They started brightly and two of the young sters, Simon Davies and Gary Doherty, even went close.

But gradually Chelsea took a grip, and they went ahead on 28 minutes. Dennis Wise swung in a corner to the near post, where Hasselbaink rose and directed a clear header inside the upright.

Things quickly went from bad to worse for Tottenham. First, one of their few experienced defenders, Chris Perry, was carried off with a knee injury, then just before the break Korsten was sent off for a second yellow card after a clumsy late challenge on Mario Melchiot.

Last Saturday Spurs had completed a remarkable comeback to beat Sunderland. But coping with Chelsea's quick-passing advances was beyond them. Early in the second half Sullivan denied Poyet and then Gianfranco Zola before Chelsea extended their lead.

Celestine Babayaro swung in a low cross from the left and Poyet was allowed enough space by the makeshift Spurs defence to stretch out his leg and guide the ball deftly past Sullivan. It was his fourth goal in the last three games.

Chelsea were now in full flow. Sullivan had to stretch to his full extent to deny Wise and Mario Stanic while Hasselbaink somehow contrived to blast over the bar after being set free on goal.

Chelsea's third arrived in in jury time when Gudjohnsen coolly slotted past Sullivanafter a lovely one-two with Hasselbaink.

fields.headline: US cuts interest rates
fields.trailText: The US federal reserve has surprised the markets by slashing interest rates by half a percentage point, the third such cut this year, in an effort to stave off recession.
fields.body:
The US federal reserve has surprised the markets by slashing interest rates by half a percentage point, the third such cut this year, in an effort to stave off recession.

The decision by the Fed's chief policy making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, came during an emergency conference call, and it drops the federal funds rate - the interest that banks charge each other on overnight loans - to 4.5%.

This is the second time this year that the federal reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has presided over a sharp rate cut outside of the Fed's scheduled meetings. The Fed cited a number of reasons for its action, including sluggish business investment, eroding consumer confidence, economic turmoil overseas and a slide in the stock market.

Taken together, this climate "threatens to keep the pace of economic activity unaceptably weak," the Fed said in a statement.

The Fed has cut interest rates by a total of 1.5 percentage points this year in an effort to stimulate the US economy. The last rate reduction came on March 20. The Fed cut the funds rate for the first time this year on Jan. 3, in a rare inter-meeting move. It followed that with another cut on January 31.

In the past, Fed chairman Alan Greenspan has said one of the biggest factors affecting whether or not the economy slides into a full-blown downturn is whether consumer confidence holds up during the slowdown.

webTitle: American markets rebound as fears of recession recede

fields.headline: American markets rebound as fears of recession recede
fields.trailText: US stock markets shrugged off a wave of profits warnings from some of the world's leading technology companies yesterday amid hopes that the economy would not sink into a full-scale recession.
fields.body:
US stock markets shrugged off a wave of profits warnings from some of the world's leading technology companies yesterday amid hopes that the economy would not sink into a full-scale recession.

A profits warning from Cisco, the leading maker of network hardware, prompted concerns of a huge sell-off on Wall Street. Yet the technology-dominated Nasdaq composite index had managed to overturn an earlier decline of 2% by noon - even with a warning from PSINet, the internet services provider, that it faced a $5.03bn (£3.5bn) loss and could run out of cash.

The Dow Jones industrial average also erased most of its earlier losses with a fall of just a few points by lunchtime.

fields.headline: BT recruits lose final salary pension
fields.standfirst:
Debt-laden company joins exodus in attempt to cut costs

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: BT has closed its traditional final salary pension scheme to new employees in an attempt to cut costs, writes Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
Debt-laden BT has closed its traditional final salary pension scheme to new employees in an attempt to cut costs, it was disclosed yesterday.

Many experts believe final salary schemes offer workers a better deal because they guarantee a certain level of pension benefits at retirement.

From this month all new BT employees will only be able to join the company's money purchase pension scheme, which offers no such guarantee.

With money purchase schemes, the value of the pension an individual receives is determined by how much is put in and the performance of the stockmarket. BT, which is trying to reduce its £30bn debt, said it made the change because money purchase schemes were more flexible and better suited to today's workers, who will often move jobs several times in their lives.

BT's £25bn final salary scheme - where the pension an individual gets is based on their salary at or near retirement - is thought to be the biggest in the country.

Lane Clark & Peacock, a firm of consulting actuaries, has said that the move away from offering traditional final salary schemes means "increased uncertainty and volatility for the employee, who is far less able to bear the risks of stockmarket fluctuations than large companies".

BT is the latest employer to close its final salary scheme to new employees. ICI adopted a similar strategy several months ago.

The change will not lead to any immediate reduction in BT's £167m annual pensions bill. It means that the company's pension costs will be more predictable; for new employees it will not be committed to paying out a particular level of pension.

A spokesman played down any impact on costs, saying that the BT Retirement Plan money purchase scheme was designed to be more flexible than the traditional scheme. "There has been a lot of research done which found that staff move around all over the place these days and this pension would be far more appropriate for that sort of workforce," he said. The change had been made following consultations with unions.

A survey last summer by Lane Clark & Peacock found that 10 of the FTSE 100 companies - all in the technology, media and telecoms sectors - offered money purchase schemes exclusively, while a further seven had closed their final salary schemes to new staff. It expected the trend towards money purchase to continue.

webTitle: Veteran film boss takes top Yahoo! job

fields.headline: Veteran film boss takes top Yahoo! job
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Yahoo!, the world's most visited internet portal, yesterday appointed a veteran film studio boss as its chairman and chief executive, prompting speculation about a change of direction for a company founded by two students.
fields.body:
Yahoo!, the world's most visited internet portal, yesterday appointed a veteran film studio boss as its chairman and chief executive, prompting speculation about a change of direction for a company founded by two students.

The appointment of Terry Semel, former co-head of the Warner Brothers film studio, marks a departure for the once high-flying internet company which has suffered from the sharp downturn in online advertising over the past year.

Mr Semel, 58, will replace Tim Koogle, the former communications industry executive who announced his decision to step down a month ago.

Mr Koogle, known as TK in the company, had intended to remain as chairman but yesterday's statement said that he would take on a "transitional role" of vice-chairman until August. The 49-year-old executive, who joined Yahoo! in 1995 and was named one of the world's top 25 executives by BusinessWeek magazine four years later, will remain as a board director.

Analysts said yesterday that the appointment of Mr Semel underlined Yahoo's desire to become a mainstream media company. It could also presage further acquisitions and alliances for one of the few profitable internet businesses.

Jordan Rohan, analyst at Wit SoundView, said the choice of "somebody ... ingrained in old media for so long" was surprising. "It does suggest a different direction for Yahoo!, one where they create content."

Shares in Yahoo!, which attracts more than 57m visitors to its site each month, edged down in a weak market to just over $17 (£11.85) yesterday. They have fallen more than 90% in value over the past year as doubts about the internet were followed by fears of a slowing economy.

A 24-year veteran of Warner Brothers, Mr Semel was credited with increasing earnings at the studio from $100m to more than $1bn by the time he and his partner, Bob Daly, left in 1999. The film studio was profitable in 19 of his 20 years in charge and ranked as number one or two in terms of box office takings.

He and Mr Daly left after several years of expensive box office flops such as Stanley Kubrick's Eyes Wide Shut. Mr Semel subsequently founded Windsor Media, an advisory business.

In a statement yesterday he said: "Yahoo! is a company with incredible potential ... The opportunities for combining traditional marketing and media with the interactivity of the internet are extraordinary. I look forward to applying my background to help Yahoo! successfully leverage both."

One analyst said Mr Semel's expertise in the entertainment industry would propel it into looking more closely at delivering new types of media over the internet.

The details of Mr Semel's pay package were not revealed yesterday. He bought 1m shares as part of his agreement to join by May 1. Mr Koogle earned $310,000 in salary alone last year.

Founders and "chief Yahoos!" Jerry Yang and David Filo have an 8% stake in the company.

Yahoo has been rocked by several executive departures in recent months, including the head of its European operations. President and chief operating officer Jeff Mallett and chief financial officer Susan Decker will continue in their roles, reporting to Mr Semel.

fields.headline: Philips to cut 7,000 jobs
fields.standfirst: Electronics group's profits warning delivers body blow to tech sector
fields.trailText: Electronics group Philips sent shock waves through the global hi-tech industry yesterday with a warning that it expects to be in the red during the second quarter and plans to cut up to 7,000 jobs.
fields.body:
Electronics group Philips sent shock waves through the global hi-tech industry yesterday with a warning that it expects to be in the red during the second quarter and plans to cut up to 7,000 jobs.

Markets are already braced for more bad news in Europe, with Swedish telecommunications equipment maker Ericsson tipped to slash thousands more jobs when it delivers results later this week.

The gloom deepened when Eastman Kodak, the world's biggest maker of photographic film, said it would cut at least 3,000 jobs and take a pretax charge of up to $450m in the wake of falling profits.

Philips' shares slumped 16% to 27.11euros - their lowest level for 18 months - while other tech stocks took a heavy battering too as the group revealed the impact of the slowdown in the crucial telecommunications equipment and personal computer markets.

Philips warned last month that two important divisions - components and consumer electronics - would slip into the red during the first three months of the year.

But yesterday's results still took analysts by surprise as solid performances from medical equipment, lighting and domestic appliances proved insufficient to offset declines in the two problem divisions. Consumer electronics lost 99m euros (£61m) - mainly due to losses at the mobile handset operations - while components lost 114m euros. The two divisions had made profits of 83m euros and 24m euros in the same period last year.

Overall net income for the group in the first three months amounted to 106m euros, as opposed to analysts' expectations of around 275m euros and 614m euros a year earlier. "The numbers blew me away. This isn't going to get better. Consumer electronics was the business they were meant to have been sorting out, at least with components it's more a sector issue," said Navdeep Sheera, an analyst at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

Philips added to the sombre mood with its view of the immediate outlook. "We see no signs that the slowdown in economic activity in certain parts of the world, particularly in the US, is near its end. This will continue to cause low growth and high price erosion for some of the markets in which Philips is active."

Philips, which employs more than 6,000 people in Britain out of a global total of 22,000, gave few details of where the job losses would take place, although consumer electronics and components are expected to bear the brunt of the group's efforts to cut costs.

The components business employs about 2,800 workers in Britain at factories in Blackburn, Simonstone near Burnley, Southport, Durham and Washington.

A Philips spokesman said yesterday that detailed plans would be drawn up over coming weeks but indicated the reduction in jobs was unlikely to be achieved by natural wastage. "We are likely to be looking at laying people off, unfortunately."

Factory closures are not being ruled out, although the indications are that most of the job losses will be achieved by slimming down numbers at individual sites.

Ericsson, which three weeks ago said it was seeking to cut its workforce by 3,000, including more than 1,000 in Britain, refused to comment on reports that it would announce a further 6,000 job losses at the end of the week.

Analysts believe Ericsson has little choice as it tries to cope with slowing order growth and falling prices in the mobile phone market."It is pure mathematics. If you want to save 20bn kronor you can't save on just travel expenses," said one Swedish analyst.

webTitle: NUS warns of limited choices in Abbey takeover

fields.headline: NUS warns of limited choices in Abbey takeover
fields.trailText: The National Union of Students has warned the competition commission that Lloyds TSB's £19bn takeover bid of Abbey National would "limit" choice for students.
fields.body:
The National Union of Students has warned the competition commission that Lloyds TSB's £19bn takeover bid of Abbey National would "limit" choice for students.

The NUS, which has a relationship with Abbey National over current accounts, recently held a private meeting with the commission's inquiry chairwoman, Denise Kingsmill, at which it voiced its concerns about Lloyds' ambition to take over Abbey.

The commission has until June 12 to advise Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, on whether the bid raises any competition concerns and should be blocked or potential remedies adopted. Mr Byers referred the bid, which Abbey is opposing, to the commission on the advice of the office of fair trading.

Joanna Wells, the director of marketing at the NUS, said the competition commission has asked for its view on the potential merger.

Ms Wells said she had told the commission that if the takeover was allowed to happen, "then student choice is limited".

She was invited to give her views to the competition commission after last month's public hearing.

Ms Kingsmill, the commission's deputy chairman, has insisted she and her fellow members of the investigation team have yet to make any decision on whether the bid raises competition concerns and is against the public interest.

The commission declined to comment yesterday, saying it was up to individuals to decide whether to make their views public.

Abbey National declined to comment. Lloyds TSB said: "We firmly believe the merger with Abbey National will not be detrimental to any of our customers, including students". Abbey said had taken a 10% share of student account market since the relationship with the NUS was initiated, last August.

Persuading students to open current accounts is considered important by banks because of the traditional statistics which show bank customers are reluctant to move their accounts. Fresh initiatives are under way in the sector to try to make it easier for customers to switch current accounts.

fields.headline: Your sinking pension
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Pensions are in the news. This is partly for good reasons, (stakeholder pensions), and partly for less good reasons stemming from pensions misselling and recent problems at the Equitable.
fields.body:
Pensions are in the news. This is partly for good reasons, (stakeholder pensions), and partly for less good reasons stemming from pensions misselling and recent problems at the Equitable. But there is a more important, more fundamental and worrying reason for pensions to be in the news. This is the impact of current deflationary pressures, which are driving down investment returns. The problems at the Equitable were a direct result of this trend.

For the past 50 years all participants in economic life have become accustomed to inflation. They are well used to beating inflation by leveraging property investment, buying equities and participating in the restructuring of the old economy with management buy-outs and management buy-ins in the venture capital industry. This process was stimulated by the tendency of governments and central banks to keep interest rates too low during the inflation of the 1970s and 1980s. The reverse risk is now occurring and it will not be long before the Bank of England's monetary policy committee will have to write to the chancellor to explain why they have undershot the inflation target, which is another way of saying that they are driving deflation.

The good news of stakeholder pensions (and the great encouragement to the public to focus on saving for retirement) must be tempered by two important factors. First, the creation of stakeholder pensions (with very modest initial commitments) is just the first step of a massive risk-transfer from the government to the public. The politicians have realised that they will not be able to afford the cost of old-age pensions and the health service and other forms of social security. So one of them has to go, and health and social security are still sacred cows in terms of risk-transfer to the public. It is by no means facile to believe that in 25 years' time state pensions will largely have been eliminated. Thus the allowable contribution to stakeholder pensions will rise steadily in order to facilitate this process.

This explains why some far-sighted fund managers have offered to run stakeholder pensions free to start with, as they correctly foresee massive increases of funds under management in this area in the future. The bad news (as personal pension holders are discovering) is that as interest rates fall and investment yields decline, so do the value of annuities. At present this is also coupled with being forced to buy an annuity at the age of 75.

The decline in investment yields will drive up the savings rate as people wake up to the new situation and realise how underfunded their pensions are. Ask anyone aged 50 or older - they have seen annuity yields fall by between 30% and 40% (people fail to realise that this is what a decline from, say, 9% to 6% really means). Although inflation may be falling, it is not producing parallel price declines. All of this will reinforce the disinflationary pressure.

Another factor that inflation has bred into the system is the concept of "total returns", adding the capital appreciation to the dividend on equities, for instance. Again the former element has been fuelled by inflation and the enormous appreciation of equity prices in recent years, which in turn has been driven by the restructuring of the old economy and the impact of technology.

The necessary adjustment to this post-inflationary environment is only just starting and will need to be fuelled by further cuts in interest rates. Unless this happens quickly so that everyone's mindset is thereby adjusted, the threat to pensions both in terms of their value and the speed with which government can transfer the risk to the private sector will increase. It is good news from the UK's point of view that we have made a major start in the risk-transfer through personal pensions and now stakeholder pensions. Europe is very far behind in recognising this problem.

The second ticking time bomb in the pensions field concerns companies (and this includes most of the largest old economy companies) which still offer final salary-linked pensions, usually with upwards-only RPI indexing. If inflation goes to zero or even negative, these companies will be faced with annually increasing pension commitments, which could prove crippling. This is exacerbated by the fact that these companies have been shrinking their payrolls by pensioning off 50 year olds, and will have to support this pension bill with fewer active members. No wonder more and more companies are closing such schemes to new joiners.

 David Potter is former chairman of City bankers Guinness Mahon.

fields.headline: £4.5m for pizza chain's shy brothers
fields.trailText: The brothers who founded pizza chain Ask Central tasted success yesterday when they pocketed more than £4.5m from selling the firm's shares.
fields.body:
The brothers who founded pizza chain Ask Central tasted success yesterday when they pocketed more than £4.5m from selling the firm's shares.

Adam and Samuel Kaye, whose group comprises 104 restaurants, sold 1.25m shares at 175p, netting £2.18m each. As other directors joined in the sell-off, the board received a total of £6.7m.

The Kaye brothers are the sons of chairman Philip Kaye, a restaurateur who made his name by running the Golden Egg chain, an early pioneer in fast food.

The pair are resolutely publicity shy, and were unavailable for comment yesterday.

webTitle: Stand up if you hate the fans who do

fields.headline: Stand up if you hate the fans who do
fields.trailText: Picking on fans who stand is only half of it - it's really the serial burger bar visitors and mobile phones nuts who should be targetted as menaces in the stands.
fields.body:
By threatening to rope off sections of Old Trafford if fans do not sit down, the local council has made its position on standing at football matches clear enough. I wonder where it stands on crouching, though.

Many football fans spend a large part of the game in a position halfway between leaping in elation and slumping in despair, a sort of anticipatory squat in which the bottom hovers six inches above the seat. I'm not sure what the safety risks of this are but it certainly plays havoc with the hamstrings.

The trouble in Manchester was easy to foresee. Ever since stadiums went all-seat there has been conflict between those who rise to their feet in moments of excitement and those who shout at them whenever they do so.

In this matter my sympathy is with the former group, if only because the latter tend to be the sort of older fans who always block your view of a last-minute equaliser when they start leaving early "to avoid the traffic".

The effect of this constant battle on the atmosphere at football matches has been deadening. Nowadays there are a number of Premiership grounds where the loudest chanting comes from the ranks of elderly men in car coats and string-backed driving gloves who yell "Sit down! Sit down!" in unison whenever anyone in front of them so much as cranes his or her neck.

It is plain that such people would be happier if football had the more tranquil, pastoral ambience of county cricket. Here the punters enjoy the opportunity to sit quietly in the fresh air for hour upon hour doing absolutely nothing. It is like fishing without the maggots. And woe betide anyone who threatens to disturb the peace.

Once at a match in Scarborough several decades back a series of vehement appeals from the Yorkshire medium-pacer Arthur "Rocker" Robin son so incensed one white-haired spectator that he rose slowly to his feet and yelled, "Will you shut up, Arthur? Some of us are trying to have a kip."

He spoke for the majority. It is an attitude that already prevails in some sections of the non-league game. At a midweek Northern League match a couple of seasons ago some garrulous away fans were asked to stop singing by the home side's secretary because "there are lads in the clubhouse trying to watch Inspector Morse".

In truth, of course, few members of a football crowd sit down for the full 90 minutes. There are those who come late, those who slip away early and those who combine the capacity to down 10 pints with a bladder the size of a Subbuteo ball.

The increase in stadium catering facilities has exacerbated the problem. Enjoyment of any game these days is bound to be regularly disturbed by some bloke, generally so wide, vast and neckless that if he sprayed himself green he would be a dead-ringer for Thunderbird 2. He apparently suffers from a medical condition that means he has to eat a hot dog and chips every 15 minutes or he will lapse into a coma.

This fellow's twice-per-half trip back from the burger bar is invariably accompanied by the following commentary: "Mind your backs. 'Scuse, pal. Can you just lift your bag up, pet? Oops! Sorry. Hey, calm down, mate. It'll wipe off with a damp cloth. It's only ketchup. Coming through. Watch your leg. YEEEEEES! GET IN THE NET! There's no need to get so narky, chief. You'll be able to see it on Match of the Day later. Hey, luv, d'you mind if I get those chips out of your hair, only I'm starving."

Should local health and safety officers widen their net and start to take action against these compulsive grazers they would be assured of my full support. And, while they are at it, what about curbing fans who insist on phoning their mates on a mobile whenever there is a goal?

Having first held the phone aloft to capture the crowd noise, these merry communicators then embark on a conversation that runs: "Gary? It's me. Are you there? I can't hear a thing. Smithy's just scored. Header. Are you there? I said, SMITHY'S SCORED. Did you hear that? Are you there? I can't hear you. Can you hear me? I'm ringing off now, mate ... "

"Bob? It's me. Are you there? One-nil to the mighty Reds! You're rubbish and you know you are, hahahahahaha. Can you hear me? I can't hear you."

If Trafford Borough Council are going to rope anything off, surely it should be these people?

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Hartson keeps Coventry hopes alive
fields.standfirst: Sky Blues on the up as dream of Europe fades for Sunderland
fields.trailText: John Hartson gave Coventry their third win in four to keep alive the club's hopes of cheating relegation again.
fields.body:
Yesterday the Welshman's sixth goal in eight games brought Gordon Strachan's team their third win in four to keep alive Highfield Road's hopes of cheating relegation yet again.

Coventry are now two points behind Middlesbrough, back in 17th place in the Premiership, with four matches to play. But in reality, given their much worse goal difference, they are three points from safety.

So the chances of Coventry extending their 34-year run in the top division are still in the balance. And, with matches against Ipswich, Liverpool and Aston Villa to come before they face Bradford City on the final day, much is going to depend on results elsewhere.

After yesterday's match Strachan accepted that his side remain favourites for the third relegation place.

"That has to be the case," he admitted, "but as long as we stay in there, annoying people, the others will not be able to shake us off."

A Sunderland side once hopeful of a Champions League place but for whom the prospect of European football is now almost lost over the horizon will understand after this defeat what Strachan means.

Coventry snapped at their heels from the outset and only after the dismissal of Stanislav Varga, following a second booking, early in the second half did Peter Reid's team get the semblance of an act together.

Even then Sunderland's hopes were preserved only by Coventry's wastefulness. Three chances fell to John Eustace in the space of eight minutes just past the hour; the first he miscued, the second bounced over the bar and the third drew a point-blank save from Thomas Sorensen.

This was the Coventry of old and once more Highfield Road thanked its lucky stars that Hartson had agreed to join the club from Wimbledon for £15,000 a game.

"John Hartson gives us a presence near goal that we've been lacking," said Strachan. "When opponents see his name on the team sheet they start to worry." The arm which Hartson thrust across the face of Emerson Thome in the second minute was a demonstration of what Strachan meant.

A minute later Jay Bothroyd, the coltish 18-year-old striker for whom Coventry paid Arsenal £1m last summer, caught George McCartney with an ugly foul. Given the benign view Dermot Gallagher took of these incidents Sunderland doubtless felt hard done by when Varga was sent off after two similar though less blatant fouls on Bothroyd.

Yet Sunderland's problem lay with their own lack of organisation and failure to support Kevin Phillips and Don Hutchison in attack.

Part of this was due to the tirelessness with which Lee Carsley and Paul Telfer denied Sunderland's midfielders time and space in an untidy, windswept match.

Coventry's goal was a delight. After 20 minutes an attack launched through Craig Bellamy on the left seemed to be breaking down - "We were screaming for Bellamy to cross it," Strachan admitted - but the midfielder kept possession and the ball found its way to the opposite flank.

Then Bothroyd chested a centre from Eustace down to Carsley, who chipped the ball square to Hartson, who nodded it past Sorensen. Hartson might have had a second immediately after Varga's dismissal but his far-post header bounced on and over the bar.

Sunderland did better with 10 men and once Niall Quinn had joined their attack Coventry lived on their nerves. In fact Quinn could have forced a draw in stoppage time but shot tamely at Chris Kirkland.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Davis gives Fulham their title party
fields.trailText: A priceless injury-time goal by Sean Davis gave Fulham the point they needed to crown their promotion with the First Division title.
fields.body:
The First Division Championship pennant was unfurled and another fat bonus is on the way to Harrods' footballing department. But this was the hardest-earned money of Fulham's extraordinary season.

Until Sean Davis's equaliser deep into injury-time - at which point Craven Cottage appeared to detonate - it seemed like the longest day for Fulham's players, supporters and officials, among them the overlord Mohamed Al Fayed.

England's most famous shopkeeper did not join the celebratory throng on the pitch for a long time. Perhaps he was still recovering from the surprise of the young midfielder's superb curling shot 40 seconds from the end of the four minutes of added time.

Wednesday had done their darnedest to ruin Fulham's celebrations, which started on Saturday with promotion. The referee Eddie Wolstenholme was also in party-pooping mood, booking Fulham's scorer for stripping off his shirt.

It was a measure of the spirit instilled by Wednesday's caretaker manager Peter Shreeves in his dozen games that an anxious Jean Tigana after the break sacrificed his three senior midfielders - Bjarne Goldbaek, John Collins and Lee Clark - in pursuit of an equaliser. Fulham's approaches became longer and more hopeful.

Even so a Route One fling late on almost brought reward when Kit Symons launched the ball forward and Kevin Pressman fumbled under pressure from Luis Boa Morte. But Louis Saha could not exploit the loose ball. Fulham's frustration reached a new high when in injury-time Saha appeared to have scored his 30th goal of the season with a header but Pressman somehow palmed the ball away.

It seemed that the championship celebrations would be delayed but the 21-year-old Davis, the youngest Fulham player on parade yesterday, was not prepared to wait.

The substitute Barry Hayles threaded a pass to Davis, who responded with a curling shot from 12 yards high inside Pressman's left-hand post.

Less happy was Fulham's United States goalkeeper Marcus Hahnemann, making his league debut after two years. In the 45th minute he misjudged a Gerald Sibon corner, punching it into his own net off a post.

Afterwards Collins described what it meant to claim the championship. "It means as much to me as winning the French title and playing for Scotland so many times. Today the first half was one of the most one-sided I have ever played in. We tried to play in our usual way but didn't get the ball into the box enough."

Are Fulham good enough for the Premiership? "We'll soon find out," the player-coach replied. "We've got a lot of good players and I'm sure the manager will bring in new faces in the summer. We've nothing to fear. We'll go there and enjoy it."

fields.headline: Liverpool's late larceny
fields.standfirst: McAllister's injury-time strike secures derby double
fields.trailText: A 44-yard free-kick from Gary McAllister three minutes into injury time left Liverpool clinging to hopes of a Champions League place despite the earlier dismissal of Igor Biscan and a penalty miss by Robbie Fowler.
fields.body:
It may have been chaotic, its spiteful edge never blunted amid the flurry of yellow cards, but Liverpool emerged from the 164th Merseyside derby last night with their first success at Everton since 1990.

Gary McAllister, a calm head amid the mayhem, catapulted Gérard Houllier's side to victory with an astonishing 44-yard free-kick in stoppage time.

With Paul Gerrard expecting a cross, McAllister hit a dipping shot into the goalkeeper's bottom right-hand corner; Gerrard left the field with the angry words of his team-mate Michael Ball ringing in his ears.

"We deserved it," said Houllier, whose side had lost Igor Biscan after the Croatian was shown two of the match's 12 yellow cards. "We stayed calm, even with 10 men, and Gary had a tremendous game. We were strong and solid and the winner was a very justified reward for the players."

"It was a bit frantic, particularly at the end, and we were slow to react to the free-kick," said Everton's manager Walter Smith. "But I'm not going to place the blame on one person. The manner of the defeat was disappointing."

The goal provided the sting in the tail of a rumbustious contest. A less than well respected minute's silence in memory of the Hillsborough disaster set the tone. Everton, who had six players booked, now face a £25,000 fine from the FA; Liverpool will lose Biscan for one match as they retain their interest in three competitions.

Yet the niggles merely added to the flavour of a wondrous contest, which saw the visitors ahead before the whirlwind opening had blown itself out. Jamie Carragher's handball, stifling Duncan Ferguson in the air, was missed as he bundled clear of a cluttered area. The ball was gathered by Dietmar Hamann via Robbie Fowler and, with Everton over- committed, Emile Heskey collected the German's astute pass, held off the retreating Steve Watson and thumped in his 21st goal of the season.

The play rattled along at breakneck pace with chances gleaned more from panic-strewn defending than any attacking poise. Kevin Campbell's ball into the area was squared by Scot Gemmill but Ferguson, looking decidedly ring-rusty, missed his kick; the pandemonium was epitomised by Sami Hyypia's fluffed clearance to Watson and Sander Westerveld's pathetic flap at the full-back's cross, although Gemmill's improvised header drifted wide.

While the visitors attempted to draw Everton's sting, easing passes into what little space existed, the home side muscled their way in among nervy defenders and three minutes before the interval found reward. Ferguson flicked Ball's pass into the area for Campbell to chase and, although Carragher stretched to prod the ball away from the striker's feet, the Scot held off his team-mate Gemmill to crash in the equaliser.

The goal should have given the home side a half-time fillip. Instead it was Liverpool who broke after soaking up a corner with Fowler accepting Hamann's 60-yard pass. Running unchecked into the area he squared the ball for Vladimir Smicer but the pass was deflected off Ball and rolled behind two back-pedalling defenders for Markus Babbel, arriving unmarked, to finish into the far corner.

Within a minute Richard Gough had been cruelly penalised as Fowler crumpled in the area only for the striker, stuttering in his run-up, to strike his penalty against the goalkeeper's left-hand post. Biscan's subsequent dismissal - Liverpool's third in four Premiership contests - and David Unsworth's equaliser from the spot after Hyypia was penalised for holding down Ferguson suggested the visitors might pay for such profligacy.

Then came a frenzied finish before McAllister, who moved the ball forward once the referee had turned his back, had his fun. "We had the belief to win this game," Houllier added. "We deserved it."

Then came a frenzied finish before McAllister, who moved the ball forward once the referee had turned his back, had his fun. "We had the belief to win this game," Houllier added. fields.headline: Palace revolt as Bolton take all
fields.trailText: The Eagles have landed - in one hell of a mess. League Cup semi-finalists in January, Crystal Palace's form has slumped dramatically since and another defeat yesterday keeps them rooted in the bottom three. In contrast Bolton were assured and confident as they stayed on the coat-tails of second-placed Blackburn.
fields.body:
The Eagles have landed - in one hell of a mess. League Cup semi-finalists in January, Crystal Palace's form has slumped dramatically since and another defeat yesterday keeps them rooted in the bottom three. In contrast Bolton were assured and confident as they stayed on the coat-tails of second-placed Blackburn.

Palace have taken five points from their last 33 and the frustration at last got to the fans, who greeted the final whistle with cries of "Smith out". The man in question, the manager Alan Smith, must now hope his team win everyone round in the remaining four games. But only one of those is at home and the three away are must-wins against fellow strugglers: Stockport, Portsmouth and Tranmere.

The last time Palace were out of the top two divisions the nation was celebrating the Queen's silver jubilee. But, with the country now laughing at Sophiegate, a return to the nether regions is a distinct possibility.

The last thing they wanted to do was hand the opposition an early lead. But on 11 minutes the Palace keeper Aleksandrs Kolinko's throw-out to Craig Harrison was too strong, fell straight to Paul Warhurst and the former Palace warhorse crossed for Ian Marshall to head home.

It was typical of a scrappy game that was full of chances. They fell mainly to Bolton as a dozy Palace defence committed error after error. Dean Holdsworth went close three times before the break, Nicky Summerbee hit the post and Ricardo Gardner somehow missed the target from a yard out.

Palace also went close in the first half. Dougie Freedman hit the bar and Fan Zhiyi's free-kick forced a fine save from Matt Clarke.

The home side applied early pressure after the break but again it was Bolton who created the better chances. Kolinko saved well from Gardner and Holdsworth was too greedy on a three-v-two Bolton break.

But the visitors' battling, confident approach deserved another goal even if it came courtesy of a second error from the Palace keeper. Summerbee found himself in possession, unmarked but tight on the right, and quickly chipped in a ball which Kolinko, in trying to push over the bar, merely helped into the net.

The game was all over and Smith was left to try to pick up the pieces. "We're confident we can get out of it," he said. "But we need to show some battling qualities. We'll see how much we've got."

fields.headline: Eranio flair lights the path to safety
fields.trailText: Before kick-off Derby County's manager Jim Smith calculated his team needed two wins from their remaining games to preserve their Premiership status and, apart from a couple of second-half sorties from Leicester, there were rarely any doubts that this would be one of them.
fields.body:
Before kick-off Derby County's manager Jim Smith calculated his team needed two wins from their remaining games to preserve their Premiership status and, apart from a couple of second-half sorties from Leicester, there were rarely any doubts that this would be one of them.

The victory - courtesy of Paul Boertien's first Premiership goal and Stefano Eranio scoring what could be his last goal for the club before he returns to Italy to end his playing career - leaves Derby five points clear of the bottom three with four games left.

Their superior goal difference to Coventry City effectively extends the safety margin to six points but Smith's chickens remain firmly uncounted. "Four or five weeks ago I said 38 points would be enough to see us safe but we're now looking at 41," Smith said.

With fixtures against Manchester United, Arsenal and Ipswich Town to come, Saturday's visit from bottom-of-the-table Bradford City is the most likely source of salvation.

Deon Burton was sent off here before the end of an intense east midlands derby for head-butting Leicester's Robbie Savage and will be suspended for the final two games of the season.

Much of the intensity was cranked up by Savage. Though his straw-coloured and stringy hair made him resemble Worzel Gummidge, he was anything but a benevolent scarecrow.

His antics went unpunished by the referee Mark Halsey but they did not escape Smith's indignation. "If Burton did head-butt him, then he will be severely dealt with," Smith said. "I didn't see the incident but what I did see was a certain Leicester player making a meal of something. I am disappointed with how Robbie Savage plays the game. He's a good enough player not to do that."

Leaving aside the less acceptable aspect of Savage's display, had several of his colleagues matched his passion and will to win then Leicester might have made more of a match of things. County always looked the likelier winners and Boertien's right-footed strike in the 24th minute confirmed their dominance. The young defender's goal followed fine work by Eranio, who added his name to the score sheet when he ended a mazy run by sliding the ball past Simon Royce.

The hosts were rarely troubled apart from two headers from corners shortly after half-time. Gary Rowett's was cleared off the line by Chris Riggott and Mart Poom tipped Arnar Gunnlaugsson's to safety via the crossbar. But City's revival was short-lived, making another dismal day for their manager Peter Taylor.

The defeat means his team have lost 10 on the bounce away from home and six in succession anywhere - a run that has probably wrecked their hopes of qualifying for Europe. "If we win our last four games that will take us to 57 points and we could be lucky and qualify," Taylor said.

"We didn't deserve to take any points today because of our first-half display and, if I'm honest, we don't deserve to qualify for Europe because of the way we're playing."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Jansen's alternative medicine relieves Souness
fields.trailText: Blackburn kept their stuttering promotion push on track but took their time to wrap things up after Huddersfield keeper Nico Vaesen was dismissed soon after half-time.
fields.body:
Blackburn's stuttering progress towards promotion is doing nothing for their manager's blood pressure. Graeme Souness was in a state of constant agitation yesterday as Blackburn, nervy and unconvincing despite going a goal up on the half-hour, were unable even to capitalise on the dismissal of the Huddersfield keeper Nico Vaesen soon after half-time and press home their obvious advantage.

Huddersfield were largely content to frustrate but they needed points themselves in their battle against relegation. Not until the late introduction of Mark Hughes, whose canny craftsmanship benefited the showmanship of Matt Jansen in injury-time, were Souness and the Rovers fans able to breathe easily.

"We stayed in a hotel last night and I forgot to take my pills with me," said Souness, who underwent a triple heart bypass nine years ago and had further surgery last year to improve the blood supply. "So it was not a good day to get me upset.

"When you are constantly attacking, everything has to be sharp. And that little bit of sharpness was missing, although we had four of five good chances. They showed us great respect and said, 'This is how we are going to play. Try and break us down.'"

There was little justification for that respect in the first half. Until David Dunn opened up the Huddersfield defence with a typical weaving run before dragging his shot wide after 22 minutes, Souness had suffered in silence in the stands. But enough was enough. Having stomped through the corridors and removed his jacket on the touchline, few Blackburn players escaped his animated wrath.

The effect was almost immediate as Garry Flitcroft anticipated a headed flick-on from Marcus Bent and raced through to slide the ball, albeit off his shin, past Vaesen.

Six minutes into the second half Vaesen charged a yard out of his area and raised his arms to stop a Jansen lob.

"The linesman said the ball would have ended up in the back of the net," said the Huddersfield manager Lou Macari. Sometimes the atmosphere leads to a referee making that decision. I was hoping he would show some common sense, give him the benefit of the doubt and book him instead."

While Huddersfield posed little threat on the counterattack, Craig Armstrong was able to exploit jitters in the home defence. After taking the ball expertly on his chest, however, his volley thumped against an upright.

Finally Hughes eschewed a shot on goal, rendering three Huddersfield defenders impotent with a clever back-heel that set up Jansen for his 20th league goal of the season, taken with a delightful strike with the outside of his left foot.

webTitle: Carlisle see three reds and Atkins makes four

fields.headline: Carlisle see three reds and Atkins makes four
fields.trailText: Run-in round-up Tranmere look certain to go down from the Second Division, while Paul Alcock heaped woe on Third Division Carlisle by sending off three of their players during the 3-0 defeat to Scunthorpe.
fields.body:
The former Premiership referee Paul Alcock, famous for falling after Paolo di Canio's push at Hillsborough in 1998, made another claim for the headlines at Glanford Park yesterday, sending off three Carlisle players - all for professional fouls - and their manager as the Cumbrians lost 3-0 to Scunthorpe.

Carlisle were already 2-0 down at the time of the first dismissal and did not concede the third until they had been reduced to eight men, by which time Ian Atkins had joined his miscreant charges in the dressing room. The result left the losers three points off the bottom of the Third Division and saw Scunthorpe climb into the final play-off position.

After the excitement of Saturday, when three clubs were promoted, Fulham's First Division title was the only thing to be confirmed yesterday. However several clubs can now be almost sure of their futures.

In the First Division Tranmere look almost certain to be relegated after losing 2-0 at QPR, the second-bottom club. With four games to play they are now eight points away from survival - as many as they have won from their last 12 matches. Defeat on Saturday, when they host third-bottom Crystal Palace and QPR travel to fourth-bottom Huddersfield, would almost certainly confirm their fate.

Andy Thomson scored Rangers' first from Peter Crouch's knock-down, and Crouch himself added the second, running on to Gavin Peacock's through-ball and sliding past Joe Murphy. "It's going to be very difficult for us now," said the Tranmere caretaker manager Kevin Sheedy. "The players are absolutely devastated. It would be easier to take if we were a poor team, but we are playing for pride now."

QPR were alone among the bottom six clubs in winning but immediately above them Grimsby and Crewe, both winners yesterday, can celebrate almost certain survival.

The play-off picture looks more complicated than ever after West Brom's defeat against Grimsby and Birmingham's draw at home to Portsmouth left their positions in doubt as Preston, Burnley and Nottingham Forest won.

With the top two in the Second Division not playing, Rotherham took full advantage by beating Northampton 1-0 courtesy of a Mark Robins penalty on the stroke of half-time, his 25th goal of the season.

The remainder of the play-off places are looking increasingly secure, particularly given the erratic form of Bristol City, 2-1 losers to Wycombe yesterday, below them.

Wycombe's success will have further disheartened the teams currently occupying the relegation places, for whom hope is rapidly disappearing. Swansea's demotion will be confirmed should they fail to beat Oldham on Saturday after they lost 1-0 at Port Vale. Luton, 3-1 losers at Wrexham, may cling on slightly longer but the result is likely to be the same.

Most of the interest in the Third Division is concentrated at the bottom. Four teams are separated by a single point after victories for Halifax over Macclesfield and Lincoln over Barnet. The Bees are looking increasingly insecure having won only one of their last 14 games and having played more games than any of their relegation rivals. Their future is unlikely to be decided before they play second-bottom Torquay on the last day of the season.

fields.headline: Valencia 1 - 0 Arsenal (agg 2 - 2)
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Valencia: Canizares, Angloma, Pellegrino, Ayala, Carboni, Mendieta, Vicente, Baraja, Angulo, Sanchez, Carew. Subs: Palop, Djukic, Zahovic, Alonso, Albelda, Aurelio, Aimar.

Arsenal: Seaman, Dixon, Keown, Adams, Cole, Lauren, Parlour, Vieira, Pires, Henry, Wiltord. Subs: Manninger, Ljungberg, Grimandi, Upson, Luzhny, Vivas, Kanu.

Referee: Kim Nielsen (Denmark)

1 Valencia kick-off this crucial game in Arsenal's season. Not surprisingly they hoof it up and Arsenal get a throw near their left corner flag.
2 Pires breaks through midfield and sprays the ball wide on the left, but Angloma puts it into touch.
4 Angulo shoots from distance wide of Seaman's right-hand post after Keown is out-jumped.
5 Valencia free-kick 25 yards out to the Arsenal right - no surprise to see Mendieta step up and rifle it towards the head of Carew in the box, but Arsenal track him in to prevent a decent crack at goal.
9 Angulo sends the ball on a flight of fancy when he crosses, sorry shoots, no, sorry, crosses towards Carew on the far post, and instead finds an outstretched Seaman.
10 Booking Keown for upending Sanchez just outside the area. The free-kick is lofted straight at Seaman. Just before that Mendieta did well to force the Arsenal keeper down with a solid shot from 20 yards.
13 Arsenal solid enough at the back during this early pressure from the home side but still finding it difficult to get out of their own half.
14 Mendieta's 50-yard pass is just too strong for the chasing Angloma on the touchline - good job too as Arsenal were wide open.
16 Parlour gets up on the left but his cross is headed clear for Valencia to break in response. Yet again they set up camp, yet again Pires tries to break out and is tackled on the halfway line - the ball comes to Carew, he races into the area and shoots with his right from 16 yards, but puts his effort wide under pressure from Cole.
19 Henry has a run at the Valencia defence as Arsenal begin to push the envelope.
21 Carew shoots high over the bar.
24 Pires races away on the left and finds Parlour in the box at the second attempt. Parlour can't hang on to it; Valencia break with Mendieta, who skips past Vieira on his way to the penalty area. Arsenal rattled as Valencia players line up to have go but nothing comes of all the bluster.
25 Carew and Vicente play a one-two for Carew to force a blinding save by Seaman from 10 yards.
28 Mendieta free-kick 25 yards out on Arsenal's left - it misses everyone.
31 Arsenal enjoy a bit of possession after Pires gets away on the left. Henry, Wiltord and Lauren knock it around the area to Parlour on the right before Valencia hoof it away.
32 Arsenal build again and this time Wiltord has a crack from just inside the area, but a deflection takes the sting out of it allowing Canizares to save to his left, albeit at full stretch. Arsenal clearly finding their feet a little more now.
35 Cole, Wiltord and Pires terrorise Angloma on the left before the ball predictably finds its way out to Parlour on the right... and that's the end of that move.
40 Sanchez fluffs his close-range shot and places it straight at Seaman before Arsenal break and Henry has a crack from distance.
41 Booking Angulo for trying to drag down Henry.
44 The home supporters starting to sound frustrated as Arsenal push up with Henry on the left.
45 Booking Parlour for bringing down Vicente on the touchline - looked harsh. One minute extra to play. Half-time. Arsenal doing a good job so far, solid at the back despite some concerted Valencia pressure but confident enough as the half wore on to push up and test the home side. Interesting to see if Arsenal pay less attention to stifling Valencia's full-backs and start the second in a more aggressive manner - or will it be more of the same as the Spaniards become more and more desperate for that one goal?

46 Substitution Ljungberg on for Parlour. There's a surprise.
48 Ayala goes down injured and is stretchered off after getting tangled up with Henry.
49 Substitution Djukic on for the injured Ayala.
51 Carboni has a pop from distance but Seaman stays cool and waves it past his right-hand post.
52 Arsenal free-kick after Pellegrino upends Henry 22 yard out. Henry takes - weak and into the wall.
55 Valencia sitting back and almost inviting Arsenal to have a go - Vieira does just that, passing to Wiltord on the edge of the area. He plays in Ljungberg on the right but his cross comes to nothing.
57 Henry races into the area, but is deflected away from goal by the attentions of Pellegrino, and the Arsenal striker can only find the side-netting.
59 Veiera coming into his own in midfield, starting things off for Arsenal and making crucial tackles.
60 Valencia manager Cuper starting to look agitated on the touchline - expect changes soon.
62 Pellegrino chops down Wiltord 35 yards out for a free-kick - wasted at a point in the game when Arsenal look the dominent side.
63 In the next minute Keown gets in a crucial header in the six-yard box to deny the goal that Valencia require. Sign of urgency from the home side as they step up the pace.
66 Heart-stopping moment for Arsenal when Mendieta goes down in the Arsenal area under pressure from Keown. Keown had his foot out but Menieta took a dive. Howls from the crowd.
67 Substitution £14m Argentinian Aimar on for Angulo.
68 Arsenal free-kick to the right of the Valencia area - straight at Canizares. Henry follows up with sublime skill in the area to tee up an ultimately aimless shot across the face of goal. In his defence, it was a hopeless angle.
71 Arsenal free-kick on the right-hand edge of the Valencia area after Henry jigs around and his dragged down by Djukic for his trouble. Pires takes; results in a corner that comes to nothing.
72 Substitution Zahovic on for Sanchez.
75 GOAL: Valencia 1 - 0 Arsenal Angloma crosses for Carew to climb above Adams and send the stadium into raptures with the goal that could well settle this tie.
77 Substitution Kanu on for Pires.
83 Arsenal pushing up at every opportunity while Valencia, with the crowd now well and truly behind them, knock the ball around as if they have been in this position all night.
85 Arsenal win a corner, comes to nothing.
89 The last few minutes have been hell for Arsenal as they fail to create any late chances and Valencia continue to pile on the pressure.
90 Three minutes of stoppage time to play. Vieira crosses to Henry at the far post, Canizares punches clear for a throw. Valencia clear and break, Vicente goes one on one with Seaman and the Arsenal keeper gets there first. Arsenal pile up for one last chance - Henry shoots from 20 yards but it is easy for Canzares. Full-time All over for Arsenal as Wenger stands disbelieving on the touchline. They controlled much of the game, but probably started to enjoy themselves too much and paid the price. Valencia it is who go through to face Leeds in the first semi-final after the Yorkshire club went through 3-2 on aggregate against Deportivo.
