fields.headline: Music inspector
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston on the debt owed by music students to an extraordinary Victorian - John Stainer
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston on the debt owed by music students to an extraordinary Victorian - John Stainer
fields.body:
There are two simple seasonal formulas for choirs: Christmas equals The Messiah and Passiontide-Easter equals . . . Well, ambitious groups with a decent soloistsÍ budget might have a bash at a Bach passion, but the staple pre-Easter Messiah equivalent is a home-grown work: The Crucifixion. And this year - the centenary of its composer's death - it's getting even more performances than usual.

These days the name John Stainer is synonymous with The Crucifixion, his best-known composition, designed as a parish church Bach Passion substitute. It is left to Anglican music wonks to know that he wrote more than 150 hymn tunes, sheaves of anthems, three evening services and a couple of oratorios: Gideon and The Daughter of Jairus.

What is largely forgotten, other than by enthusiasts for the late-Victorian music scene and the contemporaneous ñrevivalî of English music, is Stainer's immensely energetic participation in almost every corner of it: as performer, composer, musicologist and particularly as an educationalist who raised the status and standards of music tuition in universities and improved the quality of its teaching in state schools.

For the last 17 years of his life, and all his time as professor of music at Oxford, Stainer was Inspector of Music in the Training Colleges and Elementary Schools of the Kingdom, carrying out hundreds of visits to the 43 teacher training institutions.

The chief inspector rank and popularity are tricky combinations, as Chris Woodhead has found, and like him Stainer didn't mince words. His first annual report, according to the November 1884 issue of Musical Times, has some familiar observations: 'These backward students are, moreover, a burden to the music master, they endanger the success of the part-singing, and if they fail in the examination they also injure his professional reputation.' But Stainer then drops the Ofsted tone and expresses sympathy for these trainees and the burdens on them.

Music was actually financially important to schools. In 1870, elementary education had become compulsory for children up until the age of 12. One funding system rewarded schools for the attainments of their pupils in various subjects, including music. Children were tested in singing at various stages. If they could sing pieces learnt by heart, the school was awarded 6d per pupil. For passing more advanced tests, including singing from a score, the school got 1/- per head. Stainer ran a packed career. He was organist at St PaulÍs Cathedral, in which time, says the Guardian in 1878, he raised its choir to a premier position in the UK, and he helped raise the game of cathedral music after a long stretch in the doldrums. He was also professor of music at Oxford University; co-founder of the Musical Association; president of the Royal College of Organists, besides inspector of music at teacher training colleges.

Eminent and popular in his day, Stainer had a long link with the university. From 1860 to 1872 he had been the organist at Magdalen College, for a part of which time he studied for a general arts degree. In 1889 he returned to Oxford as professor of music.

Music was hardly treated seriously as a subject in universities. There were no internal music degrees as such. Oxford offered a BMus and a doctorate in music. Candidates for the BMus, and there weren't many, had to do papers in other subjects besides music. they also had to produce an 'exercise' - a composition showing competence in harmony. Applicants for the doctorate had to write an oratorio and organise its public performance - an expensive operation. These were, effectively, external degrees.

Among his first changes after being appointed professor, Stainer set up music classes and appointed various readers to give lectures in a range of musical branches, including harmony, counterpoint, form and analysis, piano technique and acoustics. His own lectures on music were so popular that university members grumbled about being squeezed out by the crowds of outsiders flocking in.

Stainer was full of ideas, not all of which were realised in his lifetime. One was to set up a sort of conservertoire in Oxford to provide top-class instrumental and practical tuition to complement the academic instruction. He rightly believed that without this the university was not equipping students for professional musical careers. Stainer published a booklet of advice to candidates for the BMu, in which he warned that two categories of candidates risked failure: the 'persevering plodders . . . absolutely devoid of musical gifts' and the musically talentyed who felt themselves above the need for hard graft on the technical side.

He set about beefing up the BMus. Out went simple questions on the dates of birth and death of composers. In came more sophisticated questions requiring wide and detailed knowledge of music of various periods. Yet Oxford had to wait until 1944 for a proper music faculty with a dedicated salaried staff and its own equipped premises.

Arguably music education needs another Stainer. At least two of his concerns are once again giving cause for worry. One is the demise of singing in state schools. The other is the technical ability of music students. Stainer advised serious music students that being able to 'hear mentally' what the eye sees on a page of music is a prerequisite. And that, say most university music teachers, is a skill woefully rare in applicants today.

fields.headline: How did they do?
fields.standfirst: Four have doctorates, five were barristers, six have taught at universities. Higher education has clearly done a lot for the men and women in Tony Blair's cabinet, but what have they done for higher education? Stephen Court reports
fields.trailText: Four have doctorates, five were barristers, six have taught at universities. Higher education has clearly done a lot for the men and women in Tony Blair's cabinet, but what have they done for higher education? Stephen Court reports
fields.body:
Without higher education, few of the present Cabinet would have risen to the positions they hold today. As Tony Blairês first administration draws to its expected close, it is timely to consider whether new Labour has left the sector in better shape than when elected in 1997. But first, what has higher education done for todayês crop of senior ministers?

Of the Blair Cabinet, 20 studied at university or polytechnic. They're quite brainy, too - four have doctorates, five were barristers and six have worked in higher education as lecturers or tutors.

Some have had further to rise than others. Deputy prime minister John Prescott was a seaman in the merchant navy before studying at Ruskin College, Oxford, and Hull University. Northern Ireland secretary Dr John Reid worked as a labourer and insurance clerk prior to gaining a degree in history and a PhD in economic history from Strathclyde University.

The Cabinet's university pedigree also stretches wider than the traditional Oxbridge stable. Eight of Blair's senior ministers form the 'Scottish and Newcastle' tendency. Not a reference to brewing - although several Cabinet members list the parliamentary Beer Club among their activities - but recognition of the number who went to university in Scotland and the north-east of England. The government minister with perhaps the strongest track record in the sector, education minister Baroness Blackstone, has yet to make it into the Cabinet. Blackstone, whose responsibilities include higher education and student support, has a PhD from the London School of Economics. She taught at the LSE, became professor of educational administration at London University's Institute of Education and was Master of Birkbeck College for 10 years before joining the government.

With ministers of Blackstone's standing outside the Cabinet, and a wealth of graduates and ex-academics inside, the outlook for higher education under Labour looked promising. Better still, there was the pre-election cry of 'education, education, education', and the 1997 manifesto pledge: 'Education will be our number one priority.'

But has higher education really benefited under new Labour? Less than three months after victory in the 1997 election, Labour decided to end the maintenance grant and introduce up-front tuition fees for undergraduates. This was in spite of the recommendations of that year's Dearing report, which advocated a student support regime based on a 50-50 mix of grants and loans and the introduction of fees paid retrospectively by graduates once their income had reached a certain level.

Up-front tuition fees were introduced in autumn 1998, and the maintenance grant was phased out in 1999. But it was not long before the cracks began to show. A report into student income and expenditure by Claire Callender and Martin Kemp found that by the end of the 1998-99 academic year, full-time students anticipated owing three times as much as students in 1995-96. The average loan taken out by students in 1998-99 was twice that taken out in 1995-96, and loan take-up was greatest among single parents.

It was perhaps inevitable that the new funding regime would affect participation in higher education. While the number of students under 21 has continued to increase in the UK since the introduction of fees and abolition of grants, applications from those aged 21 and over have dropped.

David Blunkett's regime lasted only two years in Scotland. In autumn 2000, up-front fees were abolished and replaced with an income-contingent endowment payable after graduation. From this year, means-tested, non-repayable access bursaries will be available for young students from poor families, and there will be discretionary bursaries for mature students. The reason, according to the Scottish Executive, was that high levels of debt could be a disincentive to students from lower-income families.

The impact on students suggests strongly that Labour's decision to grasp the funding nettle in 1997 was hasty and ill-thought out. This verdict is borne out by the government's move to raise to 50% the proportion of students in England who will now be exempt from fees.

What about higher education institutions themselves? In general, things have improved. The level of government grant has gradually increased under Labour, ending the damaging years of cuts in real terms to the unit of funding per student. In 2001-2, in England and Scotland, the unit is set to increase above the inflation rate. And in the three years to 2004 there will be an additional £1bn poured into the science budget for institutions' research infrastructure, three-quarters of which is coming from the government.

Nevertheless, evidence of recruitment and retention problems among academic and academic-related staff continues to grow. The main problem is pay, which in recent years has barely kept pace with inflation and has fallen way behind comparable jobs in other sectors. Another is the ever-increasing burden of bureaucracy, which has intensified under the assessment system set in place after the Dearing report.

As for what the future holds, the government has acted on its pre-election commitment to widen access, announcing in 1999 its aim to have 50% of school-leavers going on to higher education by 2010. There have been various initiatives to improve lower socio-economic group access to higher education, particularly since Gordon Brown's attack last year on universities over alleged elitism in the Laura Spence case.

But Labour's long-term plans for university expansion have yet to be costed. And any further rise in student numbers will surely mean a return to cuts in the unit of funding.

Money, as ever, remains a key issue. A report for the university vice-chancellors reckons the sector will need an additional £1.4bn a year by 2004-05. The governmentês response has been to rule out an increase in the proportion of the tuition fee which is payable by undergraduates, without working on alternatives. Although it has patched up the system, the government has not laid the foundations for its planned further expansion. And the proposal by the Conservatives to set up endowments for universities is so expensive - it would cost £89bn simply to replace recurrent grants for teaching and research in UK higher education - that only a small number of institutions could ever be funded in this way.

The issues of student debt and retention, and the impact of Labour's funding arrangements on participation by mature students, are increasingly matters of concern. Moves in Wales and Northern Ireland to follow Scotland's student support system could put pressure on the next government to undo Blunkett's settlement. This would make higher education more attractive to prospective students, but surely not as attractive as it was in the era of the full grant, when most of the current Cabinet were at university.

webTitle: How the high priests of capitalism run roughshod over fears for planet

fields.headline: How the high priests of capitalism run roughshod over fears for planet
fields.standfirst:
With Bush at its side, the world's most profitable firm waits for the science to 'get crisp'

Special report: global warming
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The home of global capitalism can be found just outside Dallas. Set in the midst of a sprawling industrial park, it is a huge, squat pink stone edifice, with a sloping black roof like a rustic villa, but a villa made for giants.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in Irving, Texas and Terry Macalister
fields.body:
The home of global capitalism can be found just outside Dallas. Set in the midst of a sprawling industrial park, it is a huge, squat pink stone edifice, with a sloping black roof like a rustic villa, but a villa made for giants.

It is the headquarters of Exxon Mobil, and it houses a plush management suite that is known across the energy industry as the "God Pod", with the reverence befitting a corporation which last month emerged as the most profitable in the history of human endeavour.

It is no exaggeration to say the decisions made here in Irving, in this high temple of private enterprise, will shape the future of the planet.

Exxon Mobil, which trades in Britain as Esso, does not believe in the certainty of global warming - it casts doubt on evidence that industrial emissions of greenhouse gases are raising temperatures. And not only is it sceptical, it has conducted an aggressive and expensive public relations operation to challenge scientific orthodoxy on the subject, as part of its battle to halt international efforts to put an expensive cap on the smokestacks.

Now a new Republican government, elected with the help of $1.2m from Exxon Mobil, has abandoned the centrepiece of those international efforts, the Kyoto treaty on global warming. The Bush administration, staffed from the president down by former oil executives, has also ruled out plans to limit US emissions of carbon dioxide in the foreseeable future.

The exact link between campaign contributions and the subsequent acts of an administration can only be guessed at. But Exxon's critics argue that the behemoth's assertive embrace of any scientific evidence against global warming - however anecdotal or dubious in origin - has lent it a credibility it does not deserve. It has also given President George Bush "cover" for his rejection of Kyoto.

The mood in Irving in the new Bush era is confident, even jovial. But it is equally clear that its executives have been put on their guard against complacency. Exxon Mobil (born of a mega-merger in 1999) has, to say the least, an image problem.

In Australia, the first ever conference of the world's green parties yesterday agreed to launch a boycott against Exxon and other US oil companies. They want to "send a message" to the companies on the role they allegedly played in getting Mr Bush elected.

"We know we have a giant target painted on our chests," said Ken Cohen, Exxon Mobil's head of government relations and public affairs. Consequently, the company has decided to emerge from its customary insularity and mount something resembling a charm offensive.

And that is presumably why the outer gates of the God Pod were opened last week, and two of the corporation's vice presidents were deployed to explain why Exxon Mobil remains dubious about global warming and how it is nevertheless cleaning up its act the free-market way.

Mr Cohen and Frank Sprow, in charge of safety and environmental health, both insist that Exxon Mobil's position has been misunderstood. Rather than denying the existence of global warming outright, they argue, Exxon Mobil is simply pointing out the room for error in such an ever-changing and unpredictable phenomenon as climate, and urging caution.

"You really can't bring human influence out of the noise of natural variability at this point," Mr Sprow said. "Science is a process of inquiry... I'd like the answer tomorrow afternoon but it may be a decade before the science really gets crisp, because there's so much fundamental information that has to be worked on."

Even though the science may not be rock hard, Mr Sprow said, Exxon is working on alternative energy sources, such as low emission fuel cells for cars, and cutting down emissions in its refineries. It spends $12m a year researching means of reducing carbon dioxide emissions, and has so far managed to reduce its own output by 3%.

These arguments have not convinced the corporation's enemies in the green camp. It is big enough and controversial enough to have galvanised an entire environmental movement, Campaign Exxon Mobil, devoted to keeping it under surveillance.

The campaign's spokesman, Peter Altman, argues that the vaunted $12m in carbon dioxide research is a fairly paltry share of the $17bn net income Exxon Mobil earned last year. Furthermore, he said, whatever beneficial effect that money might have is more than outweighed by the corporation's role in undermining the accepted wisdom that global warming is a real threat.

Other oil companies, such as BP and Shell, have crossed the barricades. At its annual general meeting on Thursday, BP will come under pressure from green activists who have laid down formal motions calling on the company to switch more resources to the development of renewable energy sources.

However, Exxon Mobil has kept up the fight on climate change, going out of its way to support maverick sceptics whose conclusions agree with its own.

"The big difference with Exxon is that it spends a lot of time and money in getting that message across," Mr Altman said.

In particular, the Exxon chairman, Lee Raymond, has referred approvingly to a 1998 petition apparently signed by 17,000 scientists questioning the evidence for global warming. However, it later emerged that the petition had been circulated by a certain Oregon Institute for Science and Medicine, an obscure body of eccentric views whose headquarters turned out to be a large tin shed.

The petition had been disguised as the work of the National Academy of Sciences and it had been "signed" by such authorities as Ginger Spice and the fictional doctors from the sit-com M.A.S.H.

The controversy, Mr Sprow said, had arisen from unfortunate misunderstandings. Mr Raymond had not sought to claim the Oregon petition as definitive, but only to raise provocative questions about the nature of climate change science.

Mr Sprow is urbane and sophisticated. He insisted repeatedly that Exxon is not "in a state of denial" over global warming. However, on two vital issues it is clear that Exxon's position remains unchanged.

It does not have faith in the dire warn ings issued this year by the UN-appointed International Panel on Climate Control (IPCC) and it is vigorously opposed to the Kyoto treaty.

In its latest assessment of the threat, the IPCC found "new and stronger evidence that most of the warming observed over the last 50 years is attributable to human activities". The panel, which consulted about 2,000 scientists from 100 countries, predicted that the earth would heat up between 1.4C and 5.8C over the next century, with potentially catastrophic results.

The report was presented as a scientific consensus, but Exxon challenges that claim. It points to the role of political appointees on the IPCC in selecting and summarising scientific evidence. The same sort of people were promoting a bureaucratic solution to the problem embodied in Kyoto.

Mr Sprow argued that there is little likelihood of Kyoto being implemented by the majority of industrialised countries, and that it would hardly make a significant difference to long-run greenhouse gas emissions even if they did.

For Exxon, these are both reasons to dump the treaty. For Kyoto's supporters, however, they are all reasons to put the treaty (which would require a 7% drop in US emissions between 1990 and 2012) into effect quickly and then move beyond it.

By poking spanners into the works, the environmental lobby believes, Exxon is helping delay concerted action to stave off global warming and the chaos it may wreak with the climate.

"Exxon is grasping at straws," said Kert Davies, the director of Greenpeace's US global warming campaign. "They're looking for everything they can do to reposition the existing knowledge on global warming from fact to theory."

Even before its current public relations drive, Exxon has had remarkable success in making its influence felt.

But perhaps more importantly, Exxon's executives appear to hold sway over a man who once dreamed of rivalling their success but failed as an oil man and had to settle this year for becoming president of the United States.

fields.headline: Researchers enter into the spirit of Edinburgh's underground ghosts
fields.trailText: The spirits who supposedly haunt the vaults and tunnels of old Edinburgh have drawn thousands of tourists to the   capital over the years. But research to be unveiled today by scientists suggests there may be something to the foreboding felt by many who venture below the city's streets.
fields.body:
There is a man in a tricorn hat who whispers malevolently in your ear, a little girl struck down by the plague, and a friendly cobbler who will finger your shoes.

The spirits who supposedly haunt the vaults and tunnels of old Edinburgh have drawn thousands of tourists to the capital over the years. But research to be unveiled today by scientists suggests there may be something to the foreboding felt by many who venture below the city's streets.

In one of the most comprehensive attempts to examine evidence of paranormal activity, more than 250 volunteers entered a network of ancient vaults and tunnels around Edinburgh castle and the Royal Mile, while equipment measured magnetic activity and changes in temperature and air flow.

Apparitions and physical sensations were reported by some of those taking part in the 10-day study. One female volunteer came close to tears after reporting sounds of breathing. Photographs taken during the experiment have also thrown up unexplained anomalies such as dense spots of light and green blobs.

The research, carried out as part of the Edinburgh international science festival, was led by Richard Wiseman, a psychologist at Hertfordshire University. "What we found was really quite intriguing," he said. "People reported far more experiences in the vaults which were allegedly haunted, and we and the volunteers were unaware of the history of the vaults. It shows there is something going on.

"Quite a lot of the experiences reported by members of the public were fairly extreme; some saw figures, a lot felt they were being observed, and some felt their clothing was being grabbed or touched. In one overnight session we asked one female volunteer to sit in one of the vaults in the dark and just tell us her thoughts. Almost immediately she reported hearing breathing from a corner of the room which was getting louder. She thought she saw a flash or some sort of light in the corner but didn't want to look back."

Last night Dr Wiseman was studying whether the scientific data backed up the volunteers' experiences.

Ailsa Templeton, of Mercat Tours, which runs ghost walks through Edinburgh, was not surprised at the initial findings. "Having seen and felt things myself, like footsteps when there is no one there, I am converted now," she said.

"People reported far more experiences in the vaults which were allegedly haunted, and we and the volunteers were unaware of the history of the vaults. It shows there is something going on. "Quite a lot of the experiences reported by members of the public were fairly extreme; some saw figures, a lot felt they were being observed, and some felt their clothing was being grabbed or touched. In one overnight session we asked one female volunteer to sit in one of the vaults in the dark and just tell us her thoughts. Almost immediately she reported hearing breathing from a corner of the room which was getting louder. She thought she saw a flash or some sort of light in the corner but didn't want to look back." Last night Dr Wiseman was studying whether the scientific data backed up the volunteers' experiences. Ailsa Templeton, of Mercat Tours, which runs ghost walks through Edinburgh, was not surprised at the initial findings. "Having seen and felt things myself, like footsteps when there is no one there, I am converted now," she said. Useful links Edinburgh science festival Richard Wiseman's university biography

webTitle: Now we know: good degrees need good teachers

fields.headline: Pay attention, please
fields.standfirst: Now we know: good degrees need good teachers, say Lee Elliot Major and Joe Plomin
fields.trailText: Now we know: good degrees need good teachers, say Lee Elliot Major and Joe Plomin
fields.byline: Lee Elliot Major and Joe Plomin
fields.body:
Students are almost twice as likely to get top degree grades if they are taught by good university teachers, new research shows. The study suggests that the wide differences in numbers of firsts and upper second class degrees awarded at universities comes down in large part to the work of inspirational lecturers, not just extra spending on students for books, libraries or computers.

A studentÕs choice of university can make a real difference to whether they graduate with first class honours or leave with an average degree, concludes the research, which looked into the reasons why some institutions award more firsts than others.

It has long been known that the proportion of firsts awarded by universities varies dramatically across the sector. Cambridge University, for example, awarded nearly a third of its students firsts in 2000, while other universities awarded top degrees to only 15% of students. But the wide differences were put down to the fact that institutions such as Cambridge enrolled more academically gifted students with high A-level grades in the first place.

However, Warwick University researcher Massimiliano Bratti has found that students who had enrolled for degree courses in the life sciences during the early nineties, with the same social class backgrounds and A-level grades, graduated with very different degree results from different universities.

At one university, they might stand an 80% chance of getting an upper second or first-class degree. But at another, their chances could be as low as 50:50. Bratti, who presented his findings to the annual conference of the Royal Economic Society last week, says that this Òuniversity effectÓ can be explained in one of two ways: either some universities are better at teaching than others, or degree standards vary from one institution to another.

Assuming that degree standards are similar across universities, Bratti considered whether the traditional indicators used to gauge good teaching in universities Ñ from spending per student to academic salaries, research ratings, and even Òpeer group effectsÓ Ñ could account for the different performance of institutions. But these factors could only explain 40% of the university effect.

Bratti puts the other 60% down to a variation in lecturersÕ teaching abilities from one university to another.

ÒOne way to explain the differences is that better universities are able to motivate students more,Ó says Bratti. ÒStudents at some universities work harder and longer than those at others.Ó

The findings have come as little surprise to those working in the sector. Sally Brown, head of the Generic Centre, part of the learning and teaching support network for academics, said: ÒOne thing students consistently say to us is that if a member of staff is motivated then it instantly motivates students, and it definitely helps to produce higher grades.Ó

But the results have serious implications for the usual league rankings of universities, says Bratti, because most do not take into consideration the value added by different academic institutions when teaching students. They only consider the degree grades of graduates, and ignore the academic abilities of students when they first enrolled at the university.

It is also important that students are aware of those universities that are best at teaching, he argues. ÒStarting salaries are higher for graduates with good degree results , and a ÔgoodÕ degree result substantially reduces the probability of unemployment and inactivity,Ó says BrattiÕs paper.

Bratti plans to do further research on degrees awarded over a number of years, and for different subject areas, to make sure that the university effect is not simply a result of some institutions awarding first-class degrees more freely than others. He also wants to extend his study to new universities as well as old universities.

fields.headline: Clever clergy
fields.standfirst: Church attendance is falling but not the high academic standards and commitment expected of students working towards ordination. Report by Stephen Bates
fields.trailText: Church attendance is falling but not the high academic standards and commitment expected of students working towards ordination. Report by Stephen Bates
fields.body:
You meet the most unexpected people behind the deli counter at Tesco these days. Take Paul Meunier - part-time at our local supermarket, where his Belgian accent adds a Continental touch to the sliced meats. In his other life, Paul is a keen theology student and has been training for the ministry. At least he was until a few weeks ago, when the 100-mile round-trip to Roffey College at Horsham, Sussex, he made each morning before his afternoon shifts got too much for him and, more importantly, for the ageing family camper van.

Paul moved to Kent from Brussels two years ago when his wife, an English cancer specialist, got a job at Great Ormond Street Hospital. He decided to take up his main interest in evangelical religion when he could not find work as a computer specialist. He hopes to resume studying for the ministry when finances permit. 'I need to look after my family first at the moment. Perhaps this is God's will for me. It doesn't take God away from me. He looks after us very well. Sometimes you have to follow what events lead you to,' he says.

Paul is one of a growing number of would-be Anglican and free church ministers who are helping to fill the shortfall in vocations facing all churches. The numbers training for ordination are low and many clergy concede quietly that there is something approaching a crisis.

This coincides with a slow decline in church-going in an increasingly secular nation where only 8% go to services on Sundays - though two thirds profess a belief in some form of supreme being.

For the Church of England this has meant increasing amalgamations of parishes, particularly in rural areas where some vicars supervise up to six churches, all of which once had their own minister. It has also meant the ordination of women - fortuitously theological and social objections were overcome 10 years ago in time to ease the shortfall - and the use of more non-stipendiary (unpaid) clergy who combine their ministry with secular careers.

Most Anglican clergy still train full-time, undertaking two- or three-year courses with fees of a little over £7,000 a year, depending on whether they have already taken a theology degree.

The long-established Anglican theological colleges last week seemed surprisingly coy in talking about their courses. When the Guardian contacted Westcott House, Cambridge, to speak to its principal, the Rev Michael Roberts, for example, it was told by a secretary: 'I am sure he would not wish to talk to you.'

But the alternative of part-time study, for those already in careers or with family commitments, is proving a successful way of gaining a wider range of recruits.

A league away from the ivy-clad halls of Cambridge, the South East Institute for Theological Education is based in an office block in Chatham. Its students - currently 90 ordinands, 82 Anglicans, five Methodists and three from the United Reformed Church - have to make a heavy personal commitment to three years' spare-time study, including evening courses, seven weekend courses each year and an annual residential course.

Those with jobs in London slip into Southwark Cathedral on their way home from work each week, some go to Greenwich University for their lectures and others attend Kent University in Canterbury.

In ages ranging from late 20s to early 60s, some students are doctors, others lawyers. Women make up about 50%. Students wishing to proceed to ordination are sponsored by their dioceses and undergo screening for suitability. The courses are of university standard, are validated by the Church of England and are certified by Kent.

Alan Le Grys, the institute's principal, says: 'It is a demanding option. As far as the calibre of students is concerned I am immensely impressed. The vast majority bring a wide range of gifts and experiences with them. We are remarkably lucky.

'There is a continuing perception among the church at large and some clergy that these courses are a Mickey Mouse option, but that is nonsense. I have taught in theological colleges and there is no doubt that the graduates we are producing are at least as good as, and sometimes better than, theirs.'

Other churches have not - yet - resorted to such expedients. For Roman Catholics, the Vatican's objections to female ordination, to ending celibacy and to part-time, semi-secular priests have not been openly challenged. The very suggestion that this might need to be looked at again - last year by Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, archbishop of Westminster, in a Guardian interview - is enough to bring on a fit of the vapours. The flow of priests from Ireland, which once met any shortfall, has now dried up as even Ireland needs all the priests it can recruit. John Wilkins, editor of the respected Catholic weekly, The Tablet, says: 'There is no doubt there is a problem. There is just one new seminarian at the English College in Rome this year and the Jesuits have recruited no one for the first time in four centuries.'

There are also suggestions that the priesthood in the western world is becoming a predominantly gay profession. A widely read book by Donald Cozzens, president rector of the graduate school of theology in Cleveland Ohio, last year wrote that 'the priesthood of the 21st century will likely be perceived as a predominantly gay profession. Studies find that approximately half of American priests and seminarians are homosexually oriented and the percentage appears to be highest among priests under 40.'

In England, the Church has not had controversy over that yet, but it has had all sorts of problems with convictions of paedophile priests. Catholic church figures show that in 1999 - the last year for which statistics are available - there were 62 students in England and Wales training for the priesthood and 25 for the religious orders. The trend has varied - in 1985 the comparable figures were 50 and 24, and in 1996, 103 and 16, but overall it appears to be gently downward.

Trainee Catholic priests either study in Britain, at one of two colleges in Rome or at one in Spain, for six years. Father Kevin Dring, himself ordained in 1993, is now director of ordinations for the diocese of Arundel and Brighton. He talks of the need to look positively and seize opportunities for developing a variety of ministries, but concedes there are problems.

'There are lots of challenges facing the Church at the moment,' he says. 'Priests still face helping people with the same joys and sorrows that they have had since the time of Christ. When I feel disillusioned about myself or the Church I always come back to the Gospel, which has been around for a lot longer than any of us. There's no gain without pain, I suppose.'

The Reform movement within the Jewish church is also suffering. Rabbi Tony Bayfield, the movement's chief executive, says it has launched a recruitment campaign to persuade young members to think of studying for the rabbinate. Five students - one of them his daughter - will commence their five year's training at the Leo Baeck college in north London this autumn.

'We have been going through a thin time. One swallow doesn't make a summer, but hopefully our outreach and recruitment programme is beginning to pay off,' he says.

Meanwhile, at the London School of Jewish Studies, affiliated to London University's SOAS, which trains Orthodox rabbis - they do six-year courses, half of which are spent in Israel - Rabbi Abner Weiss is just completing a restructuring of the training. He says they had no difficulty recruiting seven students this year and were able to reject 10 others for lacking the requisite technical background.

Some within the Jewish community suggest there may be a problem with young Orthodox rabbis who are out of sympathy and understanding with the cultural and social mores of their flocks, but Weiss denies this. 'If anything, I am worried about overproduction - there is a limited community in Britain,' he says. Even Orthodox rabbis these days need training in subjects such as time management, fund-raising and counselling, and the college is negotiating to establish a new pastoral theology course with Heythrop College, which may well be shared in an ecumenical fashion with trainees from other religions. In modern theological training, at least, some differences are being set aside.

webTitle: Bonington helps rescue climber from Ben Nevis fall

fields.headline: Bonington helps rescue climber from Ben Nevis fall
fields.standfirst: Climbing special report
fields.trailText: Veteran Mount Everest climber Sir Chris Bonington yesterday assisted at the scene of a serious climbing accident on the slopes of Ben Nevis.
fields.body:
Veteran Mount Everest climber Sir Chris Bonington yesterday assisted at the scene of a serious climbing accident on the slopes of Ben Nevis.

The 65 year-old mountaineer, who lives in the Lake District, had been rock and ice climbing on Ben Nevis at the time. He was taking an Easter break in Scotland, where winter climbing conditions are still surprisingly good for mid-April thanks to the present cold snap, which has seen nightly sub-zero temperatures on Britain's highest mountain for the past week.

Sir Chris was one of a number of climbers who saw the man fall around 500 feet down the side of Number 4 gully on Ben Nevis. The 'first knight of mountaineering' and another six climbers from various different parties made their way to the scene, where the man was lying unconscious, fighting for his life.

The Lochaber Mountain Rescue Team was called out by mobile phone and a Sea King helicopter was scrambled from RAF Lossiemouth in Moray. Due to the severity of the situation, the helicopter landed in Fort William to pick up a local doctor and two members of the Lochaber Mountain Rescue team before heading for the accident scene.

One of the duo from the Lochaber team was Roger Wild, who flew up with Dr Brian Tregaskis, from Fort William's Belford Hospital. Later Mr Wild said, "There were a group of six or seven climbers around the casualty by the time that we got there. Sir Chris Bonington was one of them. They were doing anything they could to help to keep him alive. Once we got there, they helped us put the stretcher together and then load the man on to the helicopter. We were grateful for the help we got from these people, but I would not like to single out any individual for any special mention."

Sandhurst-trained Sir Chris climbed successfully in the Alps and Himalayas as a young officer. He led the successful 1970 expedition to the south face of Annupurna in the Himalayas, and was also the leader of the British Everest expeditions of 1972 and 1975 (the second of which was the first to achieve the ascent of Mount Everest's south west face).

webTitle: Analysis: Rumble in the blackboard jungle

fields.headline: Rumble in the blackboard jungle
fields.standfirst:
The General Teaching Council was meant to raise the status of the profession. Instead, it has been drawn into a turf war with the unions

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The General Teaching Council was meant to raise the status of the profession. Instead, it has been drawn into a turf war with the unions.
fields.body:
Despite its prominent position inside St David's Hall, just by one of the entrances to the auditorium, the stand for the General Teaching Council (GTC) for England was one of the least visited by delegates to the National Union of Teachers (NUT) annual conference in Cardiff in the past few days.

But the GTC's presence is being felt, as it was at the Association of Teachers and Lecturers (ATL) gathering last week and will be again at the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers (NASUWT) event in Jersey this week.

For decades the unions have advocated setting up a GTC, which Scotland has had since 1966. Indeed it was put into the Labour manifesto mainly to satisfy the unions; the party leadership accepted the case but hardly shared the enthusiasm. The unions wanted it to raise the status of teaching, to give this large profession - the chart shows how big - comparable status with medicine and law. But since the GTC for England was formally established, with a 64-member council under the chairmanship of Lord Puttnam and the chief executiveship of Carol Adams in September 2000, the GTC and the unions have been falling out.

The 1998 Teaching and Higher Education Act gave the GTC a regulatory role. It has to establish a register of teachers with the power to ban bad teachers from schools. It also advises the education secretary on stan dards of teaching, the role of the teaching profession, development, training and recruitment. It is this advisory function - or the GTC leadership's interpretation of it - that has angered the unions. They accuse the GTC of empire-building; the GTC thinks the unions want it to fail. David Puttnam acknowledges that it has no role in pay and conditions but wants it to be able to make representations to the school teachers' review body, which advises the government and effectively decides the level of the annual pay award.

The GTC's first corporate plan talks of providing a professional voice. It is to champion teachers and advocate change on their behalf. But the unions think that is their job. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of NASUWT and a fierce critic, says the GTC should remember that it is a teaching rather than a teachers' council.

A first wrangle has been over the fee charged by the council. The view was that if the GTC were to be independent it should have its own income through a registration fee, which is due to be paid by all teachers for the first time in October. But union representatives on the GTC criticised this as a teacher tax. It has been knocked down to £25 (a net cost to teachers of £19.50, as the Inland Revenue will accept it as an allowable expense for tax purposes). This reduction came after Lord Puttnam won a £3m subsidy from the government at the last minute.

Earlier this month the NUT, threatening legal action, got it established that the GTC does not have power under the act to charge teachers for anything other than establishing and maintaining a register of teachers. The NUT is waiting for a further reduction in the fee. Yet many within the unions concede the GTC is doing impressive work in promoting professional development. Lord Puttnam, when he is not berating the media for negative coverage of teaching, is a great advocate.

The GTC says it has no desire for a turf war with the unions. But one is taking place none the less. And just because the trade unions are oversensitive does not mean the GTC is not out to get them. There is no doubt that senior elements in the GTC hierarchy think the unions should shape up or ship out, reform or die.

At the Secondary Heads Association conference in Newport, Lord Puttnam proposed a new federation of teaching unions, chaired by the GTC, to take on such issues as pensions. A spirit of unity has been in the air over the past week, but more as a means of circumventing the GTC than embracing it. While the NUT left is, perhaps temporarily, in abeyance, the ATL is radicalised. Last week it agreed in principle to join industrial action for the first time since the mid-1970s, and one ATL branch proposed setting the GTC's registration fee at "less than 1p". I have talked to several key players in all three major unions over the last week and it appears most, with Mr de Gruchy a notable exception, are now beginning to believe that a merger of the NUT, NASUWT and ATL is moving from the realms of the possible to the probable.

Opinion has hardened in the past month, as activists come to terms with the unprecedented joint motion on pay and working conditions, passed by the NUT and ATL and going before the NASUWT tomorrow. There has been joint action by teaching unions before, only for the tide of unity to recede. But this time the GTC is a new element. The threat, perceived or otherwise, of the council's ambitions is helping to make the unions work towards what most teachers want but years of splits, competition and personal acrimony have stalled. Mr de Gruchy's successor, Eamonn O'Kane, made clear during his interview for the job that he was an enthusiast for unity. On Sunday, Mr McAvoy general secretary of the NUT, predicted that unity would be achieved within eight years - in its context a stunning statement from a cautious man. History in the making? It is still much too early to say. But if it is, Lord Puttnam and his GTC would deserve more than a footnote.

Will Woodward is the Guardian's education editor.

But the GTC's presence is being felt, as it was at the Association of Teachers and Lecturers (ATL) gathering last week and will be again at the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers (NASUWT) event in Jersey this week. For decades the unions have advocated setting up a GTC, which Scotland has had since 1966. Indeed it was put into the Labour manifesto mainly to satisfy the unions; the party leadership accepted the case but hardly shared the enthusiasm. The unions wanted it to raise the status of teaching, to give this large profession - the chart shows how big - comparable status with medicine and law. But since the GTC for England was formally established, with a 64-member council under the chairmanship of Lord Puttnam and the chief executiveship of Carol Adams in September 2000, the GTC and the unions have been falling out. The 1998 Teaching and Higher Education Act gave the GTC a regulatory role. It has to establish a register of teachers with the power to ban bad teachers from schools. It also advises the education secretary on stan dards of teaching, the role of the teaching profession, development, training and recruitment. It is this advisory function - or the GTC leadership's interpretation of it - that has angered the unions. They accuse the GTC of empire-building; the GTC thinks the unions want it to fail. David Puttnam acknowledges that it has no role in pay and conditions but wants it to be able to make representations to the school teachers' review body, which advises the government and effectively decides the level of the annual pay award. The GTC's first corporate plan talks of providing a professional voice. It is to champion teachers and advocate change on their behalf. But the unions think that is their job. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of NASUWT and a fierce critic, says the GTC should remember that it is a teaching rather than a teachers' council. A first wrangle has been over the fee charged by the council. The view was that if the GTC were to be independent it should have its own income through a registration fee, which is due to be paid by all teachers for the first time in October. But union representatives on the GTC criticised this as a teacher tax. It has been knocked down to £25 (a net cost to teachers of £19.50, as the Inland Revenue will accept it as an allowable expense for tax purposes). This reduction came after Lord Puttnam won a £3m subsidy from the government at the last minute. Earlier this month the NUT, threatening legal action, got it established that the GTC does not have power under the act to charge teachers for anything other than establishing and maintaining a register of teachers. The NUT is waiting for a further reduction in the fee. Yet many within the unions concede the GTC is doing impressive work in promoting professional development. Lord Puttnam, when he is not berating the media for negative coverage of teaching, is a great advocate. The GTC says it has no desire for a turf war with the unions. But one is taking place none the less. And just because the trade unions are oversensitive does not mean the GTC is not out to get them. There is no doubt that senior elements in the GTC hierarchy think the unions should shape up or ship out, reform or die. At the Secondary Heads Association conference in Newport, Lord Puttnam proposed a new federation of teaching unions, chaired by the GTC, to take on such issues as pensions. A spirit of unity has been in the air over the past week, but more as a means of circumventing the GTC than embracing it. While the NUT left is, perhaps temporarily, in abeyance, the ATL is radicalised. Last week it agreed in principle to join industrial action for the first time since the mid-1970s, and one ATL branch proposed setting the GTC's registration fee at "less than 1p". I have talked to several key players in all three major unions over the last week and it appears most, with Mr de Gruchy a notable exception, are now beginning to believe that a merger of the NUT, NASUWT and ATL is moving from the realms of the possible to the probable. Opinion has hardened in the past month, as activists come to terms with the unprecedented joint motion on pay and working conditions, passed by the NUT and ATL and going before the NASUWT tomorrow. There has been joint action by teaching unions before, only for the tide of unity to recede. But this time the GTC is a new element. The threat, perceived or otherwise, of the council's ambitions is helping to make the unions work towards what most teachers want but years of splits, competition and personal acrimony have stalled. Mr de Gruchy's successor, Eamonn O'Kane, made clear during his interview for the job that he was an enthusiast for unity. On Sunday, Mr McAvoy general secretary of the NUT, predicted that unity would be achieved within eight years - in its context a stunning statement from a cautious man. History in the making? It is still much too early to say. But if it is, Lord Puttnam and his GTC would deserve more than a footnote. Will Woodward is the Guardian's education editor. mailto:will.woodward@ theguardian.com

webTitle: Teachers take hard line on violence

fields.headline: Teachers take hard line on violence
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The National Union of Teachers' conference yesterday endorsed a tougher stance over pupil exclusion by threatening strike action to protect staff from violent and disruptive children.
fields.body:
The National Union of Teachers' conference yesterday endorsed a tougher stance over pupil exclusion by threatening strike action to protect staff from violent and disruptive children.

Delegates in Cardiff voted for the scrapping of "arbitrary and bureaucratic" government targets to reduce exclusions.

They also called for the replacement of the independent appeals panels, which have the power to reinstate excluded pupils, by locally elected panels including teachers and headteachers among their membership.

Historically the NUT has taken a less hardline view of pupil exclusion than rival unions, particularly the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, which will debate the issue at its conference in Jersey today and is set to endorse a similar motion.

The NUT leadership announced in November it was advising teachers they could threaten strike action if headteachers refused to exclude pupils or if exclusion appeals panels overturned decisions.

The union represented members in 120 cases where pupils were being reinstated against the will of teachers. Of those cases, 76 resulted in the members refusing to teach.

The union has not yet threatened to strike but the conference decision endorses the retention of that as a last resort.

In a survey by the NUT's Gravesham branch of 42 schools, 11 said they had pupils who should be excluded because of behavioural difficulties.

The government is committed to reducing the number of exclusions from schools by one-third by 2002 from the 1996-97 figure of 12,700.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, was forced to revise guidance on exclusions after fierce protests from head teachers that appeals panels were reinstating too many pupils.

A spokesman for the education department said: "The secretary of state has made it very clear that where head teachers feel the need to exclude a child, that judgment must be upheld."

Conference also called for more support for teachers facing pupils with threatening and challenging behaviour.

The union revealed details of a £37,000 award this month to Jo Daws, 57, a teacher at Beckmead, a school for children with emotional and behavioural difficulties in Croydon, south London, after her back was damaged by having to deal with disruptive pupils. She was forced to give up teaching in December 1996. Central London county court found the school had inadequate and inconsistent procedures for dealing with poor behaviour. She was having to restrain pupils on a daily basis.

Meanwhile attempts by leftwingers to force a debate on the NUT executive's decision to suspend industrial action over teacher shortages was defeated. So too - by a narrow 102,058 to 98,150 votes - was a motion which would have committed the union to rolling industrial action up to including consideration of a one-day strike, in support of a wage claim and the abolition of performance-related pay.

But Doug McAvoy, the general secretary, faced the prospect of a sting in the tail this morning.

The results of a vote on a motion calling for a national ballot to boycott the government's performance management system, was held over until today. From the show of hands, it appeared the motion had narrowly passed.

An amendment proposed by the executive which would have overturned the strike call has already been defeated.

fields.headline: Back to school?
fields.standfirst: David Blunkett is trying to tempt teachers back into the profession with cash carrots. The unions have attacked the scheme. But what do ex-teachers think? Marina Cantacuzino asked them
fields.trailText: David Blunkett is trying to tempt teachers back into the profession with cash carrots. The unions have attacked the scheme. But what do ex-teachers think? Marina Cantacuzino asked them
fields.body:
Mari Lois-Hutchings (34) from Monmouth is married with two sons, Tywi, 5, and Jacob, 8. Her husband Patrick works with computer systems.

I went into teaching because I thought it would be a creative career and spent my first year in a very difficult school in Peckham - it was a real baptism of fire. Then I spent nearly five years in a primary school in Swindon, which I loved. It had a charismatic head and was very exciting.

But it was a very demanding job. I'd get in at 7.30am and leave at 6pm, taking two hours of work home with me. I also spent up to £50 a month on various resources for the classroom. When I got married, my husband and I were on the same salary. Four years later, his salary had doubled and mine had only crept up. When I became pregnant, I didn't know how I could possibly have children and teach because it took so much out of my time. I hated the thought of doing it badly. Also, there were a lot of changes that year, including much more paperwork, which wasn't my cup of tea. I was a creative teacher and this was crushing. I began to feel a bit of a failure.

So I gave up teaching when Jacob was born in 1993 and started doing more creative things from home. Soon, I got a toe in illustrating and designing greeting cards. Now I run a course in developing arts and crafts for other women who are at home. I have a really creative life, which I don't believe teaching can give you. My friends who are still teaching are sucked dry by the system.

Blunkett's proposals wouldn't attract me back because there are so many other issues that need to change first. For instance, teachers are stressed because there isn't adequate funding to help them deal with all the special needs children in their class.

Teachers' salaries are also an important issue. Offering them help with childcare and welcome-back bonuses isn't enough. We had to pay for our own coffee. It's a little thing, but it used to really piss me off.

Even though the proposals are a welcome gesture, and there are certainly good things in the package, it is far more important to reward those who choose to stay than to drag people back with sweeteners.

A former education manager with Lewisham LEA, Beverley Clarke-Brown (44) has two daughters, who are aged 14 and 10. She also lives in London.

I feel blessed that I've done a lot with my life. My first job was in the classroom but I left after six years because of lack of promotional opportunies and changes to the curriculum. I then went on to work in managerial roles in Lewisham LEA, affecting policy and working with teachers and their professional development. But finally last year, after the fifth restructuring, I took redundancy. I also felt I'd done all I could and I needed to shift my feet.

Now I'm ready to refocus my energies and go back into helping kids. I'm concerned about children who are excluded and particuarly the notion that black kids are underperforming. Being a black teacher and a parent, I can't see how this can be, especially when, at baseline, black children are achieving average or above. What gives me hope is that I've seen evidence of more credence and more investment being given to the profession. The opportunities were there before, but people were too knackered to take them up. The fact that the government is looking at pay structure is good, but 3.7% isn't enough. A decent salary is the main incentive to getting people back.

I completed a returner's course just before the bursaries were announced, and I think it's unfair that I didn't receive help with childcare and travel expenses. I haven't even considered the welcome back bonuses. I plan to do supply teaching before making a decision as to whether I'm better cut out for primary or secondary.

Education is a force for social change, and I want to be somewhere where I feel I can make a difference. But I know it won't be easy. Teaching is a complex and challenging craft, and the first thing a teacher needs to do is gain the respect of young people.

Danny Fishel (43) lives in London with his partner, her four children and his six-year-old son Joel. He recently decided to go back into teaching.

I passed my PGCE in my mid-twenties and did not take a post until the age of 30, as I was pursuing a career as a musician. Family commitments made it financially imperative to take up a secure post in a special school, in Leeds, teaching 11- to 19-year-olds.

I worked there for five years and then, when my son was born, decided to stay at home and look after him while my ex-wife went out to work.

When Joel started school, however, I had no role any more, and it made sense to go back into what I knew best. I was out of touch with primary education and decided that I needed to do a returner's course.

Unfortunately, I applied before the new bursaries were announced. I may qualify for the 'welcome back' bonus as I am about to start a new post for the summer term. This is at a very supportive infant school in Hampstead Garden Suburb, London. I am currently training for a second career in counselling and hope to combine those two skills.

Karen Randle (35) has four children aged between eight and 14 months. Her husband Anthony is a solicitor. They live in north-west London.

After completing my PGCE in 1988 I worked in publishing, but I found it so boring that, at 24, I moved into teaching. I was thrown into a year 4 class in a tough inner-city primary in west London. The teacher who was supposed to be guiding me had too much on her plate, so I ended up doing the lesson plans myself. It was all a bit frightening.

After two years, I got pregnant. It was a relief not to go back because it was a tough job. I hadn't really had time to consolidate my teaching, and it was at the time of many changes.

Nine years and four children later, I've come round to the idea of teaching again. Although there's no financial imperative for me to work, I've always known I wanted a job when my youngest child was at school.

Until recently, I'd dismissed the idea of going back into full-time teaching because it's too demanding with a family, but reading about all the teacher shortages in the press must have had a subliminal effect on me. The fact that I can do a returner's course without it costing me money is a big incentive. More importantly, I read an article about job-sharing which I'd never considered in a primary context. That would suit me perfectly. With the teacher shortage, I hope that more heads will consider it as an option.

Having had four children of my own I feel more confident, and my experience of going into my children's primary school has been a very positive one. It would be great not to waste my training and the two years I spent in the classroom.

John Whitty (53) lives in north London. He is married and has a 13-year-old son. He used to be head of years 7, 8 and 9 in a London secondary school.

I was a teacher for 28 years, teaching biology and chemistry at the George Orwell School in north London, until 1999 when it was closed and re-opened as a 'fresh start' school. Islington Council didn't really want any of the old teachers to stay on, so it offered substantial redundancy packages. Many experienced teachers like myself jacked it in.

I'd had enough anyway. When I started out in teaching, we all loved it. But when you've achieved seniority, it becomes difficult marrying up the teaching with the pastoral side. Preparation time suffered, and it became a matter of watching your back.

I'm now retraining to be a plumber, which I'm thoroughly enjoying. The only thing I miss about teaching is the contact with the kids and my colleagues. If I was in a less secure situation, and didn't have the retirement deal, I'd consider taking up Blunkett's recruitment and retention package. I think it's quite an attractive deal. I've also checked whether it might affect my teacher's pension but, according to the blurb, it doesn't. That's something that could be very attractive to retired teachers - as a way of topping up their pensions.

Teachers' salaries are the problem. Of those who left with me, only one has decided to go back into teaching. The others are quite happy doing something else and, in most cases, earning much more.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My 13-year old son is in year eight at a selective secondary school, but is still quite bored in maths lessons. Having looked at the GCSE curriculum, I can see it would only take a little bit of work to get him through that exam with high marks. Is this recommended? What are the pros and cons?
fields.trailText: My 13-year old son is in year eight at a selective secondary school, but is still quite bored in maths lessons. Having looked at the GCSE curriculum, I can see it would only take a little bit of work to get him through that exam with high marks. Is this recommended? What are the pros and cons?
fields.body:
My first advice to you would be to discuss the situation with your sonÍs headteacher. ItÍs not so much whether it would be intellectually possible for your son to take the exam early, but whether itÍs managerially possible for the school. But if the school is used to this kind of situation it shouldnÍt cause too much upheaval.

For 16 years I was head of a comprehensive school where it was not unusual for children to take maths early if they were capable. One of the advantages of taking the maths exam early would be apparent if your son has other things he wishes to get on with: for instance, if he finds some subjects easy and others more difficult, he could then devote extra time to the ones he finds harder, which can make good sense. Or he could further advance his maths by taking an extra exam like GCSE statistics or even starting to study at advanced level. You could also see if your sonÍs teacher could set some extra challenges: able children enjoy investigative maths that isnÍt just pursuing the syllabus, such as looking at number patterns and working in different number bases. This would keep your sonÍs interest alive and also enhance his understanding.

Jean Gemmell
Acting general secretary, Professional Association of Teachers

If you want to go down this road  and I think itÍs a really good road  the most important thing is to keep the school on-side. There will be practical problems to work out such as whether the child sits in his normal classes, how the school accommodates the change of routine, and so on. Schools work to certain systems, but you can get round them if there is goodwill. Doing something like this is great for a childÍs self-esteem and will give a great sense of achievement; bright kids can coast and itÍs good for them to be stretched.

But itÍs important to realise it will mean extra work each week and parents should be sensitive and not place too much emphasis on it if, after a few months, this boy decides heÍs fed up with extra classes. After all he will do his GCSEs anyway, so there would be nothing tragic about trying and deciding it was too much work. ItÍs good if parents are motivated to help. too. There is a mountain of material out there that they can use. The BBC provides revision materials for key stage 3 and GCSE, which have been developed with teachers, advisers and exam boards. You can find our material on www.bbc.co.uk under education; the television programmes that are part of the course are about to be repeated for this yearÍs GCSE groups and are screened on the Learning Zone at night in two-hour blocks that you tape and then use in bits.

Karen Johnson
Executive editor, BBC Education

Several organisations offer tuition towards GCSE maths. If your child is well-motivated, distance learning could be appropriate; while you donÍt have the peer support you find in the classroom, the level of one-to-one tuition can be excellent. If you decide to look into this, it is worth shopping around. Costs and levels of tutorial support will differ.

If the course is not accredited by us, you should ensure it leads up to GCSEs from an appropriate examining board. Talk to your son about what support he wants  if in school, he may have the materials he needs, but he may find tutor support by phone or email particularly useful.

We are an independent organisation providing quality accreditation for open and distance learning in the private sector  to offer reassurance that people are buying what they need.

We have a set of standards that cover all aspects of the educational service offered, from course materials and tutor support through to marketing. We publish a brochure listing all the courses we accredit and they are listed on our website (www.odlqc.org.uk) where you can also find a detailed guide to the kinds of questions buyers should ask.

Contact the Open and Distance Learning Quality Council on 020-7612 7090.

Dr David Morley
Chief executive, Open and Distance Learning Quality Council

You could also see if your sonÍs teacher could set some extra challenges: able children enjoy investigative maths that isnÍt just pursuing the syllabus, such as looking at number patterns and working in different number bases. This would keep your sonÍs interest alive and also enhance his understanding. There will be practical problems to work out such as whether the child sits in his normal classes, how the school accommodates the change of routine, and so on. Schools work to certain systems, but you can get round them if there is goodwill. Doing something like this is great for a childÍs self-esteem and will give a great sense of achievement; bright kids can coast and itÍs good for them to be stretched. But itÍs important to realise it will mean extra work each week and parents should be sensitive and not place too much emphasis on it if, after a few months, this boy decides heÍs fed up with extra classes. After all he will do his GCSEs anyway, so there would be nothing tragic about trying and deciding it was too much work. ItÍs good if parents are motivated to help. too. There is a mountain of material out there that they can use. The BBC provides revision materials for key stage 3 and GCSE, which have been developed with teachers, advisers and exam boards. You can find our material on www.bbc.co.uk under education; the television programmes that are part of the course are about to be repeated for this yearÍs GCSE groups and are screened on the Learning Zone at night in two-hour blocks that you tape and then use in bits. If your child is well-motivated, distance learning could be appropriate; while you donÍt have the peer support you find in the classroom, the level of one-to-one tuition can be excellent. If you decide to look into this, it is worth shopping around. Costs and levels of tutorial support will differ. If the course is not accredited by us, you should ensure it leads up to GCSEs from an appropriate examining board. Talk to your son about what support he wants  if in school, he may have the materials he needs, but he may find tutor support by phone or email particularly useful. We are an independent organisation providing quality accreditation for open and distance learning in the private sector  to offer reassurance that people are buying what they need. We have a set of standards that cover all aspects of the educational service offered, from course materials and tutor support through to marketing. We publish a brochure listing all the courses we accredit and they are listed on our website (www.odlqc.org.uk) where you can also find a detailed guide to the kinds of questions buyers should ask. Contact the Open and Distance Learning Quality Council on 020-7612 7090. fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.standfirst: A 10-year-old in Ipswich is facing prosecution for calling another child 'Paki'. His defence? The other child called him 'Teletubby' first. Natasha Narayan is not impressed
fields.trailText: A 10-year-old in Ipswich is facing prosecution for calling another child 'Paki'. His defence? The other child called him 'Teletubby' first. Natasha Narayan is not impressed
fields.body:
I realised there was something different about me on my first day at my new school. The children crowded round me, stroking my hair, touching my cheeks. Everyone wanted to be my friend; offering me Smarties and bits of liquorice. I was flushed with pride at being the centre of attention, I felt as exotic as a cheetah.

'Is there electricity where you come from?' the children asked. They were all white, ruddy-cheeked and big-boned. 'Do you live in a jungle?'

As an eight-year-old the questions merely seemed na´ve. 'Of course thereês electricity in India,' I replied. 'It's just like England but hotter.' I told my mum I liked my new school. The kids were really friendly. But over the next few days my new friends dropped away. By the end of the week no one would talk to me.

My primary school was in a tiny Hampshire village and I was the only 'coloured' person most of the children had ever met. I was small and scrawny, I couldnêt run and keep up with games. This helped them to mark me down as part of a weak species. When they saw me their frames of reference were It Ain't Half Hot Mum and Jungle Book. But for me they represented all the glamour of Mallory Towers and the Famous Five.

It took only a few weeks for me to be totally ostracised. Breaks became an agony as gangs of kids gathered round me in the playground to taunt me with cries of Brown Sugar and Nig-Nog. They would sing the hit Boney M song, Brown Girl In The Ring, as they spun round and round me.

I donêt recall any of the teachers intervening to stop the bullying ã which must have been apparent to even the most myopic playground supervisor. But perhaps my memories have become blurred with time.

Hampshire in the early seventies was another country. This was before 'political correctness', 'multiculturalism' and 'racism' became common currency. I didnêt know that what was happening to me might be racism. I just thought it was me. So I never told the teacher or my mum.

The bullying became a fact of life, to be borne till, thankfully, after a year my mother moved me to another school. This weekê's case - of an Ipswich primary school pupil who faces prosecution for racially aggravated assault after a scuffle with another pupil - makes me thankful, yet again, to have put the heightened racial tensions of my playground years behind me.

A 10-year-old Asian boy, 'G', is said to have mocked a 10-year-old white boy, 'H', for being overweight - with taunts of 'Teletubby' and 'skunk'. H allegedly retaliated by calling G a 'Paki bastard' and punching him.

The matter ended up in the high court where Mr Justice Kennedy said the decision to prosecute H was like 'using a sledgehammer to crack a nut'. He added 'it may do more harm than good and is unlikely to be helpful to either G, or to H, or to the other children in their class, or the reputation of their primary school and the teachers who work in it.'

The case has been seized upon by some commentators as an example of political correctness gone mad, in a society led astray by the Macpherson report definition of a racial incident as one 'which is perceived to be racist by the victim or any other person'. The Times referred to the Macpherson definition as an 'I think therefore I am a victim of racism' standard.

What, one could reasonably ask, is the difference between calling a kid fatty and Paki anyway? But the merits of this particular case aside, it seems disingenuous to equate racial abuse with other playground bullying. This is not to condone other forms of bullying - teasing a child for being fat, for example, can sometimes be extremely nasty. They are just different.

When a kid calls a classmate a Yid or a Nig-Nog or a Paki there is a network of assumptions in the term. This may be obvious but it needs restating. Racist words have a history. They also have a worldview. Both the history and the worldview assume that the Paki, or whatever, is deeply inferior. They strike not just an individual but a tribe.

Racial language speaks to deep wounds. What is so telling about the Ipswich case is that what the defence calls a glorified schoolyard incident, has actually come to the high court. To all concerned ã except the Asian boy and his family ã the incident must have seemed trivial. Apparently the headteacher had not even deemed the name-calling significant enough to suspend H for the day, while the police advised against a prosecution.

Even the best intentioned can find it difficult to navigate the murky byways of playground race relations. Tessa Payne, the mother of a mixed-race five-year-old, teaches in a Norfolk middle school, not far from the Suffolk school at the centre of the allegations. Working in an overwhelmingly white school, she says, can make dealing with racial bullying particularly sensitive.

On one occasion Payne saw her sole Asian pupil, who was 11, being attacked by bullies. It was on the edge of some woods that I saw some 16-year-old boys set on my pupil. They began clubbing him with golf clubs. It was obviously racially motivated as they were calling him stuff like Paki.

Payne admits she was unsure what to do. The incident happened outside the school gates and the bullies were not from her school, so she couldnêt report them or have them suspended. In the event she talked to the victim, but was left unconvinced that she had taken the right, or enough, action.

There is some evidence that teachers fail to respond adequately to black concerns. A survey last April by the Peoplescience Intelligence Unit, based on 612 questionnaires, found that nearly one in five black pupils said support offered against racism and bullying was poor.

The Black Child report also showed that black children who feel subject to racist treatment are twice as likely to get into fights. It has added fuel to the debate over whether teachers contribute to high exclusion rates for pupils of Afro-Caribbean descent, who are 4.5 times more likely to be permanently excluded from school than white children.

The writer Jamila Gavin ã whose book Coram Boy won this yearês Whitbread Childrenês book award ãspoke in a recent interview about a case in which the black children in a class drew themselves as white. It made me realise there were not enough stories about blackê children ã which for me meant any non-whites, Gavin said.

Back in my own childhood, I remember being given a graphic lesson on the difference between brown and white skin. I was about 11, at a friendly, liberal school, when one day three older girls seized me and took me to an empty room. They stripped me while I screamed and struggled. Then they shook talcum powder all over me and smeared toothpaste on my lips, and what breasts I had. I remember feeling angry and humiliated, though not specially traumatised. It was only years later I realised what the girls ã blatantly ã were up to. They were trying to turn me white.
