fields.headline: Let's get physical
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock forgoes the gym for the comforts of the academic treadmill
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock forgoes the gym for the comforts of the academic treadmill
fields.body:
I should have known better than to volunteer to play host to Bob, dean of communication arts from our partner college in Big Bluff, South Dakota.

Bob is keen on exercise. He insisted that I join him for an early-morning workout at the collegeÍs fitness centre. I had no idea that the college was open at 6.30 each morning, nor did I realise that you could run all the way to it from my house without expiring.

In fact, I learned quite a few things during my week with Bob. And I donÍt mean all that stuff about liberal arts programmes and student representation on faculty boards. Not even the story Bob told me about what the coach of the cheerleading squad was found doing with a raccoon. No, I mean I learned a lot about people in my own college.

One day, for example, I met the principal. Bob introduced us one morning as we mounted the exercise bikes. I got to shake his hand and I heard him speak. But like all such occasions, it was so unexpected that it seemed like a dream. All I can remember him saying was something like if I didnÍt do up the strap, I would have a nasty accident.

ñIÍve played golf with him many times over in Big Bluff,î said Bob as we manipulated our hamstrings on the exercise mats.

One morning I bumped into Murray Whelk, our head of administration. I ducked out of the way to avoid his flailing dumb-bell.

ñYou shouldnÍt make sudden movements like that,î he grunted. ñCould be dangerous.î

I retreated to the safety of the rowing machine and watched the others performing their routines to a soundtrack of Fleetwood MacÍs Greatest Hits.

There was an early morning world of activity that I never knew existed. Some people were barely recognisable.But thanks to Bob, I did begin to feel the benefits of my early morning exercise. By Wednesday, I was first in the queue for the staff dining room.Exercise gives you an appetite, so I was able to join Bob in two helpings of spotted dick and custard. By the Friday morning, I was almost enjoying my workout.

I was giving the bar on a lateral pulldown machine a good workout when Travis, one of the building supervisors, approached me with a spray can and an oily rag. ñThe principalÍs complaining about a squeaky machine. He wants it fixed,î he threatened. It was only after Travis had followed me from one piece of equipment to another, squirting his lubricant into dark crevices, that I realised what was happening. The squeaky machine was me.

Sensing that my Dunlop Green Flash plimsolls were out of place in a world of designer crop tops, I left Bob and the principal to their international high fives and crept back to the real world of further education. The one that begins at nine oÍclock with a bacon roll and ends at five with a Kit-Kat and a cup of tea.

fields.headline: Age-old story
fields.standfirst: Sex inequality on pensioners' fees could land a college in court, warns Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Sex inequality on pensioners' fees could land a college in court, warns Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Colleges are being urged to review their policies on concessionary fees to avoid being sued for sexual discrimination.

Betty Williams, Labour MP for Conwy, in Wales, issued the warning after a constituent complained that a local college was granting fee reductions to women at 60, but not to men who didn't qualify for similar concessions until 65. Williams tackled Llandrillo college in Colwyn Bay about the anomaly and its principal, Huw Evans, immediately corrected it.

But her request for clarification from ministers on what guidance colleges receive from the DfEE on age-related fee concessions drew a less conclusive response. In a written question she asked Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, about the advice given to colleges regarding the age at which men could be offered concessionary fees.

In his reply the learning minister, said that colleges were generally free to vary or waive fees as they wish. The Learning and Skills Council would compensate colleges when they remitted fees to certain groups of individuals, but these groups did not automatically include people aged over 60, he said.

Williams says she is determined to pursue the matter because she is convinced that any college cutting fees for women, but not men, aged 60 would be vulnerable to potentially costly litigation under the 1975 Sex Discrimination Act. She reckons that a number of recent or pending cases on sex discrimination indicate that a college is unlikely to be able to defend itself successfully. These include a judgment in the European Court of Justice that winter fuel payments could not be granted to men and women at different ages.

And another case moving through the courts has convinced the government to announce its intentions to equalise the age on travel concessions for men and women.

Evans said that Llandrillo college, like others, allocated concessions according to a range of criteria. These included students who were unemployed, on family credit, single parents in financial difficulties and housing benefit recipients.

On age it had historically followed the pension regulations, he said. "Part-time women students could apply for concessionary fees at 60 and could be granted up to 50% off.

Unless male students were in financial difficulties they could not apply for concessions until they were 65."

This policy was a relic of the pre-1993 era when the college was under the control of the local education authority. "When we looked at the position, we thought that in the interest of fairness we should equalise concessions at 60 years of age," he said.

This in itself would carry a significant cost to the college. "We do attract quite a few men of 60 and over," Evans points out. Nonetheless, the college was not prepared to fight a test case on the issue.

fields.headline: So you want to learn...oceanography
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
Come far? I live here.

Live here? You lucky dog! It has its moments.

All this lovely sea and sun. Can't grumble.

You work here? Thats right.

What . . . lifeguard, barman, deck-chair attendant? I'm an oceanographer.

And that lets you live in Bermuda all year round? Of course.

Sounds my kind of job, but what is it? Oceanography is a very broad subject. Its divided into four disciplines: marine biology, the study of marine plants and animals; marine geology, the study of the composition and formation of the sea-bed; marine chemistry, the chemical composition of seawater, pollutants and so on; and marine physics, the study of wave formation, ocean currents, water temperature, density and tides.

How do you do it? Like any scientist, we research in laboratories, both on and offshore. We use a lot of computer models to predict ocean temperatures and the dispersal of oil slicks, as well as writing up reports and recording data.

How do you get your data? Many ways: from satellites, research vessels, drilling into the ocean floor, static buoys and submersible vehicle work. Oceanographers usually work as part of a team, with each member specialising in a slightly different discipline.

What sort of skills are you seeking? It can be tough with the fieldwork and sea travel, so oceanographers need to be physically and mentally fit, and prepared to travel worldwide, spending time away from home.

No problem. Observational and problem-solving skills are essential, plus good oral and written communication. They should have a prior interest in environmental issues and science in general.

What qualifications are required? Employers prefer people with post-graduate degrees in oceanography or related subject. A relevant first degree could be in biology, chemistry, physics, maths, geology or any related subject such as geophysics or zoology. Or it could be oceanography - usually a combined degree that can take up to four years to complete and require some fieldwork.To get on to an oceanography degree course, you will need at least five GCSE/S (grades A-C/1-3) and at least two A-levels, preferably in science subjects. Some universities might not ask for it, but employers usually require maths at A-level. Sub-aqua and diving experience is also useful for some jobs involving fieldwork. Nearly all employers offer on-the-job training, particularly with specific procedures.

What about job opportunities? Employment tends to be research-based. Most posts in the UK are offered by centres (such as the British Geological Survey, the British Arctic Survey, the Southampton Oceanography Centre, the Centre for Coastal Marine Sciences, Sea Mammal Research Unit and the Proudman Oceanographic Laboratory). These are fully or part-funded by the Natural Environment Research Council. Universities also have some vacancies for researchers and lecturers. Some marine mining and construction companies may offer contracts. Likewise, companies concerned with the environment.

 Southampton Oceanography Centre Waterfront Campus, Southampton University, Southampton SN2 1EU.
www.soc.soton.ac.uk

fields.bodyText: Come far? I live here. Live here? You lucky dog! It has its moments. All this lovely sea and sun. Can't grumble. You work here? Thats right. What . . . lifeguard, barman, deck-chair attendant? I'm an oceanographer. And that lets you live in Bermuda all year round? Of course. Sounds my kind of job, but what is it? Oceanography is a very broad subject. Its divided into four disciplines: marine biology, the study of marine plants and animals; marine geology, the study of the composition and formation of the sea-bed; marine chemistry, the chemical composition of seawater, pollutants and so on; and marine physics, the study of wave formation, ocean currents, water temperature, density and tides. How do you do it? Like any scientist, we research in laboratories, both on and offshore. We use a lot of computer models to predict ocean temperatures and the dispersal of oil slicks, as well as writing up reports and recording data. How do you get your data? Many ways: from satellites, research vessels, drilling into the ocean floor, static buoys and submersible vehicle work. Oceanographers usually work as part of a team, with each member specialising in a slightly different discipline. What sort of skills are you seeking? It can be tough with the fieldwork and sea travel, so oceanographers need to be physically and mentally fit, and prepared to travel worldwide, spending time away from home. No problem. Observational and problem-solving skills are essential, plus good oral and written communication. They should have a prior interest in environmental issues and science in general. What qualifications are required? Employers prefer people with post-graduate degrees in oceanography or related subject. A relevant first degree could be in biology, chemistry, physics, maths, geology or any related subject such as geophysics or zoology. Or it could be oceanography - usually a combined degree that can take up to four years to complete and require some fieldwork.To get on to an oceanography degree course, you will need at least five GCSE/S (grades A-C/1-3) and at least two A-levels, preferably in science subjects. Some universities might not ask for it, but employers usually require maths at A-level. Sub-aqua and diving experience is also useful for some jobs involving fieldwork. Nearly all employers offer on-the-job training, particularly with specific procedures. What about job opportunities? Employment tends to be research-based. Most posts in the UK are offered by centres (such as the British Geological Survey, the British Arctic Survey, the Southampton Oceanography Centre, the Centre for Coastal Marine Sciences, Sea Mammal Research Unit and the Proudman Oceanographic Laboratory). These are fully or part-funded by the Natural Environment Research Council. Universities also have some vacancies for researchers and lecturers. Some marine mining and construction companies may offer contracts. fields.headline: Liberal application
fields.standfirst: First, there was Liberal Studies. Now, no one knows the answer, says Mervyn Lebor
fields.trailText: First, there was Liberal Studies. Now, no one knows the answer, says Mervyn Lebor
fields.body:
In the beginning, post-1960s, there was Liberal Studies. The godlike lecturer sat on the desk above his bright-faced, 17-year-old students who needed not only the practicalities of training, but also the supposed benefits of a ñliberalî education. From on high this lecturer said that broadsheets were superior to tabloids.

In the next phase of Creation, a beast was conceived for a far deeper purpose. This animal was sometimes called General, Complementary or Communication Studies. It was a beast with which large numbers of bikers, assorted engineers, roofers, slaters and brickies in leather jackets and army boots were supposed to grapple on their day-release apprentice courses. This was the primordial mix of the 1980s.

In response, City & Guilds evolved multiple-choice questions about bus timetables. Most students had motorbikes; no one dreamed of using the bus, except in their wildest nightmares. There was also coursework relating to an accident where a man was paralysed from receiving multiple electric shocks. Some of the cohort found this gratifying.

Then came the class-administered ñphase testî during which, say, business administrators or future British Gas operatives discussed whether the whole world, or just a land mass, would be obliterated if we adopted nuclear fusion instead of fission. The arguments were less than explosive, and so these tests were, literally, ñphasedî out. The multiple choice and its linked primitive phase test became extinct.

Then Manpower Services dreamed up Youth Opportunities, (YOPS). The central aspect of communications in this context was Life Skills, as if life, as such, had only just come into existence.

In Life Skills students might look up the names and telephone numbers of high street banks. The problem was trying to get the YOPS people to take their boots off the desks or fists out of one anotherÍs faces.

Mutant forms of communication were enthusiastically brought to life in this era. Even before the 1990s it was realised that listening, speaking, reading and writing were all key elements in the great enterprise for beings that used language. Core, common and key skills all used these elements in the fight for natural selection.

The fittest to survive, however, were the key breed. In their embryonic stage these were cleverly designed so that students could only pass their vocational courses once the communication element was imprinted into their DNA.

In the postmodern age, key skills were ñdecoupledî from vocational and academic mainstream subjects. Key skills had somehow survived the morass of predators and competitors and were about to go it alone into the 21st century.

But there were still questions. What credibility could there be in a system that never mentioned a pass mark? Why hadnÍt all universities unequivocally accepted key skills as an entry qualification? Why did the parallel universe of work show such little understanding of this revolutionary change? Why did the blueprint multi-choice exams resemble  at level one and two in so much detail  the C&G multiple-choice exams that went out in the 1980s? Why did GCSEs, AS and A2 exams already exist in all areas of the key skill subjects? Could not attainments in those exams be proof of achievement?

Yet there were certain positives. Arts students were now going to be numerate. Scientists were at last to be literate. All would have to be computer omniscient. Yet none of this was compulsory; students faced the new universe of key skills with a massive 'so what?'

The true heroes are the lecturers, burdened with an ever-escalating series of such 'evolutionary developments'. They now enter the classroom minus that godlike air. The students are still bright-faced 17-year-olds. Unsure of the answer, the lecturer asks: 'We are now going to look at the style of two passages, one is from a broadsheet, one is from a tabloid. Which do you think is better?'

Mervyn Lebor is a further education lecturer in West Yorkshire.

fields.headline: All-out strike looms
fields.standfirst: Industrial action in colleges looks unavoidable as first ballot begins, says Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Industrial action in colleges looks unavoidable as first ballot begins, says Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Strike action right across the further education sector next term was starting to look inevitable as colleges broke up for the Easter break.

Natfhe, the lecturersÕ union, is due to start balloting its members a week tomorrow for a strike on May 22.

Meanwhile, the Association of Teachers and Lecturers (A0C) slapped a demand down for a £2,500 flat-rate pay increase and threatened to ballot for industrial action if sixth form college lecturers end up with less than the schoolteachersÕ 3.7% award.

The Association of Colleges, the employersÕ body for general further education institutions, said there was still hope of avoiding a strike which it claimed would send damaging messages to government that the sector had not shaken off its industrial relations problems.

But there was a clear sense of gloom and disappointment that the Natfhe ballot would be completed - on May 9 Ñ a week before the AoC meets again with the trades unions of the National Joint Forum, which has been conducting pay negotiations. Last week Natfhe notified the principals of more than 300 general further education colleges that on May 22 its members would be balloted on the standard two questions about being prepared to go on strike or to take industrial action short of a strike.

The union is claiming a flat-rate increase of £3,000 for 2001-2002 as first step to restore further education lecturersÕ pay-relativity with salaries in schools. LecturersÕ pay has fallen about 10% behind that of teachers.

The Association of College Managers, the further education managersÕ union, has made a claim for a 6% salary increase for the next three years.

The sectorsÕ Òsupport staffÓ, represented by three tradesÕ unions, are demanding £1000 on all salary scales or a 7.5% increase, whichever is the greater. They also want the reduction of the standard working week from 37 to 35 hours.

A bulletin from NatfheÕs London headquarters to its branches called for a solid ÒyesÓ vote.

General secretary Paul Mackney advised them that the further education teachers pay initiative, despite the announcement by ministers of a further £135 million over three years, would not resolve the problem of the pay gap with school teachers.

And he reminded them, for their negotiations with their college managements about local implementation of the pay intitiative, of NatfheÕs Òcomplete opposition to all forms of performance related payÓ.

On the likelihood of resounding support for a strike Mackney said: ÒI donÕt think youÕd be able to find a single lecturer in the country who is satisfied with the level of pay.Ó

The AoC sent a questionnaire to colleges asking if they would consider or reject each of the separate pay demands. It will make its draft pay offer to the forum on May 15 based on the results.

Ivor Jones, the AoCÕs director of employment policy, said: ÒOn the whole the claims are reasonable.Ó

Referring to the Natfhe demand he added: ÒRealistically the employers are not going to be able to match the request for £3000.Ó

The AoCÕs chief executive, David Gibson, said: ÒIf we return to the strikes of the 70s and 80s everybody will suffer. We are a strong sector delivering the goods and we want to stay that way.Ó

fields.headline: The art of parenting
fields.standfirst: Stephen Hoare discovers that desperate parents are flocking back to college Ñ for training on how to manage their children
fields.trailText: Stephen Hoare discovers that desperate parents are flocking back to college Ñ for training on how to manage their children
fields.body:
In its most extreme forms, bad parenting makes compelling TV. On Channel 4Õs confessional True Lives show, presenter Ricki Lake has people erring so comprehensively from the straight and narrow that it beggars belief.

RickiÕs guests Ñ tearful teenage daughters confessing to a fourth or a fifth pregnancy, parents whose multiple infidelities are exposed by the lie detector, adolescents mortified to discover their mom is moonlighting as a stripper Ñ bare their souls in front of a noisy New York studio audience that is not afraid of offering forceful advice and trading insults.

Parenting is an essential skill, but it is an area rarely touched on by education. Too often it is seen as beyond our control. Poor parenting Ñ or lack of it Ñ is a major factor behind the abysmally low standards in BritainÕs schools. Primary teachers regularly tell of children who arrive on their first day of school completely unsocialised, having spent the previous four years strapped in a pushchair, or dumped in front of a TV. They will tell you about children who cannot learn to read because they have not yet learned to string more than three words together. There are schools where out-of-control parents abuse staff. There are parents whose children are repeatedly excluded from school and parents who encourage their children to play truant. There are children who have been abused and traumatised so that they are unable to learn.

This may explain why Merton CollegeÕs centre for parenting education has never been busier. The south-west London Further Education college runs outreach courses at 15 local schools and community centres, where it offers training to groups of up to a dozen parents. It receives five requests for new courses a week.

So what exactly is good parenting? Caroline Penney, director of the centre, explains: ÒThe key is enjoying it and improving the quality of the relationship. Parenting is based around attachment and communication skills.Ó

But which parent is going to admit that he or she is in need of training? My first mistake is to use the label Òbad parentÓ. There are few genuinely bad parents: most are ordinary people trying their best to cope under pressure. Bev Giarraputo, head of Merton CollegeÕs school of healthcare and childhood studies, who is involved in the provision of parenting training, corrects me. ÒOur aim is praising, not labelling; listening and being non-judgmental. You donÕt give them loads of advice, you give people time.Ó

Working with groups that consist mainly of mothers, the college runs 13 accredited courses, most of which involve two-and-a-half-hour sessions that are held over 12 weeks.

Parenting development worker Siabreen Fairclough encourages individuals to break the ice and start sharing their worries. It is no chat show, but it does involve people examining their shortcomings and talking frankly.

Fairclough came to Merton College 13 years ago when she attended a parenting course herself. She later trained as a facilitator. ÒI was new to the area and, as an older, first-time parent, I felt isolated. I joined a course on how to give your child confidence and I went on from there.Ó

Merton CollegeÕs success in parenting education stems from a grass-roots involvement in the community, and the college has responded to parentsÕ concerns. Courses with titles such as ÒManaging conflictÓ, ÒUnderstanding adolescentsÓ or ÒLiving with teenagersÓ Ñ reminiscent of Dian FosseyÕs Gorillas In The Mist Ñ strike a chord with any parent being driven up the wall by sulks, slamming doors and bedroom floors knee-deep in knickers and discarded coke cans.

ÒNinety per cent of a parentÕs communication with teenagers is criticism,Ó says Fairclough. ÒWe work on praise and we build on communication.Ó Courses are the route by which parents can air their concerns and facilitators can start introducing ideas such as setting boundaries for your child, challenging them in a way that doesnÕt destroy their self-esteem, and using praise rather than negative criticism. The course on parenting children with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder teaches specific skills to support parents raising children with this condition.

MertonÕs approach Ñ to train in the community wherever possible and to train local facilitators Ñ has gained the trust of all sections of the community. Every course is different. Attend one at the Leyton Road Family Centre, the Merton Wellcare Centre in Mitcham Road or the Mushkill Aasaan Community Centre in Tooting and different priorities and experiences will emerge.

ÒParenting is not like training someone to sort out a computer or a motorbike,Ó says Penney. ItÕs much more complex. We start from the premise that everyone wants to improve their relationship with their children and wants the best for them. We never stigmatise. People never say to us, ÔI can only come on this course if IÕm a bad parentÕ. People trust the facilitators.Ó

Much of Merton CollegeÕs cutting-edge work is in training other organisations to deliver parenting courses to groups that need it. MertonÕs centre for parenting education trains youth services, young offenders groups, care workers and local education authorities from Sussex, Essex and north Wales.

In a recent further education funding council report the school of Childcare was highly praised. The intention is to set up parenting courses in local schools and to involve teachers, so that they can build a better understanding of the concerns of parents in their school and start seeing things from their perspective.

Giarraputo says: ÒWeÕre hoping to become a centre of excellence within the new Learning and Skills Council, and are trying to promote ourselves as a local and a national centre of excellence.Ó

There is, of course, much more to parenting education than simply learning the techniques of being a Ògood enoughÓ parent. Can learning skills such as communication and praise really break the damaging patterns of behaviour and family history repeating itself down the ages? The Merton College team knows it is making a difference. There is no behaviour that cannot be unlearnt or bad habits that cannot be broken.

ÒInstinctively, we parent the way we were parented, or move in the opposite way,Ó says Penney. We want to give people more choices about the way they bring up children.Ó

fields.headline: The high flyers
fields.standfirst: Britain is emerging as a serious circus nation. Report by John Crace
fields.trailText: Britain is emerging as a serious circus nation. Report by John Crace
fields.body:
One billion pounds to turn Britain into one of the worldÕs pre-eminent circus nations may not sound like money well spent, but then you probably havenÕt budgeted for a dead Dome, Peter Mandelson, Lord Falconer and P-Y Gerbeau. Amid a mountain of tat on the north Greenwich peninsula, the show in the DomeÕs central arena was the one thing with star quality.

In the early 1990s, France and Canada dominated the circus landscape with their national schools in Chalon and Montreal, but in 1995 Britain started to redress the balance with the creation of Circus Space in a former electricity generating station in north London.

That year East Berkshire College, in association with Circus Space, began a two-year BTEC National Diploma in circus skills, and the course proved so successful that when the New Millennium Experience Company (NMEC) was looking for performers for the Dome, Circus Space was the first place it turned to.

ÒWe got a call in April Õ98 asking us not just to find 87 aerial performers, but also to come up with an accredited training programme for them by the autumn,Ó says Charlie Holland, Circus SpaceÕs director.

ÒWe had to scrabble around like mad to get it up and running, but somehow we made it.Ó

Around 2,000 people replied to Circus SpaceÕs Dome SOS, of which 1,000 were invited for auditions. Two of those who made it to the final troupe were Emma Insley and Joe Hull, who completed the BTEC course in 1997.

ÒOur main job in the show was flying around on bungee stilts,Ó says Emma. ÒIt took a bit of time to get used to working 30m in the air, but it was the best job IÕve ever had. I donÕt know what anyone else thought of the Dome, but we had an absolutely brilliant year.Ó

Part of the training for the Dome was to make sure that the performers would be able to find work after it closed. Some are now appearing in the West End show, Notre Dame de Paris; others are helping to create a new show for Disneyland Paris; and a few have joined Cirque de Soleil. About 20, including Insley and Hull, have become part of a new performing arts group, The Generating Company, which presents its first show, Storm, a mixture of theatre, aerial stunts and technical wizardry, at Circus Space from this week. They will then take the show to Manchester, Glasgow, Newcastle and York.

On the back of the NMEC investment, Circus Space upgraded its BTEC course to a two-year, fast-track degree run in association with the Central School of Speech and Drama.

This has to be regarded as a success story, but Holland retains an ambivalent edge: ÒWhile itÕs wonderful to be running a degree course, itÕs also left a gap in the natural training progression. We donÕt have enough space to run a degree course and a BTEC simultaneously. If there are any FE colleges which are interested in setting one up, we would be delighted to be involved at some level.Ó

So while Britain may have an enviable array of performers, Holland can only look on in envy at the funding circus skills training gets in other countries. Sweden has just spent £3m, Australia is developing its own national academy and Canada is building its City of Circus next to Cirque de SoleilÕs Montreal base. ÒItÕs extremely frustrating,Ó says Holland. fields.bodyText: One billion pounds to turn Britain into one of the worldÕs pre-eminent circus nations may not sound like money well spent, but then you probably havenÕt budgeted for a dead Dome, Peter Mandelson, Lord Falconer and P-Y Gerbeau. Amid a mountain of tat on the north Greenwich peninsula, the show in the DomeÕs central arena was the one thing with star quality. In the early 1990s, France and Canada dominated the circus landscape with their national schools in Chalon and Montreal, but in 1995 Britain started to redress the balance with the creation of Circus Space in a former electricity generating station in north London. fields.headline: Jérôme Lindon
fields.standfirst: French publisher who launched the careers of such great writers as Samuel Beckett and Alain Robbe-Grillet
fields.trailText: French publisher who launched the careers of such great writers as Samuel Beckett and Alain Robbe-Grillet.
fields.body:
It is rare that the death of a publisher should be seen as an event of national importance. But the death from cancer of Jérôme Lindon, at the age of 75, has aroused considerable emotion in France. Lindon's publishing house, Les Editions de Minuit, is not a big organisation; it publishes some 20 books a year, it has a staff of 10, and while it is no longer on the verge of bankruptcy, its profits are modest.

Lindon made Les Editions de Minuit's postwar reputation. He did this by his taste for fine writing, his flair for seeing what was important and by the confidence that he inspired in authors. Two winners of the Nobel prize for literature, Samuel Beckett and Claude Simon, were published by him, many novels on his lists were awarded the prix Goncourt, and in the world of fiction, philosophy and social thinking, he dominated French cultural and intellectual life in the latter half of the 20th century.

Then there was Marguerite Duras. With her turbulent private life and her creative energy, few authors could be as difficult as she. By 1957, she had published five novels with Gallimard. But when she finished Moderato Cantabile, she became aware of her dissatisfaction with those who seemed to publish her automatically and who, she suspected, never read her.

Lindon understood her. He told her, on the very night she delivered her manuscript, that he would read it and discuss it with her the next morning. This he did. Duras decided that she preferred the energy and the enthusiasm of a man who loved books to the daily round of a sacrosanct institution such as Gallimard. The book was published in 1958 and won the prix de Mai awarded by the St Germain bookshop, La Hune.

Lindon was born in Paris, into a family with Polish-Jewish origins. His father, a lawyer, was a nephew of André Citroën, related to the Dreyfus and Bergson families: this was the well-connected Jewish upper bourgeoisie that had become totally French. As he was 14 at the outbreak of war in 1939, Jérôme was not called up, but in 1942 he joined the resistance movement, Combat.

That February the clandestine novel, Le Silence de la Mer, a token of resistance to the Germans written by Vercors (Jean Bruller), was published. It marked the founding of the hidden publishing house - by Vercors and another member of the resistance, Pierre de Lescure - that took the appropriate name of Les Editions de Minuit, since it functioned in the depths of night, and produced some 24 further novels in wartime.

In 1946, when Lindon joined Vercors, the firm was distinctly shaky. Thanks to money invested by the Lindon family, bankruptcy was avoided. Vercors left, and by the end of 1948 Lindon, at 23, had become the director, a position he occupied for the next 53 years.

At a time when Jean-Paul Sartre and Albert Camus dominated French literature, Lindon was confident that there was a new avant-garde and that he knew how to find it. In 1950, Samuel Beckett sent him the manuscript of his novel Molloy, which had suffered five rejections elsewhere but which Lindon published in 1951; in 1953, he followed this with Les Gommes by Alain Robbe-Grillet. Soon there sprang up a group of authors who rejected traditional methods of writing. Pioneers of the nouveau roman, they were christened the "new novelists".

But the name was not accepted by everyone. It was suggested that, since the real link between them was their progressive publisher, they should be known as the "école de minuit", and one American literary review published a survey of these authors under the heading of the "Midnight Novelists".

Lindon published philosophers who were to make their names in the years that followed - Jacques Derrida, Gilles Deleuze, the social specialist Pierre Bourdieu - as well as the reviews Critique and Arguments. And as he believed in intellectual freedom, so he believed in political freedom, and he played an important role in criticisms of the French army in the Algerian war in the late 1950s. He published attacks and petitions against the use of torture that led him into conflict with the government.

From the small building in the Rue Bernard-Palissy in the St Germain quarter of Paris, Lindon defended publishers against intense commercialisation and later prepared to defend them against the internet.

After Lindon's death, President Chirac commented on his unique role and lamented the loss of a friend. Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, the ministers for culture and education, and writers such as Robbe-Grillet and Simon paid tribute to him, as did fellow publisher Gallimard. In a rare gesture, Le Monde devoted its leading article to him while Libération gave him four pages. He was buried in Montparnasse in a grave near that of his friend, Samuel Beckett.

He is survived by his wife Annette, his two sons, André and Matthieu, and his daughter Irène, who is now managing director of the publishing house.

 Jrôme Lindon, publisher, born June 9 1925; died April 9 2001

fields.headline: Italian round-up
fields.trailText: ATALANTA 0 PARMA 1
fields.body:
ATALANTA 0 PARMA 1

A fine strike from Savo Milosevic extended Parma's unbeaten run to eight matches. The Yugolsav danced past two players before beating Italy under-21 goalkeeper Ivan Pelizzoli with a delightful 28th minute chip. Atalanta, level on points with fourth-placed Parma before start of play, have not won in their last five home matches.

BARI 0 NAPOLI 1

Napoli's first win in seven outings came courtesy of a late strike from Czech midfielder Marek Jankulovski. Bari had a goal ruled out for a foul on the keeper in the first half and their young playmaker Antonio Cassano hit the post in injury time. Bari are bottom and look doomed to relegation, Napoli might still escape.

BRESCIA 1 VERONA 0

Roberto Baggio's third goal in as many matches decided this stormy relegation scrap in which two players were sent off and seven booked. Baggio scored with a 22nd minute free kick before Verona's Mauro Camoranesi was dismissed for elbowing and Natale Gonnella for a second bookable offence. Brescia looked good enough to escape the drop. Verona are 16th and struggling.

FIORENTINA 2 LECCE 0

Two goals capped an inspired performance from Enrico Chiesa, who took his tally to 16 for the season and four in the past week. His first came from a free kick which deflected off the wall and his second with a bullet of a shot which beat the keeper at the near post. Lecce's fourth consecutive defeat left them in the relegation battle.

JUVENTUS 3 INTERNAZIONALE 1

After an even first half in which Inzaghi struck the crossbar, Juve took the lead in the 50th minute when Alessio Tacchinardi found himself in space on the edge of the area and fired past Inter 'keeper Sebastien Frey. Four minutes later Juve doubled their lead when Inzaghi lost his marker Matteo Ferrari and cut in from the left to beat Frey with a low, angled shot. The result was put beyond doubt in the 63rd minute when Inter's defence stood and watched an Inzaghi cross reach Del Piero and the Juve captain drove home, with the help of a deflection off Inter defender Laurent Blanc.

AC MILAN 3 UDINESE 0

Georgian defnder Kakha Kaladze scored a scrappy opener for Milan but their other two goals were pearls. Brazilian wingback Serginho swept the ball over Udinese keeper Luigi Turci from the corner of the penalty area in the 31st minute before Andriy Shevchenko twisted inside two defenders and fired home a low shot after the break. Milan are unbeaten in six matches and pushing for a Champions League place again.

REGGINA 0 LAZIO 2

Hernan Crespo scored both goals to join Shevchenko at the top of the Serie A scoring lists with 18. His first was a powerful strike into the roof of the Reggina net, his second a delightful chip over the keeper. Fellow Argentine Diego Simeone set up both. Dino Zoff's side stayed third and their title defence was not over.

AS ROMA 2 PERUGIA 2

Last-gasp stuff from Roma, whose controversial injury-time equaliser ensured they remained unbeaten at home in the league since March 19 last year. Television replays suggested Roma's Vincenzo Montella handled the ball during a goalmouth scramble before it richocheted into the net off defender Giovanni Tedesco. Davide Baiocco put Perugia ahead and a terrible blunder from Roma keeper Francesco Antonioli handed them their second.

VICENZA 4 BOLOGNA 2

Sierra Leone's Mohammed Kallon grabbed two goals in an action-packed tie. Vicenza were 3-0 up and coasting against 10-man Bologna, who then pulled two goals back. Kallon's second sealed Vicenza's valuable three points. Luca Toni, scorer of Vicenza's opener, had another effort disallowed and replays suggested two of Vicenza's goals might have been offside. Bologna midfielder Marcello Castellini was sent off in the 56th minute.

webTitle: Israel seizes Palestinian areas in Gaza Strip

fields.headline: Israel seizes Palestinian areas in Gaza Strip
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli troops seized a Palestinian-controlled slice of the Gaza Strip early today - a first in seven months of fighting - and launched rockets against Palestinian security bases in retaliation for mortar fire on an Israeli town.
fields.body:
Israeli troops seized a Palestinian-controlled slice of the Gaza Strip early today - a first in seven months of fighting - and launched rockets against Palestinian security bases in retaliation for mortar fire on an Israeli town.

A Palestinian policeman was killed and 36 people were hurt in the attack from the ground, air and sea - one of the most extensive Israeli military operations since September.

Israeli troops also divided Gaza into three parts, barring north-south traffic in the crowded strip which is home to more than one million Palestinians, and closed the border crossing between Gaza and Egypt.

Palestinian officials accused Israel of reoccupying the Gaza Strip. The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, returning to the West Bank from a meeting with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, said the raid was a "dirty Israeli ploy to end Palestinian resistance", and that his people would keep fighting until they won independence.

Israel said it had to respond after Palestinians fired mortars at the small Israeli working class town of Sderot.

According to an army map, troops recaptured about 0.8 square miles in the northeastern part of the 140-square-mile Gaza Strip.

An Israeli commander in the Gaza Strip, brigadier general Yair Naveh, said his troops would remain in the recaptured areas for "days, weeks or months" - as long as necessary to stop the mortar attacks. He said the army had no plans to remain there for good.

Israel's strike began on Monday evening, with tanks and helicopters firing dozens of rockets at Palestinian police positions across the Gaza Strip.

In the residential Rimal neighbourhood of Gaza City, rockets hit the headquarters of Palestinian police chief Ghazi Jabali, punching holes in the facade and ceiling. Hundreds of residents, including crying children, ran into the street after the first rockets struck.

The incursion with ground troops began at around midnight on Monday. Palestinian medics carrying the body of a Palestinian policeman killed in the rocket attack ran in panic when they came under fire.

The Islamic militant group Hamas claimed responsibility for the mortar attack on Sderot, a stronghold of Sharon's Likud party about 2.5 miles east of Beit Hanoun and about five miles from the sheep farm of the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, in the Negev Desert. No one was hurt.

The Palestinians had fired dozens of mortars at Israeli targets in recent weeks, mainly Jewish settlements in Gaza.

Israel also launched an air strike against Syria on Monday after an Israeli soldier was killed over the weekend in a rocket attack by Lebanese guerrillas.

The Syrian foreign minister, Farouk a-Sharaa, said Israel was expanding the crisis and would "pay a heavy price."

In Washington, White House spokesman Ari Fleischer said today, before the occupation, that "the president urges all parties to exercise restraint".

A 14-year-old Palestinian boy was killed this morning by Israeli fire near the Karni crossing between Gaza and Israel, Palestinian doctors said. It was not immediately clear what prompted the shooting.

Since fighting erupted in late September, 473 people have been killed, including 390 Palestinians, 64 Israeli Jews and 19 others.

webTitle: Investment freedom for treasurers could create a £15bn market

fields.headline: Investment freedom for treasurers could create a £15bn market
fields.standfirst: Despite local government's somewhat chequered investment history, the tight restrictions dictating where councils can put their surplus cash may soon be loosened, writes David Harding
fields.trailText: Despite local government's somewhat chequered investment history, the tight restrictions dictating where councils can put their surplus cash may soon be loosened, writes David Harding.
fields.body:
When it comes to council finance, the current government has proved to be ultra cautious. That could be about to change.

During the summer ministers will put out to consultation what is potentially one of the most important local government reforms Labour has made since coming to power. They are considering giving councils the chance to speculate on the money markets.

A final decision is expected by the autumn and the Treasury, always the most important and difficult department to convince, is thought to be keen on the idea.

If ministers give the go-ahead they could create a £15bn market by allowing local authorities to invest spare public cash, gained from sources including council house sales, in financial instruments such as corporate bonds, money market funds and commercial paper - a short-term corporate investment.

The move to consult is a result of ongoing high-level discussions between officials from the Treasury, the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions and local government officials.

On face value the decision to allow taxpayers' money to be invested by local authority treasurers is highly contentious - history is not on the side of local government. In the 1980s and 1990s, some councils lost heavily on the market. The London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham is commonly thought to have lost millions throughout the 1980s - a claim the authority denies.

The enthusiasm with which Hammersmith and Fulham embraced the market is clear. At one stage it was the third largest trader in the country, with almost 600 transactions made between 1983 and 1989, enthusiastically investing in financial instruments such as swaps and gilt options - bonds issued by the government.

In 1991, the high court ruled that the council had exceeded its powers and that such trading was illegal, leaving banks that it had invested in to pick up a bill running into millions. Hammersmith and Fulham says that not a penny of taxpayer's money was lost, and at the time of the high court ruling it held almost £15m in reserve accounts from money it had traded.

Another authority courting controversy was the Western Isles council. It lost £24m with the collapse of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International in 1991. One of the results of this was the tightening of regulations on the types of investments councils could make.

The Approved Investment Regulations specified where councils could and could not put their surplus cash. They encourage councils to invest in government-backed instruments, such as short-term deposits with national banks, such as the Bank of England, rather than more speculative assets such as equities.

Any council that does not comply with these regulations and instead invests in a non-approved instrument has to use 50% of any yield to pay off debt - a strong disincentive to many.

However, local government officials argue that investments such as money market funds - a portfolio of short-term securities - would be less risky as they are triple-A rated, the highest form of security rating given by the City, than some of the banks councils currently put money into.

They are also easy to invest in. Seen as a short-term investment, a council treasurer could invest for a period as short as 24 hours. A minimum amount, anywhere between £50,000 to £100,000 would have to be invested.

Such arguments appear to be winning over some in government and councils accept that any changes would have to come with new regulation.

"We are not wishing to allow local authorities to use inappropriate risky investments," says Martin Easton, capital policy adviser with the Local Government Association.

"We will be expecting to stick to investments of the highest quality and the investment types under the new regulations."

This means, says Mr Easton, that councils will "certainly not" be allowed to invest in equities or derivatives.

Such views could prove pivotal if the changes are to become reality. If the government is confident that the private sector is happy with the proposals, then ministers may be more relaxed about allowing public sector money to be invested on the money markets.

fields.headline: Bridget Jones finds phenomenal success
fields.trailText: The weeks and months of pre-publicity and hype seem to have paid off as early reports suggest that Bridget Jones's Diary has banked a record £7.8m in just three days
fields.body:
It would seem the weeks and months of pre-publicity and hype have paid off as early reports suggest that Bridget Jones's Diary has banked a record £7.8m in just three days.

British cinema goers have flocked in their millions over the Easter weekend to see the Chardonnay swilling singleton, played by Renee Zellweger, lurch from disastrous love affair to embarrassing career gaff, in what could be the most successful opening ever for a British-made film.

Other Brit favourites such as Four Weddings and a Funeral, Notting Hill and Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels have been left in the shade as the long-awaited film adaptation of the million-selling Helen Fielding book proved a runaway success with British audiences of all ages.

According to the entertainment site People News about 60% of the audiences were said to be women and rather frighteningly, were said to have been flocking to the cinemas in packs. Furthermore, the film's distributors said that the audiences were made up of a large age sweep, ranging from 18 to early 50s.

The film's distributors, Miramax, who initially decided to launch the film on only 1,600 screens (half the number of some of the big American blockbusters) have added another 400 cinemas to their distribution list in the wake of the film's phenomenal success.

webTitle: The warnings Bradford should have heeded

fields.headline: The warnings Bradford should have heeded
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK

While the weekend's riots were not inevitable, the lack of real racial integration provided a backdrop for violence, writes Martin Wainwright
fields.trailText: While the weekend's riots were not inevitable, the lack of real racial integration provided a backdrop for violence, writes Martin Wainwright.
fields.body:
Today's pictures of burnt-out cars and boarded-up pubs are not fair to Bradford, but they do reinforce a warning made only three months ago by a panel that monitors local community relations.

The speed with which a pub fracas became a matter of 'defending our area' to Asian youths in the usually quiet quarter of Lidget Green lends weight to the panel's warnings of "growing ghetto-isation" in the Yorkshire city.

You could see the process in action on Legrams Lane, the commuter route from Halifax that passes all three battered pubs, the day after the brief but furious outbreak of violence.

Defiant young men recounted how "invading skinheads from out of town" had been seen off, while older residents mourned that "this used to be such a nice area".

Actually it still is. The Coach House, where the trouble began, is far from being the sort of inner city dive where you might expect brawls. A former farm, it still has an 18th-century dovecote built into its gritstone walls, and families often sit in the sun in its beer garden.

It is also just the sort of place, in modern, multicultural Bradford, where a Hindu wedding reception would go off well; and the Indian community often uses it for such events.

It was horribly anomalous that guests from just such a reception got caught up in a quarrel, then a fight, which ignited the worst window-smashing, missile-throwing and car-burning seen in Bradford since the Manningham street violence of 1995. After that, much worse, outbreak of trouble, the city worked prodigiously to re-open community links, which - fatally unnoticed - had got clogged. The problem turned out to be a mismatch between local police, particularly younger officers, and parts of the Asian community - again, especially younger people.

It largely arose, two reports agreed, because of the arthritis that eventually affects most institutional arrangements: there were plenty of discussion groups and meeting points, but they had not adapted and expanded to involve the rising generation.

People had got used to talking to the same old people. Lidget Green flags a warning that this could be happening again. Not so much with West Yorkshire police, who have sent officers to Pakistan to engage with Muslim culture and policing, but within the ordinary, everyday community-at-large.

It was strikingly demonstrated by Jean Priestley, landlady of the Oddfellows' Arms, which had 10 of its 11 windows shattered, as she chatted with the glazier over a mound of putty.

"We had the Asians in here, as usual, playing cards down this end," she said, pointing to the saloon bar overlooking the Cemetery Road stretch of Bradford's inner ring road. "The whites were up here (pointing to the Legrams Lane end of the pub), drinking at the bar."

No one can deny that the Oddfellows lives up to its billboard announcing: "Friendly family atmosphere." But the informal division Mrs Priestley describes (which involves no personal animosity) carries frightening seeds of separatism - and its offspring, mutual misunderstanding.

That is why some of Bradford's most moderate and liberal politicians are worried about the imminent prospect of a Muslim high school; a logical step, given the success of Catholic and Jewish schools, but with obvious implications for ghettoisation.

The school will happen, but Lidget Green underlines the need for mixing everywhere else: at Bradford City's football ground (blessed by local imams); in the Bradford district cricket league; at the Interfaith Centre; in shops; in jobs.

This is not a matter of do-gooder moralising but of hard-headed social and economic sense. Britain's best curry is only part of the great contribution to local prosperity made by second-generation Asian entrepreneurs.

Bradford's excellent, cosmopolitan air is, after all, what gives it a potential edge on all other northern cities.

fields.headline: Tory memo bans racist language
fields.standfirst: Special report: Race in Britain
fields.trailText: A leaked Tory memo warning candidates to avoid racist or religiously provocative language in the general election campaign has been seized on by Labour and Liberal Democrat activists as evidence of deep-seated prejudice in Conservative ranks.
fields.body:
A leaked Tory memo warning candidates to avoid racist or religiously provocative language in the general election campaign has been seized on by Labour and Liberal Democrat activists as evidence of deep-seated prejudice in Conservative ranks.

The Conservative party chairman Michael Ancram wrote to all Tory prospective parliamentary candidates in March telling them to "avoid using language which is likely to generate racial or religious hatred."

The need for such a memo prompted Labour MP Fraser Kemp to accuse the Tories of being "worried about the possibilities of racial outbursts from their candidates."

He added: ""It's going to take more than a memo to shift the fundamentally right-wing and bigoted opinions of today's Tory party."

The memo was sent to all 659 conservative candidates just two days before Tory MP John Townend's comments on immigration to a constituency party came to light.

Mr Townend, who is stepping down at the next election, blamed immigration for "undermining anglo-saxon society" and claimed that Enoch Powell would have been made prime minister if people had realised how correct his predictions were to become. He also claimed immigrants came from areas where crime was high.

The letter goes on to state: " The Conservative party is utterly opposed to racial discrimination. We believe in a Britain where what matters is your talent and effort, not the colour of your skin or who your parents were."

Today, prospective Conservative MP for Henley, Boris Johnson, added his voice to the growing row, by calling for Mr Townend, MP for Yorkshire East, to have the whip removed.

In an interview with Guardian Unlimited Mr Johnson said: "If I were leader he would have done."

In a damage-limitation exercise, backbench Conservative MP Peter Bottomley today claimed that the Tory party would be the first to have a black or Asian prime minister.

He said: "I suspect that in the same way that the Conservative party was the first party to have a prime minister of Jewish background, the first party to have a woman, we're quite likely to be the first to have a prominent black or Asian politician as our prime minister.

"The colour of my skin should be as important as the colour of my eyes or the colour of my hair; something you may notice but doesn't tell you any more about me," he added.

webTitle: Pubs and cars wrecked in Bradford riot

fields.headline: Pubs and cars wrecked in Bradford riot
fields.standfirst:
Police restore order after four hours of fighting and petrol bombs begun by wedding reception clash

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Mounting tensions among white and Asian youths in Bradford boiled over at the weekend, leaving three pubs and a chemist's shop badly damaged, eight burned out cars and scores of shop windows shattered.
fields.body:
Mounting tensions among white and Asian youths in Bradford boiled over at the weekend, leaving three pubs and a chemist's shop badly damaged, eight burned out cars and scores of shop windows shattered.

Dozens of angry youths took to the streets after a fight at a Hindu wedding reception triggered errant rumours of a racist attack against Muslims.

Lidget Green, a quiet area of the city, was littered with broken glass yesterday and pungent with the smell of burned tyres and carpets. Extra police were on duty last night as detectives traced how an isolated scuffle escalated into stone throwing and street fighting with startling speed.

A small instant response unit called to the Coach House pub - a converted farmhouse with a family garden and no record of trouble - was overwhelmed by the rapid spread of violence which led to three arson attacks.

Two men were kept in Bradford infirmary overnight with facial fractures, six others suffered minor injuries. Three men, of different races, were arrested on suspicion of causing violent disorder; they were later released on police bail.

Superintendent Mark Whyman, head of operations for Bradford North division, said that the groups involved in the initial fighting had been of mixed race. No one described the battles as racially motivated, which would have required police to treat the incident as a racist crime under a clause in the Macpherson report.

"There are tensions in Bradford, which is a multicultural society," Supt Whyman said. "But people in Lidget Green have been working very closely together and there have been no signs that anything like this could happen. It really was a surprise."

White and Asian residents watching yesterday's clear up in Lidget Green were also bewildered, but said that the second stage of the trouble had clearly been on racial lines.

Rumours of an attack on the largely Muslim neighbourhood, allegedly involving National Front members from the outlying Buttershaw estate, had spread "instantly" after the initial violence, said Mohammed Zahid Ibrahim.

Another Asian witness, who did not want to be named, said that trouble had flared at 7.30pm on Sunday between an Indian guest at a wedding reception and a young white man drinking at the Coach House: "The guest ran across to a takeaway pizza place on the other side of Legrams Lane and this other guy was after him, threatening to smash in the window if he didn't come out." Further fights broke out round the pub and windows were smashed, as the first of what Supt Whyman called "a huge number of emergency calls in a very short space of time" were made to police.

The violence escalated as white and Afro-Caribbean youths turned over a bus and began smashing shop windows, according to Mr Ibrahim. Young Asian men apparently then came out of neighbouring houses to take them on.

After smashing windows at the Coach House, the Asian youths allegedly set alight eight cars in the pub car park, some belonging to Indian wedding guests. About 130 police in riot gear arrived too late to stop the crowd moving on to two other pubs. "About 50 people started throwing stones and petrol bombs through the pub windows," said William Hand, a patron at the Second West pub.

Police and community leaders have begun talks on why the rumours were so readily believed, and why police reinforcements appeared slow to arrive. Mr Whyman said that a 32-year-old white man, a 19-year-old Asian man and a 42-year-old "dark European" man were held and questioned.

Order was restored after nearly four hours, but officers in riot gear remained in the area until 3am yesterday.

Bradford saw serious rioting in 1995 when £1m damage was done during three nights in the Manningham area.

fields.headline: Bradford reignited
fields.standfirst:
Even harmonious cities can explode

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Once again Bradford was involved in a clean-up operation yesterday after a night in which more than 100 youths were involved in torching cars, throwing petrol bombs, and attacking three white-owned pubs.
fields.body:
Once again Bradford was involved in a clean-up operation yesterday after a night in which more than 100 youths were involved in torching cars, throwing petrol bombs, and attacking three white-owned pubs.

More than 100 officers were called out to the disturbances, which were centred in the Lidget Green district. Damage is estimated to run into thousands of pounds. The trouble began after an incident in a pub between a guest at a Hindu wedding reception and a white youth. As news spread of a fight between Asian and white youths, local Asian youths sped to the scene intent on protecting their area. The scene became more complicated as through traffic became blocked and buses unloaded more white and Afro-Caribbean youths.

Sunday night's disturbance does not compare with the 1995 riot in Bradford, when 102 premises were attacked, £1m damage was wreaked and 41 people were arrested. The 1995 disturbances lasted for three days and led to two separate inquiries. There were only eight arrests and four people being treated for injuries after Sunday night's disturbance. But it does underline the tinder-box nature of many deprived inner-city areas with high ethnic populations. West Yorkshire police yesterday downplayed the idea that the disturbances were racially motivated. They claimed there were "Asian youths in the main fighting Asian youths and others".

Much resentment was generated in Bradford when the police complaints authority inquiry concluded that allegations of police misconduct in the 1995 disturbances were "without foundation". A separate three-member independent inquiry, commissioned by business, trade unions and voluntary organisations, ruled out allegations of police racism.

But it did raise questions, which are still relevant: lack of jobs, poor schools and the difficulties of policing multi-ethnic communities. The inquiry questioned whether it was possible for white police officers to carry out their duties in a district with such a high concentration of ethnic minority members. Bradford, which has had a reputation for harmonious community relations, has three separate Asian religious communities: Muslim, Hindu and Sikh. The predominant group is Muslim, but this community alone involves five different Islamic traditions. All of which only reinforces the government's drive for more ethnic minority police officers.

Much resentment was generated in Bradford when the police complaints authority inquiry concluded that allegations of police misconduct in the 1995 disturbances were "without foundation". A separate three-member independent inquiry, commissioned by business, trade unions and voluntary organisations, ruled out allegations of police racism. But it did raise questions, which are still relevant: lack of jobs, poor schools and the difficulties of policing multi-ethnic communities. The inquiry questioned whether it was possible for white police officers to carry out their duties in a district with such a high concentration of ethnic minority members. Bradford, which has had a reputation for harmonious community relations, has three separate Asian religious communities: Muslim, Hindu and Sikh. The predominant group is Muslim, but this community alone involves five different Islamic traditions. All of which only reinforces the government's drive for more ethnic minority police officers.

fields.headline: New Media Age
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 12
fields.trailText: April 12: Media owners confirmed plans to launch sports-led offerings.
fields.body:
The age of paid-for web content came dramatically into focus this week as leading media owners confirmed their plans to launch sports-led offerings.

Vodafone has entered into discussions with the England and Wales Cricket Board to obtain broadcast rights for 3G networks.

Thinkventures, the venture capital fund launched by former Freeserve co-founder Mark Danby, will not be making any more investments.

DoubleClick could face a lawsuit from Jupiter MMXI over its new Diameter audience measurement service, netScore.

Watertight audience figures for live webcasts and streamed audio/video will soon be available, with ABC Electronic announcing it is to start auditing user numbers.

Site of the week is www.totalbet.com, scoring 78/100 for pulling off "a crisp relaunch last week in time for the year's top racing event, the Grand National".

fields.headline: Naturism
fields.standfirst: Nudity is in the news after a group of Royal Navy soldiers were censured for stripping off in a Florida club. Here's our guide to the best sites on naturism on the net
fields.trailText: Nudity is in the news after a group of Royal Navy soldiers were censured for stripping off in a Florida club. Here's our guide to the best sites on naturism on the net.
fields.body:
1. The Sun has got its knickers in a twist over a group of British sailors who stripped off in a "clothing optional" bar in Florida: "It is not how you expect military servicemen to behave," says the paper's military adviser in a scathing rant.

2. This is the same newspaper that earlier this year ran a picture of a topless female soldier on a "clothing optional" page of its own.

3. Amid the hype, spare a thought for those who don't see nudity as a source of either offence or sexual gratification - the humble naturists.

4. Most naturists are men, though they would love to persuade their partners to get involved.

5. Naturists usually find themselves confined to designated areas such as certain beaches and clubs (foot and mouth disease permitting, of course).

6. Many read Health and Efficiency magazine - which has apparently cleaned up its act since the dog days of the seventies and eighties, and concentrates on "real naturism issues".

7. Such issues include recommendation 54, a proposed amendment to British law which could make naturism illegal for a man even if he does not intend to cause offence.

8. This is what most naturists think of that idea.

9. Meanwhile in America, a town's "visitors bureau" has been slated by a free speech organisation for clothing a statue of a naked Greek god at the request of a visiting conference.

10. It's a low blow, given that naturists are turning to the Hellenic ideal in their pursuit of global domination: today the women's Olympic soccer team, tomorrow the world

fields.headline: Complacency, Conjecture, and Congestion
fields.trailText: THE GAMES IN SPAIN
fields.body:
THE GAMES IN SPAIN

Matadors. Paella. Pushing a donkey off the top of a tower block. All of these quintessentially Spanish things will be prised into laboured opening paragraphs by tired journalists after Arsenal and Leeds play Valencia and Deportivo in the quarter-finals of Big Cup tonight. The Fiver doesn't hold with such cheap stereotypical nonsense, however, so clack your castanets and give a hearty cry of "Una Paloma Blanca" as we round up the latest news from both camps.

Olé!!! Here's Arsene boss Arsenal Wenger explaining why his team won't be holding out for a draw against Valencia. "We must have a go at them like we did in the first 25 minutes and the entire second half at Highbury," he said. "We have to believe in our true form and forget what happened against Middlesbrough."

Viva España!!! Own-goal saddos Edu and Silvinho won't be playing: Silvinho because he's crocked, Edu because Wenger thinks he "still does not look physically ready to play at this level". Meanwhile their hosts will be without Kily Gonzalez and Vicente Rodriguez.

Severiano Ballesteros!!! David O'Leary O'Leeds is expected to name an unchanged side to face Depor from the one which put Liverpool in their place in their place on Friday. Gary Kelly would have returned to the side, but he damaged ankle ligaments over the weekend. "It's strange to think we're leading 3-0," said chief beneficiary of Kelly's woe Danny Mills, "but it is in no way over. There is no complacency and we're certainly not thinking about a place in the final just yet."

Anyway, that's it for now. Adiós mes chiquitos!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

RIV FOREVER

As the transfer rumour mill becomes ever more sophisticated - rumour mongers are currently doing the rounds of Britain's top universities, hoping to recruit the brightest graduates into their sinister cabal - it is increasingly difficult to distinguish fact from fiction. If Jamie Oliver, say, said coriander should only be eaten when it has been rubbed between his gonads, you wouldn't believe him. But if somebody's agent told you Rivaldo was off to Manchester United, you would. Amazing.

And so, when Pep Guardiola's wangle-meister got on the case yesterday, claiming that Riv was set to join his client in leaving Barcelona this summer, the Fiver got excited. When he went on to suggest that a Premiership club would open negotiations with Barca this week over a move, we became aroused. And when the Sun claimed this morning that United were the mystery club, and that Dave Beckham (never!) could head the other way as part of the deal we, well you know.

So how surprising to find Rivaldo strolling onto his very own personal website today to pledge eternal love to Barca. For the next couple of years, anyway. "I know nothing about meetings between clubs and I don't want to know anything about them," he said, insisting that any transfer is down the club's directors. "It gives me great pleasure to see my name linked with clubs like Manchester United and Milan, but if it is down to me I will honour my contract." Which either means he's staying or just that, if he does leave he doesn't want to get lynched. Like we say though, it's impossible to tell.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Tigana is a great maestro, a great manager and that's very important. Now he has got us promoted and in the Premiership he can have whatever he wants. We hope we are going to be the champions of the Premier League!" - It's Mohammed al Fayed! He's the chairman of a Premiership club! Can the apocalypse be far away?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CANVEY KICK IT?

If Gerard Houllier fancies indulging in a paranoid rant this week, it is hang on. When Gerard Houllier indulges in a paranoid rant this week, it is likely that certain common ingredients will pop up. Firstly, the outrageously treacherous behaviour of whoever Liverpool have got to play next; secondly the continuing bias of the media; and thirdly, the incredible fixture list that will see Liverpool playing more games than Craig David would with a fly honey.

Now, this may go down well with the sort of tattle-merchants who trade in such obviously exaggerated comments (pause for quick acknowledgement of own worthlessness), but it's unlikely to earn much sympathy at Canvey Island FC. The Ryman League club have this season embarked on cup runs of Red proportions, progressing to the final of the FA Trophy and the Essex Senior Cup. But such success doesn't come without a price and the Island, as they're probably known by somebody, now face a rather daunting thirteen games in the next 18 days.

The odyssey kicks off with the visit of Maidenhead tomorrow and ends with the arrival of Hitchin on May 5, the final Saturday of the league season. And in the middle comes the ESC final against Dagenham (of make-Charlton-look-rubbish fame). In our own, typically half-cocked, fashion, the Fiver tried to get through to the club today to pass on our best wishes. But nobody was in, and their voice mail was full (presumably with messages from lost players who'd turned up for the wrong fixture). But if anyone deserves to score a last minute free-kick from 45 yards after having sneaked it forward illegally, then surely it's them.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Manchester United have joined Leeds in the chase for Newcastle's Kieron Dyer. But they'll have to do better than David O'Leary's bid of £11m, which Bobby Robson feels is derisory.

Rangers are interested in Iranian striker Ali Daei. The Teddy Bears will initially try to secure Daei's services on loan in time for next season, with a view to signing the Hertha Berlin man when his contract runs out the year after.

Southampton are showing interest in Gent striker Ahmed Hossam. The 18-year-old Egyptian international, who would cost at least £2m, is also being looked at by Ajax and Anderlecht.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Giovane Elber will be available to play for Bayern Munich in tomorrow's Big Cup match against Manchester United. The influential Brazilian, who has scored 15 goals in the Bundesliga and three in Big Cup, has been recovering from a knee injury which ruled him out of Saturday's game against Schalke. "I was desperate to be fit this week and thankfully it has happened," he told the club's official website (www.fcb.de). "I don't have any niggling injuries any more."

Alec Stock, the former Fulham, QPR, Yeovil, Leyton Orient, Luton and Bournemouth manager, has died aged 84 after a long illness. Stock will best be remembered for taking non-League Yeovil to the FA Cup fifth round in 1949, beating Len Shackleton's Sunderland along the way. He also won the 1967 League Cup with QPR, took Fulham to the 1975 FA Cup final and won the Third Division South title in 1955-56 with Orient.

Ronaldo has hinted that he could return from injury and play for Internazionale before the end of this season. "I don't know when I will be back playing but I do not exclude that if I feel good in 15 days or a month then I could do it," he said today. "Now I can do almost everything with the ball and I have played a lot of training games. I believe I am not lacking much now." The 25-year-old Brazilian has not played since tearing knee ligaments after playing just seven minutes of the Italian Cup final last April in what was his comeback game from a previous injury.

Scotland manager Craig Brown has called up the uncapped trio Dundee United's Charlie Miller, John O'Neil of Hibernian and Dundee's Gavin Rae for the upcoming friendly in Poland on Wednesday April 25. The squad: Douglas (Celtic), Sullivan (Tottenham), Boyd (Celtic), Dailly (West Ham), Davidson (Leicester), McNamara (Celtic), Pressley (Hearts), Weir (Everton), Cameron (Hearts), Ferguson (Rangers), Gemmill (Everton), Lambert (Celtic), Miller (Dundee Utd), O'Neil (Hibernian), Rae (Dundee), Booth (Twente Enschede), Dickov (Man City), Dodds (Rangers), Hutchison (Sunderland), Johnston (Rangers).

The Football Conference has signed a new four-year deal with its sponsor for the last three seasons, the Nationwide Building Society. The partnership will be worth £1.4m to the 22 Conference clubs over the next four seasons - £350,000 each campaign. The new agreement means that the competition will continue to be known as the Nationwide Conference until the end of the 2004/2005 season. This deal comes just a week after Nationwide renewed its sponsorship of the three divisions of the Football League.

Jim Baxter's funeral will take place at 10am on Friday April 20 at Glasgow Cathedral. The legendary Rangers and Scotland star died from liver cancer on Saturday aged 61. Baxter's former Ibrox colleague Ralph Brand and author and broadcaster William McIlvanney will both speak at the service.

Robert Tomaschek will miss Hearts' game against Celtic on Sunday after his appeal against a one-match ban was thrown out by the SFA.

Scotland's Hugh Dallas will take charge of Thursday's Euro Vase semi-final second-leg between Kaiserslautern and Alaves.

Greece captain Theodoris Zagorakis has tested positive for the use of anabolic steroids, his club AEK Athens confirmed on Tuesday. The 31-year-old midfielder faces up to a two-year ban after traces of the outlawed drug were recorded following a league match with Kalamata in March.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (10.20pm) A long evening of hard graft for Sideshow Bob Wilson begins here.

Football Extra (12.35am) Bob's tea break.

The Big Match Replayed (1.40am) Bob is worked like a dog into the early hours.

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.20am) Bob finishes up and drives home.

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm) Bob awakes with a start to find the past six hours were a dream and he's still got to go to work.

Football League Review (7pm) A grumpy Bob gets out of bed and puts on his pants and socks.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm) Bob puts the finishing touches to his opening script.

ONsport1: Deportivo v Leeds (7.30pm) Nightmarishly, Bob awakes to find the past three hours, during which he realised the past six hours were a dream, were also a dream and he'll have to go to work for what is in effect a third time.

ONsport2: Valencia v Arsenal (7.30pm) Bob clumsily breaks the space/time continuum and finds himself in a parallel universe.

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm) Bob has an out-of-body experience, and finds his eerie dismembered voice echoing around the land.
