fields.headline: 'A choice between victory and defeat'
fields.trailText: Although tension in the Middle East is rising inexorably, there is a curious lack of vehemence in the Arab press. Readers - in the English-language press at any rate - are being fed a bland mixture of western agency news reports and carefully worded commentaries.
fields.body:
Although tension in the Middle East is rising inexorably, there is a curious lack of vehemence in the Arab press. Readers - in the English-language press at any rate - are being fed a bland mixture of western agency news reports and carefully worded commentaries.

Fahd Husain in the Gulf News comments acidly on Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's shortcomings.

As the fighting intensifies, he writes, some bitter facts are becoming clearer: "The most important of these is the inability, or sheer helplessness, of the Palestinian leadership to control the chain of events, or even direct them towards a coherent goal.

"Yasser Arafat is yet to come out with a clear strategy in wake of the collapse of negotiations with Israel and the downfall of Ehud Barak. It is almost as if Palestinians ran out of ideas after Camp David. This intellectual drought, for lack of a more appropriate term, has already begun to take its toll on the movement."

A thoughtful editorial in the Jordan Times urges the use of diplomacy to counter Israeli aggression.

The paper endorses the much-criticised decision by the foreign minister, Abdul Ilah Khatib, to visit Tel Aviv in the midst of the latest attacks on Syrian forces in Lebanon: "It should be interpreted in the context of Jordan's unenviable position in the middle of the region.

"In this case, the only way to ensure the end to the current conflict and by extension Jordan's interests is to confront Israel's incomprehensible policy with the persuasion of diplomacy - not boycott it as many would like to see."

The leader-writer laments the lack of options available to Arab leaders: "Between the continuing aggression on the Palestinians and the renewed aggression against Lebanon and Syria, Israel is bombing the peace process to death, while its Arab partners in peace are running out of moves."

As usual, the voice of Palestine is silent on the internet, where the various information sites are either crashed or woefully out of date. Palestine-net, for example, was last updated 14 eventful days ago. The Jerusalem Media and Communication Centre also has no recent news, save for an updated list of Palestinian victims of the conflict.

There is no such reticence, of course, in the slickly presented Israeli press websites. The Jerusalem Post site features an online opinion poll on whether Israel was right to attack the Syrian radar position in Lebanon. Nearly 10,000 readers responded and, unsurprisingly, 90% of them endorsed the airstrike.

In its editorial column, the Post indignantly asserts that Israel has abided by its obligations under a 1978 UN resolution on Lebanon, by withdrawing its forces from that country (after 22 years, as the writer does not point out).

It goes on: "The spoilers here are Iran and Syria which, through their proxy, Hizbullah, have blithely continued to use Lebanese territory to attack Israel without suffering the consequences. Though the Lebanese government predictably condemned Israel's airstrike, anyone who cares about the independence of Lebanon should be thanking Israel.

"As long as the Lebanese government does not have the power or the will to resist its exploitation by Iran and Syria, Israel will have to act against those foreign forces directly."

The same macho mood surfaces in a commentary by former defence minister Moshe Arens for the liberal Tel Aviv daily, Ha'aretz.

He argues that all of Israel's problems stem from the secretly negotiated Oslo agreement, which allowed Yasser Arafat to represent the Palestinians: "There is little doubt that the Lebanon withdrawal served as fuel for the current Al-Aqsa Intifada.

"Arafat knows that Israel is capable of overcoming the Palestinian violence, but he is counting on Israel not having the staying power to handle an extended period of violence. By now it should be clear to Israel that giving in to violence is only going to lead to further violence.

"Refusing to negotiate unless the Palestinian violence ceases has become the acid test of Israel's determination to protect its interests. It is a choice between victory and defeat."

The paper endorses the much-criticised decision by the foreign minister, Abdul Ilah Khatib, to visit Tel Aviv in the midst of the latest attacks on Syrian forces in Lebanon: "It should be interpreted in the context of Jordan's unenviable position in the middle of the region. "In this case, the only way to ensure the end to the current conflict and by extension Jordan's interests is to confront Israel's incomprehensible policy with the persuasion of diplomacy - not boycott it as many would like to see." The leader-writer laments the lack of options available to Arab leaders: "Between the continuing aggression on the Palestinians and the renewed aggression against Lebanon and Syria, Israel is bombing the peace process to death, while its Arab partners in peace are running out of moves." As usual, the voice of Palestine is silent on the internet, where the various information sites are either crashed or woefully out of date. Palestine-net, for example, was last updated 14 eventful days ago. The Jerusalem Media and Communication Centre also has no recent news, save for an updated list of Palestinian victims of the conflict. There is no such reticence, of course, in the slickly presented Israeli press websites. The Jerusalem Post site features an online opinion poll on whether Israel was right to attack the Syrian radar position in Lebanon. Nearly 10,000 readers responded and, unsurprisingly, 90% of them endorsed the airstrike. In its editorial column, the Post indignantly asserts that Israel has abided by its obligations under a 1978 UN resolution on Lebanon, by withdrawing its forces from that country (after 22 years, as the writer does not point out). It goes on: "The spoilers here are Iran and Syria which, through their proxy, Hizbullah, have blithely continued to use Lebanese territory to attack Israel without suffering the consequences. Though the Lebanese government predictably condemned Israel's airstrike, anyone who cares about the independence of Lebanon should be thanking Israel. "As long as the Lebanese government does not have the power or the will to resist its exploitation by Iran and Syria, Israel will have to act against those foreign forces directly." The same macho mood surfaces in a commentary by former defence minister Moshe Arens for the liberal Tel Aviv daily, Ha'aretz. He argues that all of Israel's problems stem from the secretly negotiated Oslo agreement, which allowed Yasser Arafat to represent the Palestinians: "There is little doubt that the Lebanon withdrawal served as fuel for the current Al-Aqsa Intifada. "Arafat knows that Israel is capable of overcoming the Palestinian violence, but he is counting on Israel not having the staying power to handle an extended period of violence. By now it should be clear to Israel that giving in to violence is only going to lead to further violence. "Refusing to negotiate unless the Palestinian violence ceases has become the acid test of Israel's determination to protect its interests. It is a choice between victory and defeat."

webTitle: Livingstone turns the tube into election issue

fields.headline: Livingstone turns the tube into election issue
fields.trailText: London mayor Ken Livingstone today signalled his intention to make the future of the tube an embarrassing election issue as he spelled out his objections to the government's part-privatisation plans.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone today signalled his intention to make the future of the tube an embarrassing election issue as he spelled out his objections to the government's part-privatisation plans.

The independent mayor - flanked by his transport commissioner Bob Kiley - branded the PPP proposals as showing "contempt for the overwhelming views of Londoners."

And in a veiled warning to Tony Blair, Mr Livingstone said: "Londoners will be making this an issue with candidates because they are being told that for this parliament and the next they will not see any improvement on the Underground."

Labour has seven seats in Greater London which are within the Tories top 50 target seats, including such unlikely gains from the 1997 election as Romford, Harrow West and Enfield Southgate - where Michael Portillo lost to Labour candidate Stephen Twigg.

The scathing attack came at a specially convened press conference after the government upped the stakes by announcing it would decide which private consortia will run a partially privatised network on May 2 - more than five weeks before the mayor's judicial review of the planned PPP will reach the high court.

Mr Livingstone -who is approaching his first anniversary as mayor in May - was also angry that the GLA had only been given 10 days to respond to the Government's consultation on the preferred bidders.

He said: "I cannot recall in my 30 years as an MP such an unpopular issue with Londoners. Tony Blair talked of popular politics. This flies in the face of his own political credo."

Mr Kiley said separating maintenance and management under PPP remained "intolerable" and that the bids did not include "detailed scopes, budgets or have schedules", which he would have demanded from them for the next seven years.

The governments April 27 deadline for a response to its consultation on the preferred bidders was "preposterous", he said, adding: "It is almost saying it does not matter. "The turnaround time is superficial, cursory and perfunctory. The process is something of a sham. It's disappointing because we are reaching a point where all the bets are off."

Mr Livingstone said that under the PPP London would have to wait for 10 years for new trains, whereas he claimed that Mr Kiley, head of the capital's transport authority, Transport for London, would prioritise new trains and improve services within three to five years.

Condemning PPP as "ultra expensive, inefficient and potentially unsafe", Mr Livingstone added: "The PPP gives priority to stations, with improvements to service on many lines delayed for 10-20 years, when what passengers and businesses desperately want is for people to travel safely, quickly and cheaply."

Mr Kiley said one of his aims would be to improve disabled access. It should be provided at 25 or 30 stations instead of the 18 out of 275 stations provided under the PPP proposals.

Joining the fray, the Conservatives chose today to announce their plans to modernise the tube - and accused the government of neglecting the underground during its four years in power.

Shadow transport minister Bernard Jenkin promised to scrap Labour's PPP plans - although the Tories have no alternative proposal to put on the table - and ban strikes on the network.

Mr Jenkin said: "It is time to isolate the few militants who enjoy holding London to ransom for their own political ends."

The mayor has been in behind the scenes talks with the Liberal Democrats, over mooted proposals to oppose the government's financing scheme in the capital.

Tom Brake, the Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, said: "Clearly on the tube, which is the biggest transport issue in London, there is a big degree of agreement between us.

"There is also a degree of agreement about the necessity to stop Conservatives being elected at the general election. "If the mayor wants to express his support for Liberal Democrats, that is a matter for him."

fields.headline: BBC to begin filming Russian classic
fields.trailText: 8.30am: BBC2 is to start filming Crime and Punishment, scripted by Tony Marchant, in St Petersburg.
fields.body:
The filming of Fyodr Dostoevksy's classic novel, Crime and Punishment, scripted by Tony Marchant for BBC2, will get under way in eight weeks.

John Simm has been cast in the lead role for the piece, which will be filmed in St Petersburg.

It will be directed by Julian Jarrold, the director of Mr Marchant's most recent TV project, Channel 4's Never Never.

In Never Never, Simm starred as a loan shark living on a London council estate.

David Snodin, the BBC staff producer who produced Marchant's Bafta-winning serial Holding On, had to fight hard to win the commission.

There is said to have been disagreement about who should play the leading character of Raskolnikov, a student who kills his landlady.

Members of the production team have joked that if they had cast Jamie Oliver, the project would have been given the green light immediately.

Mr Marchant, who won the Bafta Dennis Potter Award last year, is also writing a Channel 4 project about the pharmaceutical industry called Swallow.

"It is ripe for an expose," said a production source on the project, which has been commissioned by drama boss Tessa Ross.

"However, it is at a very early stage," the source added.

fields.headline: Northern detective defeats giant lizard
fields.trailText:
3.30pm TV overnights BBC1's terrestrial movie premiere Godzilla lost out to an ITV Touch of Frost repeat last night, reports Jason Deans.
Rape lifts Corrie ratings
TV religion proves Easter turn-off
fields.body:
BBC1's big Easter terrestrial movie premiere Godzilla lost out to an ITV Touch of Frost repeat last night

Matthew Broderick's battle against the big lizard in New York went head-to-head with David Jason's dour northern detective from 8.45pm.

The BBC1 movie premiere had just 7.4m viewers and a 31% share; while ITV's Frost repeat had 8.8m, according to unofficial overnights.

BBC1 enjoyed more success with movie repeat Mrs Doubtfire, which was on between 8pm and 10pm on Thursday night.

The Robin Williams vehicle drew 7.5m and a third of viewing.

It lost out to Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, which had 8.8m, but beat ITV medical drama A&E, with 6.5m.

BBC1's big Easter drama, the Whistleblower, starring Amanda Burton as a mother who puts her family at risk from vengeful drug barons when she blows the whistle on a bank's money laundering activities, went out over two 85-minute episodes on Saturday and Sunday night.

Saturday's opening instalment had 7.2m and a 32% share; but lost out to Stars in Euro Eyes with 7.6m, and Who Wants to be a Millionaire? with 8.5m.

The second part on Sunday slipped back to 6.5m and 26% of the available audience, against ITV's concluding episode of Nicholas Nickleby, which had 7.1m.

BBC1's new Ulrika Jonsson gameshow vehicle Dog Eat Dog had a disappointing debut on Saturday night between 6.55pm and 7.40pm.

Dog Eat Dog had just 5.5m and a 27% audience share, while ITV opposition Blind Date had 6.9m.

Channel 4's Easter mini-series, star-studded US import Jason and the Argonauts, proved more successful on Sunday and Monday afternoons.

The first instalment had 3.3m and an 18% audience share; while the concluding episode the following day had 2.7m and a 14% share - both good ratings by Channel 4 standards.

The broadcaster's Sunday ratings were also buoyed up by the terrestrial debut of Julia Roberts movie My Best Friend's Wedding, from 8.40pm.

The movie had a 4.3m audience and an 18% share of viewing.

Channel 4 enjoyed more Sunday success with a repeat of religious epic the Greatest Story Ever Told between 2.05pm and 5.35pm.

It had 2m viewers and a 16% audience share.

Yesterday it was ITV's turn to score big afternoon ratings with classic bank holiday fare, in this case the umpteenth repeat of the Great Escape.

The prisoner of war escape epic had a 35% share of Monday afternoon viewing and 3.8m viewers.

fields.headline: Associate editor quits Sunday Express
fields.trailText:
1.15pm: Sue Matthias has joined the long list of journalists opting for fast-track redundancy. By Jessica Hodgson.
06.04.2001: Express columnist quits
05.04.2001: Jobson joins Express exodus
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Sunday Express associate editor Sue Matthias has joined the long list of journalists opting for fast-track redundancy from Express Newspapers.

Ms Matthias is one of the remaining members of the team of journalists recruited by former editor Rosie Boycott when she left the Independent on Sunday to join the Express.

She was brought in to overhaul the women's pages in the Daily Express.

"I don't regret joining the Express for one minute. It was a very exciting project," Ms Matthias told MediaGuardian.co.uk.

But she said "the Rosie idea" was no longer tenable at the paper under new owner Richard Desmond.

Of the original team of journalists brought in by Ms Boycott, only a handful remain.

The announcement that the Express planned to make 145 job cuts has seen journalists falling over themselves to leave the newspaper.

The most recent high profile departure has been managing editor Lindsay Cook.

fields.headline: Priest database targets paedophilia
fields.standfirst:
Special report: child protection
Special report: religion in the UK
The Nolan review in full
fields.trailText: A national database to help vet candidates for the priesthood should be set up by the Roman Catholic church in an effort to stamp out paedophile activity, a report recommended today.
fields.body:
A national database to help vet candidates for the priesthood should be set up by the Roman Catholic church in an effort to stamp out paedophile activity, a report recommended today.

No decisions on choosing would-be priests could be taken without referring to the database, under recommendations set out in the first independent report on child protection by the Roman Catholic church in England and Wales.

The database would work alongside a new national child protection unit set up by the church to promote good practice and liase with other agencies.

Between 1995 and 1999, 21 of the 5,600 Catholic priests in England and Wales were convicted of offences against children.

Today's report, headed by Lord Nolan, a former law lord, recommended that staff, volunteers and clergy should be subjected to police checks where necessary to root out child abusers.

All applicants for work in the Roman Catholic church should be asked to disclose any details of criminal offences against children and young people.

The report made 50 recommendations and follows a string of damaging revelations involving paedophile priests.

At a news conference in London, Lord Nolan said that aside from the "wickedness" of the paedophiles and the damage they had done to the victims, the scandals had caused damage to the reputation of the church.

"The care of children is at the forefront of the teachings of Christ," he said. "We believe that the Catholic church in England and Wales should become an example of best practice in the prevention of child abuse and in responding to it.

"We are confident that the huge majority of church members strongly support this objective and we have been impressed by the work many are already doing to bring it about."

The report was compiled by a committee of 10 members, six of whom were non-Catholics. The recommendations will be considered by the Roman Catholic bishops of England and Wales next week.

The Archbishop of Westminster, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, himself came under fire last July for his own handling of a scandal involving a paedophile priest.

Friar Michael Hill, who was released from prison last autumn, served three-and-a-half years of a five-year prison sentence imposed in 1997 for nine sex attacks, which included one on a boy with learning difficulties he met at Gatwick Airport chapel.

The archbishop conceded he had made a mistake when it emerged that he was responsible for appointing Hill as chaplain to the airport even though concerns had been raised about his behaviour.

The Archbishop of Cardiff, the Most Rev John Ward, has been replaced indefinitely by the Vatican amid accusations that he ignored warnings over a paedophile priest Joseph Jordan.

Friar Jordan was convicted of child abuse last year and sentenced to eight years in jail. The review was ordered in September last year, after the Cardinal admitted that "inadequate procedures" had led to errors in the past.

Cardinal Murphy-O'Connor said today that the independent report was "extremely constructive and helpful".

fields.bodyText: A national database to help vet candidates for the priesthood should be set up by the Roman Catholic church in an effort to stamp out paedophile activity, a report recommended today. No decisions on choosing would-be priests could be taken without referring to the database, under recommendations set out in the first independent report on child protection by the Roman Catholic church in England and Wales. The database would work alongside a new national child protection unit set up by the church to promote good practice and liase with other agencies. Between 1995 and 1999, 21 of the 5,600 Catholic priests in England and Wales were convicted of offences against children. Today's report, headed by Lord Nolan, a former law lord, recommended that staff, volunteers and clergy should be subjected to police checks where necessary to root out child abusers. All applicants for work in the Roman Catholic church should be asked to disclose any details of criminal offences against children and young people. The report made 50 recommendations and follows a string of damaging revelations involving paedophile priests. At a news conference in London, Lord Nolan said that aside from the "wickedness" of the paedophiles and the damage they had done to the victims, the scandals had caused damage to the reputation of the church. "The care of children is at the forefront of the teachings of Christ," he said. "We believe that the Catholic church in England and Wales should become an example of best practice in the prevention of child abuse and in responding to it. "We are confident that the huge majority of church members strongly support this objective and we have been impressed by the work many are already doing to bring it about." The report was compiled by a committee of 10 members, six of whom were non-Catholics. The recommendations will be considered by the Roman Catholic bishops of England and Wales next week. The Archbishop of Westminster, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, himself came under fire last July for his own handling of a scandal involving a paedophile priest. Friar Michael Hill, who was released from prison last autumn, served three-and-a-half years of a five-year prison sentence imposed in 1997 for nine sex attacks, which included one on a boy with learning difficulties he met at Gatwick Airport chapel. The archbishop conceded he had made a mistake when it emerged that he was responsible for appointing Hill as chaplain to the airport even though concerns had been raised about his behaviour. The Archbishop of Cardiff, the Most Rev John Ward, has been replaced indefinitely by the Vatican amid accusations that he ignored warnings over a paedophile priest Joseph Jordan. Friar Jordan was convicted of child abuse last year and sentenced to eight years in jail. The review was ordered in September last year, after the Cardinal admitted that "inadequate procedures" had led to errors in the past. Cardinal Murphy-O'Connor said today that the independent report was "extremely constructive and helpful". fields.headline: Business warms to Labour spin
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Labour's obsession with spin may be getting on everyone else's nerves, but it has impressed the business community, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Labour's obsession with spin may be getting on everyone else's nerves, but it appears to have impressed the business community.

A new survey shows Britain's business leaders regard Labour as much better at communication than the Conservatives.

Over half of all business leaders regarded the Labour party as good at communicating with business, whilst less than a third rated the Conservatives - traditionally the more business-friendly of the two.

And 48% of those questioned said Labour was good at communicating with the public, compared with just 24% for the Conservatives.

A massive 64% went so far as to say the Conservatives were bad at communicating with ordinary people.

The pre-election poll was commissioned by Weber Shandwick Public Affairs and carried out by SWR Worldwide, a leading US political research firm.

"With an election fast approaching, both Labour and the Conservatives are eagerly wooing the business audience," said a spokesman for SWR.

"Our polling shows that not only are Labour now trusted on the economy, they are seen as more effective communicators with business leaders."

fields.headline: Antonio Banderas confirmed as Phantom
fields.standfirst: Plus: New detective role for Bruce Willis; Famke Janssen joins Men in Black 2; Clint Eastwood in mystic thriller
fields.trailText: Casting couch: Antonio Banderas confirmed as Phantom Plus: New detective role for Bruce Willis; Famke Janssen joins Men in Black 2; Clint Eastwood in mystic thriller
fields.body:
Antonio Banderas's role in the movie of Andrew Lloyd-Webber's Phantom of the Opera has been confirmed. Speaking to the Daily Express, Banderas took issue with fans who have campaigned for Michael Crawford to be reinstated as the principal character. "Crawford made what actors call a creation, something that was his own, but what happens in the movies is not for an individual to decide. I am not the only actor," said the Spanish star. "If you said [the Phantom role] was going to John Travolta, not me, I would shrug and wait for another project."

Bruce Willis will play a sleuth who gets in way over his head in the movie Cross Check. Warner Brothers has purchased the rights from screenwriter Gary Scott Thompson, and is developing the detective story into a vehicle for the balding star.

Famke Janssen will star as the lead villain in Men in Black 2 for director Barry Sonnenfeld. MiB 2 will also bring back stars Will Smith and Tommy Lee Jones.

Oscar-winning screenwriter Brian Helgeland (LA Confidential) will join forces with Clint Eastwood to adapt the bestselling novel Mystic River. A psychological thriller written by Dennis Lehane, Mystic River tells of three children whose friendship ends in the wake of a tragic incident; 25 years later, the three are linked by a murder investigation.

webTitle: Yahoo! appoints Warner bros exec as new boss

fields.headline: Yahoo! appoints Warner bros exec as new boss
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Yahoo! has named top Warner Bros executive Terry Semel as its new chief, writes Amy Vickers.

12.04.2001: Killen parts company with Yahoo!

12.04.2001: Yahoo! to cut 12% of workforce

08.04.2001: Yahoo! deepens dot.com gloom
fields.body:
Yahoo! has named a top Warner Brothers executive as its new leader, replacing Tim Koogle who stepped down last month.

The internet giant announced this morning that Terry Semel will take over as chairman and chief executive from May 1.

Mr Koogle will act as vice-chairman until August, although he will remain on the board.

Mr Koogle had been expected to stay chairman, but it now appears his successor will take overall control of the company.

President and chief operating officer Jeff Mallett and chief financial officer Susan Decker are to continue in their current roles, reporting to Mr Semel.

Mr Semel, who is believed to have secured a salary much greater than Mr Koogle's £310,000, joins Yahoo! from Warner Bros where he was co-chairman and co-chief executive.

He is credited with building Warner Bros into one of the world's most successful media and entertainment operations.

"We have spent a considerable amount of time with Terry, and he clearly understands the tremendous opportunity ahead for Yahoo!" said Jerry Yang, the co-founder of Yahoo.

Yahoo has yet to appoint successors to European managing director Fabiola Arredondo or Heather Killen, the senior vice-president of international operations.

However, Mr Semal's appointment will go some way to alleviating investor concerns.

Yahoo! hit the headlines last week when it announced plans to move into pornography. But the company backtracked following complaints from users and said it would remove all offending material from its service.

webTitle: Internet teasers revealed for Spielberg's new film

fields.headline: Internet teasers revealed for Spielberg's new film
fields.standfirst: Plus: Erin Brockovich's new battle; Kate Winslet is honoured in home town; Kevin Costner weds again
fields.trailText: Internet teasers revealed for Spielberg's new film Plus: Erin Brockovich's new battle; Kate Winslet is honoured in home town; Kevin Costner weds again
fields.body:
The second trailer for Steven Spielberg's AI Artificial Intelligence has been confounding and delighting internet fans. Originally criticised for its impenetrable mysteriousness, closer study has revealed that the preview offers devious pointers to the nature of the film. Credited on the teaser, according to the sleuths at Aint It Cool News, is one Jeanine Salla, Sentient Machine Therapist. Rummaging around the internet, enthusiasts unearthed Ms Salla's homepage, a summary of the work of this artificial intelligence pioneer. This site links to The Coalition for Robotic Freedom, a lobby group purportedly attempting to free AIs from their enslavement by humans. And so it goes on. Following the links through these sites reveals an incredible web of teaser details in advance of the ex-Kubrick film's release, and is securing for the picture a marketing notoriety the original trailer seemed completely incapable of delivering.

Erin Brockovich is back in the news, in a new battle against an even more threatening opponent: household mould. The celebrated legal campaigner, portrayed by Julia Roberts in the Oscar-winning movie, is suing the former owner of her house, after discovering that it's filled with mould. The scourge, she has told legislators, is a "silent killer" - her husband and daughter have been suffering respiratory problems. But a representative for Robert Selleck, brother of Tom and former owner of the residence, claims, "there was absolutely nothing wrong with the house when Robert Selleck sold it. I think this mould nonsense is just that - nonsense".

Kate Winslet has had a street named after her in her home town, according to reports in the Daily Mirror. The deputy mayor of Reading, Tony Jones, has claimed responsibility for the wheeze, saying: "The developers wanted to name the cul-de-sac Lexington Crescent. That's such an anonymous name. I thought it would be nice to honour one of our own by calling the street after Kate." All of the 50 houses, worth £130,000 each, in Winslet Place have been sold. According to the Titanic star's dad, Roger, "Kate doesn't know what to make of it really. She's flattered but slightly embarrassed."

Kevin Costner has secretly married his girlfriend Christine Baumgarten in a chapel in Tuscany. "He fell under the spell of that lovely area," a friend said. According to the Daily Star, the pal adds: "The marriage won't be legally recognised in America until he takes out a license there. He's now telling pals and family to get ready for a Stateside ceremony." The 46-year-old star - his new wife is 20 years younger - divorced his first wife Cindy in 1994 after 16 years of marriage.

fields.headline: The power of love
fields.standfirst: Andrew's behaviour was a big problem. His teachers couldn't handle him. His peers wouldn't play with him. Then the whole class took part in a new experiment - and a small miracle happened. By Angela Neustatter
fields.trailText: Andrew's behaviour was a big problem. His teachers couldn't handle him. His peers wouldn't play with him. Then the whole class took part in a new experiment - and a small miracle happened. By Angela Neustatter
fields.body:
Eight-year-old Andrew Thomas has not found it easy settling in at Dunmail Primary School in Bristol. He arrived at the beginning of the year and his aggressive behaviour, tendency to fight and the things he said so alienated his classmates that he now spends most playtimes alone. The others choose not to sit next to him in class and there is no child he can call his friend. Andrew's is an all too familiar story and schools around the country struggle to cope with unhappy and disruptive children. At Dunmail, staff became sufficiently concerned about AndrewÍs behaviour that they knew something had to be done.

There are schools in which Andrew might have been punished and in due course excluded, but Dunmail is clear that this would be a failure for them and would only add to Andrew's own problems. Instead they decided to set up a 'circle of friends', a strikingly simple but carefully structured initiative that draws on classroom peers to take responsibility for the 'focus child's' problems and for helping him or her to change.

On the day that Andrew's circle of friends is being set up he stands facing the children with class teacher Helen Sanday sitting beside him, her arm around his waist. She asks gently: 'You're finding it difficult to make friends aren't you?' As Andrew nods looking down, giving a crooked smile but seeming close to tears, Sanday explains that the other children understand this and so they have told her all the things they like about him. She reads these out: 'he is sometimes nice to me', 'he plays football with me', 'he does good drawings'.

But, Sanday explains gently, there are also things that upset the children and these are the things that stop them wanting to be friends and Andrew listens as she recites: 'he fights', 'he doesn't share', 'sometimes he gets in moods'. Sanday then explains that the children want to help him settle in and a number have volunteered to be his special friends, staying with him in the classroom, in the playground, during activities. As she says it her class nods and smiles at Andrew and he, looking slightly dazed, sits down among them.

Dunmail introduced circle of friends, supported by the Bristol Behavioural Educational Unit, three years ago, and since then they have organised circles for four children who were causing enough concern that exclusion was being considered. Sanday explains the organisation of this project, which originated in Canada and which is now used here in more than 100 local authority primary and secondary schools for children with emotional and social difficulties:

'I begin by holding a meeting of the class but without the focus child. The children talk about the ways in which he or she annoys and upsets them. But then we think about how a person might be aggressive or show off because they feel lonely and sad and it always amazes me how much empathy and kindness children show once they think in this way. At the same time itÍs important for the focus child to hear the negatives as well as the positives and understand that they do need to change.'

ñI then ask for volunteers to be one of the child's special circle of friends and I usually get more children than I need. Each one chosen has a particular task, so a single child is not expected to be with the focus child all day long. The idea is that all through the day the child who has been isolated has 'friends' supporting him or her. There are weekly meetings with the circle of friends and the focus child to discuss how things are going.

It surprises Sanday how quickly children quieten down and become more cooperative as well as better able to learn once the circle, which generally lasts in its formal structure for a term, is set up. And she has seen how the children who have been given a circle of friends have all made lasting friendships. As she says this James Phillips, 10, for whom the first circle at Dunmail was set up, strides into the room flanked by his two 'best friends', Matthew Bartley and Lee Harris, both nine, both of whom were volunteers originally.

Sanday recollects: 'James was so troublesome we really didn't think we could keep him and his parents were very worried about how unhappy he was and how angry at home. But once the children started including him, he stopped driving them mad with his attention-seeking.' James agrees: 'I never wanted to come to school and my mum and dad got cross with me a lot. Now my friends come to the house to call for me and IÍve always got someone to play with.'

There have been similarly optimistic reports from many of the 100 local authority primary and secondary schools that, since 1998, have used the circle of friends approach. And the Gulbenkian Foundation, which provided funding for a pilot scheme in Bristol as part of its commitment to getting emotional education into schools, has just published an in-depth evaluation of how it has worked in four schools  The Positive Power of Friendship: An Illuminative Evaluation of the Circle of Friends Approach Within the Primary and Secondary School Phases.

The author, Gill Taylor, strategic manager for Birmingham Social Inclusion, explains that the whole class is mobilised in a way that strengthens the bonds between them as a community. She adds: ñThe facilitator of the class discussion has a critical role in communicating respect and care for the focus child and for highlighting the fact that the problem situation is the whole classÍs problem and not just the focus child's.'

For the evaluation Taylor and her co-author, Professor Bob Burden, head of the School of Education, Exeter interviewed the children selected, their parents and teachers, and their findings were analysed to see how far they reflected the main aims of circle of friends for the focus child, which include increased confidence and belief in the possibility of change, a sense of belonging, empowerment and improved problem-solving behaviour. Nine-year-old Sylvester is in year 4 at a London primary. He was constantly disrupting activities and class with his shouting and singing. When children told him to stop he was liable to become angry and spiteful. His mother's despair at her son's isolation crystallised in the fact he was never invited to birthday parties and no one had come to his. Sylvester was unhappy enough to respond positively when offered a circle of friends. After seven months he described how he was now 'sticking together' with the others and felt able to control his temper and walk away when he was annoyed.

His teacher had watched how the class tried to calm Sylvester down and adopted the catchphrase 'it's not worth it'. They accepted him more and he would now help other children who were hurt. For Sylvester's mother, who noted that he was better behaved at home, the greatest delight was that three people had come to his birthday party and 'he was really happy'.

Sheridan, 13, was already in secondary school when she was offered a circle of friends by teachers concerned about her inability to listen to what other children had to say, her determination to be the strongest and her inability to negotiate friendships. She was failing badly academically. And she was not enthusiastic about the group helping her at first, but after the third circle meeting her attitude began to show ña marked positive changeî.

The virtue of circle of friends, believes Taylor, who introduced it into Britain, is that it can be set up in any mainstream school without expensive resourcing, although she is adamant that proper training for the facilitating teacher is necessary. She is clear that circle of friends must be done with thought and care. For example, she says there is a risk, if all the attention is on the focus child and friends, that other children in the class will feel left out and they could then sabotage it. So some way of including them, too, is important. Also, she says, it is important that the emphasis is on letting the focus child see that they have a choice to change and that it is something they want to do rather than making it seem punitive or that they are so bad they will be rejected if they donÍt change. ñIt takes skilful handling to ensure this process of negotiation,î Taylor explains.

She hopes that the scheme will go on expanding, particularly in secondary schools where adolescents can be ñmore volatile in their emotions and more difficult to convinceî. It is also essential that there is enough teacher time for it to be done properly.

But whatever the difficulties and shortcomings teachers may encounter - and Sanday, realist to the last, talks of ñpleasing improvements not miracle curesî  Taylor and Burden are adamant that: ñIn every case . . . the conclusion of the target child, their parents and their teachers was that something positive had happened as a result of establishing a circle of friends.î

For more information about Circle of Friends, email: gill_taylor@ birmingham.gov.uk or telephone Circles Network on 0117 9393917.

For example, she says there is a risk, if all the attention is on the focus child and friends, that other children in the class will feel left out and they could then sabotage it. So some way of including them, too, is important. Also, she says, it is important that the emphasis is on letting the focus child see that they have a choice to change and that it is something they want to do rather than making it seem punitive or that they are so bad they will be rejected if they donÍt change. ñIt takes skilful handling to ensure this process of negotiation,î Taylor explains. She hopes that the scheme will go on expanding, particularly in secondary schools where adolescents can be ñmore volatile in their emotions and more difficult to convinceî. It is also essential that there is enough teacher time for it to be done properly. But whatever the difficulties and shortcomings teachers may encounter - and Sanday, realist to the last, talks of ñpleasing improvements not miracle curesî  Taylor and Burden are adamant that: ñIn every case . . . the conclusion of the target child, their parents and their teachers was that something positive had happened as a result of establishing a circle of friends.î For more information about Circle of Friends, email: gill_taylor@ birmingham.gov.uk or telephone Circles Network on 0117 9393917.

fields.headline: Weakest Link storms US
fields.trailText: The Weakest Link has been derided by the critics in America as "confusing, tiresome and gratuitously snippy", but Anne Robinson had the last laugh with ratings her rivals would kill for.
fields.body:
The Weakest Link has been derided by the critics in America as "confusing, tiresome and gratuitously snippy", but Anne Robinson had the last laugh with ratings her rivals would kill for.

On her first night on American television, this 56-year old Brit managed to beat everyone in sight.

The game show, already a massive hit on the BBC, was watched by more than 14m viewers in America.

Although the figure doesn't appear to be high for a country with more than 100m households, it was good enough to give NBC victory in its slot.

It was up against a new comedy, King of Queens on CBS which was seen in 7.9m homes.

Fox TV came third in the race with 7.5m for its second original episode of gritty schools drama Boston Public.

NBC said the show was the best performing show in its slot since the last episode of Will Smith comedy, The Fresh Prince of Bel Air five years ago.

webTitle: Councils in crisis: the issue explained

fields.headline: Councils in crisis: the issue explained
fields.standfirst: Council cock-ups make the headlines, while positive stories about well-run authorities rarely get a look-in. No wonder public opinion of local government is often negative, writes Simon Parker
fields.trailText: Council cock-ups make the headlines, while positive stories about well-run authorities rarely get a look-in. No wonder public opinion of local government is often negative, writes Simon Parker.
fields.body:
It may have been said before, but that doesn't it make it any less true - people only notice local government when it stops working.

The good citizens of Hackney in east London have been paying quite a lot of attention to their local authority over the past few years. The council's financial problems - an overspend that could total £40m - forced the borough's treasurer to issue a section 114 notice last October, freezing spending until budget cuts were agreed.

In the interregnum, bin-bags started to pile up in the streets, as the erratic refuse collection system finally gave up the ghost. Housing benefit claims continue to mount and the council still lacks clear political leadership. It is currently led by a coalition of the Conservative and Labour groups.

Hackney does not, sadly, have a monopoly on bad governance. If the London borough has become a by-word for local government chaos, then the northern council of Doncaster has become synonymous with sleaze. At least 19 councillors have been convicted, mostly for fiddling expenses claims.

Despite the Labour party's best efforts, and prime ministerial statements against council corruption, the fall-out from "Donnygate" shows no sign of abating just yet.

Both Doncaster and Hackney fit the stereotype of the dodgy, traditionally Labour-controlled urban authority, but district councils can fall into disrepair just as easily as their larger cousins. Take Harlow, branded "the next Hackey" by shadow local government minister Nigel Waterson. Or Mid-Devon, which has taken more than 25-years to decide whether to build a new civic centre.

Some of the work that is done to save poorly performing councils is carried out by local government itself. The Improvement and Development Agency sends teams of seasoned local government professionals into councils to assess their work and report back on how an authority can improve.

The government also has a range of powers it can use to intervene in failing councils, but there are question marks over their effectiveness. Under the best value regime, ministers can, for instance, personally take over the running of council services.

But ministers are reluctant to use this power. This is probably because they fear the embarrassing prospect of failing to improve a troubled authority. The danger with a council such as Hackney is that it could become the local government equivalent of Vietnam, with ministers unable to withdraw because they are unable to solve the problem.

The best value inspection regime also provides councils with an incentive to improve their performance. The inspectors take a close look at how an authority is performing in individual service areas, and the results are widely publicised, "naming and shaming" poorly performing authorities.

The real picture of local government services is a mixed one, but the public's perception sometimes seems to be shaped almost entirely by the councils in crisis - witness the thousands of column inches devoted to Hackney's woes. Things would probably be very different if the press and the electorate focused on local government's good work once in a while. But don't expect that to happen any time soon.

fields.headline: Meat safety campaign under consideration
fields.trailText: 2pm: A campaign to calm public fears over meat safety is being considered by the Meat and Livestock Commission, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
A campaign to calm public fears over the safety of meat vaccinated against foot and mouth disease is being considered by the Meat and Livestock Commission.

But even the MLC is confused over whether vaccinated animals would be destroyed or introduced into the meat chain.

A spokesman for the MLC said the original idea had been to destroy vaccinated animals to stop the spread of the disease rather than use them as food.

But the government has been talking to food manufacturers and retailers to gauge their reaction to using vaccinated meat and dairy produce.

If vaccinated meat was used as food, the spokesman said the MLC may need to address public concerns.

"If the idea is to vaccinate healthy animals and slaughter them for the food chain there might be a public concern issue," said the spokesman.

"I don't think the public will be worried about it but it could be a matter for public education."

There is no known risk to human health from meat or other products derived from animals with foot and mouth, or which have been vaccinated against it.

The government is coming under increasing pressure to decide whether to introduce a limited vaccination programme to help stop the spread of the epidemic.

But many farmers say vaccination would end all hopes of exporting meat and dairy products abroad.

The MLC has previously run campaigns to encourage consumers to buy British beef, pork and other meats.

Its campaign for British pork and bacon was banned by the Advertising Standards Authority for exaggerating the suffering endured by pigs in other countries.

The adverts urged consumers to "Look after the farmers who look after their pigs".

fields.headline: Worldpop joins Tower Records for text message scheme
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Peter Powell's Worldpop has teamed up with Tower Records to launch the retailer's first text messaging service, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Peter Powell's Worldpop has teamed up with Tower Records to launch the record retailer's first text messaging service.

The service offers information, discounts and special offers on music and entertainment products sold in Tower Records.

Consumers can sign up for the service by entering a competition to win a trip to New York which will be promoted by a print advertising campaign, via flyers, in-store and on www.towerrecords.co.uk.

As part of the initiative, "electronic vouchers" are text-messaged to mobile phone users and redeemed by consumers showing the text message they have received to the shop assistant, like a virtual voucher.

The aim of the text messaging service is to drive more music lovers to Tower Records and allows the retailer to communicate directly to consumers.

Worldpop will receive prominent branding on all promotional material for the service.

"This is a massive opportunity to drive revenue for retailers, record companies and for Worldpop," said Dan Avener, the head of marketing at Worldpop.

"We have already shown the potential in this area with a stream of recognised brands and companies advertising through our SMS 'Music Alert' services. This deal brings the service into a high street arena providing fantastic opportunities for revenue generation."

fields.headline: Religion proves a turn-off with TV worshippers
fields.trailText: As few as 1m viewers tuned in to watch religious programmes during the most important weekend of the Christian calendar, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Academics, authors and church leaders have spent the last week debating the future of christianity in Britain.

Today there is further evidence that interest in God and religion is falling away with TV ratings showing that as few as 1m viewers bothered to tune in to vicariously celebrate what is the most important feast day of the Christian calendar.

Easter Service on BBC1 and the Sunday Morning Show on ITV were watched by as few as 500,000 viewers apiece.

More viewers - 600,000 - were paying homage to temples of the flesh over on Channel 5 where Charlie's Angels was providing an alternative morning's viewing.

Even teenage soap Hollyoaks on Channel 4 fared better with 1.5m viewers.

Just 900,000 tuned in to see the ailing Pope deliver his traditional Easter message from St Peter's Square in Rome in BBC1's Urbi et Orbi.

Over on ITV, Melvyn Bragg - who is enjoying a new contract to cover the big religious issues as well as the arts - will have been disappointed to see that just 500,000 - 7% of the audience - bothered to watch the start of his new 10-part series, The Apostles.

Religious TV on Good Friday didn't fare much better - although practising Christians may well have treated this day of abstinence as a TV-free zone.

Just 800,000 viewers tuned in to see the Passion Play - Father Forgive: a meditation for Good Friday - on BBC at 11am.

The animated portrayal of the life of Jesus, Miracle Maker, was the most popular religious programme of the weekend with 2.4m - almost a third of those watching TV at the time - switching on for the award-winning film starring the voices of Ralph Fiennes, William Hurt, Julie Christie and Richard E Grant.

fields.headline: UK woos foreign tourism bosses
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Travel chiefs from around the world were arriving in Britain today to tour the countryside in a bid to convince overseas visitors that Britain is still a safe and attractive tourist destination.
fields.body:
Travel chiefs from around the world were arriving in Britain today to tour the countryside in a bid to convince overseas visitors that Britain is still a safe and attractive tourist destination.

40 leaders of international travel associations have been flown in by the British Tourist Authority (BTA) for a summit meeting in an effort to prove that the UK is still "open for business".

The industry is currently losing £120m a week as tourists decide not to visit Britain on the basis of often sketchy news reports in their home countries.

The four-day tour will take in Cumbria, north Wales, south-west England, the Scottish highlands, Edinburgh and London.

BTA hopes that the trip will help to dispel "misconceptions and misinformation" about the crisis. David Quarmby, BTA chairman, said: "There is a lot of confusion about foot and mouth overseas that is keeping people away. We need to counteract these misconceptions if we are to sustain our inbound tourism industry, which is worth £13bn a year to the economy.

"By welcoming these key opinion formers this week, we will be able to influence many thousands of their customers and commercial partners. We will also be working with them on their return home so that we can continue to generate interest in Britain as a destination."

The delegates are from the United States, Canada, Japan, France, Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Spain, Norway and Switzerland.

They will be split into two groups, with the US, Canadian and Japanese representatives heading for Scotland and Cumbria from Heathrow in a private jet provided by British Airways. The other group will set off tomorrow from Manchester for a tour of north Wales, Dartmoor and Cornwall.

Both groups will meet in London on Friday for private receptions at 10 Downing Street and Windsor castle.

fields.headline: ITC clears Millionaire question
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: The ITC has rejected viewer complaints that a question asked on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? was racist. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Broadcasting watchdogs have rejected viewers' complaints that a question asked on the popular ITV quiz show Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? was racist.

In a show broadcast in January, host Chris Tarrant asked a contestant, "Paddy is a nickname given to men or boys from which country?"

Fifteen viewers complained to the Independent Television Commission that the question caused racial offence.

But in its ruling the ITC said while the question was not well expressed, it was justified.

"The ITC believes that, while over the years the name Paddy has been used in a derogatory way in relation to Irish men, the name can be and is still used as a nickname in an affectionate and familiar sense, the diminutive form of the name Patrick," the commission said.

"The wording of the question did indicate that the acceptable use of the term was intended, distinguishing if from specifically racist terms which could never be considered nicknames."

fields.headline: Sky Pictures uncovers Ibiza
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Sky Pictures is lining up a fictional version of Ibiza Uncovered, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Sky Pictures is lining up a fictional version of Sky One's factual hit about British youth behaving badly abroad, Ibiza Uncovered.

Is Harry on the Boat? is to due to go out on Sky One or Sky Premier later this year.

The TV movie will feature a cast of young British stars, including the Royle Family's Ralf Little and former Hollyoaks actors Will Mellor and Davinia Taylor.

The drama follows a group of twentysomething tour reps sleeping their way round Ibiza during a summer of drug-taking and clubbing, before a tragedy forces them to sober up.

Shot on location in Ibiza, the film also stars Human Traffic actor Danny Dyer and former EastEnders Daniella Denby-Ashe and Des Coleman.

There are also cameos from Keith Allen and Jon Simm, star of the Lakes and Human Traffic.

Is Harry On The Boat? is directed by Menhaj Huda and produced by Alison Owen for Ruby Films.

The TV movie has been fully funded by Sky Pictures and produced in association with Rapido TV.

Jamie Roberts, head of TV film production at Sky Pictures, is the executive producer.

fields.headline: Farmers attack proposed vaccination scheme
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Farmers' leaders today warned that they will not support the proposed vaccination scheme to contain foot and mouth unless the government can show why it should be adopted and that it will not further damage the industry.
fields.body:
Farmers' leaders today warned that they will not support the proposed vaccination scheme to contain foot and mouth unless the government can show why it should be adopted and that it will not further damage the industry.

The National Farmers' Union (NFU) delivered its threat, which would effectively make the scheme unworkable, as ministers continued pondering whether to launch vaccination programmes in Cumbria and Devon, the two worst affected areas.

Government advisers now believe vaccination, in addition to the ongoing slaughter policy, could be the best way of halting the spread of the virus.

The government's chief scientific adviser, Professor David King, said yesterday that any such scheme would at first be limited to 500,000 cattle due to move on to pasture after spending the winter under cover.

However, the NFU warned that the government could be stopped in its tracks as ministers had so far failed to deliver satisfactory answers to a list of 50 written questions submitted by NFU president, Ben Gill.

The union said that responses so far provided by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff), fell short of properly addressing key issues, such as whether there would still be a market for meat and dairy products from vaccinated animals.

The NFU policy director, Martin Haworth, said: "If it [the proposed vaccination policy] is delivered on the basis of what we have seen so far then we will not support it.

"We asked [the government] whether there would a resistance by retailers in dealing in meat and dairy products from vaccinated animals. They said they did not think there would be and that simply does not answer our question. They have also failed to share the scientific arguments for introducing a vaccination scheme.

"The basic situation is still that the scientific evidence we have suggests that vaccination is an option but is not as good as the current policy [of slaughtering infected animals within 24 hours and livestock on nearby farms within 48 hours]."

Mr Haworth said that research published last week by experts at Imperial College London showed that a continuation of the current culling policy was the most effective way of eradicating the disease.

The Food Standards Agency has said that there are no human health issues connected with consuming meat or dairy products from vaccinated animals.

Local government: Foot and mouth hits council cash

The cost of handling the fallout from the foot and mouth crisis could decimate the budgets of district councils in the worst affected areas, with one authority already facing a 'serious' financial crisis.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/

fields.headline: Camelot victor joins advertising watchdog
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: The woman who saw off Richard Branson's lottery bid is to join the council of the ASA, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The woman credited with seeing off Richard Branson's challenge for the lottery is to join the watchdog that recently banned the "fcuk" adverts.

Diane Thompson, the chief executive of Camelot, will be joining the Advertising Standards Authority council alongside Dan O'Donoghue, head of strategic planning at advertising agency Publicis Worldwide.

They are the first appointments made by the ASA's new chairman, Lord Borrie, since he took on the job in January.

"I am delighted to have secured the services of two people with such vast experience and knowledge," he said.

"They will play an important role in helping to ensure that UK non-broadcast advertising is legal, decent, honest and truthful," he added.

The pair will replace Hugh Burkitt, the chairman of advertising agency Burkitt DDB, and Peter Mitchell, a director of Capital Radio, who leave after serving six years on the council.

Just four members of the 12-strong council can be from the advertising industry.

Ms Thompson became chief executive of Camelot in December 2000, having worked as commercial operations director since February 1997.

She was credited with seeing off a challenge from Richard Branson to secure Camelot a second licence to run the National Lottery.

Mr O'Donoghue has worked at Publicis for 17 years and was deputy chairman of the UK agency before moving over to Publicis Worldwide.

Ms Thompson and Mr O'Donoghue will attend their first council meeting in June.

fields.headline: Rape lifts Corrie ratings
fields.trailText: 12.30pm TV overnights: The brutal rape of Toyah Battersby lifted Coronation street ratings by more than 1m, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The brutal rape of teenager Toyah Battersby has helped boost Coronation street ratings by more than 1m.

The hard-hitting storyline is being built up as the ITV soap's answer to EastEnders's recent whodunnit, "Who Shot Phil Mitchell?", with the net of suspicion being cast wide and far.

Some 14.4m viewers - a 59% share - tuned in on Sunday to see the aftermath of the rape ordeal and a parallel storyline about long-suffering Sally Webster's frustrated quest for romantic bliss.

Like many Coronation Street brides before her, she was jilted at the altar.

Overall audience levels for the soap were 1.1m more than the previous Sunday.

On Friday night, when the rape took place in an extended 45-minute episode, Coronation Street was 0.2m down on the same night the week before, at 11.4m and a 49% share.

On Monday, in another 45-minute special, Coronation Street was 0.4m up, week on week, with 14m and a 56% share.

EastEnders was pushed later, to 8.15pm, to avoid the extended Coronation Street on Monday night.

It had 11.9m and a 45% share.

webTitle: Mallorca chomp towards the Champions League

fields.headline: Mallorca chomp towards the Champions League
fields.standfirst: The story of one man and his dentures: it's Sid Lowe's Spanish round up, this week with added puns
fields.trailText: The story of one man and his dentures: it's Sid Lowe's Spanish round up, this week with added puns.
fields.body:
There really is only one Luis Aragonés. The Mallorca manager - who's kept us entertained all season with punch-ups, "gestures" and the best press conferences in the world ever!! - has done it yet again.

As usual, the stage was the San Moix. It was Sunday night against Las Palmas. Mallorca were 1-0 up, but Josico had just wasted an excellent chance to equalise. Canal Plus trained its camera on the veteran boss who was, just for a change, doing his nut.

Blink and you'd miss it - hooray for videos - but there it was. As another profanity slipped from Aragonés's mouth, so did his teeth. Well, his dentures - the whole top row. Unfortunately, he belied his age and reacted swiftly to clamp his jaw shut before the offending item managed to fall clean away. Checking no-one was watching, he quickly and surreptitiously chewed his teeth back into place.

Desperately waiting for the break and the chance for a discreet application of Fixadent, Aragonés went rather quiet for a while. Luckily, Guayre's equaliser came right on the stroke of half-time, so the Wise (Mad) Man of Hortaleza could rush to the dressing room and rant away happily, safe from the prying eyes of the TV cameras. Fear not, for Aragonés was back to his mentalist best in the second half, barking out orders as his side struggled to get the better of Las Palmas, until Carlos grabbed a late - and slightly fortunate - winner.

There was real cause to celebrate too, and not just because the glue seemed to have done the trick - Mallorca's victory lifted them into fourth place and Champions League qualification after Barcelona drew 4-4 for the second week running, this time against Zaragoza in the Nou Camp.

3-1 and 4-2 down, Serra Ferrer's side again had to rely on an injury-time equaliser - Rivaldo becoming the league's top scorer with his nineteenth of the season.

It's been a traumatic week for the Catalan giants. A number of big names - like 10-letter Rochenback (sorry) - have been linked to the club, but there are signs that some even bigger names could be leaving.

Club offcial Josep María Orobit revealed that Barça would this week negotiate the transfer of Rivaldo to "an important English club" (hmm, wonder who that could be?), while Kluivert - not on the best of terms with Serra Ferrer - might, uh-oh, be on his way to the Bernabéu, and Gerard has attracted attention from Milan.

But the biggest shock, of course, has been the announcement that Pep Guardiola will leave in the summer to play out the rest of his career abroad. Guardiola, as he put it himself, came without a hair on his chest but leaves as a father. The last survivor of Johan Cruyff's Dream Team, captain at the Nou Camp and a champion of Catalanisme - a driving force behind Catalan literacy crusades and their national side - Pep will be sorely missed in Barcelona.

As if things Catalan weren't bad enough, Real Madrid took another step towards the title this weekend, with a 4-0 win over Villarreal on Saturday night. Guti was the man of the moment, with a performance he described as "the best of my whole life".

A few weeks ago, Steve McManaman's sensational volley against Oviedo was voted Goal of the Season in a poll on the Marca website (look, I had nothing to do with it, OK?). Much as it hurts to say, Macca might not be there for much longer: Guti hit a sensational volley from 25 yards for his first, and completed a hat-trick with two tap-ins, superbly set up by McManaman and Savio. Roberto Carlos got the other with a great free-kick.

It could have been even better for the Man in the Moustache's side, after Deportivo needed a late winner to finally see off relegation-threatened Osasuna 2-1 at the Riazor.

Javier Irureta's side remain eight points behind Madrid, and now turn their attention to Leeds. Midfielder Emerson, the man who single-handedly rescued Soul Glow during his Middlesborough days, reckons Depor can turn things around: "Scoring four goals is easier than you think", he warned earlier in the week. Emerson was talking about Leeds, but - in view of Barça's last two performances - he might be better telling that to Gerard Houllier.

That defeat against Depor leaves Osasuna second bottom, level on points with Numancia and two below Racing Santander and Real Sociedad.

On Sunday, Numancia came from 3-1 down against John Benjamin's side to secure a 3-3 draw, and could even have ended up with a win but for the intervention - three times - of the post. That might have been a bit harsh on la Real - at 3-1 up, De Paula missed a one-on-one that would surely have secured all three points.

Numancia's battling qualities certainly aren't unique - down at the bottom, no-one's giving up. Real Sociedad have improved since Toshack's arrival, and Racing Santander are also pulling out all the stops - they stunned the league's form side, Celta de Vigo 3-0 on Sunday, with Espina, Mazzoni and Regueiro the men on target.

The relegation three-from-four of a couple of weeks back might now be three-from-five (or possibly even three-from-eight).

Oviedo are only two points clear of Real Sociedad and Racing, after losing 1-0 to Valladolid, whose keeper Bizzarri (the man that finally saw John Benjamin get his marching orders at the Bernabéu) was on inspired form. That put Valladolid three points clear of Radi Antic's side - not safe, but breathing a little easier.

Level on points with Valladolid, and nervously looking down, are Las Palmas and Athletic Bilbao, who lost 1-0 at home to yet another Raúl Tamudo goal for Espanyol. Either side of them are Málaga and Rayo Vallecano - they drew 1-1 on Sunday.

Now, there are those games that lend themselves to match reports with more puns than a dyslexic bakery. And Saturday night's clash between Valencia and Alavés was one of them. Never mind that Alavés's boss, Mané, might be Vicente Del Bosque's twin brother, or that having brilliantly guided his side to the Uefa Cup semi (and probably the final) he'll almost certainly be at the helm at Valencia next year. Or even that Alavés won 2-1.

Never mind all that - what really mattered on Easter weekend was that it was Dan EGGen who scored the winner. And there's more. If this column was really sad, which of course it isn't, it'd report that Eggen ROSE (AGAIN) to head home a CROSS and secure all three PONTIUS for his side. No need to worry, though - this column would never, ever be quite that sad.

fields.standfirst: In opposition, New Labour argued that the social fund, which offers interest-free loans to help those living in poverty, was unfair and should be replaced with grants. But now the system looks set to stay. Bob Holman says the government should think again
fields.trailText: In opposition. New Labour argued that the social fund, which offers interest-free loans to help those living in poverty, was unfair and should be replaced with grants. But now the system looks set to stay. Bob Holman says the government should think again.
fields.body:
The House of Commons social security committee recently published its report on the social fund. Unfortunately, it has copped out of a recommendation that could improve the lives of poor people.

To be fair, the committee is to be congratulated on producing its report so quickly. It started receiving evidence in February 2001 and the report was published on April 4. That's lightning by parliamentary standards.

But it is to be condemned for not following the logic of its own analysis, which implied that social fund loans should be replaced by grants. It wimped out.

Prior to 1988, claimants depending upon welfare benefits long term were entitled to grants for essential domestic items such as fires and cookers. In a cost-cutting exercise, the then Conservative government devised the social fund. The fund retained some grants, called community care grants, for people leaving institutions or to prevent them having to enter institutions.

Other grants, however, were replaced by loans. Budgeting loans were for "irregular needs" - such as when a family's cooker blows up - while crisis loans were for emergencies. The loans were repaid by automatic deductions from weekly incomes. They were interest free and could take up to a quarter of the debtor's weekly income.

In opposition, the Labour party vehemently condemned the changes. But once in power it retained them. It is to the social security committee's credit that it decided to investigate the workings of the social fund, and its report provides a thorough and critical analysis.

The report points out that despite constant demand, the number of community care grants has dropped from 294,000 in 1993-94 to 219,000 in 1999-2000. Four in 10 applications for budgeting loans and nearly three in 10 (27%) for crisis loans were rejected. The applicants might well be eligible and in desperate need but under the social fund system each district has a fixed and inadequate budget. So when that budget runs out, no more is available.

Extraordinarily, some applicants for loans have been refused because they were considered too poor to make repayments. In other words, the very poorest were denied help. Those receiving loans could purchase one essential item but, the committee found, the weekly repayments left them in absolute poverty.

Both those refused loans and those repaying them then often turned to commercial lenders who charge interest rates of up to 150%.

The committee summed up: "The present social fund system is working against the government's key aim of reducing child poverty [It] is adding to the poverty and social exclusion of families with children by, in many cases, denying them access to basic necessities and increasing their indebtedness. This is unacceptable."

The report contains 218 pages of evidence from witnesses, nearly all of whom call for loans to be abolished and grants put in their place. The exception was Angela Eagle, a minister from the Department of Social Security. In words which Mrs Thatcher would no doubt applaud, she opposed grants because they were "wide open to abuse and led to expenditure spiralling out of control".

So given the evidence and the trend of the committee's analysis, it was to be expected that it would recommend the abolition of loans. Indeed, after a lone mother told them: "They must give you grants for they are essential," the committee added: "We agree."

However, despite making useful proposals to increase district budgets, to introduce an impartial review system for complaints, and to humanise the administration, it does not call for loans to go and grants to return

It lamely ends: "The level of repayments and the repayment period should be much more flexible in order to minimise the hardship which claimants experience." In short, the core of the present system should continue.

What explains this cop out? It can't be cost. In his evidence to the committee, Professor Gary Craig estimated that a scheme based primarily on grants would cost about £800m - the government throws that amount at farmers without a thought.

The committee states that the government is unlikely to accept a wholesale change to grants and implies that such a radical recommendation, therefore, is not worthwhile. Perhaps the predominant Labour membership of the committee did not want to put pressure on New Labour before the next general election. Whatever the explanation, the committee has failed the poor.

Last week a lone mother told me how her daughter had spilt a drink on, and ruined, her only fire. She has already had an application to the social fund refused. Does the committee advise her to get money from a loan shark or just to stay cold?

As a voluntary neighbourhood worker in the Easterhouse estate, Glasgow, I have seen 50 families in financial distress over the last two years. So what is my way forward? I propose that every long-term claimant be given a £500 annual bonus.

It would be up to them to decide whether to use it to buy furniture, Christmas presents or a holiday. The community care grants would have to remain, as often the costs of people taking up residence in the neighbourhood after years in an institution are more than £500.

But the loans would be abolished and, with them, their expensive administration. People on low incomes would have £500 as an entitlement and so be spared the humiliating experience of trying to convince officials that they need a loan.

But even this would not deal with poverty. It is significant that the select committee wants the government to "fund research into the levels of income needed to avoid poverty". The committee acknowledges that the social fund exists because people just do not have enough money.

Until New Labour is prepared to say just how much weekly income is required for a decent lifestyle and to ensure that all citizens have that level, then poverty will continue.

 Bob Holman is the author of the pamphlet, George Lansbury: Labour's Neglected Leader, Christian Socialist Movement.

fields.headline: Pulitzer goes to Michael Chabon
fields.trailText: The 2001 Pulitzer Prize for fiction has been awarded to Michael Chabon for The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay, his epic tragi-comic tale of two boy geniuses who start a comic strip business just as the second world war is beginning.
fields.body:
The 2001 Pulitzer Prize for fiction has been awarded to Michael Chabon for The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay, his epic tragi-comic tale of two boy geniuses who start a comic strip business just as the second world war is beginning.

The highly acclaimed American writer, whose novels The Mysteries of Pittsburgh and Wonder Boys (which was recently adapted into a film with Michael Douglas) have seen him compared to Vladimir Nabokov, Philip Roth and Don DeLillo, won America's top literary award yesterday and prize money worth $7,500.

Runners-up in the fiction category were Joyce Carol Oates for her fictional biography of Marilyn Monroe, Blonde, and Joy Williams for The Quick and the Dead, her surreal tale of the friendship between three motherless girls set in the heart of the Arizona desert.

The Pulitzer Prize for biography went to David Levering Lewis for the second volume of his biography of civil rights leader WEB Du Bois and made Pulitzer history by being the first biographer to win the award for his second volume on the same subject.

The history prize went to Joseph J Ellis for his book on the founding fathers of America, Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation.

New Jersey based Stephen Dunn won the poetry prize for his 11th collection, Different Hours and Herbert P Bix won the general non-fiction prize for his biography of the Japanese Emperor Hirohito.

The winners will receive their prizes at a ceremony at the University of Columbia next month.

 For a full list of winners and runners up, go to the Pulitzer Prize website
