fields.headline: Foot and mouth hits the web
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Almost half a million Britons logged on to the Ministry of Agriculture website last month, writes Amy Vickers.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
Maff.gov.uk
fields.body:
The foot and mouth crisis has hit the internet. Almost half a million Britons logged on to the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries website last month.

According to the latest internet charts for home usage, this demonstrates how the internet is starting to be relied upon as an information resource in times of crisis.

The Maff website, Maff.gov.uk, appears for the first time in Jupiter MMXI's monthly report, entering the ratings as number one in the government site category.

In all, some 3.3% of the home internet population visited the site last month for information on the disease, against some 24.8%, or 3.4m, of the home population who used government websites.

Other popular government websites include Open.gov.uk, Royalmail.com and Dfee.gov.uk.

Other developments during March show how the British are now increasingly using the web for different needs.

The Comic Relief site, comicrelief.com, pulled in 511,000 visitors, and for the first time ever, a football club's website entered the ratings.

Liverpoolfc.net jumped up to fourth position in the sports category charts, with 155,000 visitors.

"The internet distinguishes itself this month by providing a service in a state of emergency such as the foot and mouth disease, giving detail on the latest outbreaks for the farming industry and the British public," said Daniela Weiss, the UK managing director of Jupiter MMX.

Overall, Jupiter MMXI says there was a 2% rise in the European online population in March, taking it up to 52.4m home users.

The largest market is still the UK with 13.68m users, closely followed by Germany (12.56m) and France (7.89m).

Related stories
Special report: foot and mouth in the media

Useful link

fields.headline: Family politics in Germany
fields.standfirst: The 2002 general election looks set to be fought over families, fertility rates and immigration, writes John Hooper
fields.trailText: The 2002 general election looks set to be fought over families, fertility rates and immigration, writes John Hooper.
fields.body:
The family is beginning to shape up as a key issue in German politics, and perhaps even the one that will dominate next year's general election campaign.

Earlier this month, the constitutional court in Karlsruhe handed down a judgment with far-reaching implications for the men and women who run the country.

In Germany, taxpayers have to make a contribution to a state-run scheme to provide nursing care for them in their old age. The judges decided that the way the contributions were made was unfair because parents had to put in the same amount as those without children.

The assumption underlying their ruling was that parents could expect to be looked after by their children and would thus not become as much of a burden on the scheme as their childless counterparts. That is a pretty debatable contention in the year 2001.

But while the constitutional court's judgment has indeed sparked debate, it has not been about whether children can realistically be expected to care for their parents. Nor has it been about the further obvious question of whether a system of differentiated contributions would not discriminate unjustifiably against those who wanted, but were unable, to have children.

The debate has instead been almost exclusively about the judgment's ramifications.

The judges gave the government until the end of 2004 to change the way in which payments to the compulsory nursing care scheme were charged. But they added that, in the meantime, it had also to look at the entire field of welfare provision to ensure that contributions were levied and benefits allocated in a family-friendly fashion.

The debate has so far been all about whether Germany's welfare system is indeed family friendly and whether it has been made more or less so by the policies of Gerhard Schröder's centre-left coalition.

In particular, the Christian Democrat opposition has criticised a pension reform bill that is currently before parliament for being insufficiently attuned to the needs of the family.

Family-friendliness as a concept has scarcely been questioned - it has been accepted pretty much overnight as axiomatically virtuous. Which is what makes the debate so appealing to Germany's conservative opposition as it picks over the issues on which to fight the 2002 general election. The Christian Democrats may not relish a scrap with the chancellor over, say, structural reform of the economy, where he has even won plaudits from the business community.

However, when it comes to the family they may justifiably feel that they are in with a sporting chance -- and none more so than Edmund Stoiber.

A Roman Catholic and leader of the Christian Social Union (CSU), the Bavarian branch of the Christian Democratic movement, Mr Stoiber looks more and more like the man who will lead that movement into the next general election as its candidate for the chancellorship.

He is also the man who can take credit for first raising the issue of the family, several months before the constitutional court handed down its ruling.

That brings us to the nub of the whole issue. Very few people in Germany are saying so out loud, but the family debate is not really about families at all. It is about immigration.

Since the middle of last year, Mr Schröder and his ministers have been trying to get Germans to face up to what they see as the unavoidable implications of the country's demographic structure.

With the fertility rate - the number of children per woman of child-bearing age - now down to around 1.3, Germany, in common with many other European nations, faces a choice if it is to sustain its generous system of welfare provision.

It can either promote massive immigration or, as Edmund Stoiber first suggested last year, it can boost its birth rate. This is an exceptionally delicate proposal given Germany's past. It invites the accusation that Germans are inherently xenophobic and stirs echoes of the Nazi policy of encouraging women to breed for the Fatherland. But what the Christian Democrats have in mind is something much less ideological: a package of measures that they could, indeed, represent as thoroughly contemporary.

Mr Stoiber himself has proposed a huge increase in child benefits. And tacitly acknowledging that German women can never again be induced to limit their lives to the home, some of his colleagues have argued that the key to a higher birth rate lies in making it easier for women to hold down a job while raising a family.

Peter Müller, the head of the regional government of Saarland, has suggested, for example, that urgent consideration be given to improving childcare and extending the school day which, in most German schools, ends at lunchtime.

This is music to the ears of many German women who might not otherwise consider voting for the right. But whether it can really succeed in tackling what Christian Democrats like Mr Stoiber see as the root problem is quite another matter.

The constitutional court's own landmark judgment put it starkly. It noted that, if Germany were to keep its current age distribution, its women would in future need to bear an average of 3.8 children.

fields.headline: Marketeers left behind on interactive TV
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Marketeers lack the knowledge and skills to develop effective strategies for interactive TV, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Marketeers are falling behind on interactive TV because they lack the knowledge and skills to develop effective strategies using the technology, according to a new report.

As the internet loses its gloss, pundits are predicting the next big development will be interactive TV.

However, a report out today claims there is a distinct lack of clarity among marketeers about how iTV fits into future campaigns.

Of 300 marketeers canvassed by researchers at BMPtvi, an overwhelming 85% said they didn't know what implications iTV had for marketing.

Confusion reigns over cost, consumer penetration, lack of results and effectiveness, with 60% of those questioned unable to comment on the costs of iTV.

Additionally, 71% of participants believed there was a low level of consumer awareness of iTV, despite a 30% household penetration of the medium. This is projected to rise to 40% by the end of this year.

Andrew Howells, the managing director of iTV advertising agency BMPtvi, called for more clarity.

"It's important that the iTV platforms provide more information about their interactive services," he said.

"Marketers need more detail on viewers interacting as well as specific case study results. Case studies will only become publicly available if platforms encourage advertisers to participate on the premise that results are then shared."

At present just 9% of companies use iTV as part of their marketing mix, compared with 78% who now use internet promotions as a matter of course.

The report, "A Media In Waiting", was conducted by BMPtvi and backed by the Chartered Institute of Marketing, the Institute of Direct Marketing, ISBA, NMK and the Phoenix Network.

webTitle: Spielberg quits Scouts in discrimination row

fields.headline: Spielberg quits Scouts in discrimination row
fields.trailText: Oscar-wining movie maestro Steven Spielberg has stepped down from the Boy Scout movement's advisory board, in protest (it is believed) at their discrimination against homosexuality
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg has left the Boy Scouts. The Oscar-wining movie maestro has stepped down from the Scout movement's advisory board, in protest (it is believed) at their discrimination against homosexuality. Although Spielberg didn't cite the specific discriminatory policy to which he objected, he is thought to believe that the organisation's exclusion of "avowed homosexuals" contravenes the core values of the scouting movement.

"The last few years in scouting have deeply saddened me," said the Schindler's List director. "To see the Boy Scouts of America actively and publicly participating in discrimination - it's a real shame. I thought the Boy Scouts stood for equal opportunity and I have consistently spoken out publicly and privately against intolerance and discrimination based on ethnic, religious, racial and sexual orientation."

Last year, a US Supreme Court ruling allowed the Boy Scouts to retain its controversial entry policy. Joey Robinson, a spokesman for the LA Scouts, where Spielberg has been a member of the board, defended the snub to homosexuals. "It's not discrimination, its the right to set membership standards. Every group has its standards: The Girl Scouts have a rule that you have to be a girl," he added, in an unfortunate comparison.

Praising Spielberg's contribution to the Scouts - he devised a cinematography merit prize and contributed funds - Robinson also excused his principled departure. "This is America. Everybody has a right to voice their opinion and we respect his right," he said. Concluded Spielberg: "Once scouting opens its doors to all who desire the same experience that so fully enriched me as a young person, I will be happy to reconsider a role on the advisory board."

fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gives us The Camel, and The Camel gives us advice
fields.trailText:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £158.04

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes) = £50.01

The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £33.46

fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £158.04

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes) = £50.01

The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £33.46

Sean Ingle = £27.32

Scott Murray: Manchester United v Coventry: number of goals scored 0 or 1 £5 @ 4/1
Bet lost

Mr Murray is fast approaching "shrewdie" status in the Blue Square office. As I have preached before, the key to becoming a winning punter is finding value bets at attractive prices. To do this you often have to shy away from the obvious choices that fill many a weekend football coupon and find something more obscure.

Again, Mr Murray found a bet that represented value. Manchester United, with the title locked away weeks ago, looked like a team with priorities that didn't include this fixture with a desperate Coventry. Anyway, United were going through a veritable goal drought (by their standards) of two goals in their last three games. Coventry, John Hartson excepted, are hardly a goal-scoring machine, and could be expected to provide a stern defence for a possibly distracted United strikeforce. When relegation-haunted clubs visit the better teams late in the season, they often pack the defence and look to eke out a goalless draw and regularly perform better statistically than a similar match earlier in the season.

OK, this bet lost. But I think there was a far greater chance of a 0 or 1 goal outcome than the 20% the price Mr Murray took suggested. I am already looking forward to his next selection, as I am confident he will find another big-priced gem for the value seeker to savour.

The Prince: West Ham v Derby: Freddie Kanoute to outscore Malcolm Christie £5 @ 11/4
Bet lost

Goalscorer match bets are a relatively new addition to the vast array of bets Blue Square offer on every Premiership match. My first reaction when I saw the bet was that in general the tie between the two players at odds of around 4/7 was possibly value.

As it happens, Christie didn't start this game, so the selection was void. But he's certainly looked an out-of-form striker in recent weeks (hence his demotion to the bench I presume) and certainly couldn't be contemplated at 9/2. But was Kanoute value at 11/4? I doubt it. West Ham have been so woefully out of touch in recent weeks, scoring just two goals in their last five league outings, that backing any of their players to score is a hazardous occupation. The tie at 8/15 would have been my confident selection here. Just because a selection is short priced, it doesn't mean it's not value. I think there was a far greater than 65% chance that neither player scored, and I was getting the highly unlikely scenario that both players got 1 or 2 goals each thrown in for free. Kanoute scored, so you were unlucky not to collect here, but I still think it was a bad bet.

Nobby Dogger of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: West Ham v Derby, draw - £5 @ 9/4
Bet lost

Two teams in danger of being drawn into the relegation mire met at Upton Park, and a tense encounter was easily forecast, with both teams more interested in not making a costly mistake than offering anything constructive going forward.

As I have outlined above, West Ham have been particularly goal-shy in recent weeks, and Derby are no better. A draw was a fair shout at 9/4, but I was tempted by the no goalscorer option at 8/1 too. Two out-of-form, relegation haunted teams with no confidence in front of goal could easily have seen a goalless draw.

We lost, but I think we had value, and as I have suggested several times before, that is the road to long-term punting success.

Sean Ingle: Leicester v Manchester City: Man City to win £5 @ 10/3
Bet won

I must admit, I was mighty surprised when I saw Mr Ingle's bet for this week. I have become accustomed to the sense of dread when I scroll down to see his selection as I have - week-in, week-out - seen a weird concoction of bad-value trebles, first goalscorer and correct score bets.

But, quick as I've been to condemn Mr Ingle, I must take my proverbial hat off to him this week. Oppose bad value favourites, that is punting mantra, and find good value singles. Since I have been writing this column, Sean has ignored this advice. Until this week.

Leicester were the archetypal bad favourites, terribly out of form since being bundled out of the FA Cup by Wycombe last month. In fact they were pointless in four league matches since that outing. OK, Manchester City are pretty dreadful themselves, but the desperate relegation plight they are in often leads to improved displays at the end of the season. With nothing to play for, Leicester were crying out to be opposed by backing Man. City at 10/3. In fact how anyone could contemplate Leicester at 8/11 defies belief.

I am now going to the pub to celebrate. I'll even buy the renowned value scout Mr Ingle a pint.

webTitle: Steve Buscemi stabbed in neck during bar brawl

fields.headline: Steve Buscemi stabbed in neck during bar brawl
fields.trailText: Actors Steve Buscemi and Vince Vaughn and screenwriter Scott Rosenberg were involved in a bar brawl last Thursday that resulted in four arrests and nearly killed Fargo star Buscemi
fields.body:
Actors Steve Buscemi and Vince Vaughn and screenwriter Scott Rosenberg were involved in a bar brawl last Thursday that resulted in four arrests and nearly killed Fargo star Buscemi. The Hollywood trio are currently filming the aptly named Domestic Disturbance in Wilmington, North Carolina. Two local men allegedly picked a fight with the filmmakers when one of their girlfriends began talking to Swingers star Vaughn.

A scuffle outside the bar is reported to have taken place at 2am. Police on patrol broke up the fracas, but not before Buscemi had been stabbed above the eye and in the jaw, throat, and arm. He was taken to hospital. Vaughn was maced, according to reports. Timothy Fogerty, 21, was arrested and charged with assault with a deadly weapon for the Buscemi knifing. Another local man, 20-year-old Kenneth Purgason, was also arrested.

According to local police, the brawlers had "refused to disperse, so they all got pepper spray. In all, there were about ten involved when we got there, but the four kept fighting. Normally, we don't have any problems there". Buscemi has since returned to New York to recuperate and is consulting plastic surgeons for his wounds. "The situation could have been life-threatening," a source told America's Entertainment Weekly.

fields.headline: Concern over 'slave ship' grows
fields.trailText: Confusion is growing over the fate of up to 250 child slaves after officials in the west African nation of Benin initially found only seven children on board the ship that they had suspected was carrying them.
fields.body:
Confusion is growing over the fate of up to 250 child slaves after officials in the west African nation of Benin initially found only seven children on board the ship that they had suspected was carrying them.

The Nigerian-registered ship, MV Etireno, docked in Benin's capital, Cotonou, early this morning, and port authorities found it to be carrying mostly adults. Officials are continuing to search the ship for the missing children.

The failure to find the children on board has fuelled fears that the children may have been offloaded at a remote port in Nigeria or even thrown overboard to allow the ship's crew to escape prosecution.

The Etireno has been at sea since March 30, when it set sail from Cotonou headed for Gabon, where it was refused permission to dock. It is believed that the ship's crew intended to deliver the children into slavery in Gabon. Officials from Benin and the UN said that port authorities in both Gabon and Cameroon had reported turning away a ship with anything from 100-250 child slaves aboard.

UN officials in Cotonou earlier speculated that the Etireno's captain, a Nigerian man with a criminal past, could have thrown his human cargo overboard. After the ship's arrival, the same officials said that the truth would probably not be known until the government finished an investigation, including interviews with the passengers on board.

However, a government minister in Benin said that there has been a mix-up, and another unidentified vessel is the slave ship. The social protection minister, Ramatou Baba Moussa, said the Etireno, which UN and local officials originally thought had left Benin with the children, may have been confused with a second ship, whose name and current location remain a mystery.

She said that it was not known whether or not any unaccompanied children were on board the Etireno.

"I don't know what to think," said Nicolas Pron, a senior official with the UN children's fund in Benin. "My main concern is that the kids are here and safe, and we will hear if that is the case."

The Etireno, a white, 200-foot-long ferry, pulled into Cotonou port shortly after 1am local time (12am GMT), as Cabinet ministers, police, soldiers, journalists and UN employees crowded the dockside.

Dozens of women, a few men and a handful of children could be seen through the ship's passenger cabin windows, from which laundry was hanging inside, as the boat's Nigerian crew barked orders in English.

Journalists who boarded the ship found nervous and exhausted passengers who said that no child slaves had been on the ship. Some appeared frightened.

The vessel's 40-year-old Nigerian captain, Lawrence Onome, echoed their denials.

"I have not committed any offense that will warrant my arrest," Mr Onome said. "I am not into child slavery, they can't prove it. It is one thing to say and one thing to prove."

fields.headline: One for the hairdressers
fields.standfirst: Sports car purists won't like the new Peugeot Cabriolet's effortless automatic roof - it won't give them anywhere near enough trouble
fields.trailText: Sports car purists won't like the new Peugeot Cabriolet's effortless automatic roof - it won't give them anywhere near enough trouble
fields.body:
As the sun begins to show and as 10-minute periods without rain come to seem not only possible but almost likely, the minds of drivers turn naturally to vehicles without roofs. In which little topless sporty number will you be testing the durability of your hairstyle this season?

Personally, I'd happily settle for wearing a Peugeot 206 Coupe Cabriolet, which is relatively fresh off the catwalks and guaranteed to generate an admiring buzz as beach- or party-wear, but which also won't let you down on the more formal occasions.

Admirably unfussy to look at, it's cute enough and sleek enough to make the MGF (a close rival for price) look like a big lump of partly compressed metal with silly holes in the side. That said, it's probably not as pretty as the Mazda MX5, which may also compete for your attention at this time of the year. And it's definitely not as pretty as the Fiat Barchetta - but that only comes in left-hand drive, which can make acceleration past farm vehicles on windy roads more than necessarily stressful. Yet what it holds over all its rivals is potentially the key advantage - namely, an automatically retracting roof.

Previously modelled by the Mercedes SLK (which is twice the price of the Peugeot), the automatically retracting roof is the device that definitively moves open-topped motoring from the realm of the specialist to the place where the hopelessly impractical and the terminally lazy can enjoy it to the full, too.

For too long, al fresco driving was achieved only at the cost of intimidating activity involving rolls of canvas and recalcitrant poppers, or strange grapplings with perspex bubbles and monkey wrenches.

By some way the longest 15 minutes of my life were spent in an entirely unforeseeable Old Testament downpour just south of Croydon, jacketless and trying to snap the top back onto a Caterham 7, while thick traffic slushed past, chortling and tooting in merriment. The car had filled with water to a depth of around seven inches by the time I completed the task. Driving it on to its destination, in the prone driving position which the Caterham demands, I had to kick with my legs just to remain afloat.

Here's what you do when the sun comes out and you want to take the top off your Peugeot 206. You press the button, located right where you can get to it quickly, behind the handbrake. Then you sit there, cultivating a look based on images you have seen of Timothy Dalton, while the windows come down and the boot opens and the roof rises gently above you before setting off for the rear of the car, where it smoothly stows itself in the trunk. Then the boot closes and a quiet beep lets you know that you are clear to drive off.

And when the storm vouchsafed to Noah (but not to you) hits near Croydon? You press the button again and the whole graceful business repeats, only backwards.

Has civilisation known a greater advance than this? Even the MX5's cleverly effort-reduced roof-removal routine (a couple of clips to unfasten and a casual toss of the canopy over the shoulders) cannot hold a candle to doing nothing whatsoever.

Of course, this ease of access to the air won't meet with universal approval. The drivers of sports cars these days can be generally distributed along a scale with, at one end, spanner-wielding engine enthusiasts with oil on their hands, and, at the other end, hairdressers. It's my hunch that the 206 CC will be appealing to those nearer the hairdresser end of the scale.

It offers much to disappoint the purist, after all. It's a front-wheel drive, for one thing. The engine is under the bonnet, rather than behind the driver and close enough to warm his ears, which is where the purist might prefer it. It thrums rather than roars. And, despite the willing shown in a couple of the stylings (the bare metal gear-knob and interior door handles) driving the Peugeot is nothing like sitting inside an aluminium flight case which, again, is the way the hardcore tend to like it.

What we are dealing with here is, in essence, the high quality, well- upholstered 206 hatchback with most of the sensible aspects (the space for shopping and passengers, but not the airbags and the CD player) removed. The seats might be nearer the ground, but this is still not a car for people who like to read the road with their buttocks. It is, however, enormous fun to sling around the place and could even be argued to offer family entertainment.

The two rear seats, hollowed out of virtually nothing, are so laughably unrealistic that Peugeot even offer, as an extra, an aluminium wind deflector that you can bury the back seats under, thus increasing the car's aerodynamic performance with the roof down. However, you can get some value out of the rear cabin area by wedging small children into it. They don't complain and, in any case, they can't move. Also, small children seem to think open-top motoring is, of itself, the most miraculous invention since ice cream. They may be right.

fields.headline: IPC launches new women's title as Woman's Realm is axed
fields.trailText: 11.15am: IPC is closing Woman's Realm as it unveils a new women's weekly to launch next week, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
IPC is killing off Woman's Realm after 46 years as it announces the launch of a new women's weekly magazine for upmarket, 35-plus women.

Unveiling its new magazine, Your Life, which debuts next week, IPC confirmed that the women's market veteran will close.

Your Life will be priced £1.20 and will have a print run of 700,000.

Woman's Realm was still a profitable title, according to Linda Lancaster Gaye, managing director of IPC Connect, the division that houses its women's titles.

She said IPC would focus its energies on "the emerging market sector of the decade", older, wealthier woman.

Publishing director Sandy Gale said that by 2005 eight out of 10 British women will be over 35, which meant that concepts of age were being redefined.

Asked if the move spelled the beginning of the end for the traditional women's weekly, Ms Gale said the sector still had a loyal following and continued to attract new readers.

Mary Frances, editor of Your Life and former editor of Woman's Realm, said Your Life would have the "quality and intelligence of a monthly".

The announcement follows last week's launch of fortnightly glossy Real from H Bauer.

fields.trailText: The British nuclear submarine HMS Tireless has been repaired and should leave Gibraltar early next month, a year after limping into dock with a leak in its reactor, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday.
fields.body:
The British nuclear submarine HMS Tireless has been repaired and should leave Gibraltar early next month, a year after limping into dock with a leak in its reactor, the Ministry of Defence said yesterday.

Tireless' departure will bring to an end a long-running source of contention between London and Madrid, which has raised concerns over the safety of the repair work just miles from its territory.

The discovery of the leak in the coolant system which ensures the reactor operates at a safe temperature led to a multi-million pound overhaul of all 12 of the Royal Navy's hunter-killer subs.

Hydrostatic pressure tests were carried out yesterday on the coolant system to check that the repair had worked.

An MoD spokeswoman said: "The test is complete and was successful.There is no firm date for her to leave Gibraltar, but it is planned for early May."

Tireless' presence in Gibraltar since last May has been hotly opposed by Spaniards living near Britain's Mediterranean enclave, who feared the environmental consequences if the repairs went wrong. Local people demanded that the sub be towed to Britain to be patched up.

Protests overshadowed a visit by Tony Blair to meet his Spanish counterpart, Jose Maria Aznar, last October.
Press Association

fields.headline: Tuesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours are "strident, stiff and starchy", a bit like Anne Robinson on US TV
fields.trailText: "My death waits like an old roué / So confident I'll go his way / Whistle to him and the passing rumour"
fields.body:
Manchester United are planning to swap David Beckham for Rivaldo, reports just about everyone. We know this because Riv's team-mate Pep Guardiola's agent (keeping up?) said on Spanish telly: "Do you think Rivaldo is staying at Barcelona? I'm saying that because next Thursday there will be a meeting at which a very important English club is going to propose the signing of Rivaldo to representatives of Barcelona." But there's a stumbling block: the Brazilian will cost at least £22m and £100,000 a week. Oh, and Rivaldo himself says he wants to stay with Barca. "I know nothing about meetings between clubs and I don't want to know anything about them," he said. "If it is down to me I will honour my contract but it all depends on the fans, the president and directors."

Manchester United have joined Leeds in the chase for Newcastle's Kieron Dyer. But they'll have to beat David O'Leary's bid of £11m, which Bobby Robson feels is derisory.

Espanyol's Romanian midfielder, Constantin Galca, is being tracked by Rangers and Tottenham. And according to Planet Football, the 29-year-old will decide on his future this week: "It is nice to know Dick Advocaat was here to watch me but I've not given him my decision. I will decide in the coming days. I have offers from Villarreal and Tottenham and I know all about the interest from Rangers."

Rangers are also interested in Iranian striker Ali Daei, claims the same website. The Teddy Bears will initially try to secure Daei's services on loan in time for next season, with a view to signing the Hertha Berlin man when his contract runs out the year after.

fields.headline: New-look BBC: viewers turn off
fields.standfirst:
Senior BBC executives admit that part of their primetime problem is the lack of decent drama or entertainment hits in the can. They are now pinning their hopes on an autumn revival.
BBC1: the ratings verdict
9pm winners and losers
fields.trailText:
8.30am: BBC1 has failed to turn around its ratings decline, write Jason Deans and Lisa O'Carroll.
BBC1: the ratings verdict
9pm winners and losers
fields.body:
BBC1 has failed to turn around its ratings decline in the first six months of the new Ten O'Clock News schedule.

Its audience share has fallen beneath the pyschologically important 30% barrier.

It means significantly fewer than one in three viewers have been switching on to BBC1 in peaktime since the new-look schedule was introduced.

On occasions, the number tuning in has dropped as low as 3m.

Overall, the channel has averaged a 28.6% share in peaktime between 6pm and 10.30pm since its late news bulletin moved to 10pm.

In the same six-month period in 1999-2000, BBC1 had 30.2% of peaktime viewing.

Senior executives admit part of the BBC's problem is that it did not have the drama or entertainment hits stockpiled when the channel went head first into the ratings war with ITV.

This, at least, is what one executive admitted when asked about the poor performance on March 29, when Channel 5 achieved record ratings for its coverage of the England v Albania World Cup qualifier.

It was a crucial night for the nation's football lovers - but not for the nation.

ITV managed to hold its own by scheduling a documentary on the Sound of Music.

The BBC had a reduced audience of 3m and a 13% audience share during Celebrity Ready Steady Cook, which featured guests Greg Rusedski and Tara Palmer-Tomkinson.

BBC insiders accept the new schedule was launched without the necessary programming in place to give ITV a serious run for its money.

In tts first week, the corporation pulled out all its best programmes.

This did wonders for the ratings - the new and final series of One Foot in the Grave, the Royle Family and the Men -n Black movie premiere got the new-look BBC1 got off to a good start.

But the lack of suitable ratings-grabbers soon became apparent.

So shows such as Pete Postlethwaite's drama, the Sins, and David Attenborough's natural history documentary State of the Planet, which were never conceived as big audience pullers, were thrown into the mix and pulverised.

One of few positive signs the BBC1 controller can point to is the ratings have been boosted between 9pm and 10pm.

"This is good news," said a BBC spokeswoman.

"It indicates we have stabilised and even increased audiences in that important slot against the background of rising multichannel viewing."

Also, after a particularly grim time in January, there have been signs of a BBC1 fightback over the past couple of months.

In the six weeks to April 8, the channel has recorded a 29% peaktime audience share after slumping to just over 27% in January.

Contributing factors have included the 'who shot Phil Mitchell?' storyline in EastEnders, the foot and mouth crisis boosting news audiences and Liverpool's run in the Uefa Cup, which was covered live in Thursday night Match of the Day specials.

BBC1 has also enjoyed some success with its Monday and Tuesday night drama slots, which have been branded Crime Doubles in a dedicated marketing campaign.

The Clive Owen vehicle Second Sight was the only show to misfire badly.

Looking to the future, Lorraine Heggessey has made long-running crime dramas a priority.

No less than 14 new dramas, mostly with a crime theme, will be launched this spring and summer in an attempt to find future ratings bankers that can return next year.

BBC1 still has big problems on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday nights.

The fourth daily instalment of EastEnders - expected to get under way sometime in the spring or summer - will plug a hole on one of those evenings. Wednesdays seem to be the most needy case.

However, fixing the BBC1 schedule will take longer than six months.

"We have always said consolidating the new schedule would be a long game," the BBC spokeswoman confirmed.

fields.headline: Day 57: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 57: Troops are being used to build pyres while farmers say the government should think twice about vaccination.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Guardian
Reports on the front page that the government is preparing for foot and mouth vaccination by reassuring the public that meat from vaccinated cattle is safe to eat. The governmentÕs chief scientific adviser says limited vaccination could limit the disease in highly infectious areas.

The Daily Telegraph
On the front page, angry farmers say the government should think twice about vaccination. On page 6, experts urge the use of germ warfare equipment to test infection levels in pyres.

The Times
Reports on page 8 that troops are being used to build pyres for cattle in Northern Ireland.

The Mirror
Quotes a doctor on page 2, saying that protesters campaigning against a giant pyre in Holsworthy in Devon risk getting cancer from the dioxins contained in the smoke.

Daily Mail
On page 4, Christopher Booker slams the governmentÕs handling of the crisis as the most incompetent he has seen in 40 years. Page 5 reports that the tourist industry will lose £1.8bn due to the epidemic.

fields.headline: 'It's been a bit like the Wild West'
fields.standfirst: The Kilshaw case has exposed major flaws in the rules governing international adoptions. The couple's QC, Allan Levy, tells  Clare Dyer how the sorry saga is speeding up reform
fields.trailText: The Kilshaw case has exposed major flaws in the rules governing international adoptions. The couple's QC, Allan Levy, tells Clare Dyer how the sorry saga is speeding up reform
fields.body:
One look at the TopShop gear and the necklace spelling out "Foxy" and you somehow knew, when Judith Kilshaw arrived at the high court last week, that she was not going to be allowed to take those twins home. The babies she and husband Alan had found on the internet and paid £8,200 to adopt would be on their way back to Missouri, their home state, to face a new legal battle between their estranged biological parents over their future.

The nation watched in fascinated horror as the saga unfolded. First the tiny babies were grabbed back from their first would-be adopters in California after the Kilshaws offered more money, then they were driven across America to be adopted in Arkansas, where the residency requirements, lax though they were, were flouted by the babies' mother. Doubts grew about the couple's suitability as replacement parents.

The Kilshaws' venture into free-market baby acquisition has left them bruised by the media they courted, and tens of thousands of pounds poorer. But the tale, unedifying as it is, will leave one enduring legacy. As the twins head for their fifth short-term home in nine months of life and the battle ground over their custody shifts to a courtroom in St Louis, laws to protect future Belindas and Kimberleys are being rushed into force in Britain.

The Kilshaws' QC, Allan Levy, maintains a discreet professional silence on his controversial clients and the merits of their case. Barristers are obliged by the cab-rank rule to pick up any litigant who happens to flag them down. But Levy - a leading child law specialist whose CV includes the Cleveland abuse inquiry in the 1980s, the Pindown children's home scandal in the early 1990s and the recent case of the Siamese twins Jodie and Mary - welcomes moves to tighten the lax controls on adoption from abroad as a vital protection for vulnerable children.

"The problem has been that intercountry adoption has not been properly regulated in any way," he says. "At worst, it's been a bit like the Wild West, where anything went. Although there have been lots of successful intercountry adoptions, I've been involved in cases in the past where there were thoroughly unsatisfactory goings-on in certain central and south American countries and indeed one lawyer who specialised in adoption in a South American country was jailed.

"In certain countries where there had been civil wars, when the British embassy, perhaps at the instigation of the Official Solicitor, was investigating the source of the child, trying to track down the natural parents, they were finding addresses in war zones that were probably non-existent and certainly couldn't be reached. There was a very real likelihood that a serious racket was going on where the children were being sold or, even worse, kidnapped, or the parents were being subjected to some sort of duress or extortion."

Couples brought in children without the knowledge or approval of social services and immigration officers turned a blind eye. Once the child was settled and had bonded with the new parents, the courts came under huge pressure to approve the adop tion. Had the Kilshaws kept their heads down and avoided the media, the outcome of their case might have been quite different.

There has been only one other recent case where a child brought to the UK for adoption was sent back: last year an adoption agency in Texas got back a seven-month-old baby already removed from the prospective adopters by social services, who had deemed them unsuitable to adopt before they went to America. Had the baby been with the couple for a year, said the judge, the decision would have been much more difficult.

"By the time the procedures were gone through, often a year, 18 months, or two years had gone by and it was almost impossible for the court to move the child, so it was a fait accompli," says Levy. "The welfare of the child demanded that the adoption order be made, even though the whole process may have been very dubious."

From April 30, anyone who brings in a child from abroad without prior approval by an adoption agency and the agreement of the Department of Health will commit a criminal offence, punishable by up to three months in prison, a fine of up to £5,000, or both. The new law will spell the end of immigration officers' practice of simply waving through babies who arrive in their new parents' arms without the proper entry clearance.

The reform was planned before the internet twins hit the headlines but their story was the catalyst for rushing it into law. Ironically, though, it would probably not have stopped the Kilshaws because they had an apparently valid adoption order from the US. American adoption orders are recognised in the UK, along with those of the older Commonwealth countries and many European states. But comparatively few US children are brought into Britain for adoption; more than half now come from China, with India the next biggest source.

A further measure will be needed to make sure that all adoptions from abroad measure up to the stringent standards that apply to home adoptions. The UK is finally on course to ratify the Hague convention on intercountry adoption next year.

Under the convention, couples wanting to adopt a child will have to apply to a central authority here, who will send a report on the would- be parents' suitability to the corresponding authority in the child's country. The adoption will go ahead there only if the natural parents have consented, the central authorities in both countries agree, and the child has been cleared by the Home Office to settle in the UK.

Levy, who has appeared in many adoption cases and written a book on the subject, points out that couples have felt compelled to look abroad not just because of the shortage of young babies to adopt in this country but because social services departments have been so restrictive in their adoption policies. "One of the reasons people were driven to go abroad to countries like China, Ecuador, El Salvador and the USA is that they found social services were not approving them as adopters because they were too old at 35 or 40. Or they were thought to be too middle class or the wrong ethnic origin, or they smoked too much or were overweight. I'm amazed there hasn't been a case that has challenged social services departments on the basis that they were fettering their discretion by taking such narrow views of people who were probably admirable adopters."

The government agrees that many local councils applied too restrictive a policy in the past, allowing too many children to languish in care. The tiny number of babies given up for adoption at birth means that most of the children adopted in the UK come from care, and the government wants more of them to be found permanent homes more quickly. The adoption and children bill, now going through parliament, was originally pencilled in for the government's second term; its fast-tracking is another legacy of the internet twins drama.

"It's horrific how many placements in care some children have," says Levy. "But adoption in this country in the main means older children, and children who have had a bad start in life and who've got physical or psychological problems. The startling statistic is that one adoption in five of children in care breaks down, and for children aged nine or over the failure rate, amazingly, is 40%. So it's not a primrose path by any means. But I think the government is right to try to speed up and centralise the process because it's far too late. There also needs to be much more post-adoption support for families, and much more galvanising into action of particular councils. The disparities between the numbers of adoptions in different authorities and between the length of time different authorities take to find permanent homes for children is disturbing."

But while he welcomes most of the bill, he takes issue with one of its reforms, which he thinks may breach human rights laws. One clause replaces the current provision under which a court may override a natural parent's refusal to consent to adoption, if the parent is deemed to be "unreasonably" withholding agreement. That provision requires the court to weigh up what a reasonable parent would do in the circumstances, and provides some safeguard for the biological parent. The new clause would simply allow the court to override the parent's refusal if the child's welfare warranted it.

"I think there's a real danger of social engineering," says Levy. "It's not a sufficient safeguard to protect the natural parent. At first blush, what's wrong with the welfare of the child being paramount? But I think there's a great temptation for the court to say 'Well, I think that child would have a better future with the adoptive parents' - and that is pure social engineering - rather than having to say that there is no way this child's welfare can be properly protected by the natural parent and so the court is compelled to make an adoption order.

"I anticipate that this will be an area which will be subject to considerable discussion and opposition. I feel very uneasy about it. I think lawyers and others will make their views very firmly known to parliament - at least I hope they do."

"I anticipate that this will be an area which will be subject to considerable discussion and opposition. I feel very uneasy about it. I think lawyers and others will make their views very firmly known to parliament - at least I hope they do."

fields.headline: Look out for the Borismobile
fields.standfirst: Boris Johnson, the blond bombshell editor of The Spectator, is shortly standing down as editor of the right-wing magazine to step into the shoes of Michael Heseltine - if the voters of Henley will allow him. Matthew Tempest poses the questions
fields.trailText: Boris Johnson, the blond bombshell editor of The Spectator, is shortly standing down as editor of the right-wing magazine to step into the shoes of Michael Heseltine - if the voters of Henley will allow him. Matthew Tempest poses the questions.
fields.body:
Q: You're the Conservative prospective parliamentary candidate for Henley, Michael Heseltine's old seat. What problems could Henley possibly have?

It has the problems of affluence, the problems that affluence brings. Housing is very desirable so goes at too high a price, so young policemen and young nurses can't afford to live there.

Traffic and congestion, the one way system, all are a problem. It's a very prosperous area, but it does have pockets of deprivation, and aside from that it has the problems everyone faces: a crumbling NHS and too high a tax burden. But I'm not going to pretend it has the same amount of problems as other places.

Another thing is finding space for our old people, and stopping care homes closing.

Fortunately, Michael sensibly lives just over the constituency border, so I won't have him as a constituent!

Q: Michael Heseltine had an 11,000 majority - what does it feel like to be an MP-in-waiting?

Well, I've already bought a place in the constituency, or rather found one to rent in a little town called Swyncombe. We were thinking of getting a houseboat, but after all the flooding I thought our houseboat might end up in someone's frontroom! It's a nice place but believe me it doesn't have an arboretum!

But I'm not being presumptuous. There are other candidates, including a Green party candidate who is an old friend of mine but who I won't give the oxygen of publicity to by naming him! I went skiing with him but he's very misguided now.

I shall be on the Borismobile battlebus, which is my old Toyota Primera. I stress I'm not being presumptuous though - I haven't given any thought to a maiden speech, or select committees or anything like that.

Q: Do you think you'll have tone yourself down for life as an MP - you're rather larger than life as an editor and media pundit?

I know what you mean, and I should think I will have to, but I have absolutely no creative ideas about how I should go about it. Maybe I could swap notes with Yvette Cooper, she worked as a journalist at Canary Wharf, I used to see her around all the time, and now she's in the government. We used to get the bus to work together and have the most tremendous rows. I miss that bus.

Q: You're joining the ranks of Conservative MPs at a strange time: no hope of victory, a leadership contest and then the battle for the euro looming.

What do you mean, a leadership battle? For Blair's spot when he loses the election? You mark my words, the Tories will be back. They're a wonderful political party who try to conserve the good and prevent upheavals by doing what needs to be done. The challenge facing Tory-thinking now is how to provide public services and cut taxes. The public want better public services, but how do you provide them without pouring money down the black hole? That's the great intellectual challenge facing conservative thinkers.

On the continent they are healthier by almost any index you care to choose - heart disease, cancer survival rates - they spend more per capita on health, yet they don't have socialist state monopoly providers of health care - how is that? They cycle everywhere, yet it can't just be to do with that. As for the euro, the government have already lost that battle, and they've lost it by refusing to fight it. I don't think they can turn public opinion around.

Q: What do you think of prime minister Blair?

He sucks up to business, he talks the talk but he doesn't walk the walk. What he was very clever in doing is realising Britain is basically a conservative, right-wing country and moving his party to power on that. But he has made three major errors:
 the constitutional carve-up: Blair's devolved constitution is neither a happy nor settled solution
 Labour took more tax than they needed to thinking there was going to be a big economic downturn in 1998, and they've piled regulations onto business
 their attacks on Tory sleaze turned people off politics and they must take the blame for that.

Q: But isn't Labour's ploy of painting the Tories as right-wing extremists working, when people like John Townend can get away with racist comments and remain Tory MPs?

What Townend said was disgusting and it was bollocks. Whether he should have had the whip removed, if I was leader he would have done. Removing the whip is a symbolic gesture - what does it actually mean? - but it's a question of media management, which Labour are perhaps more successful at than we are. There are tensions and stresses in a multiracial society, people are prejudiced, and prejudice is a bad thing, but where does it get you if you start whinging about it? Nowhere. I do object to the terrible fascist tyranny of what you can talk about and what you can't, but his views were frankly stupid. We've not been and never were a homogenous anglo-saxon society, not since 1066 when the Normans invaded, so he doesn't know what he's talking about.

Q: What about the editorship of The Spectator?

Well, I'm not even going to get into that.I'm not interested in a successor and neither are you.

Q: When are you going to step down?

I don't know.

Q: June 8th [the day after expected election]?

Yes.

fields.headline: Star shines in latest ABCs
fields.trailText:
10.30am: The Daily Star has seen its circulation rise by more than 10% in the last year, reports Claire Cozens.
Useful link: ABC website
fields.body:
The Daily Star has seen its circulation rise by more than 10% in the last year, in spite of a difficult market for daily newspapers.

The paper added 54,184 readers in the year to the end of March, according to the latest ABC figures.

The Daily Express, the Star's stablemate, is also clawing back readers after dropping below 1m earlier this year.

Strenuous marketing efforts by new owner Richard Desmond led to a 2.55% rise in the paper's circulation in March, although the figure remains below 1m at 974,714.

Elsewhere, the FT's circulation has passed the half-million mark, up 5.76% from February at 503,766.

The paper's circulation has been rising steadily for the past year.

Of the Sundays, all but the Sunday Times, Sunday Mirror, Sunday People and Scotland on Sunday saw circulation rises.

Sunday Business was up 8.17% to 57,948, although the paper is still well down on this time last year. In March 2000 Sunday Business's circulation was at 70,613.

The Observer's figures rose by almost 11% year-on-year, up to 451,834 from 407,462 in March 2000.

Useful link
ABC website

webTitle: PR consultant's silent minute with Mr Blair

fields.headline: Seeking to prevent a meeting with Blair turning into a blur
fields.trailText: When public relations consultant Andy Green met Tony Blair he was so stunned to be shaking the prime minister's hand that he could not think of a word to say.
fields.body:
For many it would be a golden opportunity to pass on their views, gripes or constructive suggestions to the country's most powerful man.

But when public relations consultant Andy Green met Tony Blair he was so stunned to be shaking the prime minister's hand that he could not think of a word to say. Two awful minutes of awkward silence followed - the two simply clutching each other's hand.

So chastened was Mr Green by his experince that he has devoted himself to finding out what others would have said to the prime minister. He is collecting the thoughts in a book which he hopes to present to Mr Blair.

Mr Green, 36, from Wakefield, West Yorkshire, met the prime minister at last year's Labour conference. He said: "I got the chance to have my photo taken with him and we started to shake hands and waited for the camera to click. Then the photographer had to change the film and we were left in mid-pose.

"The pause seemed like an eternity. I thought 'Say something, anything.' Unfortunately the only thing I could think of was 'Nice speech' and then there was complete silence for nearly two minutes.

"We ended up holding hands for nearly two minutes. He acknowledged my 'Nice speech' and remained really professional in the handshaking pose but the time seemed to be an eternity."

Mr Green has been compiling the thoughts of people, including some celebrities, on what they would have said on a website.

Suggestions for topics range from the ridiculous - for example had he changed the toilet seats at No 10 so he would not be sitting on the same piece of plastic or wood as Margaret Thatcher - to the very serious, including Ireland, devolution and the plight of pensioners.

The suggestions are to be gathered in a book called A Minute With.

Anyone who wants to offer a contribution to the book should look at the website www.aminutewith.com

fields.headline: Does length matter?
fields.trailText: Does length matter?
fields.body:
If you have been struggling to read the Daily Telegraph lately, it's not because it's a frothing rightwing rag that really believes William Hague would make a good prime minister, it's because your arms are too short.

Yes, it's official. Telegraph chiefs are concerned that their paper is just too big for women to handle. Chief executive Dan Colson said: "Smaller papers are viewed as more user-friendly, especially by women whose arms aren't as long."

Ever keen to embrace women's issues at the highest level, the long-armed, pinstriped males plan to shave 4cm off the width of their paper. This, they claim, will make it more attractive to female readers.

Who has been advising them, I wonder? I live in Gloucestershire, so much the natural home of Telegraph readers that our newsagent has a special counter for it. As I timidly view the queue of horsey women in quilted Barbours and field boots, it occurs to me that any of them has arms long enough to read two Telegraphs Sellotaped together.

So what's behind all this? As every woman knows, size matters. There have been efforts in the past decade to catch female cash by designing products, other than make-up and sanitary towels, with women in mind. Adjustable car seats and lighter tools recognise that women are built differently from men. Women prefer electronic equipment that does the job without enough programmes to blast the washing into space.

This is all well and good. Difference is valuable and desirable. I suspect, though, that we are still not very far away from the masculine as standard, feminine as deviation mentality that has stamped western thought since Aristotle.

If the male is standard, a woman will more or less have to fit round him. This happens in sex, it happens with working hours and it happens with copies of the Telegraph. Board the first class of the 7.41am from Charlbury to Paddington and you will see no faces, only beautiful cufflinks notched round a wall of Telegraphs. Then you will notice that while most of these Telegraphs hardly twitch, a few are contorted into a ceaseless rustling origami.

Closer inspection reveals that the men have filled all the air space and the table in front of them. Arms outstretched like the crucified Christ, they read their broadsheets in comfort, while the unfortunate woman squashed beside them either plasters her paper against the window or hangs it over the aisle. His or her arm length is not the problem. It's his dick that gets in the way.

Women are encouraged to take up less space than men. Observe the body language in any public place and you will find that while men are expansive, women are contained. Do I mean restrained? Physical space is an extension of psychic space. If you feel like a nobody, you don't need much room.

Self-confidence should not be a gender issue. Boys are not born more confident than girls. Society makes them so because it traditionally values their skills and aptitudes above those of women. Women have responded by demanding a place in the male world of money and power, and we have seen enormous changes. What we haven't seen is a change to working hours or a significant shift in the structure of the family. Women have had to adapt to a system that suits men much better than it suits women. We are still the variant, not the standard.

Let me tell you a secret. The type of man who runs the world never worries that his arms are too short or his bottom is too big. He gets his suits made at the tailor's. At the tailor's, even a baboon is god. While women are being cut down to size by a Naomi Campbell- cloned shop assistant who assures you that this style suits everybody -strange that it makes you look like a fat dwarf - men are being measured in a mahogany fitting room, by an oozing tailor who calls them Sir. Or Madam, in my case, because that's where I learnt this secret. Wearing clothes that fit you perfectly makes you feel that the rest of the world will fit you perfectly, too.

It's quite different from feeling glamorous or beautiful. It's not about being on show. It's saying: "I'm worth it." Women who believe they are worth it will not be intimidated by the size of their paper or by the size (or not) of any other type they run into of a morning.

If the Telegraph wants to attract more women readers, it should hire more women journalists and try to sound less like a Biggles comic. Women need more media representation, but we don't need smaller newspapers. Thanks - we can hold our own.

This column appears fortnightly. www.jeanettewinterson.com

fields.headline: Where there is hypocrisy
fields.trailText: I had never heard of the book before, so I took it away on the Easter holiday. It turned out to be the most relentless and comprehensive attack on the theory and practice of the New Labour government I have ever read.
fields.body:
I had never heard of the book before, so I took it away on the Easter holiday. It turned out to be the most relentless and comprehensive attack on the theory and practice of the New Labour government I have ever read.

It mocks the government's supposed commitment to education, complaining bitterly that its "crucial requirement is not a broadly educated workforce of the many but the visionary entrepreneurship of the few: an individual combination of energy, initiative and drive for selling or trading that thrives in a kind of caricature economy more like the rag trade than the real thing". As for transport, "almost everyone except government ministers recognises there is a need for an integrated transport system, and such a system would be a more efficient use of national resources. Yet since the government abandoned the idea of co-ordinated transport planning, the transport system has become increasingly chaotic."

The book points out that the government's election manifesto "said little about privatisation", yet ministers promptly embarked on an orgy of privatisation. "The main beneficiaries of privatisation," it reminds us, "have been the City institutions which organised the sales and the top executives who now run the privatised companies." Then comes a familiar question: "And what about the workers? They have done less well. No dramatic pay rises for them and not much pride of ownership either."

Are there any real advantages in privatisation? "There is little evidence," the book proclaims, "to justify the automatic benefits of privatisation." On the contrary. "Privatisation has been a costly experiment whose benefits have been at best dubious." And yet "there is no declared limit to the government's privatisation plans. One government minister has suggested that the boundary between private and public sector should be refined so that only defence, law and order and some basic regulatory tasks should escape privatisation. Grey areas where the private sector would become increasingly involved included, in his view, health and education, and already such developments are taking place."

All this happened against a background of growing inequality. "The distribution of income in Britain has now become so unequal that it is beginning to resemble that of a third world country." Who has gained? "The real beneficiaries of tax reforms have been the few at the top of the scale. Not only income tax changes have favoured the very rich. Changes in capital and inheritance taxation have helped them too, making Britain's inequalities even greater."

The author was infuriated by the inherent contradiction in the government's attitude towards rich and poor. "How is it that incentives for the rich and poor are so very different? How can it be that for the rich the only stimulus to economic endeavour is that the rewards become increasingly lavish, while the poor are in continual need of the spur of their poverty?"

I hope I've given you enough of a taste of the book's socialist inspiration and its indignation at government policies. Sadly, though, you might find it hard to get hold of a copy. It is entitled Where There is Greed, a spoof quotation mocking Margaret Thatcher's stomach-churning reference to St Francis of Assisi when she went into Downing Street.

The book was published by Mainstream in 1989. Its author was a dynamic Labour MP called Gordon Brown. How strange that a Labour MP of the same name and age has been in charge of recent tax policies which have widened the gap between rich and poor; and who told the general secretary of the TUC the other day that if New Labour gets a second term only the police and health service will be free from privatisation. (I wouldn't count on those exceptions either).

Normally I would rejoice at news of distress for Colin Myler, who has resigned as editor of the Sunday Mirror. He came to Mirror Group Newspapers as a standard-bearer for the Montgomery massacre of 1992 and 1993, and eagerly took part in the wholesale union-busting sackings that followed. He sacked my friend Tim Minogue, allegedly for shaking hands with me, though I am sure Tim's offence was more trivial, and was probably connected with his courage in accepting union office and having the guts to stand up to the Montgomery/Myler brigade.

A week or two ago it would have been impossible to imagine anyone on earth who would make me feel sorry for Myler, but then it would have been impossible to imagine anyone in public life as crass and arrogant as Mr Justice Poole, whose decision to stop the Leeds footballers' trial for alleged contempt of court was almost as indefensible as his incidental, imbecile and reactionary remarks at the time (which I am now apparently forbidden by the judge's own order from describing).

I hope I've given you enough of a taste of the book's socialist inspiration and its indignation at government policies. Sadly, though, you might find it hard to get hold of a copy. It is entitled Where There is Greed, a spoof quotation mocking Margaret Thatcher's stomach-churning reference to St Francis of Assisi when she went into Downing Street. The book was published by Mainstream in 1989. Its author was a dynamic Labour MP called Gordon Brown. How strange that a Labour MP of the same name and age has been in charge of recent tax policies which have widened the gap between rich and poor; and who told the general secretary of the TUC the other day that if New Labour gets a second term only the police and health service will be free from privatisation. (I wouldn't count on those exceptions either). Normally I would rejoice at news of distress for Colin Myler, who has resigned as editor of the Sunday Mirror. He came to Mirror Group Newspapers as a standard-bearer for the Montgomery massacre of 1992 and 1993, and eagerly took part in the wholesale union-busting sackings that followed. He sacked my friend Tim Minogue, allegedly for shaking hands with me, though I am sure Tim's offence was more trivial, and was probably connected with his courage in accepting union office and having the guts to stand up to the Montgomery/Myler brigade. A week or two ago it would have been impossible to imagine anyone on earth who would make me feel sorry for Myler, but then it would have been impossible to imagine anyone in public life as crass and arrogant as Mr Justice Poole, whose decision to stop the Leeds footballers' trial for alleged contempt of court was almost as indefensible as his incidental, imbecile and reactionary remarks at the time (which I am now apparently forbidden by the judge's own order from describing).

fields.headline: High street revival falters
fields.trailText: Government attempts to revive the high street are showing little sign of success, with rent increases and tough trading conditions forcing shopkeepers to pack up and leave, writes Terry Macalister.
fields.body:
Government attempts to revive the high street are showing little sign of success, with rent increases and tough trading conditions forcing shopkeepers to pack up and leave, writes Terry Macalister.

Only businesses in high-margin sectors such as mobile phones, coffee bars or fast food restaurants can afford space on the high street, according to a report published today by retail consultancy Verdict.

Many shopkeepers face rent reviews and a vicious circle of lack of choice is causing shoppers to switch to out-of-town stores.

The number of consumers who believe high streets have enough shops is 26%, compared to 34% last year. While 46% of shoppers 12 months ago preferred to shop in a high street rather than an out-of-town mall, that figure has dropped to 32%.

This research is a blow to the government, which is committed to regenerating high streets through planning laws restricting out-of-town shopping centres and supermarket sites.

A working group of landlords and tenants set up by the planning minister, Nick Raynsford, recently failed to reach a voluntary agreement to introduce greater flexibility into arrangements with retailers.

Verdict said that such flexibility was urgently needed, but retailers also had to take a tougher line when negotiating with landlords.

Even the "superleague" of city centres, led by the West End of London, Birmingham, Manchester and Glasgow, did not offer shoppers enough choice.

fields.headline: Elstein leads digital initiative
fields.trailText:
10.15am: Former Channel 5 boss David Elstein is spearheading a scheme to slash the cost of digital TV access, writes Dan Milmo.
Digital giveaway planned
fields.body:
Former Channel 5 boss David Elstein is spearheading an initiative to slash the cost of digital TV access for viewers.

Mr Elstein is chairman of Xios Transcast Corporation, which plans to cut the cost of the set-top boxes that decode digital TV signals.

"This technology could solve the problem of how to produce cheap set-top boxes. It could be on the way to creating a worldwide standard as ubiquitous as Microsoft's Windows," he said.

The government plans to switch off the analogue TV signal over the next five years, but millions of homes will have to be kitted out with set-top boxes in order to meet the deadline.

Mr Elstein believes a new product from XTC provides a cheap solution to the problem, and is looking for £6m from investors to see the company through the next two years.

"It is quite possible to imagine £1bn of sales in several years," he said.

XTC has found a niche in the market thanks to the prohibitive cost of computer memory, which is keeping the price of current set-top boxes high.

The new box reduces the amount of memory needed by streaming information from a satellite rather than storing it in a box and filtering it into a television.

The company plans to license the technology rather than manufacture it itself.

Mr Elstein has been a busy man since he resigned as chief executive of Channel 5 in October last year.

He works as a media consultant at Arthur D Little and recently joined the board of film and TV production group Civilain Content. He has also received offers to be chairman of other companies.

webTitle: News of World censured for secret video

fields.headline: News of World censured for secret video
fields.standfirst:
Granada wins ruling from press commission

MediaGuardian.co.uk
PCC adjudication printed in NoW
fields.trailText:
After the fake sheikh fiasco, a more mundane tabloid sting has resulted in a check to the News of the World. by Matt Wells.
PCC adjudication printed in NoW
fields.body:
After the fake sheikh fiasco, a more mundane tabloid sting has resulted in a check to the News of the World.

In a significant ruling that passed almost unnoticed at the weekend, the press complaints commission held that the NoW had breached the editors' code of conduct by covertly filming a private party given for the cast of the television series Emmerdale - even though the paper's journalists left when spotted and no story was published.

While the newspaper could expect to defend any complaint from Buckingham Palace over the Sophie tapes affair on the grounds of public interest, a similar defence in the Emmerdale case was rejected. In the former, the NoW was investigating a tip-off about the way that the Countess of Wessex's PR firm was run; in the Emmerdale situation it was found to have been engaged in a "fishing expedition".

The incident occurred last December at the Rudding hotel, scene of a Christmas party thrown by Yorkshire Television. The venue was chosen for its secluded location outside Leeds: the programme makers wanted to reward the cast and crew for a successful year in which the show had transferred to a five nights a week format on ITV, and was attracting the youthful audience coveted by advertisers.

There were two unwanted guests: journalists from the News of the World, caught with covert video equipment. When challenged they left; but the PR department at Granada, which owns Yorkshire and other ITV franchises, thought the incident worthy of pursuit.

At the weekend the NoW was forced to print the commission's adjudication: the partygoers had a "reasonable expectation of privacy" at the hotel. The commission rejected the paper's defence that "wild behaviour" had been reported at previous parties: "There was no evidence that the newspaper might have been able to expose any crime or serious misdemeanour by secretly videoing the partygoers. The commission will always protect a paper's right to investigate matters of genuine public interest, but in this case the public interest defence did not justify the photographing of individuals in private places."

Guy Black, the commission's director, acknowledged that the Emmerdale ruling was "interesting". He said: "The code isn't there to stop legitimate investigation; it is there to stop fishing expeditions."

Granada, responsible for Coronation Street, Cold Feet and Popstars among many other programmes, has made a point of using the press code to its fullest extent. The Coronation Street actress Jacqueline Pirie won a significant victory last year when the commission ruled that a salacious NoW article about her sex life had contravened the code. While Ms Pirie had volunteered information about her private life in previous interviews, she had not divulged the deeply personal details published by the paper. That, too, was a significant ruling.

Yet the NoW appears to want to push the boundaries too. Last Sunday it published pictures of the Hear'Say band member Noel Sullivan embracing another man in an Ibiza nightclub. Mr Sullivan, who shot to fame in Popstars, has never discussed his sexuality.

Sallie Ryle, head of media relations for Granada's north of England franchises, said yesterday: "Interest in our stars' private lives is very intense. Some of the people involve seek celebrity, so that's fine. But I think that for the people who want to try and remain private they are perfectly entitled to expect support from us.

"We have tried to use the code as much as we can when it's appropriate - it's the only comeback we have."

Going under cover for headline news

Countess of Wessex

The News of the World would have a strong case in arguing that it was justified in secretly taping her conversation with a fake sheik. The countess' company, RJH, had taken out an injunction preventing its employees from talking to the press, so the paper could argue that the only way to find out information about the countess allegedly making money from her royal connections was by deception.

Lawrence Dallaglio

The England rugby captain was a victim of a "honeytrap" sting when in May 1999 he told two undercover reporters from the News of the World that he had taken drugs in his youth. He might have been able to argue that this was an invasion of his privacy - law-breaking or not - had he not got carried away by the reporters' goading and told them, allegedly, that he had used drugs on an England tour, something that he later denied.

David Mellor and Antonia de Sancha

The People broke the story of actress de Sancha's affair with the then national heritage secretary in July 1992 when it published excerpts from private tape-recorded conversations. The People justified the story on the grounds that the married Mellor allegedly told de Sancha in the conversation that the affair was interfering with his job.

Piers Merchant

The Sun printed four pages of photos of the Tory MP kissing Anna Cox, a 17-year-old Soho hostess, in a London park in March 1997. He initially denied her assertions that they were having an affair and paraded his family to prove it. Cox was aware of the photographer's presence while Merchant was not.

fields.headline: PCC adjudication
fields.standfirst: The Press Complaints Commission adjudication, published on page 10 of the News of the World on April 15
fields.trailText: The Press Complaints Commission adjudication published in the News of the World.
fields.body:
Ms Sallie Ryle

Ms Sallie Ryle, Head of Media Relations North for Granada Media, complained that journalists from the News of the World took video footage of individuals at a private Christmas party in breach of Clause 4 (harassment) of the Code of Practice.

The complaint was upheld.

The complainant said that journalists from the newspaper had been found at the party, which was thrown for the television programme Emmerdale at a hotel, taking undercover footage - which was submitted to the Commission - of the guests as they enjoyed their evening. The complainant also submitted a letter from the hotel confirming that YTV had booked private rooms.

The paper said that the area was public and that anybody could walked into the party. It added that there had been 'wild behaviour' at previous parties and maintained that it was in the public interest to explore whether this would be the case. The investigation was conducted in a low-key manner and the journalists left when their presence was detected.

The Commission was persuaded by the complainant's evidence that the partygoers had a reasonable expectation of privacy. In any case, if the party was not private as the newspaper maintained, it would not have made sense for the journalists to have used concealed cameras.

Such a breach of the Code could only be excusable in the public interest and the Commission was not persuaded by the newspaper's justification. There was no evidence that the newspaper might have been able to expose any crime or serious misdemenour by secretly videoing the partygoers. The Commission will always protect a paper's right to investigate matters of genuine public interest, bit in this case the public interest denece did not justify the photographing of individuals in private places.
