fields.headline: Government is top UK advertiser
fields.trailText: The government has overtaken consumer giants Unilever and Proctor & Gamble to become the country's biggest spender on advertising.
fields.body:
The government has overtaken consumer giants Unilever and Proctor & Gamble to become the country's biggest spender on advertising, industry figures showed yesterday.

The government spent more than £16.4m on advertising campaigns in February, according to figures from media monitoring service ACNielsen MMS.

The second biggest advertiser, Unilever, spent £12.2m, while rival soap giant Proctor & Gamble was at number three with £10.1m.

The government's main advertising campaigns in February included one encouraging families to claim the new children's tax credit, one attempting to recruit more nurses, and another urging people to plan sufficient pension provision.

In the whole of 2000, the government ranked as the fourth biggest advertiser, below Unilever, Proctor & Gamble, and BT.

Government spending on advertising has increased steadily since Labour was elected, the figures showed. In 1997, spending totalled £43.8m, but by 2000 this had more than doubled to £102.7m.

Although the money has not been spent on promoting the Labour party itself, critics say that the advertising campaigns might serve political objectives. The Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, said: "This is yet more evidence of a government obsessed with spin, prepared to spend taxpayers' money on mass advertising."

A survey of the world's 10 biggest advertising markets in the latest edition of trade magazine Ad Age Global, indicates Britain's level of government advertising is unusually high. The only other country where the government appears among the top 10 advertisers is Canada.

A Labour party spokesman denied that taxpayers' money was being used to promote the party's policies in the run-up to the general election. He said: "Each of the campaigns is for the legitimate purpose of imparting important information to the public.

"The money spent on the campaigns is a fraction of what is available for distribution in the case of children's tax credit, for example. All governments in the past have advertised what they have been doing."

Labour is to launch a poster campaign this week highlighting its achievements in the run-up to the general election.

Press Association

webTitle: Comment: Slaughter is still the best medicine

fields.headline: Slaughter is still the best medicine
fields.standfirst:
Demands for vaccination against foot and mouth are growing - but it could actually make things worse

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: With half of Britain's livestock threatened with destruction farmers and the public are demanding to know why vaccination is not being used to stop the slaughter. Vaccination has been highly effective against the human smallpox and polio viruses but its effectiveness against foot and mouth is not so clear cut.
fields.body:
With half of Britain's livestock threatened with destruction farmers and the public are demanding to know why vaccination is not being used to stop the slaughter. Vaccination has been highly effective against the human smallpox and polio viruses but its effectiveness against foot and mouth is not so clear cut.

First, foot and mouth presents itself as a multiplicity of strains and vaccination against one strain gives variable protection against others. Further, the virus has the unfortunate knack of mutation, so vaccines that give good protection on one occasion may be less effective subsequently. Efforts to mitigate this situation take the form of the production of multivalent vaccines - that is, vaccines containing several of the strains deemed of likely occurrence in any given area. Although this produces a wider umbrella of protection, even the best vaccines are less than perfect.

The shortcomings of the vaccines is only part of the problem. The protective antibodies in cattle subside relatively quickly, sometimes rendering animals susceptible to reinfection in as little as six or seven months. Biannual vaccination would be expensive and inconvenient, requiring a cumbersome administrative structure and inspection to ensure that the programme was being universally applied. The biggest problem from a commercial view, however, is that vaccinated animals may harbour the virus without showing signs of ill health, effectively putting paid to Britain's meat products export trade for an unforeseeable period.

The kneejerk demand for vaccination ignores the fact that the slaughter policy has kept Britain free from substantial losses due to foot and mouth since 1967. The only outbreak in those 34 years occurred in the 1980s when this now reviled policy resulted in rapid containment and eradication of the disease.

Any decision about whether to vaccinate is difficult because there are so many unknown factors, the chief of these being the frequency and costliness of outbreaks. It is worth noting that the incidence of the disease worldwide (and hence the possible sources of infection) has increased in recent years. However, Britain's position as an island remote from any endemic infected lands means, in theory at least, that the exclu sion of infected materials should be straightforward. On the other hand, increasing international trade presents the hazard of importing infected material either inadvertently or by means of smuggled goods.

Contingency plans for vaccination do exist and are under continuous consideration, though they would probably be used only as a last resort. This is because a switch to vaccination at this stage might well produce the worst of all worlds. Taiwan did just that recently, with the result that after the expense of slaughter and disposal of thousands of pigs they must endure the expense and inconvenience of vaccinating all remaining stock once or twice a year. Further, the virus probably still lurks among the vaccinated animals, and all exports are banned. International regulations dictate that no animal exports are permitted for three years after the last vaccinated animal has been destroyed. If infection is detected after vaccination has commenced, the delay in resuming exports would be set back even further.

Limited vaccination in the form of the inoculation of livestock in a barrier area surrounding infected areas is also under consideration. However, it is moot whether such ring vaccination would be effective in stopping further spread. In the past a puzzling aspect about transmission has been the jump of infection from one point to another many miles away without infection on the intervening premises. The virus has already been carried across the English Channel to Holland and France and also across the Irish Sea, which suggests that ring vaccination may not be very effective as a containment strategy.

Despite years of effort, the means of transmitting the virus is still imperfectly understood, though windborne transmission is strongly suspected. The saliva of afflicted animals is heavily loaded with the virus, so that the surrounding atmosphere becomes contaminated both by drooling and by exhalation. After death, contamination of the surroundings is relatively limited and the virus, which is quite fragile, is largely destroyed by putrefaction. So criticism of the authorities for delays in disposing of carcasses is largely misplaced.

Transmission of infected droplets by the wind is favoured by high humidity and this year's exceptionally wet conditions may be responsible for the difficulties in controlling the scourge. Hopefully drier and sunnier weather will soon come to the country's assistance. In the meantime the best we can probably do is batten down the hatches, sit tight and hope for the best.

After all, in spite of foot and mouth and the stockmarket crash, all is not gloom. Our cricket and rugby teams are doing wonderfully well.

Leonard Black was veterinary immunologist in charge of foot and mouth vaccine evaluation for Wellcome Laboratories from 1972 to 1983.

Although this produces a wider umbrella of protection, even the best vaccines are less than perfect. The shortcomings of the vaccines is only part of the problem. The protective antibodies in cattle subside relatively quickly, sometimes rendering animals susceptible to reinfection in as little as six or seven months. Biannual vaccination would be expensive and inconvenient, requiring a cumbersome administrative structure and inspection to ensure that the programme was being universally applied. The biggest problem from a commercial view, however, is that vaccinated animals may harbour the virus without showing signs of ill health, effectively putting paid to Britain's meat products export trade for an unforeseeable period. The kneejerk demand for vaccination ignores the fact that the slaughter policy has kept Britain free from substantial losses due to foot and mouth since 1967. The only outbreak in those 34 years occurred in the 1980s when this now reviled policy resulted in rapid containment and eradication of the disease. Any decision about whether to vaccinate is difficult because there are so many unknown factors, the chief of these being the frequency and costliness of outbreaks. It is worth noting that the incidence of the disease worldwide (and hence the possible sources of infection) has increased in recent years. However, Britain's position as an island remote from any endemic infected lands means, in theory at least, that the exclu sion of infected materials should be straightforward. On the other hand, increasing international trade presents the hazard of importing infected material either inadvertently or by means of smuggled goods. Contingency plans for vaccination do exist and are under continuous consideration, though they would probably be used only as a last resort. This is because a switch to vaccination at this stage might well produce the worst of all worlds. Taiwan did just that recently, with the result that after the expense of slaughter and disposal of thousands of pigs they must endure the expense and inconvenience of vaccinating all remaining stock once or twice a year. Further, the virus probably still lurks among the vaccinated animals, and all exports are banned. International regulations dictate that no animal exports are permitted for three years after the last vaccinated animal has been destroyed. If infection is detected after vaccination has commenced, the delay in resuming exports would be set back even further. Limited vaccination in the form of the inoculation of livestock in a barrier area surrounding infected areas is also under consideration. However, it is moot whether such ring vaccination would be effective in stopping further spread. In the past a puzzling aspect about transmission has been the jump of infection from one point to another many miles away without infection on the intervening premises. The virus has already been carried across the English Channel to Holland and France and also across the Irish Sea, which suggests that ring vaccination may not be very effective as a containment strategy. Despite years of effort, the means of transmitting the virus is still imperfectly understood, though windborne transmission is strongly suspected. The saliva of afflicted animals is heavily loaded with the virus, so that the surrounding atmosphere becomes contaminated both by drooling and by exhalation. After death, contamination of the surroundings is relatively limited and the virus, which is quite fragile, is largely destroyed by putrefaction. So criticism of the authorities for delays in disposing of carcasses is largely misplaced. Transmission of infected droplets by the wind is favoured by high humidity and this year's exceptionally wet conditions may be responsible for the difficulties in controlling the scourge. Hopefully drier and sunnier weather will soon come to the country's assistance. In the meantime the best we can probably do is batten down the hatches, sit tight and hope for the best. After all, in spite of foot and mouth and the stockmarket crash, all is not gloom. Our cricket and rugby teams are doing wonderfully well. webTitle: Vodafone dials up first 3G phone call

fields.headline: Vodafone dials up first 3G phone call
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Vodafone has made the UK's first 3G phone call but it will be a year before the public benefits, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Vodafone has made the UK's first ever 3G phone call, but the mobile phone giant is a year away from making the technology available to the public.

The call was made yesterday over Vodafone's mini-3G network in the Thames Valley.

"Our announcement of the first 3G voice call marks yet another significant milestone in the development of our multimedia services and forms part of our rollout plans for 3G mobile," said Gavin Darby, chief operating officer of Vodafone UK.

But customers must wait until the middle of next year before they can get their hands on the new handsets, which offer high-speed internet access and the ability to download video images.

"It is anticipated that commercial 3G services will be launched in the second half of 2002," the company said.

Vodafone boss Chris Gent was recently forced to reassure investors that 3G networks would be ready by 2002, amid fears that cost and technology issues would delay the new service.

Telecoms operators spent a staggering £50bn on 3G licenses in the UK and Germany alone last year, sparking fears that the new networks will not generate enough income to pay back the massive investments.

fields.headline: Labour poster prompts privacy complaints
fields.trailText: 9.30am: A Labour poster depicting William Hague and Michael Portillo as 'Mr Boom and Mr Bust' has been criticised for breaking privacy rules, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A Labour party poster depicting William Hague and Michael Portillo as "Mr Boom and Mr Bust" has been criticised for breaking privacy rules.

But the adverts will stay up because politicians have exempted themselves from the rules governing advertising.

The Advertising Standards Authority said it had received several complaints about the adverts but was powerless to act on them.

And industry experts say that the film-style posters, which show the grinning faces of Mr Hague and Mr Portillo above the words "Economic Disaster II", are in direct contravention of advertising rules on privacy.

The watchdog's rules state that advertisers should not portray people in a negative way without their permission.

It was this rule that led to the banning of the Conservatives' infamous "demon eyes" posters during the 1997 election potraying Tony Blair as the devil.

"We have received complaints and have sent back letters saying it's not within our remit any more," said an ASA spokesman.

"We upheld complaints about 'demon eyes' on the grounds that Mr Blair had been portrayed in a negative way without his permission. Clearly these new adverts are along the same lines."

The row surrounding "demon eyes" infuriated the advertising watchdog so much that it washed its hands of all future political campaigns, saying the parties would have to come up with their own system of regulation.

But politicians have so far failed to do so, prompting fears that the coming election campaign could be one of the dirtiest in history.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: News of Alastair Campbell's imminent retirement as Mr Tony's press chief (to do the identical job but without briefing the lobby in public) causes mixed emotions.
fields.body:
News of Alastair Campbell's imminent retirement as Mr Tony's press chief (to do the identical job but without briefing the lobby in public) causes mixed emotions.

Of course, we'll miss the merriment - who can forget him being questioned by a detective who'd read the cobblers here about him and Jill Dando? Then again, the career opening excites me.

A few years ago I turned down the job of Ali's deputy for personal reasons, but times have changed. So my colleague Marina Hyde rings No 10 for my application form. It's a sign of how well open government has caught on under Ali that the first person refuses to give her name.

Then Anne Shebas comes on. "There isn't a position available," she begins primly. Ah, so it's been filled already? A long pause ensues. "There isn't a position available. You're simply referring to something in the papers." Yes, and presumably it's you lot who placed it there. "There is no position available," she repeats. "I have nothing more to say. Goodbye." I like this Anne's style. Stick with me, girl, and I'll fly you to the stars.

 Further to our item on Robin Cook sponsoring the annual, US-planted anti-Cuba resolution in Geneva this week, we hear of a rival entertainment being got up by Glasgow MP George Galloway. As the government is putting the resolution, at some unknown time between now and Thursday, George and the Cuba Solidarity Campaign are planning an impromptu rally in Livingston, Cookie's constituency, to protest about "the sight of Cook kissing the backside of one US administration after another", as George diplomatically puts it, and also to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the Bay of Pigs. More details if we get them.

 Behold, better late than never, our Easter eggheads. This snap of the David Yelland Appreciation Society's inaugural meeting (with Marina Hyde and myself are John Vidal, Kay Balogun and Seumas Milne; next time, Polly, and that's a promise) may entice others to join. The first outing will be to Wapping where DYAS members, each claiming to be the alopecian Sun editor and demanding entry, will play out the Spartacus scene by shrieking "I am Yelland", "No, I am Yelland," etc, etc at the security guard. Applications by email or phone.

 Speculation about the Spectator intensifies by the hour. Although his enemies malevolently suggest Boris the Jackal Johnson wants to stay on after entering parliament, the notion that an ambitious Tory backbencher could be seen to be using an independent-minded journal to boost his political career... it doesn't deserve the dignity of a completed sentence. So the mag's publisher Kimberley Fortier casts her net. Today editor Rod Liddle, an admirably mischievous leftie, was an idea of genius - hats off, Kimmy! - and on the off chance that he will decline, other possibles include Mark Seddon, Paul Foot, Tariq Ali, Arthur Scargill and Pol Pot. David Icke was approached before Christmas and said no, but is being lined up for a column.

 When we rang Simon Walker's office last week to ask if the Queen's troubled press secretary would be returning to work after his holiday, Sue Derry said he'd be back today. Mentioning an imaginary parcel we need to get to him, we ring back to double check. Will he definitely be back? "Yes, he will," Sue assures us. No doubts? "Well, assuming the airlines run to schedule. He'll definitely get on a plane, but I can't make any assumptions about its arrival." Blimey. A bit drastic, isn't it? Still, if you upset the family...

webTitle: Fine tuning in a knife edge marginal

fields.headline: Fine tuning in a knife edge marginal
fields.standfirst: In the second of a three part series on tactical voting in key constituencies the Guardian looks at the Labour seat of Kettering
fields.trailText: In the second of a three part series on tactical voting in key constituencies the Guardian looks at the Labour seat of Kettering.
fields.body:
On Saturday afternoons, when most MPs try to snatch a few hours rest, Phil Sawford attends to vital constituency business in Kettering. After hearing the woes of voters at his weekly surgery, the laid-back MP files away his papers and turns his attention to tuning guitars for local schools.

A fractional increase in support for the Tories at the general election will bring an abrupt end to the career of Britain's highest paid guitar tuner, who is defending a majority of just 189. But there are signs that the Tories have a fight on their hands in the prosperous Northamptonshire seat.

Private telephone polling by Labour, which realises the symbolism of the fight in the former Tory stronghold, shows that the two parties are on virtually the same level of support as 1997. This places Mr Sawford at just over 43%, marginally ahead of his Tory rival, Philip Hollobone, on just over 42%.

Such results will send a shiver down the spine of Mr Hollobone, who should snatch Kettering back without lifting a finger on a swing of just 0.15%.

Roger Freeman, the former cabinet minister who held Kettering with a 12,187 majority in 1992, only conceded defeat in 1997 after four recounts. Tory fears will be compounded by signs that the Liberal Democrats, whose candidate Roger Aron polled 10.7% last time, may vote tactically to support Labour.

"The idea that Labour can hold on to Kettering should be absurd, but it isn't," says an increasingly confident Mr Sawford. "This is going to be a very tight fight, but it ain't over in Kettering by any means."

In common with scores of Labour MPs in marginal seats, Mr Sawford has been given a free run by the party's whips to spend most of his time canvassing in Kettering, a former Labour stronghold which switched to the Tories in 1979 when the steel-producing town of Corby was removed from the constituency.

Officially every vote is up for grabs, but in private Labour will write off the western side of the constituency, towards Daventry, a sparsely populated rural area which is overwhelmingly Tory. Instead, the party will be concentrating its efforts on the eastern, urban side of the constituency around Kettering and the small "A6 towns" of Desborough, Burton Latimer and Rothwell. As a supporter of the leftwing Campaign group of MPs, Mr Sawford is an unlikely figure to woo comfortable voters. He has never taken New Labour to heart and believes that the government weakened public services by sticking to the Tory spending limits for its first two years in office. His campaign literature pointedly refers to the Labour party with no mention of New Labour.

But Mr Sawford, 50, has impeccable local credentials which will stand him in good stead. Born and raised in the constituency, he served on the town council for 20 years until his election as an MP. He is one of the few MPs who wears shoes made in his constituency - a smart pair of black lace-up shoes bought from the Cheaney's factory shop in Desborough.

With his roots in such a Conservative area, Mr Sawford is enough of a realist to know that Gordon Brown's devotion to prudence will play well in his constituency. " The average mortgage is down £1,000 in parts of Kettering which shows that we've killed off the idea that Labour can't run the economy," he says. Such sound management of the economy is denting Tory support in areas of the constituency which should be plastered in blue. On the Ise estate, one of the largest private housing developments in Europe which sprouted up on a picturesque greenfield site on the edge of Kettering in the 1970s, there is little enthusiasm for the Tories.

John Bird, 51, an admirer of Margaret Thatcher who voted Labour in 1997, is not yet ready for a change. "Tony Blair is a bit flash, but I think we should give him another shot," Mr Bird said. "My wife works in our local school and she says that it is noticeable how much more money is being put into education."

Another admirer of Lady Thatcher, who voted Conservative in 1997, is adamant that she will not support the Tories this time. Jabbing her finger, Rita Paterson, a pensioner, said: "I will not vote Conservative. Who are their leaders? Where are they going? I will probably abstain, although I like Gordon Brown. He had the sense to realise that he knows nothing about money, so he left it all to the Bank of England to work out."

Their remarks showed grudging support for Labour in Kettering, where voters are turned off by what they see as the government's metropolitan arrogance. Debbie West, a hairdresser who voted Labour in 1997, is unsure how she is going to vote, even though she has benefited from the minimum wage.

"I have not got that much faith in the government because they have not done all they said they would to improve schools and hospitals," she said. "Tony Blair is remote and arrogant, unlike William Hague who comes across as a people's person."

Mr Hollobone, the quietly spoken Tory candidate, has the unenviable task of persuading the likes of Ms West to put their faith in Mr Hague. A fervent Eurosceptic, and a committed "never" man on the single currency, the 36-year-old former Territorial Army officer is attempting to tailor his campaign to local concerns.

From the Tories' headquarters in the centre of Kettering, Mr Hollobone is drumming up support by sending out thousands of questionnaires which ask voters what issues worry them. The top three issues are an unpopular new traffic system in Kettering, law and order, and the health service. "This is a national campaign with a very local flavour," Mr Hollobone said. "The common themes that are emerging are people's deep fear of crime and of anti-social behaviour."

Labour will be concerned to hear that some of the most critical responses for the government came from a survey of the Grange estate in Kettering, a solid Labour area, where there were serious fears about crime. "We say to voters that you have paid the taxes, so where are the police?"

This is a far cry from Mr Hague's controversial "foreign land" speech, indicating that Tories in marginal seats have quietly decided that they should tack to the middle ground.

Mr Hollobone says little about his hardline stance on Europe, although this may change if Barry Mahoney, the United Kingdom Independence Party candidate, makes waves. The Referendum Party secured 2.7% of the vote in 1997.

Adopting the cautious approach that served Labour well in 1997, Mr Hollobone insists that he is not complacent and is conducting his campaign as if he were attempting to overcome a 10,000 Labour majority. However, he points out that the Tories have increased the number of councillors on Kettering borough council from 6 to 18 since 1997.

Whether this will be enough to ensure a comfortable berth for the Oxford graduate at Westminster is debatable. "What a shambles the Tories are, they don't stand a chance until they start to look like a government," one ex-Tory voter moaned.

webTitle: Portillo accused of targeting tax cuts at society's most affluent 10%

fields.headline: Portillo accused of targeting tax cuts at society's most affluent 10%
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, is today accused of preparing to bankroll the rich, with figures showing that his planned tax cuts would benefit the most affluent 10% of society.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, is today accused of preparing to bankroll the rich, with figures showing that his planned tax cuts would benefit the most affluent 10% of society.

Average pensioners and typical taxpayers stand to gain nothing under a Tory government which would target two thirds of its £8bn tax cuts at the richest, according to figures compiled by the Liberal Democrats.

"It's lose-lose for Middle England under the Tory plans," said Matthew Taylor, the Lib Dem economics spokesman. His remarks came after parliamentary answers from the Treasury and work by the Institute for Fiscal Studies which showed the effects of three flagship Tory tax cuts.

Mr Portillo has pledged to:

 Raise the level of income at which people pay the upper rate of tax, at a cost of £500m. This would provide no benefit to the average taxpayer, but would benefit the top 10%, according to the institute, which said: "Of course the impact of such a reform is felt almost exclusively at the top of the income distribution where families containing higher rate taxpayers are concerned."

 Cut the basic rates of income tax on dividends and savings income, at a cost of £2.97bn. This would benefit the typical taxpayers by £6 and £12 respectively, according to a written answer from the Treasury which showed that 92.5% of taxpayers are either not liable to income tax from dividends income or are liable for less than £50.

fields.headline: Muslim voters get awkward
fields.standfirst: Labour MPs should watch out
fields.trailText: An election is in the air. It must be when a man you've never seen before suddenly gives you a knock. And especially if that stranger is your local MP.
fields.body:
An election is in the air. It must be when a man you've never seen before suddenly gives you a knock. And especially if that stranger is your local MP.

The first few Sundays of spring might not be everyone's idea of prime campaigning time. But if you're in Barry Gardiner's shoes you cannot afford to be complacent. With a slim and volatile majority to defend for the government at the next election Gardiner knows success involves pounding many more pavements and doors in Brent North between now and D-day.

Gardiner overturned the straight- talking Rhodes Boyson's majority of 10,000 at the last election - a result that was in line with the national defection by Tory voters. But winning a seat is one thing, holding on to it in a traditionally hostile area is another. As his constituency encompasses the leafier parts of an otherwise deprived London borough, it is certain to be near the top of the Tories' recapture list.

No wonder Gardiner indulged my thoughts on noisy neighbours and volunteered to help by writing to Brent council. He must have figured that if a personal intervention did not persuade this working-class, ethnic-minority voter (typologically speaking of course) to break his habit of non-voting, nothing would. He has a point. I have not cast my ballot in the last three elections - not since the 1987 poll, in fact, when I was first eligible to vote.

My MP is entitled to wonder what has gone wrong in the intervening period. Has this former politics student lost faith in the political process? Have I lost my "natural" affinity with Labour? Or have I just become apathetic?

Tick all of the above. In the 16 years since my enfranchisement I've bagged two degrees and several years' journalistic experience but I have seen my economic prospects improve little. Yet I should count myself lucky to be able to command some kind of income. On a collective level, I have seen the Muslim community - my community - emerge as a new underclass propping up every single socio-economic index.

That is one reason I don't feel any natural inclination to turn out for Labour, the party which could historically rely on the support of people like myself - the son of a northern immigrant textile worker who lost his job in the mass manufacturing-sector redundancies of the early 1980s. After showing initial promise, the party's record in government barely betters my experience of the Tories. Tokenism, cronyism and rejection continue to dominate its dealing with Muslims.

It's enough to breed disillusionment and apathy in the most faithful democrat. But paradoxically these are also the strongest spurs to action. I'm fed up with the system, but I'm not going to lie back and be a victim - not a passive one at any rate. Mr Barry Gardiner should know that I do intend to turn out at the upcoming general election. But he should also know it is not because he has intervened in my domestic dispute. In fact he should be watching his back.

In an unprecedented development, Mr Gardiner and many of his Labour peers will be fighting a rearguard battle in the coming months. This might be news to him, but all over the country Muslim candidates are preparing to throw in their topis against sitting Labour MPs.

Gardiner is protecting a majority of only 4,000. It may need only a slight swing back to the Tories and the helpful nudge of a few hundred Muslim voters to send him packing. Elsewhere, in Ilford South, a bitter gloves-off battle has ensued between local Muslims and Mike Gapes, whose majority of 14,000 may not be as comfortable as it appears. In 1992, he won the seat by just 400 votes.

In Birmingham Sparkbrook and Small Heath, which contains one of the nation's highest numbers of Muslim voters, a fight is under way to oust Labour's Roger Godsiff. The pretender here is a one-time Labour member, Qassim Afzal, now standing for the Lib Dems. In Jack Straw's seemingly unassailable constituency, Blackburn, the rumour mill is churning out news of a challenge to the home secretary.

What connects these disparate and uncoordinated local challenges - and the list is far from exhaustive - is that they are the work of second and third generation Muslims whose motivation has less to do with class and race than religion. Gardiner and Gapes are being targeted because of their Zionist associations - both are members of Labour Friends of Israel. Although Godsiff has been sensitive to local pressure to back Kashmiri independence, he has failed to support calls for an end to sanctions against Iraq and the Russian invasion of Chechnya. As for Straw, he is being cast as the draconian enforcer of the anti-Muslim Terrorism Act 2000.

Some of these challenges are more optimistic than real, some are merely symbolic. Some challengers may even be supping with the devil - the Tories - to drive home their message. But they are important in that they represent a sweeping away of the old order whereby Labour could expect the "ethnic vote" and safeguard it by courting clan leaders and community strongmen.

These developments also show that Labour is in danger of ignoring the new priorities of my generation. My peers cannot be bought off with the promise of a regeneration budget and community centre here, and a peerage there. In a contracting world, our concerns are increasingly for the welfare of our co-religionists abroad. On the domestic front, our measures are more communal than personal; religious discrimination, underemployment, and equality in state finance of "separate" education and a general empathy with our faith-based outlook.

It is too early to say whether this might amount to the beginnings of a Muslim vote. What it does signal is a new political consciousness. We have realised that a default to Labour does not work. We are also aware that in a constituency-based electoral system one of our main handicaps - our ghettoisation - is also our biggest strength. There are at least six constituencies where the majority of the sitting MP is lower than the eligible number of Muslim voters and where, if the result remains unchanged, a strategic vote by Muslims could swing the seat. In at least another 10 seats, the Muslim vote has the potential to assist an opposition swing and return their candidate.

The discerning Muslim voter has arrived. For MPs like Barry Gardiner that is sufficient reason to be knocking down doors on Sunday morning.

webTitle: MP urges teacher unions to end ghastly conference ritual

fields.headline: End ghastly union ritual, urges MP
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Teacher unions should end the "ghastly ritual" of their Easter conferences because they turn off would-be recruits, the chairman of the Commons education committee said last night.
fields.body:
Teacher unions should end the "ghastly ritual" of their Easter conferences because they turn off would-be recruits, the chairman of the Commons education committee said last night.

Labour MP Barry Sheerman said he was dismayed by the behaviour of some delegates at the National Union of Teachers' conference in Cardiff, who jeered and held up placards when the education secretary, David Blunkett, addressed them.

The complaint comes a few days after Theresa May, shadow education secretary, said the teaching unions were the "last bastions of unreconstructed trade unionism". But it was flatly rejected by the NUT and the Liberal Democrats.

Mr Sheerman condemned teacher unions for backing a joint motion threatening industrial action if the government failed to hold a full inquiry on pay and conditions. "They want to be treated with respect, But some of their behaviour makes the National Union of Students look statesmanlike."

He believed about 20% of those thinking about going into teaching decided against it because of the poor impression given by trade unions. "At a time when so much effort has been made to improve the status and respect of the teaching profession, we have the annual ghastly ritual of the conference season giving such a negative impression of teachers."

But Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT, said: "I don't believe Mr Blunkett had a tough time on Saturday." He added: "If you can't make progress by dialogue, what else can you do? Industrial action is there as a last resort."

Phil Willis, the Liberal Democrat education spokesman, who yesterday supported the unions' call for a 35-hour week, said: "Where else do teachers come to be able to express their views?"

webTitle: MoD leak reveals airfield services sell-off

fields.headline: MoD leak reveals airfield services sell-off
fields.trailText: Fire and crash services at military airfields are to be privatised under a controversial £4bn Ministry of Defence plan to transfer 2,100 staff to commercial companies.
fields.body:
Fire and crash services at military airfields are to be privatised under a controversial £4bn Ministry of Defence plan to transfer 2,100 staff to commercial companies.

A confidential MoD document seen by the Guardian reveals that detailed negotiations are under way with three bidders to take over duties at up to 96 locations, including sites in Britain, Germany and Cyprus. All three bidders are threatening job cuts.

As well as providing fire and crash cover, the bidder winning the 25-year contracts would refuel and tow aircraft, control aircraft movements on the ground and clear ice and snow from runways and planes.

The winner, which will be selected by Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, would also be required to support "operational deployments", such as peacekeeping in the Balkans.

The Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, last night warned that the proposals could compromise security and urged ministers not to get locked into long, inflexible agreements.

"These services will be provided at some of the most sensitive military sites in the country," said Mr Campbell. "There are bound to be questions about security and it does seem pretty strange that this contract is to run for 25 years. The MoD document, headed "restricted - commercial", was prepared for the department's equipment approvals committee. It discloses that the winning bidder would assume responsibility for 3,500 vehicles worth £350m, in addition to the workers involved.

"The airfield support services project aims to pass responsibility for certain airfield services, currently undertaken by some 2,100 MoD civilians, to a private sector provider," says the report.

"These services consist of fire-crash cover, aircraft fuelling, movements and air cargo handling, airfield clearance, aircraft services and a part of air traffic control services (the runway caravan)."

Civilians at Gibraltar's RAF base would be kept in MoD employment for "political reasons" while a "memorandum of understanding" to provide fire cover at seven US airfields in the UK must be renegotiated.

fields.headline: Clarke denies leadership plot
fields.trailText: Kenneth Clarke, the former Conservative chancellor, moved yesterday to quash rumours that he is planning to form a "modernisers' pact" to deliver the party leadership to Michael Portillo.
fields.body:
Kenneth Clarke, the former Conservative chancellor, moved yesterday to quash rumours that he is planning to form a "modernisers' pact" to deliver the party leadership to Michael Portillo.

After newspaper reports of his post-election plans, Mr Clarke dismissed speculation that he had instructed his supporters on the Tory left to throw their weight behind the shadow chancellor.

"I have read with incredulity the stories concerning me, Michael Portillo and the Conservative party leadership," he said "I have not backed Michael Portillo or anybody else for any future leadership contest.

"The whole thing is fiction. I have spent the last few days reading very few newspapers, doing nothing political and not talking about the leadership with anybody. The newspaper stories have therefore caused me some amusement."

A report in the Times on Saturday claimed that Mr Clarke had advised the breakaway Pro Euro Conservative party, led by the former Tory MEP John Stevens, not to stand against Mr Portillo in his Kensington and Chelsea constituency. This was interpreted as a sign of support for Mr Portillo, even though Mr Clarke has always urged Mr Stevens not to stand against official Tory candidates.

Mr Clarke said: "I have never asked John Stevens not to stand against Michael Portillo... I have spoken to John Stevens once in the last two years. He telephoned me, and I declined his suggestion that I should issue a statement asking him not to stand at the next general election."

Mr Stevens insisted that Mr Clarke had offered him advice. "Ken believes we shouldn't be rocking the boat because he... thinks that Michael Portillo, if he becomes leader, would give to frontbenchers the freedom to campaign in favour of the euro," he told Radio 4's The World at One.

Conservative central office last night welcomed Mr Clarke's comments. A source said: "The media has got itself into a media feeding frenzy on a quiet bank holiday weekend."

webTitle: Prescott forced to climb down over Kyoto

fields.headline: Prescott forced to climb down over Kyoto
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: John Prescott was forced into an embarrassing climbdown yesterday over his pledge to confront the US government's rejection of the Kyoto climate change treaty.
fields.body:
John Prescott was forced into an embarrassing climbdown yesterday over his pledge to confront the US government's rejection of the Kyoto climate change treaty.

The u-turn fuelled speculation that Downing Street had urged Mr Prescott to tone down his language which contrasted with Tony Blair's "softly softly" approach to wards the new US administration.

As the deputy prime minister arrived in Washington last night for a meeting with his US counterpart, the environment department said the Kyoto protocol would form no part of his formal discussions in America this week.

"John Prescott is not going to America to kickstart the Kyoto protocol," a spokesman said.

"If it comes up he will discuss it, but he is not going to America to put it back on track."

In an interview on GMTV on Sunday, Mr Prescott criticised President George Bush for rejecting the Kyoto treaty and pointed out that his father had signed the original Rio deal on the environment in 1992. Asked about his US trip, Mr Prescott said: "We must argue with the Americans and get them to agree we have to have a global solution and America is a very important part of that solution. So I shall be over there arguing the case again."

He will hold talks in Washington today with the US transportation secretary, Norman Mineta, about aviation policy. He will then fly to New York for a meeting of the UN commission on sustainable development, where he will discuss transport and air quality. There will be no formal discussions on the Kyoto treaty which is not due to be discussed at the UN ministerial level until June.

Mr Prescott played a key role in negotiating the 1997 Kyoto treaty in which the former US vice-president, Al Gore, signed up to a legally binding 5% cut in greenhouse gases by 2010.

The statement yesterday from the environment department indicated that Downing Street's cautious approach to President Bush's rejection of the Kyoto deal has prevailed. One government source said: "There is a strong belief that the more confrontational we are with the US, the less easy it will be for us to influence the US administration."

The government was privately appalled by the abruptness of the US decision to pull out of the Kyoto treaty last month.

The Bush administration's opposition to the treaty was well known. But the force with which it announced its position - abandoning earlier controls on carbon dioxide emissions as not in the interests of the US economy, and with the White House national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, aggressively pronouncing the treaty "dead" - took diplomats by surprise.

"An ill-advised and provocative act of political cowardice," said one senior British diplomat at the time.

fields.headline: 'Less lethal' police arms tested
fields.standfirst:
Home Office reviews latest in alternative weapons to stave off need for beat officers to carry guns

Special report: crime
fields.trailText: Home Office reviews latest in alternative weapons to stave off need for beat officers to carry guns.
fields.body:
The Home Office has amassed an arsenal of new generation weaponry, including electrical stun weapons, rubber ball rounds, laser guns and glue guns, which are being tested for possible use by police forces.

Government officials have requested samples of products from arms manufacturers in Europe and the US in the past six months, amid the concern of chief constables that forces need access to more powerful, "less lethal" weapons, if the drastic step of arming officers with guns is to be avoided.

Among products obtained by the Home Office are an electric stun gun that paralyses the central nervous system, a device that temporarily blinds the target by overloading the optic nerve, and a weapon that fires bean bags filled with lead shot, knocking the target to the ground.

Officials from the defence evaluation and research agency have also travelled to California to investigate a laser that fires an ultra-violet beam that paralyses the subject. Prototypes of the "tetanizing beam weapon", a version of which can disable the electrical system of a car, tank or aeroplane, will be ready for testing within a year.

A Home Office spokeswoman confirmed that Dera and the police scientific development branch were reviewing "the full range" of less lethal technology available, and would select specific weapons for possible deployment to officers.

The weapons being reviewed included water cannon, stun guns, rubber ball rounds and glue weapons.

The Association of Chief Police Officers has pressed for forces to be given access to weapons that have been restricted in the UK but are widely used elsewhere.

CS gas is the only "non-lethal" option for mainland UK forces, although Sussex police last month became the first force to be issued with pepper spray on a trial basis. Nottinghamshire is the only mainland force to arm officers on the beat.

Any new technology would have to be tested and approved by the Home Office, but some forces have been impatient for results. Representatives from Sussex, Nottinghamshire, Lancashire and Hertfordshire constabularies were among delegates at an alternative weapons trade fair in Florida in February.

This month the Northern Ireland Office published a report on the first stage of its own investigation of alternative weaponry. The study was in response to the Patten report on policing, which called for a safer alternative to plastic bullets.

It has examined weapons including chemical sprays, smoke grenades, laser and stun guns, baton rounds and incapacitation devices using nets and glue.

Steve Tuttle, director of government and law enforcement affairs for the laser weapon manufacturers Taser International, said the Home Office late last year had requested two samples of its Advanced Taser M26.

The weapon fires two probes a distance of up to five metres, delivering a 50,000 volt electric shock that sends the victim into a foetal position on the floor.

The company had been trying to interest the Home Office in its product for six years, Mr Tuttle said. He felt that the present trial indicated a change in its attitude to alternative weaponry. "They are now trying to get several of these emerging technologies into the Home Office to see if they are viable."

The human rights organisation Liberty said it welcomed weapons that could reduce the risks to officers and individuals being arrested, but it was concerned about how they would be used. "They have to be accompanied by rigorous training and restrictive guidelines on their use," said a spokesman.

What they might use

Taser
A gun-like device that fires two probes up to 21ft. These can penetrate up to two inches of clothing, before delivering a five second, 50,000 volt electric shock.

Laserdazzler
A laser gun that resembles a torch but temporarily blinds the subject for up to 15 minutes. It fires a random series of green flashes up to 400m, which block out part of the light spectrum. Japanese police might use them for crowd control in the 2002 World Cup.

Bean bag gun
Fires 40g "socks" filled with lead shot, which knock the subject to the ground. Designed to be "non-penetrating" and spread the impact over a wide surface area, delivering a blow comparable to "a punch from a professional boxer". Police in Canada suspended use of the weapon in April 1997 after a man shot by a bean bag round died of blood loss.

Glue guns
Sticky foam, stored under pressure in a canister, expands and hardens extremely rapidly once fired, entangling the subject. Can also be applied to road surfaces to deny access. The gun has a range of 10m and presents a serious risk of suffocation if fired at the nose or mouth.

Tetanizing beam weapon
Immobilises people and animals from a distance by instantly paralysing their skeletal muscles with an ultra-violet ray. The effect is designed to last only a few seconds. Also being developed is a version that could interrupt the electrical systems of a car, tank or plane.

fields.headline: The Pope's record is dreadful but his conviction is heroic
fields.standfirst: Secular government could do with some of his unflinching steadfastness
fields.trailText: Secular government could do with some of his unflinching steadfastness.
fields.body:
En route to the election, I took the path to Rome. For a cradle Catholic, Easter in Rome is the apex of ceremonial experience. The majesty of the religious services at the seat of western Christianity gets close to numinous as well as logistical perfection.

Easter close to Pope John Paul II, on the other hand, made a jarring start to a springtime which will be spent in the company of relativist politicians. Being in the presence of absolute conviction is something one has seldom experienced in the past 20 years. In the end, I decided that what ought to jar a modern voter was less the sight of this conviction than its well-spun, infinitely pliable opposite, which is to be found in every secular politician of the day.

The Pope has been in many ways disastrous. Yet in one way he is heroic. Viewed from close quarters he exudes, even for a liberal sceptic, the aura of a unique being. No one immersed in politics can escape the shock of witnessing the most unfashionable political figure in the world. Those of us destined to spend the next seven weeks in thrall to Tony Blair can see here someone who embodies the one quality every other leader, including not least Mr Blair, conspicuously lacks.

The disasters John Paul II has inflicted on the Catholic church over 20 years in the Vatican would be hard to exaggerate. His record is such an offence against elementary tenets of liberal decency that even a Catholic who has not entirely lost his ability to submit to the church's teaching finds certain particulars intolerable. This papacy has devoted itself to undoing much of the work of the Second Vatican Council, held in the 1960s, and reclaiming for the iron authority of Rome what the council, initiated by a much wiser pope, had begun to yield to wider discourse and less centralised decision.

The repudiations have been numerous. High on my list of them is the church's treatment of women. In his compelling new book, Hans Kung summarises the story: "This pope has waged an almost spooky battle against modern women who seek a contemporary form of life, prohibiting birth control and abortion (even in the case of incest or rape), divorce, the ordination of women and the modernisation of women's religious orders." As a result, writes Kung, countless women have tacitly turned their backs on a church that no longer understands them.

This has happened simultaneously with a fearsome crusade against free speech. Vatican II opened up the possibility of discussion, which the Roman curia, encouraged by the Pope, now ruthlessly suppresses. Liberal theologians, Kung among them, have had their teaching faculties withdrawn.

North America and Europe, Latin America and Asia, are littered with priests and thinkers terrorised by secret process into remaining silent under pain of excommunication. Such is the secrecy that nobody is permitted to know who exactly these are or what is their offence.

In Rome the perpetrators of the modern Inquisition, the curial cardinals led by Joseph Ratzinger, paraded at the ceremonies. From my favourable seat, I found it hard not to gaze on the red-mitred collective with fascinated horror. The imperium now displays itself with practised insouciance, as if nothing could challenge it. Ratzinger, once a liberal colleague of Kung's in a German university, presides over a doctrinal regime that in some ways pre-dates Vatican II, deeming other religions to be beyond possibility of truth, issuing multiple documents that reaffirm the church as patriarchal, intolerant and triumphantly backward-looking.

This performance is as unsuccessful as it has been, in the wider liberal world, aberrant. It has not done the church much good. Not merely is church attendance falling and the priesthood shrinking in Europe and North America, but Rome's former authority is being quietly rejected.

Even 23 years of John Paul II have not been enough to install in every diocese in every country bishops who are prepared to be Rome's mouthpiece. The doctrine of papal infallibility, as propounded by Ratzinger, is widely rejected. In some places, including Britain and the US, only the political cunning of key bishops has preserved the local church from Rome's imperious edicts and thereby retained a core of the faithful.

So the balance-sheet on John Paul's era will, I think, be as red as a cardinal's hat. It looks, functionally and philosophically, doomed. It proposes a degree of absolutism that even Catholics of impeccable loyalty and goodwill cannot reconcile with the modern world.

Hans Kung is very likely right when he ends his book by calling for Vatican III, a new council, to lead the church back towards a simpler, more generous, more authentic Christianity, away from the deadly power-hunger of the Roman bureaucracy, whose control mechanisms put those of all other political organisations to shame.

A nd yet, that doesn't say quite all there is to be said about the Easter experience. The record is appalling, but it's not the end of the story. Looking at John Paul II, homing in on his intimate presence, you're forced to recognise a quality that's missing from political life elsewhere. It hits you with an awful power that here is a leader who brings truly undeviating commitment to principles he believes in.

His intolerance of everyone else is a shocking scar. But the fierceness of his conviction is never now seen in secular government, and we are surely sometimes the worse for it. Here I kneel, he seems to say, and this is the God to whom I devote my life. I'm not interested in your dissent, still less in what opinion polls have to say. I may care how many people fail to get the message, but I'm not prepared to temper it. I declare my beliefs, which will not change. Follow me, or go elsewhere.

Here, in other words, is a holy man; dedicated to his conviction; granite in its expression; a man of character, as Kung admits, an impressive champion of human rights and social justice everywhere except in the church itself; a man seen as more worthy of moral trust, despite that large exception, than almost anybody else in contemporary society.

To have witnessed such a leader close up at this season is decidedly unsettling. It makes one note the statements of belief that the coming election will not yield. Who, any longer, has convictions they won't surrender to the latest focus group? Who will talk about social justice, ready to offend every corporation that violates it? Who will make an unflinching case for asylum-seekers? Who will take on any enemy, and let the votes fall where they may?

Just as the Pope has no divisions, he may need no votes. But there's a part of him that grandly challenges those who do.

· Hans Kung, The Catholic Church, a short history (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £12.99)

This performance is as unsuccessful as it has been, in the wider liberal world, aberrant. It has not done the church much good. Not merely is church attendance falling and the priesthood shrinking in Europe and North America, but Rome's former authority is being quietly rejected. Even 23 years of John Paul II have not been enough to install in every diocese in every country bishops who are prepared to be Rome's mouthpiece. The doctrine of papal infallibility, as propounded by Ratzinger, is widely rejected. In some places, including Britain and the US, only the political cunning of key bishops has preserved the local church from Rome's imperious edicts and thereby retained a core of the faithful. So the balance-sheet on John Paul's era will, I think, be as red as a cardinal's hat. It looks, functionally and philosophically, doomed. It proposes a degree of absolutism that even Catholics of impeccable loyalty and goodwill cannot reconcile with the modern world. Hans Kung is very likely right when he ends his book by calling for Vatican III, a new council, to lead the church back towards a simpler, more generous, more authentic Christianity, away from the deadly power-hunger of the Roman bureaucracy, whose control mechanisms put those of all other political organisations to shame. A nd yet, that doesn't say quite all there is to be said about the Easter experience. The record is appalling, but it's not the end of the story. Looking at John Paul II, homing in on his intimate presence, you're forced to recognise a quality that's missing from political life elsewhere. It hits you with an awful power that here is a leader who brings truly undeviating commitment to principles he believes in. His intolerance of everyone else is a shocking scar. But the fierceness of his conviction is never now seen in secular government, and we are surely sometimes the worse for it. Here I kneel, he seems to say, and this is the God to whom I devote my life. I'm not interested in your dissent, still less in what opinion polls have to say. I may care how many people fail to get the message, but I'm not prepared to temper it. I declare my beliefs, which will not change. Follow me, or go elsewhere. Here, in other words, is a holy man; dedicated to his conviction; granite in its expression; a man of character, as Kung admits, an impressive champion of human rights and social justice everywhere except in the church itself; a man seen as more worthy of moral trust, despite that large exception, than almost anybody else in contemporary society. To have witnessed such a leader close up at this season is decidedly unsettling. It makes one note the statements of belief that the coming election will not yield. Who, any longer, has convictions they won't surrender to the latest focus group? Who will talk about social justice, ready to offend every corporation that violates it? Who will make an unflinching case for asylum-seekers? Who will take on any enemy, and let the votes fall where they may? Just as the Pope has no divisions, he may need no votes. But there's a part of him that grandly challenges those who do. · Hans Kung, The Catholic Church, a short history (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £12.99) hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Time to take a whole-life approach to mental illness

fields.headline: Time to take a whole-life approach to mental illness
fields.standfirst: Mental health service users deserve a treatment strategy that addresses their need for support but allows a certain level of freedom, writes Sandra Banawich
fields.trailText: Comment:Mental health service users deserve a treatment strategy that addresses their need for support but allows a certain level of freedom, writes Sandra Banawich.
fields.body:
Schizophrenia is a serious illness, one that has an impact on every aspect of the sufferer's life. When drawing up a strategy for treatment, we need to address the effects of the illness on a person's life and develop a whole-life strategy.

A whole-life approach should look at the user's relationships and family. It is stressful for relatives to support a mentally ill person, and relationships can break down. In these circumstances, advice on relationships for all members of the family would be helpful, along with support groups or befriending schemes when these relationships are no longer working.

Mental health service users can lead productive, well-ordered lives, if they are given opportunities and support. It is time for the government and mental health service providers to put resources into real choices and opportunities - to commit to providing real inclusion and equal opportunities for the service user, and to protect their human rights.

Of course, treatment and hospitalisation play a vital role under the Mental Health Act 1983 - and are a necessary evil at times. Voluntary treatment in the community, however, gives service users greater control over their own lives and is more beneficial in the long term.

At present, there is a delicate balance of trust and confidence between service users and providers. This could be undermined by government proposals, set out in the recent mental health white paper, for compulsory community treatment.

Where medication is concerned, there should be room for negotiation between the service user and provider. Being allowed to lower or increase medication levels or try different medication is vital in finding a solution that works for the sufferer.

Mental health crisis teams provide valuable support in the community and often prevent the need for hospitalisation. If the government goes ahead with the white paper on mental health, then it must be supported by a commitment from all involved in the mental health field to train service users as advocates and mentors.

Advocates need to have a legally recognised status, which is stronger than next of kin, so that the service users' opinions are heard and carry weight with officials.

Mental health groups, charities and drop-in centres can provide a safe environment for service users - but are we creating a mental health sub-culture? Is this really what we mean by social inclusion?

We need more schemes centred on encouraging the mentally ill to rejoin the rest of society, providing links to community groups, education and employment. Such schemes would offer real opportunities to mental health service users.

 Sandra Banawich was diagnosed with schizophrenia 10 years ago and was treated under section in hospital. She is married with four children and is receiving treatment from a local community mental health team. She is a Labour councillor on St Helens borough council, Merseyside, and a member of Mind.

fields.headline: BBC1: the ratings verdict
fields.standfirst: It is six months since the BBC launched its new-look BBC1 schedule. The Ten O'Clock News looks in great shape, but peaktime has taken hammering
fields.trailText: Jason Deans analyses BBC1 ratings since the introduction of the new-look schedule in October.
fields.body:
Peaktime share down
Since October 16 BBC1 has averaged a 28.6% peaktime share, compared with 30.2% in the equivalent period 12 months earlier. But BBC insiders are quick to point out that peaktime multichannel viewing has been rising over the same period, from 11.1% to a 13.1% audience share.

Ratings up between 9pm and 10pm
Between October 16 2000 and March 25 this year, the average BBC1 audience across this hour has been 6.6m. This is up by 0.8m compared with the equivalent period in 1999-2000. In audience share terms, BBC1 has raised its game between 9pm and 10pm year-on-year from 23.7% to 26.3%.

ITV's performance undented
So far ITV has hardly been affected by the changes to the BBC1 schedule. The network's overall peaktime share over the past six months has been 35.9% - ever so slightly down from the 36.1% it recorded 12 months earlier. And ITV's share of viewing between 9pm and 10pm has actually increased slightly year-on-year, by 0.3% to 35%.

Ten O'Clock News versus News at Ten? A draw
Both BBC1 and ITV can claim credit in the TV news wars. ITV reinstated its News at Ten for an average of three nights a week on January 22. Between then and Monday April 9, 5.1m viewers on average have tuned into both the BBC1 Ten O'Clock News and ITV's late evening bulletins. This, however, includes at least two nights a week when there is no News at Ten on ITV. When the 10.15pm, 10.30pm or 11pm ITV bulletins are taken out of the equation, the result is different, however. When it comes to a head-to-head battle at 10pm, News at Ten comes out on top, averaging 6m viewers.

The Ten O'Clock News versus the Nine O'Clock News? A draw
Overall, going back to the start of the Ten O'Clock News on October 16, the new BBC1 bulletin has still averaged 5.1m viewers - exactly the same as the average for the old Nine O'Clock News in 2000. The BBC claims the figures vindicate its decision to move the news, which was done with the aim of stemming the decline in audiences for the Nine O'Clock News.

Between 1996 and 1999 this bulletin's average audience fell from 6.3m to 5.1m. If the Nine had stayed and this rate of decline had continued between October 2000 and now, the BBC argues, it would have been averaging 4.8m viewers - 300,000 fewer than the Ten over the same period.

fields.headline: The BBC's 9pm winners and losers
fields.standfirst: The BBC's lack of hit drama could mean its peaktime crisis will continue for some time
fields.trailText: The BBC's lack of hit drama could mean the crisis in the peaktime schedule will continue for some time, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC still struggles to bring in the regular 10m plus audiences so often seen by ITV bosses. And its lack of hit drama could mean the crisis in the peaktime schedule will continue for some time.

The average BBC1 audience between 9pm and 10pm since the new-look BBC schedule was introduced on October 22 has been a mere 6.6m compared with ITV's 8.9m.

A number of shows have regularly pulled audiences above that average since the Nine O'Clock News was ditched. But the two top shows have already disappeared from the schedules.

One Foot in the Grave came to its end when Victor Meldrew was run over at Christmas and Caroline Aherne, star and writer of Royle Family has announced she is quitting TV.

And the BBC can't take much comfort from Silent Witness either - it only puts in only occasional appearance in the BBC1 schedule.

The top five BBC1 shows since October are as follows:

1. One Foot in the Grave: 10.7m

2. The Royle Family: 9.3m

3. Silent Witness: 9.3m

4. The Inspector Linley Mysteries: 7.7m

5. NCS: Manhunt: 7.4m

9pm losers

All these series had average audiences below the 5.8m average for the 9pm-10pm slot in the equivalent period in 1999-2000, when the first half hour was still taken up with the Nine O'Clock News.

1. The Human Face: 4.3m

2. Office Gossip: 4.8m

3. Adrian Mole: The Cappuccino Years: 4m

4. The Sins: 5.3m

5. State of the Planet: 4.8m

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror Digital axes 85 staff
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Trinity Mirror Digital has made 85 staff redundancies as part of its month-long 'consultation process', reports Amy Vickers.

Mar 26: ic trouble ahead

Mar 22: Trinity Mirror Digital chief quits

Mar 16: Trinity Mirror cuts back net spend
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror Digital, the troubled internet arm of Trinity Mirror, has made 85 staff redundancies as part of its month-long "consultation process", it emerged today.

The figure may rise to 100 if the technical infrastructure which supports the service is axed.

Problems with the technical platform were partly blamed for the late launch of the Mirror group's internet service and ultimately its demise.

Originally the redundancy figure touted by Trinity was 60, but after a month-long review and the closing of several key websites, that figure has stretched beyond initial estimates.

The news of cutbacks first emerged in mid-March when Trinity closed icShowbiz and icSport and announced it was selling off its internet service provider, ic24.

The Sportinglife website is still up for sale and it is thought it will now be sold as a whole property, rather than as a 50% joint venture with PA.

PA has been keen to move out of the consumer market ever since it was forced into selling Ananova.com last year because of conflicts of interests with its newspaper group shareholders.

Reports have suggested that Tiscali, the pan-European internet service provider, has been in talks with David Clarke, the outgoing managing director of Trinity Mirror Digital, about buying ic24. MediaGuardian.co.uk has learned that Cable & Wireless, the network provider for ic24, is the favourite to take full control of the ISP.

TMD staff that were already on 'gardening leave' were told of their fates earlier last week, after what has been described as a "chaotic but not especially malevolent" consultation process.

According to insiders, most people seemed satisfied with their redundancy terms.

Many of the remaining assets and duties of the now supertrim TMD have been broken up and distributed to regional teams, leaving a skeleton operation based in London.

Trinity Mirror would not comment on the results of the consultation period.

fields.headline: Quiz inquisitors nominated for Baftas
fields.trailText: Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? and The Weakest Link have been shortlisted for best entertainment programme at the Baftas, writes David Brown.
fields.body:
After a year in which quiz shows have dominated our television screens it came as little surprise last night when Bafta revealed that two of the most popular shows have been shortlisted for best entertainment programme.

Chris Tarrant's Who Wants To Be A Millionaire and Anne Robinson's The Weakest Link have shaken up a previously staid format with big money prizes, abrasive presenting styles and eye-watering brutality towards competitors.

Old favourites also make a good showing in the list, with Michael Gambon nominated for best actor for Longitude - the Channel 4 production was also nominated for best drama serial - and Dame Judi Dench up for best actress in Last of the Blonde Bombshells.

But it is the quiz shows that are putting British television on screens across the globe.

Tarrant's show has already become a huge money-spinner for British television, with the format sold to stations across the world. Millions of viewers have watched Tarrant clones grill contestants from India to the United States.

Robinson has gone one better and is appearing herself in the American version of The Weakest Link, which made its debut last night.

But the American critics have proved that they can dish out the rough treatment as well as the presenter.

The Washington Post described the show as "confusing, tiresome and gratuitously snippy." The New York Times derided Robinson's "twittering style" and panned her insults as "innocuous". USA Today said that if the show catches on it would be akin to foot and mouth disease.

The television channel broadcasting the show, NBC, had promoted it with trailers featuring Robinson as a black-clad dominatrix who insults quiz contestants. But the channel appears to have insulted its own viewers by admitting the questions are easier than the British version.

The Bafta also sees the coming of age of reality television, with Channel 4's Big Brother and BBC1's Castaway nominated in the innovation category.

The BBC dominates the shortlist with more than a half of the entries, with ITV lagging behind Channel Four.

Caroline Aherne, who has vowed never to appear on screen again because of media harassment, is shortlisted for best comedy performance in The Royle Family, and the show is nominated for best situation comedy.

Sacha Baron Cohen's streetwise Ali G is nominated for the best comedy show and he is shortlisted for best comedy performance. Have I Got News For You has received nominations for best entertainment performance for both host Angus Deayton and team captain Paul Merton, leaving fellow team captain and Private Eye editor Ian Hislop out in the cold.

Rory Bremner is nominated for best entertainment performance for his satirical look at New Labour in Blair Did it All Go Wrong.

The BBC has picked up all four nominations for best presenter, with David Attenborough, Michael Parkinson, Jeremy Paxman and Louis Theroux. The programmes nominated for best drama series were Clocking Off, BBC1; The Cops, BBC2; Fat Friends, ITV; The Sins, BBC1.

fields.headline: Q&A: Yahoo! and porn
fields.standfirst: Yahoo!'s decision to remove 'adult' material from its website was an attempt to avoid a repeat of last year's 'Nazi auction' scandal. But what's all the fuss about?
fields.trailText: Yahoo!'s decision to remove 'adult' material from its website was an attempt to avoid a repeat of last year's 'Nazi auction' scandal. But what's all the fuss about, asks Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Yahoo! and porn - what's the big deal?
The internet media giant Yahoo! bowed to customer criticism on Good Friday when it agreed to remove all pornography from its shopping and auction channels, as well as reject similar advertising.
Yahoo! said its US site would take a few weeks to remove offending material but that it could still be on sale on its other portals around the world. Yahoo!'s individual country managers have been told to make up their own policy on porn matters, but it is unlikely they will fail to follow the lead of Yahoo! US.

Why was Yahoo! so keen on porn in the first place?
It was the money, stupid. Having been a victim of the current slump in online advertising sales, Yahoo! was hoping it could cash in on one of the internet's most profitable areas - porn.
When the world's media cottoned on to Yahoo!'s plan to expand its revenues from porn, the company initially came back with platitudes such as, "We're taking extra precautions by placing adult merchandise and products behind a secure firewall." To enter 'porn areas' Yahoo users would have to enter their credit card details and verify their age.

What happened?
Just two days after Yahoo! came out in defence of its controversial "Adult and Erotica" store featuring hard-core porn tapes, it caved in to widespread objections and said it would remove all pornography from its shopping and auction services. Within hours, much of the offending material was gone.
Jeff Mallett, Yahoo!'s president and chief operating officer, put a statement up on Yahoo's press website late Friday saying that, "While Yahoo! has offered controlled access to adult products available via the Internet since launching our commerce services more than two years ago, many of our users voiced concerns this week about some of the products sold by merchants on Yahoo! Shopping. We heard them and swiftly responded."

But why did Yahoo! back-pedal?
Because it received a barrage of criticism after the Los Angeles Times ran a piece saying Yahoo! was upping its carriage of porn. Yahoo! clearly didn't want a repeat of last year's Nazi memorabilia fiasco when the auction of weapons, uniforms and recruitment posters on one of its sites landed the internet giant in court, so it quickly did a u-turn to make sure it didn't get back into people's bad books. Yahoo was put in a glaringly uncomfortable spotlight.
The flap over porn came as Yahoo! faced increasing financial woes, staff discontent and headhunting troubles after a number of key executives have quit. It didn't need to become embroiled in a smear campaign.
In the end, it was easier for Yahoo! to simply pull the plug on porn.

Was Yahoo! right to ditch porn?
Morally yes, but commercially no. Yahoo! has been in the financial doldrums of late and with porn being such a strong revenue driver, this would perhaps be the kind of boost Yahoo! needed. A posting on the dot.com death website, Fuckedcompany.com, said it all: "They would have made a shitload of money and the complainers would have stopped caring after two weeks."

webTitle: Reporter injured in Sri Lanka battle

fields.headline: Reporter injured in Sri Lanka battle
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: A Sunday Times journalist has been seriously wounded in a skirmish between government troops and Tamil Tiger separatist guerrillas in Sri Lanka.
fields.body:
A Sunday Times journalist has been seriously wounded in a skirmish between government troops and Tamil Tiger separatist guerrillas in Sri Lanka.

Marie Colvin, 44, a reporter with the paper, suffered shrapnel wounds in her head, chest and arms, after being caught in crossfire during the exchange in the Vavuniya district.

Ms Colvin, an American, had been the first foreign reporter to visit Tamil-held areas since 1995. The Sunday Times editor, John Witherow, said: "She is enormously resourceful, resilient and experienced, and if anybody can cope with an injury then she can.

"Jon Swain is getting a visa to get out there to see what he can do to help. We believe she has been transferred from a military to a civilian hospital, and our aim is to get her to Colombo and into the best hospital as quickly as possible and then to get her home.

"The initial report was that her injuries were quite serious, but later reports from our stringer indicate that the injuries are not as bad as feared."

Ms Colvin was conscious on arrival in hospital yesterday and asked to see a representative of the US embassy in Colombo, said local diplomats.

The Foreign Office said staff at the British high commission were trying to establish the facts of the incident.

In a report in Sunday's paper, Ms Colvin had recorded her difficult journey to reach Tamil Tiger headquarters in Mallawi and described how she risked stepping on land mines.

The violence in which she was injured came only hours before a five day truce between troops and the Tamil Tigers was due to expire.
