webTitle: Bank of Japan says worse is to come

fields.headline: Bank of Japan says worse is to come
fields.standfirst:
Downgrade for national economy amid growing political unease

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Downgrade for national economy amid growing political unease.
fields.body:
The Bank of Japan yesterday added to a growing sense of gloom by downgrading its forecasts on the state of the local economy for the second consecutive month.

The institution cited falling exports and lower industrial production for its negative outlook, which was made worse by new figures showing a downturn in department store spending.

Analysts at the New York headquarters of the investment bank Merrill Lynch said they now anticipated that there would be lower level of growth in gross domestic product in the second and third quarters of the year.

"This means that we expect a technical recession," said Matthew Higgins, a Japanese specialist at the bank.

The bleak assessment by the central bank - which revived a zero interest rate policy last month - comes only days after the Japanese government described the struggling economy - which is still the second largest in the world - as "weakening" for the first time since 1995.

The Bank of Japan's report for the month of April said the country's sales abroad had been hit by the slowdown in the North American and Asian economies.

"Adjustments in economic activity have been under way as production is declining, reflecting a fall in exports," it concluded. The bank highlighted a further weakening of industrial output activity alongside a growing need for inventory adjustments and a slowing in the growth of corporate earnings.

Business sentiment was, according to the bank, "worsening, particularly in manufacturing industries". It predicted that there would be a prolonged deceleration in overseas economies.

The central bank also warned of deflationary pressures piling up but took heart from an anticipated future bounceback in the North American economy.

Its immediate concern about falling production compared with March's report, which talked about the recovery in Japan's economy "coming to a pause" due to lower exports.

Meanwhile, the Japan Department Stores Association said sales throughout the Tokyo area had fallen 0.6% in March from a year earlier to ¥189.9bn (£1bn).

Economic figures published earlier showed Japanese exports falling 1.3% in February, down from a rise of 2.9% in January and double-digit gains last year.

The rapidly slowing economy is bad news for the four contenders in the ruling Liberal Democratic party's presidential election. The poll for the office of prime minister takes place on April 24.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Reckitt chief receives £2.7m
fields.body:
Reckitt chief receives £2.7m

Bart Becht, chief executive of household products group Reckitt Benckiser, has been awarded a £2.7m remuneration package.

Mr Becht, who took over the top job when Reckitt and Colman merged with Dutch group Benckiser two years ago, picked up a £1.62m performance bonus, on top of his annual salary of £650,000. He also received relocation expenses of £300,000 and £28,000 of benefits. In addition a contribution of nearly £100,000 was made to his pension.

The scale of the bonus is bound to attract criticism, in the wake of the £2.5m "thank you" payment made to four Royal Bank of Scotland directors for winning control of NatWest after a long takeover battle.

Reckitt Benckiser, whose brands include Harpic, Brasso and Calgon, pointed out that Mr Becht had met and exceeded three performance targets, including growth in net revenue, a rise in net income and a reduction in working capital.

Reckitt Benckiser's share price has doubled since March 2000 and pre-tax profits rose from £289m to £391m last year.

AirMedia plans Europe growth

AirMedia, a technology firm that provides wireless solutions to businesses, has bucked the negative trend surrounding the sector and received $13.5m (£9.4m) in third round funding.

The American firm, which recently launched in Britain, will use the money to expand into Germany, France, Italy and Spain.

"Our technology helps companies to develop an independent wireless presence available on all mobile networks at a much lower level of investment than traditionally associated with developing a wireless portal," the company said. AirMedia, which is backed by Citigroup Investments, has not yet reached profitability.

Campell's 50s brand remixed

The maker of one of the US's most iconic brands, Campbell's soup, yesterday announced plans it hopes will revitalise its stagnant business. It is to separate its soup unit from its other businesses - drinks, sauces, cookies and crackers - and has replaced the soup business's chief.

But US analysts were unimpressed. Bank of America's soup watcher said Campbell's had one big problem - that its soup was of the condensed variety: "It's a 1950s kind of product - low in quality and inconvenient".

First 3G call for Vodafone

Vodafone UK yesterday made Britain's first live voice call over its third generation network.

The call was made yesterday over the telecom firm's initial 3G network of 30 radio base stations in the Thames Valley. The company has been rolling out its 3G network - the licence for which cost it €6bn - since autumn 2000.

webTitle: M&S takes axe to its top table

fields.headline: M&S takes axe to its top table
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is understood to be planning a top-level management reshuffle as it struggles to rediscover its winning formula.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is understood to be planning a top-level management reshuffle as it struggles to rediscover its winning formula.

The revamp will focus on amalgamating the two boards that run the business. The changes are likely to be announced when M&S reports its annual profits on May 22.

The ailing store chain is also expected to name two new design heads this week. It is bringing them in to oversee womenswear and menswear, in an attempt to win back dissatisfied customers and halt the recent slide in sales.

A senior insider has estimated that women's clothing sales have fallen by up to 25% in recent weeks. The design duo, both of whom are being brought in from outside the M&S group, are currently in the final stages of contract negotiations.

Womenswear, which is crucial to any turnaround at M&S, has proved to be a bigger problem than M&S first had thought. Over the past 18 months the group has repeatedly stated that its new ranges would be winners, only to see shoppers spurn them.

In December, according to internal M&S documents, the retailer was expecting womenswear sales to be £1.3bn this year, some £70m less than last year. It cut prices by more than £60m to generate more sales, but the move generated only £12m as customers were still not tempted to buy.

Its menswear ranges have performed equally badly. Sales there are forecast to be 10% down on last year's level, at £800m. Prices in that department were cut by more than £32m, but profits still slid by £17m.

The chairman, Luc Vandevelde, who remains under pressure over a potential £800,000 bonus, admitted at the weekend that he was considering a change in the boardroom structure.

If a reshuffle goes ahead it will be the third in two years. In the past two-and-a-half years the board has been almost completely replaced. Only the finance director, Robert Colville, remains and he is retiring in the summer.

At present M&S has a main executive board and a UK retail board. The main board oversees British and international operations, marketing and strategy.

It comprises Mr Colville, chief operating officer Roger Holmes, strategy director David Norgrove and Alan McWalter from marketing alongside Mr Vandevelde and the non-executive directors. None of the directors has any clothing or fashion expertise.

The UK retail board, chaired by Mr Holmes, includes the seven business unit directors (Buds) along with supply chain, finance and personnel managers, and the newly-appointed creative director, Yasmin Yusuf. The new heads of womenswear and menswear design will report to the Buds.

With M&S committed to closing the group's international operations it is now regarded as unnecessary to have two boards. Shareholders will welcome the move to a more streamlined boardroom, but are likely to be less happy that Mr Vandevelde still has no plans to put a clothing expert on the top table.

webTitle: Notebook: Irritants have a right to be heard

fields.headline: Business has to fight its corner
fields.standfirst: Irritants have a right to be heard
fields.trailText: Green activists meeting in Australia yesterday declared war on oil companies. Animal rights groups converge on Oxford today in protest at Yamanouchi. The Co-op bank is polling its customers on ethical issues, and later this week BP faces shareholder resolutions on human rights issues in Tibet.
fields.body:
Green activists meeting in Australia yesterday declared war on oil companies. Animal rights groups converge on Oxford today in protest at Yamanouchi. The Co-op bank is polling its customers on ethical issues, and later this week BP faces shareholder resolutions on human rights issues in Tibet.

These protests are led by single issue groups and appear to have nothing in common - although perhaps they are united in a wider sense as voices of opposition against globalisation and corporate power. Some of their aims might be misguided and some of their means are certainly questionable, but less and less are they being dismissed in boardrooms as the lunatic fringe.

This week's sheer number of events show it is only the foolhardy who delegate corporate and social responsibility to the unpopular personnel manager who needs a new post.

As government power wanes, there are growing demands and expectations from both consumers and shareholders alike for high ethical standards and social responsibility in the corporate sector.

Investors, both individual and institutional, are increasingly being targeted by activists as a way of winning a corporate change of tack. Protesters, too, have found the soft corporate underbelly of the bottom line.

Not for nothing did Greenpeace recently organise its first business seminar for City institutions. And it was not held in a dusty university lecture hall, but at shiny clean offices of the London Stock Exchange.

The call for a boycott against Exxon-Mobil was made at an inaugural global greens conference where delegates from 60 countries resolved to "send a message" to Big Oil.

They blame Exxon and others for helping persuade US president George Bush to dump the Kyoto treaty on global warming. No details of planned protests have been drawn up, but activists remember how Royal Dutch-Shell was driven to drop plans to abandon the Brent Spar platform at sea after petrol station demonstrations.

Today's action against Yamanouchi by Stop Huntingdon Life Sciences appears to be built on questionable information - in that Yamanouchi have not even confirmed whether they are involved in animal experimentation of the kind of which they are accused. But the activist action threatens not only to drive Huntingdon out of business but also puts at risk £1bn worth of new Japanese investment as well as damaging the whole biotech sector in this country.

BP on Thursday is under assault from the Free Tibet campaign along with Greenpeace and a range of other non-governmental organisations over a range of issues, from human rights to the environment.

The various different motions will require 75% of shareholders to vote for them at the annual meeting - so there is next to zero chance of any of them being adopted.

They are no doubt seen as an irritant, and BP chief executive Sir John Browne has questioned the standing of some pressure groups. But Sir John, hailed in many quarters as Britain's top industrialist, will also argue that these groups have a right to make their case.

As he told a conference in Cambridge recently: "If international companies are to succeed ... they have to listen, understand and argue their case with anyone at anytime."

Overrated

A new mystery has emerged in the world of finance, where the major players are masters in the black arts of confusion and cunning - and it is the overdraft rate.

The £150m a year in interest charges for overdrafts current account customers is probably an underestimate. This covers only authorised overdrafts, and does not attempt to calculate the unjustifiable cost of a little or occasional overindulgence.

But, a fraction of the truth is starting to come out. There is absolutely no connection between the price of your over draft and the official bank lending rate. The only science deployed by the banks is monitoring their rivals to see what they can get away with.

However, when - along with your rivals - you control 70% of the market, this is a very effective pricing policy.

It is certainly something that Denise Kingsmill at the competition commission should be interested in.

Her remit is only to look at the implications of Lloyds TSB taking over Abbey National. But even that limited brief will be enough to show further inquiry is justified.

Current account users have the ultimate power to swiftly whip the banks into more competitive - that is, lower - charging. If we all voted with our feet and took our overdrafts to one of the newer players which do charge less for dipping an occasional toe into the red, the big boys would soon be forced to do the decent thing.

webTitle: Citigroup and Bank of America feel profits squeeze

fields.headline: Citigroup and Bank of America feel profits squeeze
fields.trailText: Citigroup, the world's largest financial services group, reported an 8% decline in net income yesterday as a result of investment losses and lower earnings from corporate advisory work.
fields.body:
Citigroup, the world's largest financial services group, reported an 8% decline in net income yesterday as a result of investment losses and lower earnings from corporate advisory work.

At the same time, Bank of America, the third-largest US bank, suffered a 17% fall in net profits after increasing its provisions for bad loans.

Shares in Citigroup and BoA fell as Wall Street, after showing initial relief that the numbers were not worse, absorbed the long-term implications.

The first quarter of this year was the slowest for new share offerings, on which banks earn brokerage and advisory fees, in more than 10 years.

Declining stock markets also hit the value of investment portfolios held by banks while struggling corporations deferred loan payments.

The quarter was also measured against last year, the height of the stock market boom.

Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that Citigroup's results in particular "demonstrated the value of [its] diversification in a tough environment".

Citigroup reported net income of $3.5bn (£2.4bn) in the quarter, down 8% after investment losses and restructuring charges were taken into account.

The losses outweighed a strong performance at the company's US credit card business and global consumer finance division.

Salomon Smith Barney, the group's investment banking business, also performed well with its European division increasing market share after advising on several large transactions, such as France Télécom's $16.4bn corporate bond issue.

Sandy Weill, chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, said: "This is precisely the kind of market that demonstrates the power of our franchise."

Increased provisions for bad loans hurt Bank of America, which is one of the largest unsecured creditors to PG&E, the Californian utility which filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month.

The North Carolina-based bank posted a first-quarter profit of $1.87bn, down from $2.24bn last year, after almost doubling its provision for credit losses to $835m in the period.

Net charge-offs, loans for which the bank does not expect to recover payment, rose to $772m in the quarter from $420m a year ago.

Gains from equity investments also fell $416m in the quarter, prompting a 2% decline in overall revenues.

Hugh McColl is to step down next week after 20 years at the head of Bank of America.

Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that Citigroup's results in particular "demonstrated the value of [its] diversification in a tough environment". Citigroup reported net income of $3.5bn (£2.4bn) in the quarter, down 8% after investment losses and restructuring charges were taken into account. The losses outweighed a strong performance at the company's US credit card business and global consumer finance division. Salomon Smith Barney, the group's investment banking business, also performed well with its European division increasing market share after advising on several large transactions, such as France Télécom's $16.4bn corporate bond issue. Sandy Weill, chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, said: "This is precisely the kind of market that demonstrates the power of our franchise." Increased provisions for bad loans hurt Bank of America, which is one of the largest unsecured creditors to PG&E, the Californian utility which filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month. The North Carolina-based bank posted a first-quarter profit of $1.87bn, down from $2.24bn last year, after almost doubling its provision for credit losses to $835m in the period. Net charge-offs, loans for which the bank does not expect to recover payment, rose to $772m in the quarter from $420m a year ago. Gains from equity investments also fell $416m in the quarter, prompting a 2% decline in overall revenues. Hugh McColl is to step down next week after 20 years at the head of Bank of America.

fields.headline: Activists target HLS associate
fields.trailText: Rights activists today are threatening to converge on the Oxford research labs of Yamanouchi as the campaign against animal testing begins a new chapter.
fields.body:
Rights activists today are threatening to converge on the Oxford research labs of Yamanouchi as the campaign against animal testing begins a new chapter.

Yamanouchi faces further demonstrations at its West Byfleet offices on Thursday and a world day of action on May 25. Those targeting the company admit, however, that they are unsure of the exact role of the Tokyo-based company in animal testing.

Yamanouchi is in the firing line because it is thought to be carrying out experiments in the US at the laboratories of Huntingdon Life Sciences, the British-based company activists want to drive out of business.

The campaign organised by Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty, or Shac, is being coordinated on the internet. The Shac website reads: "Whilst Huntingdon Life Sciences kill 500 animals every single day in their lab we will target their customers."

The activists claim they have written to Yamanouchi to ask about its involvement in animal experiments but received no reply.

webTitle: Slow demand forces Intel to cut Pentium 4 prices

fields.headline: Slow demand forces Intel to cut Pentium 4 prices
fields.trailText: Intel, the world's largest semiconductor chip maker, slashed prices yesterday as a suspected slump in demand prompted a sell-off in its shares.
fields.body:
Intel, the world's largest semiconductor chip maker, slashed prices yesterday as a suspected slump in demand prompted a sell-off in its shares.

Shares in the California-based company were down 5% to $26.62 (£18.50) yesterday morning after a leading analyst issued a profits downgrade because of slowing demand. Intel's shares have fallen from a 52-week high of $75 last September. Prices of Intel's powerful Pentium 4 chips were cut by up to 19% yesterday as part of its attempt to stimulate demand. Several Wall Street analysts believe that yesterday's cuts - part of a monthly pricing review - will be followed by even more drastic changes before the month ends.

Dan Niles, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, is among those who believe that prices for various Pentium 4 models could be cut by up to 60%.

The changes are expected to spark a bitter price war in the semiconductor market, which has been hit hard by the sharp downturn in demand for hi-tech products.

Analysts fear the price cuts will harm margins and fail to stimulate sufficient demand to compensate for the downturn.

Ashok Kumar, an analyst at US Bancorp Piper Jaffray, said: "It's going to have a catastrophic impact on gross margins."

Intel regularly cuts prices to avoid stock build-ups as new products come on to the market. But a 60% cut in a month would be the sharpest for years at Intel, which controls more than 80% of the world's microprocessor market.

The gloomy outlook for the chip industry prompted a sell-off in technology shares yesterday. At noon, the Nasdaq composite index was off 31 points at 1,930, erasing some of last week's 14% gain.

Seth Walker, an Intel spokesman, confirmed yesterday's price cuts but refused to discuss any future announcements. The company is expected to launch a 1.7GHz Pentium 4 chip later this month. The launch of more powerful chips is typically followed by price-cuts in slower models.

Intel issued the latest of a series of profits warnings last month when it announced 5,000 job cuts around the world. Falling demand from some of the world's largest computer manufacturers and a slowing economy have hit the company's profits.

Mark Edelstone, analyst at Morgan Stanley, slashed his earnings outlook on Intel and the rest of the chip sector for this year and next on the eve of Intel's quarterly results, due out today.

The leading Wall Street analyst cut his earnings estimate by 25% from 60 cents to 45 cents for the current year.2222

webTitle: Prescott to revive open skies debate

fields.headline: Prescott to revive open skies debate
fields.trailText: John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, is to meet the US transport secretary today for the first time, in an effort to reopen fractious talks between the two countries on transatlantic air travel.
fields.body:
John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, is to meet the US transport secretary today for the first time, in an effort to reopen fractious talks between the two countries on transatlantic air travel.

Mr Prescott and Norman Minetta, his opposite number in the US, are expected to discuss the issue of an open skies deal.

Sources close to the British government say that Mr Prescott will seek to force the issue back on to the agenda after reaffirming interest in doing a deal. Talks between the two sides, which have been going on for years, reached a dead end under the Clinton administration amid disagreement on several issues.

Some large American airlines have lobbied for access to Heathrow, while British Midland wants to offer flights to the US. Under the current transatlantic alliance, only four airlines - British Airways, Virgin, United and American Airlines - are allowed to offer direct flights between the two countries using Britain's largest airport.

Mr Prescott is understood to be keen to start discussing a deal to broaden the agreement.

BA, which has more slots at Heathrow than any other airline, is reluctant to relinquish its dominance. In recent months the company has put on the back burner its plans for a closer alliance with American Airlines, because the likely cost of an agreement - giving up lucrative slots at Heathrow - was considered too high.

However, Mr Prescott may seek a mini-deal which would involve British Midland and one US airline.

A brief statement about air transport featured in the joint communique issued by Tony Blair and George Bush after their Camp David talks earlier this year.

Mr Prescott, who is expected to spend 24 hours in Washington on his way to environmental conferences in New York, will also meet the head of the US federal aviation authority and a transport spokesman for the Democrats.

webTitle: Paint misbehaving Crazy name, crazy show?

fields.headline: Paint misbehaving Crazy name, crazy show?
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones checks out Death to the Fascist Insect that Preys on the Life of the People
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones checks out Death to the Fascist Insect that Preys on the Life of the People
fields.body:
The Rokeby Venus has had a few adventures. When Velazquez painted her in the mid-17th century in Catholic Spain, she had to be hung discreetly away from Inquisitorial eyes, and she was still under wraps 150 years later when the Duchess of Alba gave her as a present to Spain's first minister. He kept Venus and Cupid, as the painting was then called, in a private room of saucy art that also contained a painting apparently conceived as a parody of it: Goya's Naked Maja (1800).

Velazquez's nude came to Britain in 1813, to hang at Rokeby Hall in Yorkshire, and then in 1906 was purchased for the National Gallery and for the first time went on permanent public view. The consequences were catastrophic. At 11am on March 10, 1914, a woman was seen to stare at the Rokeby Venus for some time and the next minute set about "hacking furiously at the painting with a chopper which, it is assumed, she had concealed under her jacket". This was the Suffragette Mary Richardson, protesting at the treatment of Emmeline Pankhurst in Holloway prison but adding in 1952: "I didn't like the way men visitors gawped at it all day long."

Repaired, celebrated, recently reframed and certainly not shocking any more, the Rokeby Venus hangs today in state - only to be subjected to one more ignominy, one more act of vandalism. The painter Nicholas Barker has copied it, emulating the luxuriant, silky brushstrokes, get ting the structure, if not the precise texture, of the painting just right; then, over Venus, he has spliced in a nastily pornographic 1970s centrefold model. While the copied details from Velazquez are aged, rich, Old Masterish, the Playmate's skin is sleek, fetishy, with the coldness of a photograph.

Barker's vandalised Old Masters are the most immediately striking things in an exhibition that claims "to inject some life into the dead dog of painting". The show is called Death to the Fascist Insect that Preys on the Life of the People and is curated by painter and self-publicist Martin Maloney. And it has definitely got something going for it: vulgarity. In Britain now avant-garde art is the new religion, and when you go to Tate Modern it's clear what the prime relics are, those Minimalist objects by Don Judd and Carl Andre. Then you look at what's on in London'sEast End and it seems every young artist is trying to make a statement more coolly restrained than the last. Bad taste is sorely lacking from today's art scene.

Maloney's claims to be spokesman for a generation are pretty much exhausted, given the critical condemnation of his last outing, Die Young Stay Pretty at the ICA, and his close involvement in Charles Saatchi's Neurotic Realism. This time, however, he seems to have his tongue in his cheek. The show's silly title is a piss-take of the very idea of an avant-garde storming the bastions, driving the fascist insects out of the castle of high culture, and so on. The very location of the show is a travesty of the rhetoric of the East End. It takes place in a crumbling, abandoned building with lots of neglected space for young artists to colonise. But this building is in the heart of the West End and is owned by the international art dealer Anthony d'Offay and is to be converted into a hi-tech art space by Sir Norman Foster. Maloney has short-circuited the avant-garde fantasies of contemporary art - the dance of small spaces and big dealers - admitting right off that the tough rhetoric is phoney.

Do Maloney and co reanimate the corpse of painting? It's embarrassing to look at Barker's canvases. In addition to the Velazquez he exhibits personal tributes to two Titian masterpieces, the Penitent Magdalen and the Venus of Urbino, both in the Uffizi in Florence. The warmly painted skin of Titian's Venetian beauties is replaced by the intensely tanned, hard flesh of porn stars; the titillating way in which Titian reveals Mary Magdalen's nipples through her long hair is brought crassly to the point by Baker's centrefold with her Farrah Fawcett hair. The jokes are in the details: the oaky, undulating locks of the Magdalen are contrasted with the airbrushed lifeless hair of the model; the Magdalen's hand on her heart is replaced by the model's hand next to her crotch. But can you look long enough to notice these parallels?

Painting has been going on for too long, is too saturated in convention and tradition, ever to be truly "youthful" or "in-your-face". To paint is to do some thing recherché, not to mention bourgeois, and the lengths to which contemporary artists go in order to make painting hip, abolishing every colour but one, copying images from Vogue, only make painting look more foolish, more vulnerable. Painters can't paint as if they were the first painter in the way that it's possible to make videos as if you were the first video artist. Painters need to paint as if they were the last painter, relating themselves to everything that has gone before. This is why painting worth its salt is never restrained. It's tasteless in its consumption and vomiting of the past. Goya parodies Velazquez, and Nicholas Barker parodies Goya parodying Velazquez.

The significance of the tangled story of Velazquez's Rokeby Venus is that it once troubled its viewers; and the history of modern art is of painters becoming bolder in their attempts to do this and make painting live. Manet's Olympia, the prostitute replacing Velazquez's Venus, is one of the modernist paintings Barker recapitulates; and then there's Cézanne's Modern Olympia and Courbet's The Origin of the World. All this is in Barker's ugly, imposing pictures.

It's in Elizabeth Neal's crass pop collage-paintings too, which fill a room with body parts, tabloid headlines and the mentality of someone spray-painting obscenities under a motorway bridge. And in Kirsten Glass's pictures, which reek of a teenager's bedroom with their cut-up magazine faces and sexy daydreams. These pictures are tacky, but that's evocative of the history of painting, the sillier uses to which painting has always been put. Fragonard painted ridiculous erotic scenarios too.

Martin Maloney may be pushy but at least he appears to like art, and so do the painters he promotes here. Martin McGinn's Iceland, a vast perspective view down an aisle of the frozen-food store, is not nearly as dull as it sounds. Actually, you could look at it for hours. This is because it is made of receding planes of creamy paint whose luxury of texture and colour - golds, crimsons, olive green, flesh pink, the purest white - intimates deliberately, and rather more subtly than Barker, the glory of Velazquez. Even the scale and recessive grandeur of the space is a restaging of Velazquez's Las Meninas. Instead of the king and queen, whose faces we see in the mirror at the back of Velazquez's painted room, we see at the end of the aisle a man in shirt and tie with no face, just a blank disc.

But the stars of the show are a collective of eight painters who call themselves Hobbypopmuseum. They come from various parts of Europe, live in London and have created something truly excessive, a sprawling, ludicrous installation of big, loosely painted canvases. They give you a satisfaction that only grows with time. This palace of painted surfaces, wrapped around pillars as well as dominating the walls, is easy to dismiss as derivative. It's obviously indebted to the late painter and prankster Martin Kippenberger. It also pays homage to Gainsborough in its louche landscapes, Daumier in its caricatures conjured in a couple of brushstrokes, Tiepolo in its decorative magnificence. There are painted tower blocks that remind you again of what a pointless artist Julian Opie is as they take his banal architectural motifs and breathe life into them.

Once you get past the jokey profusion, you notice that these painters can paint. The terrorists, planes held at airports and interrogation rooms on which their imaginations immaturely feast have a sensual presence; the hooded figure marching across one canvas with a machine gun looks like a Republican mural if it had been painted by a French Impressionist.

Promiscuous and in poor taste, this is a visual pleasure, which is what painting is supposed to be. It's easy to imagine one of the Hobbypop artists turning out to be a real painter, a brash eater of art history. Nothing about this show justifies premature celebrations of painting's resurrection, but at least it presents work that is literate in its own traditions, and therefore has a chance of a future.

 At the Anthony d'Offay Gallery, 6 Haunch of Venison Yard, London W1 (020-7499 4100), until May 5. The Rokeby Venus is at The National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885).

webTitle: 'There's a wall blocking new music, and sometimes it feels as if I'm banging my head against it'

fields.headline: 'There's a wall blocking new music, and sometimes it feels as if I'm banging my head against it'
fields.standfirst: Composer Colin Matthews talks to  Stephen Moss
fields.trailText: Composer Colin Matthews talks to Stephen Moss
fields.body:
There is a fax machine in the toilet of Colin Matthews's house in Wandsworth, south London, and a large pile of recent communications. Their location is open to several interpretations, but the one I prefer is that Matthews is always active, working, thinking of ways to propagate contemporary music in his many guises. As composer, teacher, administrator and record producer, he has taken on a task that would have given Sisyphus pause for thought.

After all, we don't even know what to call this music: "new", "serious", "contemporary classical"? Record companies are often loath to commit it to disc. Orchestras seem happy to give first performances, but how many will play new pieces thereafter? Audiences are small. Few composers, even those as established as Matthews, can make a living from their compositions alone. Where contemporary music is concerned, we deny ourselves context and continuity: we label it difficult but its difficulties stem from our unwillingness to engage with it. It is a vicious circle that only we, the prospective audience, can break.

"Sometimes I feel composers have no role whatsoever," Matthews once said, after the hostile reaction to the performance of Harrison Birtwistle's Panic at the 1995 Proms. "If we withdrew our labour, nobody would notice, and quite a few people would give a cheer." That bleak statement is hard to square with the evangelising Matthews, who produces records of British contemporary music on the NMC label, helps run the Holst and Britten estates, and has been made professor of composition at the Royal College of Music - and so it proves. The panic seems to have passed.

"Most of the things I do are attempts to break through the wall blocking contemporary music," he explains. "That's the reason I got NMC going. I'm optimistic that the wall will get broken through, but sometimes it does feel as if you're banging your head against it. I don't know whether it's our fault or because music is now so available: we're fighting for shelf space in a way that has never happened before. And composers have become a different breed. The composer of the 19th century was always a performer, and contemporary music was the only music that was played."

I first met Matthews last autumn at a play-through of a new piece called Continuum, commissioned by the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group and financed under its "sound investors" scheme. Matthews was meeting his backers, and there was great warmth between them. Even though the piece, only 10 days or so from its premiere, was not quite complete, the shareholders evidently had confidence in the creative director.

Matthews wrote about the genesis of Continuum for the magazine Areté last year. What is intriguing about his account is how discontinuous the process of composition was. The piece evolved over three years, interrupted by other commitments - adjudicating a composers' competition in Jerusalem, supervising the recording of Anthony Payne's reconstruction of Elgar's Third Symphony, and a disastrous couple of months working on the score for the Hugh Hudson film My Life So Far, only for Miramax to drop it and commission a new score from Howard Blake.

Matthews was also simultaneously working on three other commissions, including one fraught with danger - the addition of Pluto to Holst's Planets. Would audience or critics forgive such heresy? Happily for Matthews, they did. Once the media had stoked the fires of controversy, he expected to be booed at the premiere last May, but the piece was encored and has been well received in subsequent performances.

Like Continuum, Matthews's Horn Concerto, which will be premiered at the Royal Festival Hall on Sunday, also had a prolonged birth. "It was commissioned in the mid-1990s, and I did a lot of work then, but the premiere was postponed. I did a lot of sketching in 1997, then tied the sketches up and didn't reopen them until last November. I was horrified: they were awful." While the shape of the piece and some of the ideas have survived, he had to start the music itself more or less from scratch.

That separation of intellectual impulse and musical realisation is characteristic of Matthews. "I do think of things visually and architecturally," he says. "It's a failing in some ways, and it probably reflects the fact that my background is not particularly musical. I never went through the normal academic mill and I can't just let the music come out; it has to be constructed. But that can be an advantage because I come in at a rather odd angle."

Matthews makes a similar point when he refers to his early affinity with Michael Tippett. "Tippett sometimes seems to be almost struggling to find the notes, and I found that very inspiring, particularly the music from The Midsummer Marriage onwards to the late 1960s. After that, the notes were coming more easily, and the music tails off as a result."

Matthews taught himself to compose. He and his elder brother David, who is also a composer, grew up in Leytonstone, east London. They learned piano and decided to throw themselves into composing in their early teens. Their lives have developed in parallel ever since: both studied classics at Nottingham University before formally studying composition; both worked with Benjamin Britten, and both helped Carl Davis on scores for silent films such as The Wind. The brothers remain close, occasionally collaborate, and now live about a mile apart.

"It's an odd relationship but it's never been adversarial," says Colin, at 55 the younger by three years. "We've always felt encouraged by the other's success. Coming from a non-musical background, there was no reason that either of us should have become composers, let alone both of us, so there's been a strength in that."

The teenage Colin must have been frighteningly intense. At 14, already a Mahlerian, he heard Deryck Cooke's "performing version" of Mahler's 10th Symphony on the radio (the composer had left only sketches of the work on his death). Matthews borrowed a score, studied it, and wrote to Cooke pointing out errors and infelicities. "Amazingly, instead of slapping me on the head and telling me to go away, he said that no one had ever written anything quite like that before and that he welcomed the comments," Matthews recalls. "I went to meet him, we talked for hours and from then on it became a collaboration."

The collaboration lasted 10 years as Cooke prepared the score for publication. "We had to take what Mahler left in the state he left it," says Matthews. "Deryck was adamant that there would be no recomposition. You could add detail, but it was a rule that nothing would be changed, even where it was obvious that Mahler had been working in extreme haste."

Towards the end of this period, Matthews began working with Britten, copying scores and later, as Britten became weaker physically, as his amanuensis. "He didn't really like talking about music," says Matthews, "though in the last three years of his life his personality changed and I was able to talk much more freely to him. He was aware that I was a composer and asked to see some pieces of mine, which was generous because he didn't normally do that.

"He had had a heart operation, which left him with a weakness on his right side. He could only play the piano with his left hand, so he asked me to come and play things through for him. That went on until his death [in 1976], and I took over the orchestration of his last two pieces." In 1980, Matthews became a trustee of the Britten foundation, and later became chairman of the Britten estate.

Matthews's work with Britten in Aldeburgh also brought him into contact with Imogen Holst, who was editing her father's work, and the two collaborated until her death in 1984. He became director of the Holst foundation, and over the past 20 years his income as a paid administrator for the two estates has, he says, allowed him to survive as a composer. Without it, he would have had to concentrate on film and TV work. His experience on My Life So Far suggests that was a fate he did well to avoid.

fields.headline: Plain sailing
fields.standfirst: Starsailor have been tipped as the most exciting band since Coldplay. Has that been a curse or a blessing, asks  Dave Simpson
fields.trailText: Starsailor have been tipped as the most exciting band since Coldplay. Has that been a curse or a blessing, asks Dave Simpson
fields.body:
Jamie Walsh remembers his foray into acting. "I was doing musical theatre at college and I had to play Seymour in Little Shop of Horrors. I could hear the teachers saying, 'He's got to play the lead because he's got such a good voice. But is there some way we could work round it so he doesn't have to do any acting? He's absolutely terrible.' "

Four years later, theatre-lovers can rest easy. Walsh, 20, is putting his voice to use as a singer, and his band are the hottest property in British rock. At the start of this year almost every music publication in the land predicted great things for Wigan boys Starsailor, dubbed "the new Coldplay" before they had even released a record. They have now been on the cover of NME, done Top of the Pops and joined the Brats tour of rising new bands. Starsailor's label, EMI, said it would be "delighted" if their first release entered the top 100; in the event, the Fever EP went in at 18. The next single, Good Souls - an uplifting, electric affair that should dispel associations with the morose new acoustic movement - deserves to do even better.

"It's been insane," says Walsh, who has a hushed speaking voice but sings in a hurricane falsetto. "But because everything's happened so quickly, it's been easier to keep our feet on the ground. We're still the same people." And perhaps that's true, since none of the hyperbole has come from Starsailor themselves. "You get bands who shout from the rooftops about how good they are, but deep down they tend to be the most unconfident, with no real ability whatsoever," says Walsh. "Terris said they were going to make the best album ever. How can you follow that? It's just putting extra pressure on yourselves. We tend to keep quiet, because we know we're doing our best."

Drummer Ben Byrne and bassist James Stelfox have been playing together since the age of nine, when Stelfox was given a bass by his father, and formed the band with Walsh four years ago at a Wigan college for drama and music. They played "horrible" gigs across the north-west with various guitarists, under names such as Waterface or Morph. The present name came from an album by Tim Buckley, father of singer-songwriter Jeff, to whom they are often compared.

"I love Jeff Buckley," Walsh admits. "You have to be honest about you're inspired by. But my songs start off a lot more Buckley than they finish. I have so much respect, I'd never try to copy him."

Seeing the Verve at their Wigan Haigh Hall gig in 1998 was a turning point for Walsh. However, while noting the ambition of the hometown headliners, he was particularly drawn to the support act, folk-rocker John Martyn. "He got the worst reception I've ever seen," Walsh remembers. "They were throwing bottles of piss at him! But he had real soul."

Starsailor's line-up was completed last year when Barry Westhead joined on keyboards. Shortly afterwards, Byrne, Stelfox and Walsh (who now does guitar duties) moved into the same house, where they live with their roadie, Les, who "drinks like a fish and has one lung. It's like the Monkees."

This being the rock world, things could go wrong any minute. But for the moment Starsailor are on a roll. Walsh has had a marriage proposal, the band already have a stalker and they have undergone the attentions of record company stylists after turning up to a video shoot looking like tramps. More importantly, they have enough killer tunes to cause Coldplay and others a few sleepless nights.

"It helps that we're all close friends," says Stelfox. "You look around and there's three of your best mates with you."

Are they comfortable with being styled? "I'm comfortable with it all," insists Walsh. "I've always dreamed of singing in a band and everything that goes with it. I've never had any desire to do anything else."

 Good Souls is out on Chrysalis/EMI next Monday.

webTitle: Frenzy to find treasure that could pay Thai debt

fields.headline: Frenzy to find treasure that could pay Thai debt
fields.trailText: Acting on nothing more than a tale from an elderly monk, an army of Thai government officials, soldiers and labourers yesterday began a treasure hunt for a stash of booty from the time of the second world war worth more than the entire national debt.
fields.body:
Acting on nothing more than a tale from an elderly monk, an army of Thai government officials, soldiers and labourers yesterday began a treasure hunt for a stash of booty from the time of the second world war worth more than the entire national debt.

Driven by a belief that no one would lie to Thailand's revered king and under instructions from the prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, the 60-member team started drilling through portions of the roof of the Lijia cave in Karnchaburi province, 70 miles west of Bangkok.

They were guarded by 400 policemen and forestry department officials, who were called in to keep hundreds of onlookers at bay.

The forestry department chief, Plodprasop Suraswadi, was reported as saying the team would dig for seven days and use no explosives as that might risk burying any treasure.

The speculation about the treasure began last week when a senator, Chaovarin Lathasaksiri, said he had discovered evidence of a horde in the cave after a five-year search. He claimed the booty was left by retreating Japanese soldiers in 1945 and included 250 US federal reserve gold bullion bonds with a total paper value of £17.5bn.

The bonds, he maintained, were issued in 1934, had a maturity period of 30 years and were payable with an annual interest rate of 4%. Local media have quoted the senator as saying the cave is also home to 2,500 tonnes of gold bars.

This would be more than sufficient to wipe out the national debt of 280bn baht (£4.32bn) and revive an economy that has yet to recover fully from the crash of its currency almost four years ago.

Initially, few people took Mr Chaovarin seriously because he had made several similar claims in the past that came to nothing. But that all changed when Mr Thaksin, the prime minister, visited the cave on Friday to assess the possibility of further exploration. He was sufficiently convinced to order the operation despite Mr Chaovarin's admission on Friday that his claim was based entirely on a document from an elderly monk to the Thai monarch, King Bhumibol Adulyadej.

"I have never been into the cave. I never saw the real gold but I was citing a document to his majesty, and I believe that in this country nobody would lie to the king," he was quoted as saying.

Mr Thaksin said he would seek help from friends in the US who have access to a "remote sensing" satellite that is due to pass over Thailand in the next week and could penetrate up to a third of a mile beneath the earth's surface.

The frenzy has prompted other hunters to claim that treasure troves exist elsewhere in Thailand.

Suwat Yomchinda, leader of the Progressive party, claimed on Sunday that there are four more sites where Japanese loot is hidden.

fields.headline: Australia goes after white supremacists
fields.trailText: Two Australian states are to introduce laws to try to stop racist threats. There is growing evidence that white supremacist groups are renewing hate campaigns against aborigines in some provincial towns.
fields.body:
Two Australian states are to introduce laws to try to stop racist threats. There is growing evidence that white supremacist groups are renewing hate campaigns against aborigines in some provincial towns.

Under legislation drafted by Labour governments in Queensland and Victoria, individuals who publicly incite racial or religious hatred could face up to six months' jail, while companies could be fined up to $A30,000 (£11,000).

"It is a clear statement - both to the small minority of violent racists, and to overseas observers concerned about recent racism in Australia - that this type of damaging behaviour has no place in our community," Queensland's premier, Peter Beattie, said.

Aborigines have reported a rash of racist threats against them by extreme rightwing groups, including some linked to the American Ku Klux Klan.

In Casino, 450 miles north of Sydney, a man of 51 faces charges of making offensive statements and carrying offensive weapons after wearing a Ku Klux Klan outfit, brandishing a baton and threatening aboriginal residents that he would "take care of the niggers".

A local aboriginal politician, Bernie Walker, said aborigines in Casino, a town of 12,000 people, had also received written threats, including one message that warned: "We are watching you."

"There is a lot of fear in our community that KKK activity is rife," Mr Walker told the Sydney Morning Herald. "Our kids are frightened to be in the street on their way to school."

The Australian branch of the World Church of the Creator, a US-based white power movement, last month plastered "White Race Awake - White People Unite" stickers on buildings belonging to aboriginal groups in Rockhampton, 400 miles north of Brisbane.

The government's big parliamentary majority in Queensland should see its bill passed, but in Victoria there is resistance from opposition politicians and church groups. Government research found particular opposition in rural areas.

webTitle: Rebel leader says Nuba have the will to fight Khartoum

fields.headline: Rebel leader says Nuba have the will to fight Khartoum
fields.trailText: Representatives of the Nuba people of central Sudan have vowed to continue fighting the Islamist government in Khartoum despite the death of Yousif Kuwa, who led the resistance in the Nuba mountains for 16 years, and the UN's failure to deliver on a promise of desperately needed food and relief.
fields.byline: Julie Flint in the Nuba mountains, Sudan
fields.body:
Representatives of the Nuba people of central Sudan have vowed to continue fighting the Islamist government in Khartoum despite the death of Yousif Kuwa, who led the resistance in the Nuba mountains for 16 years, and the UN's failure to deliver on a promise of desperately needed food and relief.

In his first act as military governor of rebel territory in the Nuba mountains since Kuwa's death on March 31, Abdel Aziz Adam el-Helo last week convened the Nuba's advisory council, or parliament.

More than 200 delegates who had walked for up to three days to attend the meeting voted unanimously against surrender, according to Commander Helo, who leads the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) in the region.

"They said: 'Yousif brought us out of the caves and opened the door for us to express ourselves as Nuba'," Commander Helo said in an interview in the secret mountain location where Kuwa was buried with full military honours on April 10.

"Yousif's death has depressed people because he was a teacher and a father, but they are still committed. People are determined - they want a way out," he said.

In the year before his death, illness kept Kuwa away from the mountains. Government troops, militias and "holy warriors" captured much of the Nuba's best agricultural land, forcing starving civilians to flee to government garrisons where the only possible identity is an Arab-Islamic one.

Ambushes and rape increased significantly in the plains between the mountains, cut off from the world since the National Islamic Front seized power in 1989.

Since arriving among the African Nuba two months ago, Commander Helo - a friend of Kuwa and reputed to be one of the SPLA's most effective leaders - has been reorganising to try to seize the initiative for the first time in a decade.

He has two priorities: "To recapture productive land and to ensure that the democratic process instituted by Yousif continues and flourishes."

Morale was high at Kuwa's funeral as 120 soldiers escorted the coffin to the foothills from the rough airstrip that is the Nubas' only gateway to the world. "Yousif had the vision. Abdel Aziz is the man to implement that vision," a mourner said.

Government troops, militias and "holy warriors" captured much of the Nuba's best agricultural land, forcing starving civilians to flee to government garrisons where the only possible identity is an Arab-Islamic one. Ambushes and rape increased significantly in the plains between the mountains, cut off from the world since the National Islamic Front seized power in 1989. Since arriving among the African Nuba two months ago, Commander Helo - a friend of Kuwa and reputed to be one of the SPLA's most effective leaders - has been reorganising to try to seize the initiative for the first time in a decade. He has two priorities: "To recapture productive land and to ensure that the democratic process instituted by Yousif continues and flourishes." Morale was high at Kuwa's funeral as 120 soldiers escorted the coffin to the foothills from the rough airstrip that is the Nubas' only gateway to the world. "Yousif had the vision. Abdel Aziz is the man to implement that vision," a mourner said.
fields.bylineHtml: Julie Flint in the Nuba mountains, Sudan

webTitle: Belgium puts nuns in dock for Rwanda genocide

fields.headline: Belgium puts nuns in dock for Rwanda genocide
fields.standfirst: Church forced to yield up sisters charged with war crimes
fields.trailText: Two Rwandan nuns go on trial in Belgium today accused of fanning the flames of ethnic hatred through direct complicity in a massacre of up to 6,000 Tutsis in a southern region of the country in 1994.
fields.body:
Two Rwandan nuns go on trial in Belgium today accused of fanning the flames of ethnic hatred through direct complicity in a massacre of up to 6,000 Tutsis in a southern region of the country in 1994.

Proceedings against the women, known as the nuns of Sovu - the site of their monastery, near the town of Butare - are opposed by the Roman Catholic church, which has staunchly defended the accused. Investigators allege that the church has gone to the extent of obstructing their inquiries.

The trial will be the first of its kind, held before a civil jury outside the former Belgian colony. Belgium passed a law in 1993 giving itself the right to try war-crimes cases regardless of where the alleged crimes were committed, the nationality of the victims or the nationality and place of residence of the accused.

The present case has been put together by Damien Vandermeersch, the crusading Belgian investigative judge who fought hard to get the former Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet, extradited for trial in Belgium.

The two Benedictine nuns, Sister Gertrude, 42 (née Consolata Mukagango) and Sister Maria Kisito, 36 (née Julienne Mukabutera) stand accused of siding with Hutu extremists in 1994.

They will be joined in the dock by two other accused. Vincent Ntezimana, 39, a university professor, and Alphonse Higaniro, 51, a businessman and former minister, are accused of masterminding the slaying of thousands of Tutsis in the same southern Rwandan region.

It is alleged that far from providing refuge for the persecuted in the tradition of churches, the two nuns drove thousands of Tutsis out of the monastery at Sovu and into the clutches of waiting Hutu militiamen.

The nuns, both Hutus, are then accused of standing by and watching as the Tutsis who had sought shelter in the church compound - many of them women and children - were killed with machetes and in some cases burned alive in the name of ethnic cleansing.

Sister Maria Kisito is specifically accused of supplying petrol which the militiamen used to set alight a locked garage in which 500 people were sheltering.

It is estimated that as many as 6,000 people were butchered in the episode.

Last year, African Rights published testimony it got from the leader of the Sovu militia, warrant officer Emmanuel Rekeraho. He presided over the carnage and is now in jail.

"Although they did not use weapons to kill people, Sisters Gertrude and Kisito got the Tutsis out of their hiding places and handed them over to us. Those two nuns collaborated with us in everything we did," he claimed.

"They shared our hatred for the Tutsis. I did not do anything without first discussing it with Kisito and Gertrude. They handed over innocent people, without being threatened in any way, and without us having to use force."

Rekeraho alleges that the nuns did nothing to try to hide the Tutsis, though the monastery at Sovu is large and has many rooms that could have served the purpose.

"I have heard that the nuns are denying responsibility. I'm ashamed for them. If God let me meet them face to face, I'd see whether they could deny what happened at Sovu," he is quoted as telling African Rights.

In the course of the trial, expected to last six weeks, the Brussels court will hear from as many as 171 witnesses, including about 50 from Rwanda and others from Burundi, Belgium and Germany. The two nuns will be brought to court from the neo-Gothic Benedictine abbey behind whose tall grey walls they have been living in the pretty village of Maredret, in the Ardennes forest.

They were moved out of Rwanda to Belgium for their own safety in 1994. They have lived freely there ever since because prosecutors failed to obtain arrest warrants for the two women when they originally opened proceedings.

Sister Benedicte, the abbess at Maredret, is not keen to talk about the case and refuses to allow her two charges to be interviewed. Bespectacled and mild mannered, she is the epitome of the traditional nun in her Benedictine habit as she fusses over Christians who have paid to come to the abbey for an Easter retreat.

But, mention the two Rwandan nuns, and her kindly features become troubled.

"For us the sisters are innocent," she told the Guardian. "The accusations are false. So many travesties and bad things have been written about them that I promised myself I wouldn't say another thing about the case."

"They work and study with us here. They needed somewhere to stay, that's all," she explained with controlled irritation before scurrying away. "Don't write things about them which aren't true."

fields.headline: Japanese joy at heir apparent
fields.trailText: The crown princess of Japan, Masako, may be pregnant after eight years of marriage, according to court officials who risked an early announcement to call for media restraint.
fields.body:
The crown princess of Japan, Masako, may be pregnant after eight years of marriage, according to court officials who risked an early announcement to call for media restraint.

It is just two years since a miscarriage disappointed an imperial family with a succession problem: only sons can inherit but no males have been born into the line since Crown Prince Naruhito's brother in 1965.

The princess, 37, who was educated at Oxford, is thought to be little more than a month pregnant and will be examined by doctors soon. Kiyoshi Furukawa, grand master of the crown prince's household, told reporters. "We request your cooperation in watching events as quietly as possible."

Despite the request, newspapers printed special editions and television stations interrupted regular broadcasts to announce the news. The yen rose and shares in companies producing children's goods jumped as investors predicted a copycat baby boom.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: The French health minister plans to press for the legalisation of euthanasia after favourable opinion polls in France. The Netherlands became the first country to legalise it last week.
fields.body:
France weighs up euthanasia

The French health minister plans to press for the legalisation of euthanasia after favourable opinion polls in France. The Netherlands became the first country to legalise it last week.

Bernard Kouchner said in Le Monde yesterday that he would open a debate on the right of incurably sick people to have their lives ended.

Reuters, Paris

Easter killings in Colombia

An Easter Sunday attack left nine people dead when hundreds of leftwing guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia stormed a village controlled by far-right militias, the authorities said yesterday.

Houses and cars were burned in La Caucana in north-western Antioquia province.

Reuters, Bogota

Sudan silent on BBC reporter

The family of a Reuters and BBC reporter, Alfred Taban, detained last week during a demonstration in Khartoum, said yesterday they had no word of him.

Geert Linnebank, Reuters' editor-in-chief, has written to ask President Omar al-Bashir to release Mr Taban, a Sudanese national.

Reuters, Cairo

Australians dive for free beer

Dozens of Australians put on scuba gear to dive for 24,000 bottles of lager lost after a truckload of beer fell into a river at Tweed Heads, north of Sydney, at the weekend.

One man alone was reported to have netted 400 bottles.

Patrick Barkham, Sydney

Yemen arrests bomb suspects

Five people suspected of ties to Islamist terrorist cells were arrested at the weekend in an investigation into October's bombing of the destroyer USS Cole.

In the past three weeks, 20 people have been arrested in Aden, where the attack took place. Seventeen US sailors were killed and 39 wounded.

AP , Sanaa

Baby turtles spawn hope

Thousands of baby Olive Ridley turtles have begun crawling out of eggs laid on India's east coast, making officials hopeful that the species can be pulled back from the brink of extinction.

The sandy shores of Orissa are teeming with about 200,000 hatchlings.

Reuters, Bhubaneshwar

webTitle: Police in Al Capone's city lead the way

fields.headline: Police in Al Capone's city lead the way
fields.standfirst: As riots shake Cincinnati, officials turn to Chicago's innovative community policing for answers
fields.trailText: Suddenly, complacency about the way America is policed seems more out of place than ever. The riots in Cincinnati last week sent a shiver through every other city in theUS. If it could happen in Cincinnati, they ask, what is to stop iton their doorsteps?
fields.body:
Suddenly, complacency about the way America is policed seems more out of place than ever. The riots in Cincinnati last week sent a shiver through every other city in theUS. If it could happen in Cincinnati, they ask, what is to stop iton their doorsteps?

What is to stop it from happening in Chicago? The city was once America's crime capital - in some people's minds it still is, though the days of Al Capone and John Dillinger are long gone.

Only a minority in today's Chicago remember the 1968 riots and the gang gun violence of the 1990s is declining fast. Chicago is going relatively straight these days.

So much so that the city has a different image now: it is a laboratory for a new kind of policing, a sort apparently not practised in confrontational Cincinnati.

Chicago protesters once chanted that the whole world was watching, and it is again today. Police chiefs from across the US and the world - though not from Cincinnati - have come to learn how Chicago's community policing works.

This is how it operates in the heart of the South Side, Chicago's overwhelmingly black inner city area. At St Elizabeth's Roman Catholic church on South Michigan Street a group of police and local people are holding their monthly police community beat meeting. On this cold, dark night, 19 residents have turned out to discuss their area's problems.

Tonight's meeting is one of nearly 6,000 that take place across the city each year, each one a small brick in a community edifice known as the Chicago Alternative Policing Strategy - shortened to Caps - that allows the Chicago mayor, Richard Daley, to tell me the next morning: "I am hopeful we are building something that really works."

Beat 214, the area of the South Side that is centred on St Elizabeth's, covers an area six blocks by four blocks in the Wentworth district. It is the third most crime-ridden area in Chicago, and the worst for violent crime. As the meeting begins, Officer Claude Dunlap hands out the latest monthly figures for Beat 214. There have been 26 known cases of battery, 24 narcotics cases, 10 thefts and five assaults. Street prostitution has been reported for the first time since the winter snows came.

The figures may sound bad for such a small area, but in context they are pretty good. Crime in Chicago has fallen to a nine-year low, with a 4.9% drop in 2000. There were 627 murders in Chicago last year, a 33-year low and the sixth consecutive year the homicide rate has fallen.

In the city's 2nd District, which includes Wentworth, the progress is even better. Last year, crime fell by 19%, with violent crime down 16% , the best record in the city. The authorities are not slow to attribute the success to Caps.

"It's no coincidence that the steady drop in crime started when we implemented Caps back in 1992," Chicago's police chief, Terry Hilliard, says.

Mr Daley adds: "The backbone of fighting crime in Chicago is Caps. A declining crime rate is what we expect when residents partner with the police to solve local problems and get gangs, guns and drugs off the streets and away from our children."

Here on Beat 214, it does not sound quite so straightforward to a large black woman who has come to speak to the Caps meeting. She doesn't want her name in the papers, she says, but her son is being harassed by gangs on the way home from school. As she explains, she begins to cry: "Look, to you my son's just one of many. To me he's the only one."

The meeting lasts about an hour. It has been a warm day in Chicago, the first of the year, the locals say, and in the early evening the prostitutes were back on the streets.

Someone suggests that, they should cut back the bushes and trees along the street where the prostitutes hang around, so that there is no place to hide. The police and the Caps staff make a note of the idea.

A man called Gerald tells the meeting that cocaine is being sold in a house on South Wabash Street. "It's nothing but a white clientele," he says. "They just walk in. Then in 15 or 30 seconds they're back in their cars and off. It starts about two or three o'clock in the afternoon and goes on until midnight."

Officer Dunlap says tonight's meeting has been typical: "Why don't more people come? 'Cause they're scared. They won't come out at night. They're scared of the gangs. And because they don't trust us. But in our district it's getting better. When people are homeowners they care more."

Peter St Jean, a sociologist at the University of Chicago, says the city is "number one" for community policing. "The city has invested enormously in it. No other place in the United States has been so committed on such a scale for so long."

"We simply decided that the traditional approach to policing, based on crime and disorder, was obsolete," Vance Henry, the Caps project manager for the whole city, says.

"Ours is recognised as the most ambitious community policing model in the United States. Caps is not just about policing but about community life in all respects."

Many researchers agree with Chicago's claims. It is a "flagship community policing programme," says Wesley Skogan, a political scientist who heads a research project on the programme at the city's Northwestern University.

In recent years, many US intellectuals and policy makers have become obsessed with the idea that Americans have become socially isolated from one another.

But some political scientists argue that Caps proves that community institutions can still work. "Concern with crime was once thought to stifle collective action; now it is proving to be a principle of social integration and civic renewal," Eric Klinenberg, a sociologist, says.

No one claims that community policing is a panacea or that it will be able to withstand a ferocious wave of outrage of the kind that has swept through Cincinnati.

"If you think you're going to wave a magic wand, then you're making a great mistake," Mayor Daley says.

"But if you don't go with community policing then you're viewed as someone coming into the community from the outside. You have to have the police accountable to the community."

webTitle: Ex-president faces charge of plundering Philippines

fields.headline: Ex-president faces charge of plundering Philippines
fields.trailText: The disgraced former president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, was arrested yesterday after a Manila court issued warrants on charges of graft and perjury.
fields.body:
The disgraced former president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada, was arrested yesterday after a Manila court issued warrants on charges of graft and perjury.

Toppled from the presidency in a "people power" revolt in January, Mr Estrada looked crestfallen as court officers took his fingerprints five times.

Mr Estrada was released on bail but six other charges are pending against him, including one of economic plunder, a non-bailable offence theoretically punishable by death.

A state ombudsman, Aniano Desierto, said yesterday that prosecutors planned to streamline their case by withdrawing five of the charges to concentrate on the plunder allegation. It is alleged that Mr Estrada engaged in massive corruption during his 31 months in office, including taking bribes from illegal gambling syndicates and pocketing tax revenues.

The former president has said the charges are part of campaign to disgrace him by the government of his successor, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, who was his vice-president.

He is currently campaigning for his party's candidates in the May 14 legislative elections. His wife, who is also facing a graft case, is running for the senate.

Reuters

webTitle: Dead are piling up in Turkish jail protest

fields.headline: Dead are piling up in Turkish jail protest
fields.trailText: Another Turkish prisoner died yesterday in a nationwide hunger strike, involving hundreds of leftwing inmates, which is threatening to spill out of control. Thirteen people have now died in the bitter dispute about prison conditions, and dozens more are reported in critical condition.
fields.body:
Another Turkish prisoner died yesterday in a nationwide hunger strike, involving hundreds of leftwing inmates, which is threatening to spill out of control. Thirteen people have now died in the bitter dispute about prison conditions, and dozens more are reported in critical condition.

As Turkey struggles with an economic crisis, the hunger strike has received little attention in the local media. But that is starting to change.

"Our prisons have become cemeteries", wrote Derya Sazak in Milliyet newspaper. "If the deadlock continues for the rest of this week, the death toll could rise above 100".

The latest hunger striker to end his life was Sedat Gursel Akmaz, 41, a member of the extreme leftwing Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front (DHKP-C), who died in hospital in the south-western city of Izmir.

On Sunday, Canan Kulaksiz, a student of 19, died in a house in Istanbul where a number of prisoners' relatives have been on hunger strike in solidarity with the protest. Eleven inmates and two of their relatives have starved themselves to death since March 21.

"I, too, love living, but you have to pay a price to get your rights," Ms Kulaksiz said in an interview with Cumhuriyet newspaper two days before she died. "They are building coffins for the people in the prisons, and I cannot act as if nothing is going on".

The government, however, insists there will be no negotiation with the prisoners, who are protesting about the enforced transfer of about 1,000 people to controversial new jails where inmates are held in cells for up to three people. The government says it had to move prisoners out of old-style dormitory wards which the inmates ran as their own private fiefdoms.

Pressure groups such as Human Rights Watch have condemned the new prisons, which they say contravene international standards. The Council of Europe has also expressed concern. Prisoners allege they are beaten every day. The government says such allegations are propaganda.

The number of people involved in the hunger strike has fluctuated, but a senior official from the ministry of health said yesterday that 791 inmates were taking part in the protest, and 222 of them were on what they call a death fast. Human rights groups believe the total number of protesters could be above 1,000.

More than 150 prisoners have now been transferred to state hospitals, where doctors say dozens are in critical condition and refusing treatment. The protesters are chained to their beds, though they are too weak to move.
