fields.headline: Lebanon: war's playground once more
fields.standfirst:
Beirut fears Israel-Hizbullah conflict could bring collapse if cross-border raids escalate

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: It has long been feared that the Palestinian intifada would widen into a regional confrontation, and that south Lebanon, the last militarily active frontier of the Arab-Israeli struggle, would be the flashpoint.
fields.body:
It has long been feared that the Palestinian intifada would widen into a regional confrontation, and that south Lebanon, the last militarily active frontier of the Arab-Israeli struggle, would be the flashpoint.

Now, with Israel's first deliberate attack on a Syrian target since its 1982 invasion of Lebanon, that confrontation could begin. And Lebanon, resuming its hapless role as an arena for other people's conflict, is once more trapped -in the words of its most sharp-tongued politician, Walid Jumblatt - "between Hanoi and Hong Kong". Hizbullah embodies Hanoi.

It was Hizbullah's killing of an Israeli soldier on Saturday that prompted the air raid against a Syrian radar station. He was the third to die in such cross-frontier raids since Israel withdrew, last May, from the zone it had taken over in south Lebanon.

Hizbullah cites three motives for its continued "resistance": national, Islamic and regional.

Nationally, the liberation of south Lebanon is incomplete. There still remain the so-called Shebaa Farms. They were under Syrian control when Israel captured them in the 1967 war. Suddenly, in the last months of Israeli occupation, the Lebanese government staked a claim. That now furnishes Hizbullah with the justification for its operations.

Islamically, and with the "liberation" of Jerusalem as a basic tenet, Hizbullah sees itself as a model for the Palestinian intifada. It takes pride in the great prestige it has won in Palestine and the Arab world.

Regionally, Hizbullah serves Iranian and Syrian sponsors. South Lebanon, and the pain which, via Hizbullah, Syria could inflict on Israel there, had long been a vital asset in Syria's negotiations for a settlement. With Israel's withdrawal Damascus seemed to be losing that asset; that is why it promoted the Lebanese claim to the Shebaa Farms.

Rafiq Hariri is now the personification of Lebanon-as-Hong Kong. The tycoon came to power as Lebanese prime minister with a popular mandate to carry through the country's post-war "reconstruction" - but what he really faces is a relentless economic decline that could become an outright financial collapse. He desperately needs foreign investment.

Nothing will scare it off like renewed warfare in the south. Though, in principle, Mr Hariri has acquiesced in the "legitimacy" of continued "resistance", in practice he is deeply at odds with Hizbullah over the need for these trans-frontier operations.

The economic crisis cannot be separated from another, political one - centred on Syria's controversial hegemony over Lebanon - which has lately become so serious as to remind the more despondent commentators of the atmosphere preceding the outbreak of civil war in 1975.

Under the 1989 Taif agreement, foundation of the post-war order, Syrian troops should have withdrawn from the rest of Lebanon to the Bekaa valley by 1992. The continued Israeli occupation in the south became their main pretext for delay. But since Israel withdrew, agitation for Syria to do likewise has grown. Though a reduction of the Syrian presence would be welcomed by the bulk of the people, the agitation is strongest among the Christians. Whatever they really think, most Muslim leaders insist, in the stock phrase, that the Syrians' presence, albeit "temporary", is for the foreseeable future "legitimate and necessary".

Nothing would deepen this crisis like renewed hostilities with Israel. Referring to what most Lebanese believe to be the main reason for the Syrian presence, its utility in peace negotiations, Gibran Tweini, editor of Beirut's leading newspaper al-Nahar, asked: "Why should Lebanon be more royalist than the king; why doesn't Syria itself open the Golan for military opera tions aimed at its liberation?"

Syria has not responded in kind to the Israel attack. "It simply doesn't have the means," said an experienced Lebanese commentator, "and the question is whether it will ask Hizbullah to do so".

Ever since the Israeli withdrawal, Hizbullah has been pointing out that that its men now have access to the Israeli frontier.

According to their leader Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, they boast such an arsenal that "one million Israeli settlers will have to flee the area if the orders go out to our fighters to open fire".

Recriminations all round

'We will turn Sharon's dream of terrorising our people into a nightmare that will chase the defeated, invading Zionist army, their terrorist bases and their camps'
Hizbullah

'We condemn this escalation and the cycle of violence that was initiated by Hizbullah in a clear provocation designed to escalate a tense situation'
US state department spokesman Richard Boucher

'The German government urgently appeals to all parties to abstain from further military action and to avoid bloodshed'
German foreign minister Joschka Fischer

'Regrettably, this is a dangerous escalation that drags the whole region into a very critical, bad and grave situation'
Yasser Arafat

'The action by Israel shows that it does not want peace but is going along the path of aggression'
Syrian foreign minister Farouq al-Shara

'We are unlikely to let it go as it is, and deliberations are under way to decide what further steps should be taken to bring about the cessation of such hostilities'
Ariel Sharon's spokesman, Raanan Gissin

Audio report
Suzanne Goldenberg in Khan Yunis, Gaza Strip

webTitle: Upset at Sharon son's visit to Arafat

fields.headline: Upset at Sharon son's visit to Arafat
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, looked at risk of opening a rift with his rightwing constituency yesterday because he used his son as a secret emissary to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, looked at risk of opening a rift with his rightwing constituency yesterday because he used his son as a secret emissary to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

The prime minister's use of his businessman son, Omri, 36, who is regarded as the mastermind of Mr Sharon's election victory last February, raised hackles in expected quarters: the foreign ministry, legal circles, and the left. But Mr Sharon is also under fire from far-right members of his coalition.

On Sunday, Israel's attorney general, Elyakim Rubinstein, told Mr Sharon that sending his son to talk to Mr Arafat violated the spirit of a ban on government officials giving jobs to their relatives. The Omri Sharon met the Palestinian leader twice this month, and met Mr Arafat's financial adviser in Vienna in January.

"Sending a family member on diplomatic missions is not acceptable in a properly conducted state," Mr Rubinstein said.

Mr Sharon argues that sending his son would be seen as a demonstration of his sincerity by Mr Arafat, who shares his prediliction for mixing the personal with the political.

"Sharon said something very interesting: that he sent his son to Mr Arafat because in the Middle East that kind of gesture is appreciated by leaders," said a rightwing author, Yossi Klein Halevy.

But this nod to Middle Eastern custom was not appreciated by members of Mr Sharon's coalition who accused him yesterday of breaking an election pledge not to negotiate with the Palestinians until they end their uprising.

Suzanne Goldenberg in Khan Yunis, Gaza Strip

webTitle: Israel blasts Gaza from land, sea and air

fields.headline: Israel blasts Gaza from land, sea and air
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel launched air, sea and ground attacks on the Gaza Strip last night, capping a day that saw tensions climb sharply all over the Middle East.
fields.body:
Israel launched air, sea and ground attacks on the Gaza Strip last night, capping a day that saw tensions climb sharply all over the Middle East.

Helicopter and navy gunships bombarded a post of Yasser Arafat's elite Force 17 security section in Deir al-Balah in central Gaza, and armoured bulldozers, backed by tank fire, rolled into Palestinian-ruled territory at Beit Hanoun, in the north of the territory.

The twin assaults came less than 24 hours after Israeli warplanes attacked a Syrian radar station in Lebanon, heightening international concerns that the bloody seven-month Palestinian uprising could fuel violence elsewhere in the region.

As fears grew of the possibility of a direct confrontation between the two great enemies of the Middle East following the Israeli attack on Lebanon, Jordan led a flurry of international demands for restraint.

"We think this is an unjustified escalation that will have a negative effect on the security and stability of the region," the visiting Jordanian foreign minister, Abdul-Ilah Khatib, said in Jerusalem.

"Once again the use of force will not solve anything on the ground."

The overnight attack - the first deliberate strike on a Syrian position in Lebanon since Israel's 1982 invasion - marks a steep escalation of Israel's response to attacks by Hizbullah guerrillas.

Three Syrian soldiers were killed in the raid, which Israel said was in retaliation for the killing of a soldier by Hizbullah guerrillas on its northern frontier at the weekend. It accused Syria of encouraging such attacks to ratchet up the pressure as it confronts a Palestinian revolt.

"The rules of the game have changed. We will extract a price from Syria if they fail to constrain Hizbullah," a spokesman for the hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, said.

The cycle of attack and reprisal remained unbroken. Hours after the raid on Lebanon, Palestinian militants fired mortar shells on the southern development town of Sederot, which lies inside the borders of the Jewish state.

The missiles landed harmlessly, but the attack on Sederot, about three miles from the Gaza Strip, fed Israeli fears that the Palestinians are beginning to get greater range from their home-made mortar launchers, and are singling out population centres.

The army's inevitable retaliation arrived swiftly. In Beit Hanoun, in the northern Gaza Strip, Israel launched its third ground invasion of Palestinian-ruled territory in a week, sending tanks and bulldozers to pound two police buildings.

Hours later, the airforce attacked Deir al-Balah, injuring three people.

The spasm of violence demonstrated the ease with which events on Israel's northern frontiers can fuel an escalation in the West Bank and Gaza.

Most of the Hizbullah attacks have focused on a disputed stretch of the northern border called the Shebaa Farms. Although the UN says the territory is part of the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights, Hizbullah claims it is Lebanese and should have been evacuated when Israel ended its 18-year occupation in May.

In recent weeks Israeli military officials have claimed evidence of growing collaboration between the Lebanese militants and Palestinian groups; they claim to have uncovered a Hizbullah cell which has fired mortars on Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip.

Hizbullah remained defiant yesterday saying in a statement from Beirut that it would choose its moment, and its means, for taking revenge.

"We will chop off the hand of the enemy which reached into our land and our brothers'.

"We will turn Sharon's dream of terrorising our people into a nightmare that will chase the defeated, invading Zionist army, their terrorist bases and their camps," the statement said.

The Lebanese president, Emile Lahoud, said the attack "revealed anew the blood-coloured policies" of Mr Sharon, the architect of Israel's 1982 invasion.

Meanwhile in Damascus, an official spokesman called the reprisal attack "a challenge to the will of the Arab nation".

The angry exchanges sharpened concern in Washington, Paris, Bonn, London and Moscow, where there were universal calls for restraint.

Suzanne Goldenberg in Khan Yunis, Gaza Strip

webTitle: Fears grow for children as slave ship docks

fields.headline: Fears grow for children as slave ship docks
fields.trailText: A suspected slave ship missing off the coast of west Africa carrying around 180 children docked in the capital of Benin, Cotonou, early this morning.
fields.byline: James Astill in Nairobi and agencies
fields.body:
A suspected slave ship missing off the coast of west Africa carrying around 180 children docked in the capital of Benin, Cotonou, early this morning.

Port sources said there appeared to be only seven children on board, but a full search of the ship was being carried out.

The Nigerian-registered ship had been spotted on Sunday in the straits between Malabo, in Equatorial Guinea, and Douala, in Cameroon.

The situation was thrown into confusion last night when a Benin government minister claimed the MV Etireno was not carrying any children and had been mistaken for another vessel. The social protection minister Ramatou Baba Moussa could not provide the name or location of the second ship.

Benin had appealed for international help to track down the Etireno, as it only has five small navy patrol vessels.

It has been at sea since March 30, when it set sail from Cotonou headed for Gabon, where it was refused permission to dock. It was feared the children may have been offloaded at a remote port in Nigeria or even thrown overboard.

Unicef said it feared what the Etireno's captain - a man with a criminal record who has been accused of trafficking child slaves in the past - might do to evade arrest.

"When we heard that [the captain] has a criminal past, we imagined the worst, and the worst is that they could have been thrown overboard," Nicholas Pron, a Unicef official based in Benin, said.

Even if the children remained aboard the ship, their food and water could have run out. The Etireno refuelled in Douala last Thursday, but port authorities there said it was short of food even then and some of the children looked ill.

Benin police yesterday issued arrest warrants through Interpol for the captain and crew, and for three businessmen. The businessmen, led by Stanislas Abatan, are accused of transporting hundreds of children to work in Gabon's cocoa and rubber plantations.

The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, has instructed US diplomats in west Africa to "do everything possible" to assist authorities in finding and dealing with the ship.

His spokesman said that the help was likely to take the form of an "exchange of information", adding that embassy staff throughout the region were working on the case.

Unicef said it feared what the Etireno's captain - a man with a criminal record who has been accused of trafficking child slaves in the past - might do to evade arrest. "When we heard that [the captain] has a criminal past, we imagined the worst, and the worst is that they could have been thrown overboard," Nicholas Pron, a Unicef official based in Benin, said. Even if the children remained aboard the ship, their food and water could have run out. The Etireno refuelled in Douala last Thursday, but port authorities there said it was short of food even then and some of the children looked ill. Benin police yesterday issued arrest warrants through Interpol for the captain and crew, and for three businessmen. The businessmen, led by Stanislas Abatan, are accused of transporting hundreds of children to work in Gabon's cocoa and rubber plantations. The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, has instructed US diplomats in west Africa to "do everything possible" to assist authorities in finding and dealing with the ship. His spokesman said that the help was likely to take the form of an "exchange of information", adding that embassy staff throughout the region were working on the case.

webTitle: Israel launches new attack on Gaza HQ

fields.headline: Israel launches new attack on Gaza HQ
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli helicopter gunships attacked Palestinian security headquarters in central Gaza last night, in the latest serious escalation of violence.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem and agencies
fields.body:
Israeli helicopter gunships attacked Palestinian security headquarters in central Gaza last night, in the latest serious escalation of violence.

Two people were wounded in the attack on the headquarters of Force 17, an elite security unit, in the Deir al-Balah refugee camp. "Three missiles hit the headquarters," a police officer at the scene said.

The gunships struck just hours after militants had sent mortar shells crashing into the Jewish settlement of Sederot, near Gaza, as fighting across the region saw a marked upsurge. The mortar attack was in response to Israel targeting Syrian radar positions in Lebanon on Sunday night.

Elsewhere in northern Gaza, Israeli forces raided Beit Hanun, an area under Palestinian control, destroying Palestinian border police positions with bulldozers.

Jordan led the cry of international concern yesterday about the danger of a direct confrontation between the two great enemies of the Middle East after Israeli warplanes bombed the radar stations.

"We think this is an unjustified escalation that will have a negative effect on the security and stability of the region," the visiting Jordanian foreign minister, Abdul-Ilah Khatib, said in Jerusalem. "Once again the use of force will not solve anything on the ground."

The overnight attack - the first deliberate strike on a Syrian position in Lebanon since Israel's 1982 invasion - marks a steep escalation of Israel's response to attacks by Hizbullah guerrillas.

More recent damage to Syrian positions was the result of collateral not intentional fire.

Three Syrian soldiers were killed and six injured at the radar station.

It immediately deepened international concerns of a wider conflagration. Hours after Israel's attack on Lebanon, the Palestinians further increased tensions when militants fired mortar shells on the development town of Sederot, about eight miles east of Gaza, the first such attack on a Jewish town since the start of the uprising.

The inevitable and immediate Israeli retaliation, which saw tanks pound a police station in Gaza, is bound to feed Arab anger.

Israel, which said the raid on Lebanon was in retaliation for the killing of an Israeli soldier on its northern frontier at the weekend by Hizbullah guerrillas, was unrepentant.

"The rules of the game have changed. We will extract a price from Syria if they fail to constrain Hizbullah," a spokesman for the hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, said.

Israel accuses Syria of encouraging Hizbullah attacks on its northern borders to ratchet up the pressure as it confronts a Palestinian revolt against its occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

The attacks have focused on the disputed stretch of the border, called the Shebaa Farms, which Hizbullah claims is still under Israeli occupation following the end of the 18-year occupation last May.

In recent weeks, Israeli military officials have claimed evidence of growing collaboration between the Lebanese militants and Palestinian groups; they claim to have uncovered a Hizbullah cell which has fired mortars on Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip.

Hizbullah remained defiant yesterday saying in a statement from Beirut that it would choose its moment, and its means, for taking revenge. "We will chop off the hand of the enemy which reached into our land and our brothers'.

"We will turn Sharon's dream of terrorising our people into a nightmare that will chase the defeated, invading Zionist army, their terrorist bases and their camps," the statement said.

The Lebanese president, Emile Lahoud, said the attack "revealed anew the blood-coloured policies" of Mr Sharon, the architect of Israel's 1982 invasion.

Meanwhile, in Damascus, an official spokesman called the reprisal attack "a challenge to the will of the Arab nation".

"Syria holds Israel responsible for this dangerous escalation," he said.

The angry exchanges sharpened concern in Washington, Paris, Bonn, London and Moscow, where there were universal calls for restraint.

fields.headline: Close to the wind
fields.standfirst: British yachtsman Tony Bullimore finally completed his round-the-world challenge on Sunday, limping home 42 days behind the winner. But what was life at sea like with the skipper dubbed Captain Calamity?  Rob Salvidge, who abandoned ship in New Zealand, reveals all
fields.trailText: British yachtsman Tony Bullimore finally completed his round-the-world challenge on Sunday, limping home 42 days behind the winner. But what was life at sea like with the skipper dubbed Captain Calamity? Rob Salvidge , who abandoned ship in New Zealand, reveals all
fields.body:
Tony Bullimore celebrated his 63rd birthday aboard the giant catamaran on which he has just sailed around the world. The sun was setting, sending glorious bright orange streaks across a calm ocean as we cracked open a bottle of champagne and enjoyed the relaxed moment and more of Tony's yarns. It felt a great privilege to be one of the nine crew on board Team Legato, helping Tony fulfil his dream of racing non-stop round the world.

Back in our home city of Bristol, over the previous two years Tony and I shared many Sunday mornings eating bacon sandwiches and drinking mugs of tea on the dockside. As we chatted he outlined his project for The Race, and every so often he would reveal a little more of his fascinating past and I got a glimpse into the very individual mind of this most enigmatic sailor.

Tony is obviously best known for his sailing exploits and his dramatic rescue from the southern ocean in 1997, but in Bristol he is also known as one of the city's great characters. Over the years he has owned a number of nightclubs in the city - the Granary and the Bamboo are fondly recalled by those now too old for the austere techno caverns favoured by the kids of today.

Tony doesn't often talk about the deep-rooted connections he has with the city's Afro-Caribbean community, however, on many occasions as we sailed together, he mused about the time not too far off, when he will retire with his wife Lalel to her native Jamaica.

My communication station on board Legato was near Tony's bunk and the ship's main satellite phone, so I was there when they spoke fondly to each other on his birthday. Too soft you might think from such a bulldog of a man with his famous will of steel, yet I saw that gritty determination, even stubbornness, in fair measure too.

For several days we were becalmed in the notorious equatorial doldrums and when we picked up wind again, somebody noticed that one of our wind generators wasn't turning properly. This time Tony wasn't sailing single-handed, and with the luxury of a crew he could easily have dispatched someone to sort it out. But he decided this was a task he was going to do himself. Armed with a pocketful of spanners and screwdrivers he perched precariously on a communications dome and stolidly took the thing apart bit by bit before it became apparent that the fault was terminal and we didn't have the kit on board to fix it.

A more comical example of Tony's behaviour came shortly after we crossed the equator when the weather was warm, but the wind was picking up. We had all enjoyed several days in shorts and T-shirts, but now the spray was starting to fly again and even though the water was warm, most of us thought it was sensible to wear oilskins on deck. But not Tony, he would appear for his watch looking like a slightly overweight beach boy. He would take the helm, stand there jauntily eyeing the rig until, wallop, the bows pitched in and we took a corker of a wave right over the cockpit. Tony often apologises for his swearing and promises to give it up, but on such an occasion the resolution was forgotten. You'd have thought he would learn a lesson, but, no, this happened many times until every T-shirt he had was sopping. The rest of us thought it was hilarious, but you don't laugh about such things to Tony's face.

At times, I felt like the luckiest person alive to be sailing the great oceans with this great adventurer. We shared some great laughs, but there were other times when I felt Tony was annoyed with everyone and would rather be alone. Sometimes he would jibe at the race committee or have a dig at the people who had packed our food in Barcelona - dedicated folk who had done the best they could in an incredibly short time. He would also lambast the British press for not paying more attention to his efforts and finding plenty of column inches for fellow racer Ellen McArthur - that is not a criticism of Ellen, for whom he has the highest possible regard.

Most of Tony's adventures have been solo projects and I think he was always going to find the daily business of managing a crew of nine on board a 105ft boat (not to mention the need to keep a shore team on side and fully supportive) quite a challenge. Many of Tony's achievements have been against the odds and so it has become instinctive for him to feel he has to remain a maverick and operate on the edge of the system in order to get things done.

I suppose the problem is that if the public adores or hates you because you are a loveable rogue, you simply aren't the sort of person who finds it easy to compromise and appease. Pete Goss, with his Team Phillips project, was everybody's friend. He got every school kid in Devon and their grannies involved and even managed to get the Queen to crack a bottle of champagne over the catamaran's bow, but it didn't get him to the start of the race. Tony struggled for funding and will possibly have to sell the boat to clear his debts now. He had a mountain to climb before he started and I haven't made it any easier for him by getting off half way round, although for me it was the right decision.

I felt some of the crew-management issues and inevitable conflicts on a voyage such as this were not being handled properly. I was concerned about safety, a feeling exacerbated when I was nearly swept off the back of the boat by a wave. Also, the film I was taking wasn't telling the full story of life on board. I explained these reasons to Tony when we docked in New Zealand, and we parted good friends. In fact, we shared a good late-night cook-up in a Maori taxi-drivers' cafe in Wellington. After that, a part of me yearned still to be on board the mighty white ocean-eating sailing machine that was my home for 50 days.

Tony is like the oceans we sailed together, often warm and alluring, always fascinating, ever changing, sometimes merciless, but there is always a depth that you'll never fathom. That's what makes both the sea and Tony Bullimore so fascinating and so compatible.

fields.headline: Life after life
fields.standfirst: John Kamara spent almost 20 years in prison for a murder he did not commit. When he was finally freed on appeal last year, there was no apology, no offer of counselling and nowhere for him to go.  Louise Shorter  followed his progress during his first traumatic year of freedom
fields.trailText: John Kamara spent almost 20 years in prison for a murder he did not commit. When he was finally freed on appeal last year, there was no apology, no offer of counselling and nowhere for him to go. Louise Shorter followed his progress during his first traumatic year of freedom
fields.body:
For three days I sat in the public gallery of court number six, heart in mouth and eyes fixed on the top of the head in the dock. It was all I could see of the man everyone was talking about. He was an angry man, they said. Volatile. Prisoner H10109 had been locked up for the past 20 years for a brutal murder he said he hadn't committed. This was his last chance to prove his innocence. If this appeal failed he knew he would die in prison. It was a real-life drama unfolding before my eyes and I had persuaded my boss and John Kamara to let me film him from the moment he got out. If he got out.

The appeal had been running for three days when suddenly the judges took their leave. Nobody knew what was going on. It was a strange place to stop. A detail of one of the witness statements, which had been buried for 20 years, was being examined. The judges had drawn their heads together in a huddle and then, suddenly, they got up and left. Everyone in the court room - lawyers, journalists and supporters sat in tense silence. Five minutes later, the judges returned and abruptly told the defence barrister, Michael Birnbaum QC, that Kamara's conviction had been quashed. Nobody moved a muscle. There wasn't a murmur. All my preconceived notions of families jumping in the air, shouting in jubilation, were out of place that day. The judges didn't have a single word of apology for Kamara. Their thanks went to the lawyers. They didn't even look at the man who had been robbed of 20 years of freedom.

An hour later, I stood at the back door of the appeal court and waited for Kamara to come out into the sunshine. Finally, I met the man who, until an hour before, was classed as one of the country's most dangerous men. He was quietly spoken and bemused. He said he didn't understand what the judges were saying when they quashed his conviction. He thought he was being taken back to the cells, then he heard one of the security guards saying he would be going home.

The trouble was, he had no home. We got into a taxi and started filming as we pulled out of the court precinct. A small crowd of supporters shouted and cheered as we drove out on to the Strand and Kamara flinched and blinked in the glare of the lights. I didn't want to rush in with 101 idiotic questions so we sat in the taxi - Kamara, his brother, a friend, me, and a colleague, Sara Hardy, who was operating a video camera - in silence. The atmosphere was charged as, for what seemed like an hour, we drove through London and looked at the view.

When I viewed the raw footage later I was amazed to discover it only lasted eight minutes. Then I began talking to Kamara. He was friendly and kind but punch-drunk. When he found the words to express himself they came in a jolt. He said it felt as if the taxi was driving too fast. Later, he would tell me that everything seemed to be going too fast, even people walking looked as if they were scurrying about on fast-forward. His eyes couldn't take in the colour because in prison everything is grey, so on that first journey, the tones, to him, were like an overexposed photograph. Finally, we arrived at Paddy Hill's house. The two men had met in Parkhurst prison in the early 80s - eight years before Hill's release as one of the Birmingham Six. Kamara was going there because he had nowhere else to go. At the court he had been given £46 and a travel pass that ran out that evening at 8pm. He left with sacks and sacks of court papers and one set of clothes. As an innocent man, nobody in authority had responsibility for Kamara. He didn't fall into the remit of the probation service because they only deal with guilty people. He had spent 16 of the past 20 years in solitary confinement fighting his case. No human contact for 23 hours a day. Day after day. Year after year. He had been told when to eat, sleep and exercise for two decades and now he was being put back on the streets with no help at all.

When we got to Hill's house we continued filming. Suddenly the tables had turned for Kamara. After all those years of being told what to do, I started asking him for opinions and permission to film. He didn't know what I wanted him to do, but I didn't want him to do anything for the camera. I wanted him to be natural but he didn't know what natural was.

We stopped filming when it got dark. News crews were turning up, thrusting huge cameras about the place. Kamara was giving interviews and saying he was waiting for a prison guard to tell him to get behind his cell door. Sara Hardy packed up the camera and we left. I shook Kamara's hand on the way out.

The next time I spoke to Kamara he was going to Liverpool, so we met there. He had stunned me by saying he was going to meet the father of the victim of the crime for which he had been imprisoned. BBC Radio Merseyside had tracked Kamara down and invited both men on to its live phone-in show the next day. For years, John Suffield, the victim's father, had believed Kamara was guilty. Now he wanted to meet him. I arranged to be there, too, and film the meeting. Afterwards, Kamara and I would return to London on a train. I had heard stories of other people released from long prison sentences who had freaked out on a fast-moving vehicle or gone berserk if an unwitting bystander had shut the door on them while in a small room.

The radio interview went well. The two Johns showed nothing but mutual respect and it was plain that Kamara was comforted by Suffield declaring publicly in a loud, clear voice that he was an innocent man. Suffield had sat through the appeal. He knew that Kamara was not one of two men who had bound his son, a betting shop manager, to a swivel chair and tortured him for the combination to the safe. It was a combination the manager could not give because, in his terror, his stammer worsened and he could not get the words out. It was another emotional, highly charged day for Kamara, made worse by the huge cameras of the local news crews who followed him everywhere. He was happy with ours because it was so small and, probably, because we were two women who didn't crowd him. But the bulk of the crews and their equipment nearly panicked him.

Over the following months Kamara and I spoke daily and met regularly. Sometimes Sara or another colleague came too and filmed. Other times, we just sat and chatted. Kamara had a rollercoaster of a life those first few months - tracing and meeting lost siblings, trying to get benefits to live on, trying to come to terms with the fact that, after a 20-year battle to clear his name, people now expected him just to forget about it. He had virtually no friends and nothing to do except go over the case papers which had been the focus of his life for so long. He was not offered counselling; he needed people to talk to.

I had to resolve issues too. How do you draw the line when you are so personally involved? There were times when I thought Kamara would end up homeless because he didn't exist in the eyes of the social services and wasn't eligible for housing. Should I offer my spare room? I couldn't film with him all day and then leave him out in the cold, but I couldn't save him either. How could I make a film about the injustice done to people freed after wrongful conviction, but step in and provide the food and shelter he was denied?

Three months after Kamara's release he reached his lowest point. He had arranged to go to the House of Commons to meet his MP, Louise Ellman, with whom he had corresponded regularly from prison. We arranged to meet at Westminster underground station where we had permission to film Kamara's arrival. It had always been virtually impossible to ask Kamara to do anything for the camera. He felt self-conscious walking in or out of a building for us, so we couldn't get set-up shots. He would get angry and anxious and was in danger of de-camping entirely; we always had to grab whatever we could on the hoof. On this particular June morning, Kamara was in such a state of despair he could barely talk to me. We were held up at the tube station by a delegation of Japanese businessmen on a guided tour. Every time I tried to go up to Kamara to explain, he would cross the street and walk away. He looked gaunt and was a shadow of the punch-drunk but dignified man released from prison a few months previously.

At times, Kamara would telephone to say he didn't want any more to do with the film. He would shout and rant and say he was pulling out of the project and wanted all the tapes. He was still being messed around by social services and had no home of his own. He couldn't sleep and spent most nights sitting up at Alexandra Palace, staring at the distant lights of London, wishing he was back in prison. He needed some outlet for the anger that had reached boiling point and I was one of a small number of people with whom he had regular contact.

A year on, I class Kamara as a friend. He is now spending his time trying to help other prisoners who claim to be innocent. He has a strong network of supportive friends and family. He has his own home; he has even found love and plans to marry.

I have acted as a kind of counsellor to him at times, but have also had to keep a distance and observe. It has been a difficult line to tread, but it has allowed me to witness the extraordinary strength of his character: Kamara survived in spite of the system, not because of it.

 Life After Life, a Rough Justice special, is on BBC1 tonight at 10.35pm.

He thought he was being taken back to the cells, then he heard one of the security guards saying he would be going home. The trouble was, he had no home. We got into a taxi and started filming as we pulled out of the court precinct. A small crowd of supporters shouted and cheered as we drove out on to the Strand and Kamara flinched and blinked in the glare of the lights. I didn't want to rush in with 101 idiotic questions so we sat in the taxi - Kamara, his brother, a friend, me, and a colleague, Sara Hardy, who was operating a video camera - in silence. The atmosphere was charged as, for what seemed like an hour, we drove through London and looked at the view. When I viewed the raw footage later I was amazed to discover it only lasted eight minutes. Then I began talking to Kamara. He was friendly and kind but punch-drunk. When he found the words to express himself they came in a jolt. He said it felt as if the taxi was driving too fast. Later, he would tell me that everything seemed to be going too fast, even people walking looked as if they were scurrying about on fast-forward. His eyes couldn't take in the colour because in prison everything is grey, so on that first journey, the tones, to him, were like an overexposed photograph. Finally, we arrived at Paddy Hill's house. The two men had met in Parkhurst prison in the early 80s - eight years before Hill's release as one of the Birmingham Six. Kamara was going there because he had nowhere else to go. At the court he had been given £46 and a travel pass that ran out that evening at 8pm. He left with sacks and sacks of court papers and one set of clothes. As an innocent man, nobody in authority had responsibility for Kamara. He didn't fall into the remit of the probation service because they only deal with guilty people. He had spent 16 of the past 20 years in solitary confinement fighting his case. No human contact for 23 hours a day. Day after day. Year after year. He had been told when to eat, sleep and exercise for two decades and now he was being put back on the streets with no help at all. When we got to Hill's house we continued filming. Suddenly the tables had turned for Kamara. After all those years of being told what to do, I started asking him for opinions and permission to film. He didn't know what I wanted him to do, but I didn't want him to do anything for the camera. I wanted him to be natural but he didn't know what natural was. We stopped filming when it got dark. News crews were turning up, thrusting huge cameras about the place. Kamara was giving interviews and saying he was waiting for a prison guard to tell him to get behind his cell door. Sara Hardy packed up the camera and we left. I shook Kamara's hand on the way out. The next time I spoke to Kamara he was going to Liverpool, so we met there. He had stunned me by saying he was going to meet the father of the victim of the crime for which he had been imprisoned. BBC Radio Merseyside had tracked Kamara down and invited both men on to its live phone-in show the next day. For years, John Suffield, the victim's father, had believed Kamara was guilty. Now he wanted to meet him. I arranged to be there, too, and film the meeting. Afterwards, Kamara and I would return to London on a train. I had heard stories of other people released from long prison sentences who had freaked out on a fast-moving vehicle or gone berserk if an unwitting bystander had shut the door on them while in a small room. The radio interview went well. The two Johns showed nothing but mutual respect and it was plain that Kamara was comforted by Suffield declaring publicly in a loud, clear voice that he was an innocent man. Suffield had sat through the appeal. He knew that Kamara was not one of two men who had bound his son, a betting shop manager, to a swivel chair and tortured him for the combination to the safe. It was a combination the manager could not give because, in his terror, his stammer worsened and he could not get the words out. It was another emotional, highly charged day for Kamara, made worse by the huge cameras of the local news crews who followed him everywhere. He was happy with ours because it was so small and, probably, because we were two women who didn't crowd him. But the bulk of the crews and their equipment nearly panicked him. Over the following months Kamara and I spoke daily and met regularly. Sometimes Sara or another colleague came too and filmed. Other times, we just sat and chatted. Kamara had a rollercoaster of a life those first few months - tracing and meeting lost siblings, trying to get benefits to live on, trying to come to terms with the fact that, after a 20-year battle to clear his name, people now expected him just to forget about it. He had virtually no friends and nothing to do except go over the case papers which had been the focus of his life for so long. He was not offered counselling; he needed people to talk to. I had to resolve issues too. How do you draw the line when you are so personally involved? There were times when I thought Kamara would end up homeless because he didn't exist in the eyes of the social services and wasn't eligible for housing. Should I offer my spare room? I couldn't film with him all day and then leave him out in the cold, but I couldn't save him either. How could I make a film about the injustice done to people freed after wrongful conviction, but step in and provide the food and shelter he was denied? Three months after Kamara's release he reached his lowest point. He had arranged to go to the House of Commons to meet his MP, Louise Ellman, with whom he had corresponded regularly from prison. We arranged to meet at Westminster underground station where we had permission to film Kamara's arrival. It had always been virtually impossible to ask Kamara to do anything for the camera. He felt self-conscious walking in or out of a building for us, so we couldn't get set-up shots. He would get angry and anxious and was in danger of de-camping entirely; we always had to grab whatever we could on the hoof. On this particular June morning, Kamara was in such a state of despair he could barely talk to me. We were held up at the tube station by a delegation of Japanese businessmen on a guided tour. Every time I tried to go up to Kamara to explain, he would cross the street and walk away. He looked gaunt and was a shadow of the punch-drunk but dignified man released from prison a few months previously. At times, Kamara would telephone to say he didn't want any more to do with the film. He would shout and rant and say he was pulling out of the project and wanted all the tapes. He was still being messed around by social services and had no home of his own. He couldn't sleep and spent most nights sitting up at Alexandra Palace, staring at the distant lights of London, wishing he was back in prison. He needed some outlet for the anger that had reached boiling point and I was one of a small number of people with whom he had regular contact. A year on, I class Kamara as a friend. He is now spending his time trying to help other prisoners who claim to be innocent. He has a strong network of supportive friends and family. He has his own home; he has even found love and plans to marry. I have acted as a kind of counsellor to him at times, but have also had to keep a distance and observe. It has been a difficult line to tread, but it has allowed me to witness the extraordinary strength of his character: Kamara survived in spite of the system, not because of it.  Life After Life, a Rough Justice special, is on BBC1 tonight at 10.35pm.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Constable country
fields.trailText: Constable country
fields.body:
Blackmore Vale

Country walkers must look for alternatives to footpaths through farmland, and a magazine article pointed us towards Gillingham, a town we regularly visit for the dentist, but which (despite the attraction of Chantry Fields, where the Stour winds through meadows and is joined by the narrower stream of Shreen water) lacks obvious visual appeal. One guide describes it as "singularly devoid of architecture worth noticing", but John Constable was there in 1820 and 1823, staying with his friend the vicar, and found in the streams, bridges and watermills views worth painting.

Not much of the old picturesque remains, but a footpath (still open for man and dog), across the watermeadow where the chantry chapel once stood, led us over a footbridge hidden in a wood, past two ancient thatched dwellings just right for a Constable view, and into the square beside the old Phoenix Inn. On the way into Gillingham we had passed Slaughtergate farm, set in gentle dairy country. We could not leave the road, so we did not see the long barrow that gives the farm its name, thought to be the burial ground for Danes slain by Edmund Ironside's soldiers before a treaty was made at nearby Peacemarsh. We were luckier on the way home. A quiet residential turning off the Shaftesbury Road leads over yet another stream in this watery plain, towards a field where you can see, just beyond the gate, an impressive arrangement of grassy ramparts, ditches and humps. King John spent £350 on stone here to build a hunting lodge long before the forest was cleared for agriculture.

fields.headline: Pick of the day: TV
fields.trailText: Fever Pitch | Working Girl | This Sporting Life | The Fall of The Roman Empire | Live Football
fields.body:
Films

Fever Pitch
(David Evans, 1996)
10pm, FilmFour

This adaptation of Nick Hornby's hotshot novel is watchable but disappointing - and not only because it's about an Arsenal fan during the club's boring-boring heyday. Colin Firth is Paul, the big kid masquerading as a teacher, but living for Saturday afternoon at Highbury; Ruth Gemmell the colleague turned lover infuriated at sharing him with 11 men, as the promotional guff put it. But the pair aren't very likeable, which sinks the romantic interest; and with the sharp, perceptive humour of the book left behind on the touchline, the highlights are flashbacks to young Paul's awkward, loving relationship with absent dad Neil Pearson.

Working Girl
(Mike Nichols, 1988)
10pm, Sky Cinema

A deft and witty romantic comedy with its heart firmly in the 30s. Melanie Griffith is the secretary trying to go places in the company, but she is being exploited by imperious corporate woman, Sigourney Weaver. Harrison Ford is the other point in the triangle, shifting allegiance from Weaver to Griffith, but the women are very much the bosses. Kevin Wade's script sparkles and there's hilarious comic support from Joan Cusack's secretary.

This Sporting Life
(Lindsay Anderson, 1963)
11.45pm, FilmFour

More sports action, with director Anderson knuckling down to capture the full earthy flavour of David Storey's bleak novel about rugby league, in the days before big salaries and Antipodean sunshine transformed the game. Hardnut Richard Harris batters his way through as miner turned league star Frank Machin, foolishly spurning the plain love of widowed Rachel Roberts. It's a dour, cold tale, and that "Sporting" is deeply ironic. The cast includes a tough scrum of Alan Badel, Colin Blakely and Arthur Lowe.

The Fall of The Roman Empire
(Anthony Mann, 1964)
1.45am, The Studio

This widescreen, Technicolor epic of the empire's last days is a fascinating precursor to the Oscar-laden Gladiator. Christopher Plummer's corrupt emperor Commodus - played by Joaquin Phoenix in Ridley Scott's film - rules a Rome beset by barbarians: the light is growing dim, and Mann creates a tangible sense of spreading darkness. The heroic set pieces - a chariot race, a duel with javelins, the occasional clash of swords, may be weedy compared to Gladiator, but Alec Guinness is a marvellous Marcus Aurelius, Stephen Boyd a creditable, Russell Crowe-ish Livius, and Sophia Loren a classic heroine.

Paul Howlett

Sports

Live Football
7pm, ONsport2 & ONsport1

So, which is the most successful footballing nation in Europe? Will it be Spain or could it be England? Tonight we may know, as Leeds and Arsenal travel to Spain for the right to play each other in the European Cup semi-finals. Even if they both win - and Arsenal will struggle - Spain could still have both Uefa Cup finalists and Real Madrid still in the continent's premier competition.

Simon Burnton

fields.headline: Pick of the day: Radio
fields.trailText: Magic, And Medicine | Black Market Britain | Case Notes
fields.body:
Dr Michael O'Donnell's fascinating series on the medical use of various creatures, Murder, Magic, And Medicine (11.0am, Radio 4), concludes with an examination of animals' self-medication. It includes such examples as chimps who find plants to rid themselves of parasites or even to cure their constipation. Their behaviour is worth observing because it can lead to cures which might otherwise elude medical science.

Allan Urry winds up his investigation into Black Market Britain (8.0pm, Radio 4) with a disturbing report on the IRA's involvement in the dodgy motor fuel racket. The underside of the protests about filling-station prices has been a considerable increase in unofficial suppliers. Criminal gangs have not only been marketing stolen (and untaxed) agricultural diesel, but have introduced unorthodox fuels which work almost as well. What was already a thriving operation in the Irish Republic has been extended to the mainland, and the terrorists are raking in millions.

On television, pathologists are godlike paragons, who can instantly deduce that a stray bone came from a 13-stone Pict with bad knees and halitosis. Conversely, recent official inquiries have portrayed them as heartless monsters hoarding children's organs for no clear purpose. In Case Notes (9.0pm, Radio 4), Dr Graham Easton offers a more balanced account of their work and its scientific importance.

fields.headline: TV review
fields.standfirst: We've seen it all before
fields.trailText: We've seen it all before: Strippers | Britney Spears: There's No Place Like Home | Ball Breakers On The Box
fields.body:
Is there a stripper in the entire country who hasn't been followed around by a camera crew intent on "uncovering the real women" behind the lip gloss and titty tassles? What with high-class erotic performers, private dancers - any old music will do - and lesbian strippers peek-a-booing out from television lately, it's a miracle that these working women actually manage to fling their g-string anywhere without it landing on a big furry mike. Strippers have replaced animals and airline employees as the docusoap-makers' subject of choice.

The number of willing subjects comes as no surprise. After all, in what is quite literally showbusiness, it pays to advertise, especially when your ambitions extend to the heady heights of glamour modelling, acting or pop stardom. What is more remarkable, however, is the appetite of folks - well, men - for this so-softcore-it's-mushy porn, and that commissioners are so convinced of the audience's stupidity, and so uninterested in making interesting television, they continue to bulk order it.

And so along comes Strippers (E4). Only Strippers, implies the narrator, isn't your average exploitative tits'n'ass TV, designed to titilate its male post-pub audience. Strippers, she goes on, has been made by "an all-female team". Well dip me in honey and throw me to the lesbians. How feminist is that.

One imagines that the "all-female team" thought they would subvert the genre with their film and really reveal the real women behind the lip gloss and titty tassles. (Does that sound familiar to you?) Thus, one stripper revealed how much she hates her job and thinks about what she's going to have for her dinner when she's dancing. Another offers the insight that, "It's not an art. It's getting your fanny out in public", while a third sees stripping - being able to manipulate herself and her audience - as empowerment.

What the "all-female team" fails to realise is that the audience doesn't care what these women think or say. Just as the customers in the pubs where the strippers dance treat them like a fruit machine or a juke box - they pop 50p into a pint glass for a brief distraction - so the camera does the same. With ideas above its station, Strippers is the worst kind of documentary. It thinks it's worthy but it's not.

And if you need proof of that, consider that next week Strippers promises an introduction to Kitty, who uses magic in her act. The mind boggles as to from where she pulls the white rabbits. Enough knockers already.

"What's the point in being a virgin if you're going to act like a lap dancer?" snorts the female friend with whom I watch Britney Spears: There's No Place Like Home (Channel 5). She isn't a fan - one of Britney's knockers in fact - though she does concede Britney has "brilliant hair".

None of the many teachers, acquaintances and other residents of Kentwood, Louisiana who line up to sing - or at least mime - Britney's praises, in this weird tour video-cum-tourist board ad for Britney's hometown, comment on the jailbait pop moppet's hair. They were far too busy oohing and aahing at her amazing talents even as a youngster.

Renee Rusciano Donwar, for example, has a lot to answer for. She taught Britney Spears how to dance. "You could always tell she was going to be a big performer", Renee reminisced. "Her personality just came out. Boom", she explained. Boom indeed and there was Britney's personality as we cut to her looking not unlike one of the Strippers, only without a pint glass for her 50 pences. She gyrates, she touches her bits, she glimmers with lip gloss and heaves her cleavage. Jump-cut back to her with pigtails and jeans, talkin' dreamily of her dear old home and how she loves her family, and it is clear there are only two ways Britney could evolve. Either she is going to turn into Madonna or she is going to turn into Michael Jackson.

Much has already been written about the Ball Breakers On The Box (Channel 4) so I shan't say much more other than it was another sufferer of Salacious Title Syndrome seemingly endemic to Channel 4. I only hope the other channels resist infection lest Time Of Our Lives becomes Sex Change Man In Bomb Blitz and Son Of God turns into Bethlehem Uncovered. At least Strippers did exactly what it said on the tin.

fields.headline: Howard Roberts
fields.standfirst: Proprietor of Wales's first successful commercial art gallery
fields.trailText: Howard Roberts, who has died aged 79, established the Howard Roberts Gallery, Wales's first successful commercial art gallery.
fields.body:
In 1956, when private galleries were rare outside London, Howard Roberts, who has died aged 79, established the Howard Roberts Gallery, Wales's first successful commercial art gallery. It generated interest in Welsh artists, and showed work by names in modern British art such as Henry Moore, Ben Nicholson and Bridget Riley.

Roberts was born in Cardiff and attended Cardiff High School. In his teenage years, a voyage to Italy opened his eyes to Renaissance architecture and the riches of Florence's Uffizi Gallery. From 1938 to 1941, he attended Cardiff College of Art, where he met his first wife, Joan Prosser. His education was interrupted by gruelling war service in North Africa, as a wireless operator in the 57th Field Regiment, Royal Artillery, but he eventually transferred to a camouflage unit in company with other artists. Towards the end of the war he taught art in Florence and met the war artists Carel Weight and William Coldstream.

From 1947 to 1955, Roberts taught at Tiverton Art School in Devon, after which he returned to Cardiff to concentrate on painting. His studio was a £2-a-week former hotel kitchen on the top floor of Imperial Buildings in St Mary's Street.

There were four large rooms with skylights, and he and Joan decided to open a gallery. Its only predecessor had lasted a matter of months. From the beginning, the gallery concentrated on Welsh art. As well as exhibiting established painters such as Augustus John, Alfred Janes and David Jones, it was a significant force in developing the careers of Kyffin Williams, John Elwyn, Ernest Zobole and Will Roberts, among others. It made the reputation posthumously of Morland Lewis, who had died on active service in 1943. The gallery also became a centre for modernism, initially with Ceri Richards and John Piper.

When London's Marlborough Gallery, then establishing the first exclusive contracts with artists, approached Richards and Piper, both would sign only if they could continue showing with Roberts. As a result, Marlborough agreed commission arrangements with the gallery, and let it have work by other artists. By the early 1960s, it stocked work by all the principal Welsh painters and the likes of Barbara Hepworth, Graham Sutherland, Prunella Clough and Patrick Caulfield.

The enterprising programme included thematic exhibitions. Trends and Trendsetters in 1965 selected artistic pioneers including Merlyn Evans, Victor Pasmore and Peter Blake. Undefined Situation showed op art and an environment by Stephen Willats.

Hardly any gallery has had such an impressive stable of artistic talent. The mix proved commercially viable and educated customers into new avenues of collecting.

Howard's quiet strengths in gallery display were complemented by Joan's talent for leading people to appreciate the unexpected. Nevertheless, expenditure on new premises and competition from galleries that followed their example led the gallery to close in 1970.

The couple moved to Wimbledon, where Joan died in 1975. Howard then took a post at Emanuel School in Battersea. He continued to exhibit regularly, especially after his retirement in 1987, painting post-impressionist landscapes characterised by strong use of colour. West Wales and Venice were favourite subjects.

The Howard Roberts Gallery has left a permanent legacy in public collections. The major bequests by Derek Williams to the National Museum in Cardiff and Sir Alex Gordon to the Glynn Vivian Art Gallery in Swansea are dominated by works purchased from the gallery and tastes developed there.

Roberts is survived by his son Paul, a painter and songwriter, his daughter Melanie, an art historian, and his second wife, Marion, whom he married in 1980.

 Howard Roberts, artist, teacher and gallery proprietor, born February 25 1922; died February 27 2001

As well as exhibiting established painters such as Augustus John, Alfred Janes and David Jones, it was a significant force in developing the careers of Kyffin Williams, John Elwyn, Ernest Zobole and Will Roberts, among others. It made the reputation posthumously of Morland Lewis, who had died on active service in 1943. The gallery also became a centre for modernism, initially with Ceri Richards and John Piper. When London's Marlborough Gallery, then establishing the first exclusive contracts with artists, approached Richards and Piper, both would sign only if they could continue showing with Roberts. As a result, Marlborough agreed commission arrangements with the gallery, and let it have work by other artists. By the early 1960s, it stocked work by all the principal Welsh painters and the likes of Barbara Hepworth, Graham Sutherland, Prunella Clough and Patrick Caulfield. The enterprising programme included thematic exhibitions. Trends and Trendsetters in 1965 selected artistic pioneers including Merlyn Evans, Victor Pasmore and Peter Blake. Undefined Situation showed op art and an environment by Stephen Willats. Hardly any gallery has had such an impressive stable of artistic talent. The mix proved commercially viable and educated customers into new avenues of collecting. Howard's quiet strengths in gallery display were complemented by Joan's talent for leading people to appreciate the unexpected. Nevertheless, expenditure on new premises and competition from galleries that followed their example led the gallery to close in 1970. The couple moved to Wimbledon, where Joan died in 1975. Howard then took a post at Emanuel School in Battersea. He continued to exhibit regularly, especially after his retirement in 1987, painting post-impressionist landscapes characterised by strong use of colour. West Wales and Venice were favourite subjects. The Howard Roberts Gallery has left a permanent legacy in public collections. The major bequests by Derek Williams to the National Museum in Cardiff and Sir Alex Gordon to the Glynn Vivian Art Gallery in Swansea are dominated by works purchased from the gallery and tastes developed there. Roberts is survived by his son Paul, a painter and songwriter, his daughter Melanie, an art historian, and his second wife, Marion, whom he married in 1980.  Howard Roberts, artist, teacher and gallery proprietor, born February 25 1922; died February 27 2001

fields.headline: Pamela Dellar
fields.standfirst: Leading light in the world of community theatre
fields.trailText: Pam Dellar, who has died aged 73, was a leading light in the world of community theatre.
fields.body:
I first met Pam Dellar, who has died aged 73, when she invited me to Hull Arts Centre in 1974 to see a play, A Farthing for Public Opinion, which she thought would interest me as a local historian. It was a lively production, a vivid, humorous portrayal of the impact on Hull of James Acland, a radical orator and journalist who arrived there in the 1830s and made the town's corrupt corporation the target for his vitriolic tongue and pen.

It was a good example, too, of the documentary style that she had developed in her combined roles of writer, actress and producer, and of her philosophy that "if nothing's happening you make it happen, and a way to make it happen is to make a play". On this occasion more happened than she had expected: the headline in a local newspaper, "Play shows old Hull a corrupt city", resulted in council complaints protests arguing that there was no corruption in Hull.

Pam had already made her name as an outstanding promoter of community theatre, but her career might easily have been different. Born Pamela Goodwin in Crewe, the daughter of a businessman, she and her family later moved to Congleton, where she attended Lowther College School. She then trained at the Central School of Speech and Drama.

In 1948, she began looking for work. Turned down by the Rank Organisation, she was then interviewed by the impresario CB Cochrane. He didn't see her as one of his "young ladies", but he did introduce her to an agent. As a result she joined a group, the Compass Players, who were based in Gloucestershire but travelled all over Britain, taking erudite drama to places where it had never before been seen.

During the three years in the early 1950s that she spent with this company, Pam absorbed social, political and spiritual values that were the inspiration for all her later work: making theatre more accessible to more people, and sharing with them the rich variety of experiences it offers. She was a woman of imagination, vision and ideals who saw her role as opening people's eyes to the possibilities of life, persuading them to break through the restrictions that prevented them from realising their potential.

Later she joined the Century Theatre, where she met and married Harold Dellar. She moved to Hull in 1954 when Harold became a lecturer in social administration at the university. After training as a teacher she briefly taught at Hull High School for Girls, but soon devoted her energies to promoting community arts.

In the mid-1960s she put on a drama evening course. With not a hint of West End glamour, she held the classes in a disused Victorian school. It was, she observed "damp, with antique radiators, an ill-lit vestibule, a large hall, some sinks and a small room where we huddled over a gas fire".

Performances took place in such unlikely venues that it was a relief when all the actors managed to find their way. A series of workshops in the community centre at the Bransholme housing estate culminated in a torchlight procession and bonfire, which came to an abrupt end when the chairman, alarmed by the euphoria, yelled, "Out!" Pam, unusually, decided not to argue.

Bursting with ideas and working with such keen colleagues as Alan Plater, she helped found the Hull Arts Centre, which she was involved in from the first plans in 1963 to its opening in 1970. Various transformations followed, leading to its current incarnation as Hull Truck Theatre. This was the base for John Godber's highly successful plays such as Up 'n' Under, Bouncers, and Putting on the Ritz. Pam encouraged Gill Adams, recent winner of an an Edinburgh fringe festival award, to write her first play, and Gill saw her as someone who ignited talent in people of all ages with an amazing ability to "both scare the hell out of you and inspire you within one conversation".

An integral part of her dynamism was an artistic temperament that could erupt in chair-throwing, though her outbursts were received with delight by disabled actors. It was, they explained, the first time anyone had treated them like other people.

Pam Dellar compiled and edited three books, Plays Without Theatres (1989), People Make Plays (1992) and The Swelling Scene (with Gill Holtby and Barbara Robinson, 1996), all published by Highgate of Beverley.

Defying a cruel illness, she continued her activities unembarrassed by her wheelchair and her need for oxygen. Her husband predeceased her. She leaves a son, a daughter and two granddaughters.

fields.headline: My inspiration
fields.standfirst: Simon Hughes
fields.trailText: Simon Hughes
fields.body:
ñBoth my parents were actors, though my mum gave up when I was three. My dad was a successful character actor, which brought me a certain notoriety, especially when he appeared in the KelloggÍs ads. He didnÍt keep office hours, of course, and in the summer term he would meet me and eight friends at the school gates and take us to play cricket.

ñMy first school was Montpelier Primary in Ealing, London and my only real memory is of eating my lunch in the park. Even in the 1970s my mum was into healthy eating and she refused to allow me to have a school meal; the school refused to allow me to eat a packed lunch on their premises so I had go out by myself every lunch time.

ñI was never particularly academic but IÍve been sports mad since I can remember. I played cricket for Ealing and Middlesex juniors and was captain of the Latymer Upper School team. Hugh Grant was in the same side, but I rather had him down as a cardboard cutout cricketer. He didnÍt bowl and he batted at number 9. ñMy main interests were geography and English, and my earliest attempts at creative writing were writing Daily Telegraph-influenced match reports, which I read out in assembly.

ñI did also take French A-level, mainly because the two teachers, Bruce Perkins and Peter Winter, happened to take cricket as well, but I was hardly a natural. Even though I altered my A-level certificate for French from an F to an E, I still wasnÍt offered an automatic place at university. In fact, it was only after I wrote to Durham mentioning my success with the England U19s and the Middlesex Second XI that I got in at all.î

Simon Hughes is a former county cricketer. He is now a writer and broadcaster with Channel 4 and his latest book, Jargonbusting: an AnalystÍs Guide to Test Cricket, has just been published.

fields.headline: A housewife less ordinary
fields.standfirst: Jenny Male hid her real job when she appeared on The Weakest Link - but was exposed as a prostitute in a tabloid. She tells  Nick Hopkins how it tore her family apart
fields.trailText: Jenny Male hid her real job when she appeared on The Weakest Link - but was exposed as a prostitute in a tabloid. She tells Nick Hopkins how it tore her family apart
fields.body:
Jenny Male pours herself a glass of white wine to calm her nerves and suggests we get a few things straight before we start. "Look, babe, these are the ground rules. No names of ex-husbands or children. And I'd rather you didn't mention where I live."

Being in control is important to Male. Now, perhaps, more than ever. For most of her strikingly privileged life - public school, famous friends, wealthy partners - she felt dependent on others. Then, three years ago, when she was single and, for the first time, penniless, she found a freelance job that paid her a half-decent wage and allowed her to break free from a troubled past. The career? Prostitution.

With income came the freedom to manage her own time; to read, to study at university, to see her children. At 42, Male was enjoying independence. But she didn't have it for long.

It was ripped from her, she says, and much more besides, by a Sunday tabloid which three weeks ago exposed her life as a "secret call girl", shortly after she appeared as a contestant on the BBC quiz The Weakest Link, hosted by Anne Robinson.

She thought she had persuaded the News of the World not to run the story, but a piece appeared anyway - on Mother's Day - leaving her no time to tell her sons, aged 23, 21 and 17, and her daughter, who is 14. None of them knew, or even suspected. The boys in particular were devastated. "You could have done anything else and we'd have forgiven you, but not this," said one. Another claimed his "whole world had fallen apart".

"To see them hating me," Male says, "to see them so cold and hard, when we have always been so close - it took away feelings from me that prostitution never could. I hope I can get them back."

Male understands their reaction - she was brought up to believe prostitution was "totally vile" - but she wants them to listen to her. Morality works on all sorts of levels, she says.

So how did a self-confessed Sloane Ranger, who grew up in a six-bedroom Worcestershire farmhouse, (with live-in nanny, housekeeper and maids), and went on to marry men who had respectable, well-paid jobs, end up becoming a suburban escort?

The crunch came, she explains, in the mid-1990s, following the break-up of her second marriage, when she was alone and trying to raise four children with virtually no money. "I'd been trying to meet new men, going out on dates with people who had advertised in the Sunday Times magazine. They were wealthy Yorkshire farmer types. They'd take me to expensive restaurants and give me lovely presents. But what use were they to me? I didn't need another fantastic meal or Gucci handbag. I needed to pay for food in Tesco and I wanted time with my children."

When one of her regulars called to ask her out again, she suggested alternative entertainment. "I told him I would see him, but that it would cost £100. And instead of having dinner, I said, why don't we just go to bed? It seemed a much more honest exchange of my time for his money. He wanted to sleep with me, so why go through a four-hour dinner ordeal?

"I'm not prudish about sex. It is a pleasurable thing. I didn't tell anyone because of the way society treats prostitutes. Did I feel ashamed or embarrassed? No, I felt terrific."

Male vetted her clients by asking a series of questions of anyone who answered her newspaper ad. Those who spoke eruditely had a chance. Those who didn't were fobbed off. She charged £70 for every half hour and saw no more than two men per day.

After a series of failed relationships, there was, she says, a simplicity to sleeping with strangers. "I know lots of women in unhappy marriages who are forced into sex. I have suffered violence and abuse from boyfriends, but not once from a client. I'm always on top, so they cannot trap me.

"When men sleep with a prostitute, they wear a condom because they are worried about catching something. You try to get a man to wear a condom when you are on a date! I didn't feel cheap being an escort. Feeling cheap is when you sleep with a man and never get a call the next day."

Appearing on The Weakest Link was, Male says, rather foolish. During the show, which was broadcast on Monday March 26, she told Anne Robinson she was a housewife from Sussex. Someone watching knew it was a lie and two days later, a well-spoken man made an appointment. He told her he was "in property" and was heading for a meeting at Gatwick airport. The man paid Male £70, but then took a call on his mobile phone and said he had to leave immediately.

Male says she tried to give the money back, but he insisted.

Male was the victim of a classic tabloid exposé. In a blind panic, she demanded to speak to a senior editor to plead that the story should not be printed. "I told him the pain and hurt this would heap on my children. He told me the paper was doing me a favour because I'd been putting myself in great danger as a prostitute."

Male agreed to see a journalist face to face and by Saturday evening she was urging a reporter who had flown to the Algarve not to pursue the story. The paper went ahead re gardless. "A friend called me at 8am to say I was on the front page. I rang home immediately and spoke to my son. I told him something awful had happened, but I couldn't bring myself to tell him what it was. I didn't know what to say. I'd never considered myself a whore before it was written in the paper. For the first time in my life, I felt I'd been raped."

On Sunday evening, her daughter and middle son flew to Portugal for the most difficult meeting of all their lives. "I met them at the airport and my son's body language said it all. The next morning we went for a walk along the beach and he told me I had destroyed the family."

Knowing that the News of the World hoped to run a second story the following week, Male needed advice on damage limitation. She rang international directory inquiries and asked for Max Clifford in London. The number was in the book.

Clifford advised her to give the News of the World a story or risk seeing it print whatever it liked. She cooperated and was paid £1,000 by the paper. Clifford received nothing.

"I told them my clients included a doctor, a judge and an Olympic gold medallist. It was rubbish, but it kept the names and photographs of those closest to me out of the paper. I was wary of ringing Max, but he gave me good advice when I was crying my eyes out and I'm grateful to him."

Male is now back in the UK and trying to reconstruct her life. She has "retired" from prostitution. With the help of her daughter, she is hoping to be reconciled with her sons.

"The stuff about Mum is not going to affect the way I feel for her," the 14-year-old says. "And it's not going to affect the way she feels for me."

fields.headline: Ol' Blue Eyes is tops, poll shows
fields.trailText: The enduring appeal of Frank Sinatra lives on as he has beaten his nearest rival Elvis Presley to be crowned most popular voice of the century, according to a poll of more than 40,000 BBC Radio 2 listeners.
fields.body:
The enduring appeal of Frank Sinatra lives on as he has beaten his nearest rival Elvis Presley to be crowned most popular voice of the century, according to a poll of more than 40,000 BBC Radio 2 listeners.

Ol' Blue Eyes, who was renowned for his rich voice and high living, secured many more votes than Presley, who is still regarded by many popular music lovers as the king of rock'n'roll.

Thousands of listeners of Radio 2 helped compile the Voices of the Century list - in total 44,756 votes were cast, with the majority received via the station's website.

The views of a panel of singers and musicians were also taken into consideration by disc jockey Paul Gambaccini and producer Kevin Howlett, who compiled the list.

Part of the reason for Sinatra's success, aside from the quality of his music, was the extraordinary length of his musical career - 53 years. Close behind him was Presley, who is credited as having the most number one singles by a solo artist in the US and Britain.

Of the top 10 singers, only two - Aretha Franklin and Barbra Streisand - are alive. The smooth ballads of Nat King Cole secured his place at number three, with jazz singer Ella Fitzgerald in fourth place, followed by Bing Crosby in fifth position.

The list is dominated by men, with a total of 66 male and 34 female singers.

Former Beatles John Lennon and Paul McCartney were at sixth and 12th place respectively, with the latter being credited for his work with the Beatles, with Wings, and in his solo career.

Only a few of the singers are still making any impression on the charts - such as Robbie Williams, Sting and U2's Bono.

The poll excludes classical and operatic performers, although Luciano Pavarotti is an exception at number 46 because of his chart success in the 1990s.

It is inevitably likely to prompt much debate among music lovers, as it poses such questions as whether David Bowie is really a better singer than Bob Dylan, the relative merits of Kate Bush and Madonna, and whether Robbie Williams really deserves only his relatively humble ranking at number 89.

Gambaccini, who presented a full rundown of the singers on Radio 2 over the Easter weekend, said: "It was an emphatic victory for Fabulous Frank - it wasn't even close.

"Frank Sinatra is the voice of the century and he is clearly the winner, both through listeners' and our experts' votes."

He added: "Interestingly both public and panel appreciated the late Eva Cassidy, who by reaching number one in the UK album chart in March 2001 with material recorded in the 90s, is the most recent artist on the list.

"The earliest singer in the list is Enrico Caruso, the first star of the gramophone, who recorded popular material as well as classical favourites."
