fields.bodyText: The enduring appeal of Frank Sinatra lives on as he has beaten his nearest rival Elvis Presley to be crowned most popular voice of the century, according to a poll of more than 40,000 BBC Radio 2 listeners. Ol' Blue Eyes, who was renowned for his rich voice and high living, secured many more votes than Presley, who is still regarded by many popular music lovers as the king of rock'n'roll. Thousands of listeners of Radio 2 helped compile the Voices of the Century list - in total 44,756 votes were cast, with the majority received via the station's website. The views of a panel of singers and musicians were also taken into consideration by disc jockey Paul Gambaccini and producer Kevin Howlett, who compiled the list. Part of the reason for Sinatra's success, aside from the quality of his music, was the extraordinary length of his musical career - 53 years. Close behind him was Presley, who is credited as having the most number one singles by a solo artist in the US and Britain. Of the top 10 singers, only two - Aretha Franklin and Barbra Streisand - are alive. The smooth ballads of Nat King Cole secured his place at number three, with jazz singer Ella Fitzgerald in fourth place, followed by Bing Crosby in fifth position. The list is dominated by men, with a total of 66 male and 34 female singers. Former Beatles John Lennon and Paul McCartney were at sixth and 12th place respectively, with the latter being credited for his work with the Beatles, with Wings, and in his solo career. webTitle: Seahenge timber could turn into 'tankful of sludge'

fields.headline: Seahenge timber could turn into 'tankful of sludge'
fields.trailText: The 4,000-year-old timbers of Seahenge are in danger of turning into "a tankful of sludge", while academic argument rages about the eventual fate of the unique monument.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The 4,000-year-old timbers of Seahenge are in danger of turning into "a tankful of sludge", while academic argument rages about the eventual fate of the unique monument.

Many archaeologists now believe the circle, which appeared at low tide on the beach at Holme-next-the-Sea in Norfolk in a storm two years ago, should never have been excavated. If no money can be found for permanent display the timbers will be reburied, near their original site.

English Heritage believes burial will preserve the timbers, possibly for another generation with more money to spare for one of the most evocative ancient monuments ever found.

However, some scientists, including Mark Jones, Cambridge professor of archaeological science, believe burial will destroy the monument. He is convinced that the timbers will decay rapidly if buried.

The Timber Circle Forum has concluded that permanent display is impractical and too expensive, and that the timbers should be buried. An English Heritage spokeswoman said the decision will soon be taken by the commissioners, probably next month.

Rosemary Cramp, former professor of archaeology at Durham, of Antiquaries, said: "This is a sorry story. If there is now good scientific evidence that burial will destroy the timbers, there must be time to halt the process and consider all the options, including the funding options for permanent display."

Other archaeologists put it more strongly. Mike Pitts, an authority on the history of Stonehenge and Avebury, said: "Archaeologists may be about to turn one of the great ancient discoveries of our time into the greatest archaeological disaster." Local archaeologists and English Heritage agreed that the scouring action of the tide would destroy the timbers.

They were removed amid protests and taken to Flag Fen, outside Peterborough, where Francis Pryor and his wife, Maisie Taylor, have become authorities on ancient waterlogged timber. Dr Pryor said: "My fear is that by the time a decision is taken, they will turn to the timbers and find there is nothing left but a tankful of sludge."

webTitle: 5p punter urged to collect his £130,000 winnings

fields.headline: 5p punter urged to collect his £130,000 winnings
fields.trailText: A pensioner in south Wales who put a series of 5p bets on six horse races has won more than £130,000 - if he comes forward to collect his winnings.
fields.body:
A pensioner in south Wales who put a series of 5p bets on six horse races has won more than £130,000 - if he comes forward to collect his winnings.

Before the final race on Saturday afternoon, the unnamed man phoned his bookmaker to ask how much he would get if his horse won. Told it would be in excess of £100,000, he put the phone down to watch the race on the television - and has not been heard of since.

Bookmakers Jack Brown last night appealed for the man, who is from a small village near Bridgend, to come forward. The pensioner placed 5p bets totalling £6.30 on six races at Kempton Park and Haydock. His first horse, Bob's Buster, lost. His next choices, Crystal Gift and Skillwise, both at 12-1, and Heavenly Whisper at 16-1, ran out winners. When Herodotus, making his racecourse debut, won at 33-1, the man made his call to the betting shop.

By then he had won £7,500 on a complicated game run by the shop that includes an accumulator. When his final choice, appropriately named Tycoon's Last, won at 20-1, his winnings totalled £136,223.72. If he had paid the tax on his stake when making the bets, he would have been due a further £13,000.

A spokesman for Jack Brown said: "It is a phenomenal return. Somebody out there is walking around with a betting slip in their pocket worth £130,000. We're hoping he will get in touch with us soon."

webTitle: Docker with fear of illness gets payout

fields.headline: Docker with fear of illness gets payout
fields.trailText: A retired docker has become the first person in Britain to win compensation for the stress of worrying about whether he will get an asbestos-related disease, despite showing few signs of developing one.
fields.body:
A retired docker has become the first person in Britain to win compensation for the stress of worrying about whether he will get an asbestos-related disease, despite showing few signs of developing one.

Ronald Lyons, 68, who worked with asbestos on Southampton docks for more than 15 years, suffers frequent panic attacks, bouts of "paranoia" and severe depression because he is convinced he will be struck down with such an illness.

Mr Lyons, who has chronic breathing problems and diabetes, was among hundreds of dockers employed to unload cargo, including bags of asbestos, from ships' holds during the 1950s and 1960s.

"Of all the things we handled the asbestos was the most deadly of all," he said yesterday.

"We wouldn't be able to see each other sometimes because of the clouds of dust. They did not tell us there was any danger at the time. They just let us get on with it."

The father of five, from Rownhams, near Southampton, described the trauma of watching colleagues with whom he had worked die from asbestos-related lung complaints and expressed a deep fear he would meet the same fate. "Several of my colleagues have already died of asbestos-related illness, so why shouldn't I die like them? I breathed it in just like they did, for more than a decade. I am convinced that this is the problem with my chest.

"When I used to go into town people used to keep coming up saying 'Did you hear about so and so? He died of asbestos.' Eventually, you get paranoid about it."

Doctors had warned him he could develop a fatal disease associated with asbestos such as mesothelioma, a form of lung cancer, he said.

"It is like someone holding a loaded gun to your head and saying they are going to pull the trigger but they won't tell you when. It's like a time bomb inside me.

"I have been waking up at night with panic attacks about it and I really want the ground to swallow me up."

He was awarded an undisclosed out-of-court settlement by his former employers, Union Castle (now the Stuntbrand Mail Steam Ship Co) and Associated British Ports, earlier this month after a seven-and-a-half-year legal battle.

"It's the only case in Britain of its kind. It is unique in so much as no one has ever been paid compensation for not ac tually showing any signs of an asbestos illness. But it is something I know is going to happen. It's just a matter of when," he said.

His solicitors, Moore & Blatch of Southampton, confirmed he was the first person they had come across who had obtained a compensation settlement in such circumstances.

Mr Lyons said he was happy to have won his battle but he branded the size of the award "pitiful" and "an insult". Although he refused to divulge the exact amount because it was a "personal matter", he confessed it was "well below £10,000".

He added: "To be honest, it is not about the compensation. If they had given me £600,000 it would not solve my problems. I have to go on suffering every day. Nothing can change that."

The Transport and General Workers' Union, which is involved in the organisation of an asbestos awareness raising week later this month, said yesterday it was important to recognise that the substance remained a crucial health and safety issue.

"Despite the fact that it is banned in the UK there is still asbestos up and down the country with which dockworkers and construction workers come into daily contact," a spokesman said.

webTitle: Two hurt in oil refinery explosion

fields.headline: Two hurt in oil refinery explosion
fields.standfirst: 'Miracle' escape for workers as flames leap 200ft high
fields.trailText: Two oil refinery workers suffered minor injuries yesterday in a "miraculous escape" from an explosion that shook one of the UK's biggest ports and sent a column of smoke a mile high.
fields.body:
Two oil refinery workers suffered minor injuries yesterday in a "miraculous escape" from an explosion that shook one of the UK's biggest ports and sent a column of smoke a mile high.

Windows were shattered more than half a mile away from the Conoco complex at Immingham on the Humber estuary, where 60 firefighters tackled flames leaping 200ft from a shattered liquid petroleum gas tank.

Four staff were missing in the confusion after the explosion, which threatened other LPG and petrol tanks on the 480 acre complex on the port's South Killingholme reach.

They were later accounted for after a series of roll calls of 199 Conoco employees and contractors working on expanding the plant.

Investigators were hoping to get closer to the wrecked tank last night to start tracing the cause of the blast. There were no initial indications of terrorist involvement.

An air ambulance and seven paramedic teams were sent to the complex after scores of emergency calls at 2.30pm, which triggered the port's incident emergency system. Residents, whose houses were shaken by the blast, were told to shut doors and windows and stay inside.

Black smoke poured from the stricken section of the refinery, clearly visible from Immingham, six miles inland, where a stench of petrol sent sightseers back indoors. Cars on the dual carriageway linking the port to the M180 were hit by flying debris but escaped serious damage.

Pauline Hull, chairwoman of South Killingholme parish council, said she had been terrified by "a huge explosion" while out walking. "There was a whoosh sound, then an almighty explosion. After that there were many more blasts, one after the other. A huge flame of fire shot into the sky, and then there was another explosion.

"It was so frightening. I ran home, and everybody was rushing out of their houses. It's an absolute miracle if nobody was badly hurt. The lady next door to me had her greenhouse door blown off, and we are half a mile away.

"Apparently the community centre had its extractor fans blown in, and that's about the same distance away."

Hilda Howell, who described the blast as the worst she had heard since the second world war, found her living room at South Killingholme black with soot.

Her neighbour Graham Chapman said: "There was a fireball of about 200ft high and 200ft wide. The explosion made the ground and the house shudder. It has gone with a hell of a bang."

Angela Smith, 43, of Immingham, said she felt the main tremor from the explosion go right through her body as her house shook. Ros Chapman, who farms at North Killingholme, a mile from the plant, said: "My husband thought the boiler had gone up in the house."

The Conoco plant is one of two sprawling refineries in the Immingham complex, which, when combined with the other Humber centres of Grimsby, Goole and Hull, forms Britain's biggest port.

Seven pipelines connect the refinery and a neighbouring one - run by Fina and Total - to Immingham's gas jetty, which takes tankers of up to 300,000 tonnes.

The two operations form Britain's third largest refinery and were a prime target for last autumn's petrol blockade.

The Conoco plant has a frequently practised emergency procedure, and police, fire and ambulance teams were at the scene within minutes.

Margaret Hartley, who has lived near the refinery for 31 years, said: "The fire people on the site are very quick to respond, as are the local fire brigade. People aren't panicking because we trust the refinery.

"The last time something like this happened was a few years ago, and there were no casualties then."

First aid was given to secondary victims of the blast, including a woman blown off her feet while walking over a mile away. A one mile exclusion zone was imposed for non-residents to keep sightseers away from the area.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Climber hurt in Ben Nevis fall
fields.body:
Climber hurt in Ben Nevis fall

A climber was fighting for his life in Belford hospital, Fort William, last night after falling 700ft from Ben Nevis. The man, his 30s and from Scotland, was picked up by the Loch Aber mountain rescue team after falling into No 2 gully.

Sword attack injures three

Three men were in hospital in Cheltenham last night with serious injuries after being attacked with a samurai sword, near the scene of a similar attack last year in which a Liberal Democrat party worker was killed and an MP injured. Police said a 21-year-old man had been arrested.

Mob stops match

An amateur football match at Cookley, near Kidderminster, Worcestershire, was halted on Saturday when a 25-strong mob attacked players. Police refused to name the teams but said the mob smashed changing rooms and a social club.

Young inmates wreck prison

Police and jail staff are investigating a disturbance at Norwich prison's young offenders' block when five youths caused £5,000 damage during the weekend.

Man accused of killing wife

Belfiore Apicella, 78, is to appear at Wellingborough magistrates court, Northamptonshire, today charged with murdering his wife, Carmella, 76, on Saturday evening.

webTitle: Icing forced emergency landing by British jet

fields.headline: Icing forced emergency landing by British jet
fields.trailText: A safety warning has been issued after a passenger jet on its way to Britain was forced to land at Paris when an engine iced up, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A safety warning has been issued after a passenger jet on its way to Britain was forced to land at Paris when an engine iced up, it emerged yesterday.

The plane, which was carrying 109 passengers and five crew, was a BAe 146, a series popular with charter operators on short haul flights, and also often used to ferry the royal family and government ministers.

Pilots flying the type have been warned against exceeding a specified altitude in any situation that could involve icy weather.

The plane was cruising at 28,000ft on its way from Marseilles to land at Stansted one evening in last June when it met a thin layer of cloud and climbed to 31,000ft, the type's maximum altitude.

Storms forced the plane to descend to 26,000ft. The captain, aged 43 and with 7,800 hours flying experience, noticed that the fan speed of one of the four Lycoming engines was decreasing. The engine also began to overheat.

The captain shut down the engine and was given permission to divert to Charles de Gaulle airport, where he landed safely.

An examination of the plane's flight recorder data, according to an air accidents investigation branch bulletin yesterday, found that the engine problem was probably caused by ice; the bulletin said the other engines were unaffected because of minor variations in their condition.

The BAe 146's icing problem had been noted in the past, and modifications made to some planes of the type but not all. Pilots flying planes with unmodified engines have to follow a revised flight manual - drawn up two years ago - prohibiting them from flying above 26,000ft in conditions where a plane is likely to encounter ice.

In this case, the bulletin said that the revised instructions were misinterpreted. The pilot had believed he could fly above 26,000ft for a portion of the flight when there was no risk of encountering ice. The manufacturer intended that a plane should not fly above the limit at all if ice was going to be encountered at any point.

Since the incident the manual has been rewritten to clarify the point, and the manufacturer has been told to review the risks of the problem. Extra training may also be given to pilots.

The BAe 146 first flew commercially in 1983, and over the next 10 years more than 200 came into service. There are three versions: the Marseilles plane was a 300 series, built in 1989, with a maximum of 112 seats.

The Queen has at her disposal three adapted BAe 146s, which can carry a maximum of 26 passengers. Last year it was reported that the Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne had complained about having smelled fuel while on the planes.

Earlier this year it emerged that government ministers used the royal flight more often than the Queen and her family between last April and the end of January. The government argued that royal flights were often cheaper than commercial flights.

It is not known how many BAe 146s are still flying with unmodified engines.

Nobody from BAE Systems, formed following a merger between British Aerospace and Marconi Electronic Systems, was available for comment.

The BAe 146 first flew commercially in 1983, and over the next 10 years more than 200 came into service. There are three versions: the Marseilles plane was a 300 series, built in 1989, with a maximum of 112 seats. The Queen has at her disposal three adapted BAe 146s, which can carry a maximum of 26 passengers. Last year it was reported that the Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne had complained about having smelled fuel while on the planes. Earlier this year it emerged that government ministers used the royal flight more often than the Queen and her family between last April and the end of January. The government argued that royal flights were often cheaper than commercial flights. It is not known how many BAe 146s are still flying with unmodified engines. Nobody from BAE Systems, formed following a merger between British Aerospace and Marconi Electronic Systems, was available for comment.

webTitle: Woman run over and killed by thieves

fields.headline: Woman run over and killed by thieves
fields.standfirst: Robbery victim crushed by car after chase for stolen handbag
fields.trailText: Robbery victim crushed by car after chase for stolen handbag.
fields.body:
Police last night launched a murder inquiry after thieves deliberately drove over a woman they had just robbed.

The 43-year-old from west London, who has not been named, ran after the pair as they fled with her handbag.

Travellers at Euston station, central London, watched in horror as she was hurled on to the bonnet of the Ford Fiesta after she tried to stop them, but was thrown off and then crushed beneath the front wheels.

Witnesses said the woman clung to the bonnet of the car for up to half a minute while the driver drove forwards and backwards at speed, trying to shake her off. The woman screamed for help but finally lost her grip and was run over by the car, as her husband looked on.

Detective Inspector Martin Lee, of the Metropolitan police's serious crime group, described the incident as "absolutely horrendous and absolutely traumatic".

"It would appear that she was run over deliberately. I cannot say anything other than that it was a horrendous and appalling incident."

He said detectives were examining CCTV footage from cameras at the station, adding that they were hunting a man and a woman, both white and in their mid-20s.

Asked about the woman's decision to chase after the thieves, he said: "She acted bravely on impulse."

The woman was waiting for a train in the Cafe Ritazza coffee shop at the station with her husband at around 9am yesterday when her handbag was snatched.

Justin Nam, a waiter at the cafe, said that the woman chased after the thieves, although her husband tried to stop her. The thieves then jumped into a white Ford Fiesta and tried to drive away.

Det Insp Lee said the circumstances surrounding her being hit by the car were "a little sketchy".

Martin Johnson, a Big Issue seller who was on his way to work, said he saw the car driving at between 40 and 50mph while the woman clung on to the bonnet, kicking violently.

He said that the Fiesta then reversed at full speed and hit a kerb, while the woman screamed "help me, help me" to a nearby bus driver.

"The car then went full speed ahead and the woman's legs were now dangling over the front," he said. "She lost her grip and the car went over her. I heard a thudding noise and screams.

"As the front wheels went over her, her body was turning over, but because she was a big-boned woman, her whole body was being crushed by the underside of the car.

"The driver had no thought of stopping. It was horrific, I could not believe the driver just ploughed over her like that."

An air ambulance was called and the woman was taken to the Royal London hospital in Whitechapel, east London, for emergency surgery, but she suffered a heart attack and died around 2pm from multiple injuries.

The couple had no children, a Scotland Yard spokeswoman said last night.

Two firefighters rushed out of nearby Euston Road fire station when they heard the commotion. Station commander Bill Carruthers said they saw the car stop and the woman fall to the ground. As the firefighters were running towards the woman the car drove over her," he said.

One of the officers threw his helmet at the car's windscreen in an attempt to stop the thieves escaping, while another tried to give the woman first aid.

"We just felt real anger at what we were seeing," said one.

"Now we feel nothing but sympathy for the poor woman and her family. It was terrible."

Mr Carruthers added: "The crews are used to dealing with road accidents and fire injuries so the physical side of it wasn't too dramatic."

A British Transport police spokesman said the car was later found abandoned, with damaged front panels. The woman's handbag had also been handed to police.

fields.headline: Playing footsie with Nader
fields.trailText: My one quibble with Gary Younge's otherwise excellent piece (Challenging the big buck, April 15) is this: Nader's been saying and doing the same things for over 30 years. I grew up reading Unsafe at Any Speed, his attack on the automobile industry which he wrote in the 60s. I decided not to follow him then, and I feel the same now. Everyone knew the catastrophe that a Bush presidency would be, most of all Nader.
fields.body:
My one quibble with Gary Younge's otherwise excellent piece (Challenging the big buck, April 15) is this: Nader's been saying and doing the same things for over 30 years. I grew up reading Unsafe at Any Speed, his attack on the automobile industry which he wrote in the 60s. I decided not to follow him then, and I feel the same now. Everyone knew the catastrophe that a Bush presidency would be, most of all Nader.

He also knows how the system works: there are two parties, and only two parties, and when it comes down to hardball, you choose either of those teams or you're not in the game. Bush a big business presidency? America has been in thrall to big business since 1776, and until the whole of the American people chooses to live in the world with everyone else, that's the way it will be. Ralph Nader playing footsie again in the political arena won't change a thing.
Bonnie Greer
London

 It isn't "astonishing political arrogance" of Democrats to say that if Nader hadn't run for the presidency, Al Gore would be in the White House. It is psephological fact, just as it is that literally anything might have swung Florida, the vote there was so narrow. Gary Younge overlooks the Perot effect. Perot received some 5% of the popular vote in the 1996 presidential election; his "successor", Pat Buchanan, only 1% in 2000. In Florida certainly, and in New Mexico, and likely in Missouri, Iowa, New Hampshire, Tennessee and Nevada, if Perot had run and done as well as in 1996, the Bush vote would have been split further and Gore would have won by a landslide.
Robert Worcester
London Worc@mori.com

 Driving home along the Dulles corridor at 2am this week and seeing empty office building after empty office building with every floor fully lit, made me see the error of my ways. Dubya is right. America cannot afford to ratify the Kyoto agreement.
Kevin Corley
Leesburg, Virginia

fields.headline: Cuba libre
fields.trailText: When the UN is asked to condemn human rights abuses in Cuba, Steve Wilkinson of the Cuba Solidarity Campaign protests that the United States and Britain are being vindictive (Letters, April 16).
fields.body:
When the UN is asked to condemn human rights abuses in Cuba, Steve Wilkinson of the Cuba Solidarity Campaign protests that the United States and Britain are being vindictive (Letters, April 16).

Can this be the same Steve Wilkinson who, only last month, was urging his fellow journalists in the NUJ to vote against a motion tabled for the union's annual conference on the grounds that it was wrong to condemn press censorship in Cuba?

If Steve Wilkinson wants to make himself look an ass by supporting human rights abuses, that's his business. But to do so in the name of "solidarity" with Cuba is nauseating. Yes, we should condemn bullying by the United States and question the double standards of our own government. But slavish support for Cuba is counterproductive because it obscures the real arguments in favour of the society Cuba is trying to create.
Jacob Ecclestone
London scawfell@dircon.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Let's get on and vaccinate

fields.headline: Let's get on and vaccinate
fields.trailText: The toughest decision is to know when to stop (Teams get ready to vaccinate cattle, April 16). A rapid "cull and dispose" policy may be appropriate in the early stages of a foot and mouth outbreak, but it must be imposed hard and fast.
fields.body:
The toughest decision is to know when to stop (Teams get ready to vaccinate cattle, April 16). A rapid "cull and dispose" policy may be appropriate in the early stages of a foot and mouth outbreak, but it must be imposed hard and fast.

Sadly we must now accept that this outbreak was not dealt with hard, nor fast, enough. The most optimistic forecasts show that there will still be sporadic cases in the early autumn by which time over 3m animals will have died. Pessimistic forecasts suggest 30% of all livestock will need to die and cases will continue well into 2002.

The painful alternative of allowing the disease to run, with mass vaccination and losing our disease free status, is now the lesser of evils. Farmers can not condone the unnecessary deaths of healthy animals, or the suffering of animals unable to be moved from muddy fields. Farmers are worried that all these acts are creating an appallingly wrong image of agriculture. Farmers also are aware that tourism can't be made to suffer much longer, and ancillary businesses must not be pushed into bankruptcy. For the sake of the whole countryside, farming must now suffer the loss of our disease free status and the loss of our export markets.
Anthony Steel (farmer)
Lockerbie, Dumfriesshire aisteel@aol.com

 It is a sad day when one has to feel sorry for the government. But it is made to seem foolish when "best advice" from British experts and scientists, said to be based on scientific facts, can be both conflicting and unreliable at best, and spun in favour of particular interests at worse. Now the chief scientist is singing a different song from the chief vet, while both seem to ignore significant information available on the internet, from sources such as the Canadian government.

It is not surprising the public loses faith that policies are sound and credible when the Ministry of Agriculture says the foot and mouth virus can travel for as much as a 100km on dust in air currents, but that GM maize pollen will travel no more than 50m or so. We are told foot and mouth cannot infect humans (shades of BSE/CJD?), yet several sources agree it can, if only rarely, causing only flu-like symptoms with some blistering (Warwickshire county council) and "exanthemas on fingertips and interdigital spaces, fever and miocarditis" (Our Food website) .

Were the strains of the picornavirus that caused rare cases of FMD in humans the same as that now in British cloven-hooved livestock? There is, apparently, no record of human-to-human transmission (Bupa website), but if the infection is rare, was this ever looked for?

The Institute for Animal Health is the official international vaccine bank. It holds the stock vaccine, long-lasting concentrates, stored under liquid nitrogen, that have been obtained from "commercial sources that offer the highest standards in vaccine manufacture and quality control" (institute website). The vaccine bank was established in 1985. Presumably these vaccine sources were all created from cattle that, even at that date, could be guaranteed free from BSE. Or might there be some small reluctance to vaccinate because that cannot be certain (Afro-nets website)?
Dr Colin Leakey
Cambridge clal@zoom.co.uk

 I was asked recently by a friend in the west country to set up a website which corresponds to the request made by Judith Cook (Letters, April 14). The site is active and allows for correspondence and debate which is open and visible to all. It also has links to other relevant sites http://www.vexxed.co.uk
Andrew Walworth
London andrew.walworth@vexxed.co.uk

fields.headline: Borderline issues
fields.trailText: Malachi O'Doherty's thoughtful critique (Breeding schemes, April 13) of what others call Sinn Fein's "rabbit politics" - dubious demography allegedly delivering a majority of northern Catholics for Irish unity - highlights a contradiction in the Belfast agreement.
fields.body:
Malachi O'Doherty's thoughtful critique (Breeding schemes, April 13) of what others call Sinn Fein's "rabbit politics" - dubious demography allegedly delivering a majority of northern Catholics for Irish unity - highlights a contradiction in the Belfast agreement.

This is the tension between "sufficient consensus" - the checks and balances that prevent simple majority rule by requiring that key decisions have majority support from both nationalist and unionist blocs in the assembly - and the theoretical provision for a referendum, based on 50% plus one, that could see Northern Ireland become part of a united Ireland. Irish unity on such a slim basis could simply rekindle conflict by creating a new disaffected minority.

All this highlights another contradiction, between the hope of building more normal left-right-centre politics to unite Catholics and Protestants in common endeavours on bread-and-butter issues, and the way in which the new political dispensation could entrench rather than transcend such ancestral voices. I, along with many others, backed the Belfast agreement in the hope that such arrangements were a necessary nonsense to help overcome the legacy of the troubles. Irish unity may occur somewhere down the line but, in the meantime, the priority is reconciliation within the north, without which a wider unity would not be worth a penny candle.
Gary Kent
Chair, New Dialogue

 Malachi O'Doherty is right to point out that it is extremely simplistic to assume that a Catholic majority in Northern Ireland would automatically ensure a united Ireland. Indeed, he may be right to say that up to 30% of Catholics would not support the idea, but there is another factor that needs consideration: the number of Protestants who would prefer unification.

This is not as fanciful as one might suppose, given that the republic is now in euroland and the numbers of people - of both religious persuasions - who cross the border to fill up with petrol here. There are many other cross-border scams, many of which are an open secret and provide lucrative profits for those willing to bend the law.

It may be economic issues rather than religious distinctions that determine the future of Northern Ireland. Just as many Protestants have already voted with their feet (to leave the province), so many others may be tempted to vote with their wheels to reap benefits in other ways.
Mick Williams
Nenagh, Co Tipperary, Eire mick.williams@ geo2.poptel.org.uk

webTitle: Letters: Slaves to our taste for chocolate

fields.headline: Slaves to our taste for chocolate
fields.trailText: You say "thousands of children aged nine to 12 are thought to be enslaved in Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa producer" (UN to help shipload of 'child slaves', April 14). In our film, Slavery, A Global Investigation, broadcast on Channel 4 last September, we demonstrated beyond reasonable doubt that slavery is widely practised on cocoa plantations in the Ivory Coast.
fields.body:
You say "thousands of children aged nine to 12 are thought to be enslaved in Ivory Coast, the world's top cocoa producer" (UN to help shipload of 'child slaves', April 14). In our film, Slavery, A Global Investigation, broadcast on Channel 4 last September, we demonstrated beyond reasonable doubt that slavery is widely practised on cocoa plantations in the Ivory Coast.

However, the physical nature of the work involved means there is no demand for slaves younger than around 16 years of age. There are younger children enslaved in the Ivory Coast, but they are mostly working on cotton plantations, as recorded in a Unicef investigation in 1999.

We defined a slave as someone who is unpaid, unable to leave and controlled by violence or threat of violence. Using that rigorous definition, the experts we spoke to estimated that some degree of slavery exists on 90% of Ivorien cocoa farms. If this estimate is correct, then since the Ivory Coast produces half the world's cocoa, this leads to the disturbing conclusion that almost half the world's chocolate is contaminated by slavery. As one rescued slave explained it: "Tell the people in Europe who enjoy chocolate, that they are eating my flesh."

Sadly there has been little follow up of our findings. However, the BBC reported last week that thousands of children are indeed being trafficked into slavery in the Ivory Coast from Mali. I hope that now that our allegations have been independently confirmed that the chocolate industry and, most important of all, the public, will take notice of this most appalling form of exploitation and take all possible steps to end it.
Brian Woods
Co-producer, Slavery, a Global Investigation brian@truevisiontv.com

 I wonder how many of this year's chocolate Easter eggs were made from cocoa beans harvested by child slaves similar to those on the MV Etireno (Ship of despair, April 16)? I wrote to the managing director of a premium chocolate manufacturer last November, asking whether the firm tries to avoid sourcing cocoa from the Ivory Coast, and how it monitors the pay and conditions of workers producing cocoa used in their chocolate. I have yet to receive a reply.
Rev Philip Richter
Salisbury

webTitle: Leader: Europe sets enviable holiday standards

fields.headline: Banking on holidays
fields.standfirst: Europe is setting enviable standards
fields.trailText: The Bank of England used to close on over 40 saints days a year. But after 1834, when the number of bank holidays was reduced to four, they were not something you could bank on any more.
fields.body:
The Bank of England used to close on over 40 saints days a year. But after 1834, when the number of bank holidays was reduced to four, they were not something you could bank on any more.

Now there is a move, led by the Fabian Society, to increase them to levels prevailing on the continent, where Italy has 16 and Spain 14. A new ICM poll suggests that three out of four people want January 2 to become a holiday to give more time to recover from the new year. January 2 is not one of those days when people are working at their highest level of productivity.

It is curious how everyone has got used to calling them "bank" holidays, even though banks have fallen greatly in public esteem. Very few people think they should be the touchstone for how many public holidays we should have.

Nowadays banks could not take a complete day off anyway because their internet, cash dispensing and telephone activities carry on throughout the night. Not to put too fine a point on it, maybe it is time that bank holidays were rebranded. It would not seem quite right to call them Building Society holidays or even Tesco days in return for all stores closing for a day.

The now defunct National Economic Development Council once suggested a "Harvest Day" in October but it did not catch on. If the tradition of having a holiday in exchange for an activity ceasing for the day in question, then perhaps there should be a Transportation Day during which all motorised vehicles would be banned. Failing that, everyone should be able to claim a day's holiday to be taken whenever they want it. That, at least, would avoid more bank holiday snarl ups. This could be a chance for Tony Blair to boost his European plans.

If he promised European-scale bank holidays - on the grounds it only makes sense to have the same currency as the rest of Europe if we had the same number of days off to spend it - then he may find that opposition to the euro dwindles rather fast.
fields.bodyText: The Bank of England used to close on over 40 saints days a year. But after 1834, when the number of bank holidays was reduced to four, they were not something you could bank on any more. Now there is a move, led by the Fabian Society, to increase them to levels prevailing on the continent, where Italy has 16 and Spain 14. A new ICM poll suggests that three out of four people want January 2 to become a holiday to give more time to recover from the new year. January 2 is not one of those days when people are working at their highest level of productivity. It is curious how everyone has got used to calling them "bank" holidays, even though banks have fallen greatly in public esteem. Very few people think they should be the touchstone for how many public holidays we should have. Nowadays banks could not take a complete day off anyway because their internet, cash dispensing and telephone activities carry on throughout the night. Not to put too fine a point on it, maybe it is time that bank holidays were rebranded. It would not seem quite right to call them Building Society holidays or even Tesco days in return for all stores closing for a day. The now defunct National Economic Development Council once suggested a "Harvest Day" in October but it did not catch on. If the tradition of having a holiday in exchange for an activity ceasing for the day in question, then perhaps there should be a Transportation Day during which all motorised vehicles would be banned. Failing that, everyone should be able to claim a day's holiday to be taken whenever they want it. That, at least, would avoid more bank holiday snarl ups. This could be a chance for Tony Blair to boost his European plans. If he promised European-scale bank holidays - on the grounds it only makes sense to have the same currency as the rest of Europe if we had the same number of days off to spend it - then he may find that opposition to the euro dwindles rather fast.

webTitle: 'It's been a bit like the Wild West'

fields.headline: 'It's been a bit like the Wild West'
fields.standfirst: The Kilshaw case has exposed major flaws in the rules governing international adoptions. The couple's QC, Allan Levy, tells  Clare Dyer how the sorry saga is speeding up reform
fields.trailText: The Kilshaw case has exposed major flaws in the rules governing international adoptions. The couple's QC, Allan Levy, tells Clare Dyer how the sorry saga is speeding up reform
fields.body:
One look at the TopShop gear and the necklace spelling out "Foxy" and you somehow knew, when Judith Kilshaw arrived at the high court last week, that she was not going to be allowed to take those twins home. The babies she and husband Alan had found on the internet and paid £8,200 to adopt would be on their way back to Missouri, their home state, to face a new legal battle between their estranged biological parents over their future.

The nation watched in fascinated horror as the saga unfolded. First the tiny babies were grabbed back from their first would-be adopters in California after the Kilshaws offered more money, then they were driven across America to be adopted in Arkansas, where the residency requirements, lax though they were, were flouted by the babies' mother. Doubts grew about the couple's suitability as replacement parents.

The Kilshaws' venture into free-market baby acquisition has left them bruised by the media they courted, and tens of thousands of pounds poorer. But the tale, unedifying as it is, will leave one enduring legacy. As the twins head for their fifth short-term home in nine months of life and the battle ground over their custody shifts to a courtroom in St Louis, laws to protect future Belindas and Kimberleys are being rushed into force in Britain.

The Kilshaws' QC, Allan Levy, maintains a discreet professional silence on his controversial clients and the merits of their case. Barristers are obliged by the cab-rank rule to pick up any litigant who happens to flag them down. But Levy - a leading child law specialist whose CV includes the Cleveland abuse inquiry in the 1980s, the Pindown children's home scandal in the early 1990s and the recent case of the Siamese twins Jodie and Mary - welcomes moves to tighten the lax controls on adoption from abroad as a vital protection for vulnerable children.

"The problem has been that intercountry adoption has not been properly regulated in any way," he says. "At worst, it's been a bit like the Wild West, where anything went. Although there have been lots of successful intercountry adoptions, I've been involved in cases in the past where there were thoroughly unsatisfactory goings-on in certain central and south American countries and indeed one lawyer who specialised in adoption in a South American country was jailed.

"In certain countries where there had been civil wars, when the British embassy, perhaps at the instigation of the Official Solicitor, was investigating the source of the child, trying to track down the natural parents, they were finding addresses in war zones that were probably non-existent and certainly couldn't be reached. There was a very real likelihood that a serious racket was going on where the children were being sold or, even worse, kidnapped, or the parents were being subjected to some sort of duress or extortion."

Couples brought in children without the knowledge or approval of social services and immigration officers turned a blind eye. Once the child was settled and had bonded with the new parents, the courts came under huge pressure to approve the adop tion. Had the Kilshaws kept their heads down and avoided the media, the outcome of their case might have been quite different.

There has been only one other recent case where a child brought to the UK for adoption was sent back: last year an adoption agency in Texas got back a seven-month-old baby already removed from the prospective adopters by social services, who had deemed them unsuitable to adopt before they went to America. Had the baby been with the couple for a year, said the judge, the decision would have been much more difficult.

"By the time the procedures were gone through, often a year, 18 months, or two years had gone by and it was almost impossible for the court to move the child, so it was a fait accompli," says Levy. "The welfare of the child demanded that the adoption order be made, even though the whole process may have been very dubious."

From April 30, anyone who brings in a child from abroad without prior approval by an adoption agency and the agreement of the Department of Health will commit a criminal offence, punishable by up to three months in prison, a fine of up to £5,000, or both. The new law will spell the end of immigration officers' practice of simply waving through babies who arrive in their new parents' arms without the proper entry clearance.

The reform was planned before the internet twins hit the headlines but their story was the catalyst for rushing it into law. Ironically, though, it would probably not have stopped the Kilshaws because they had an apparently valid adoption order from the US. American adoption orders are recognised in the UK, along with those of the older Commonwealth countries and many European states. But comparatively few US children are brought into Britain for adoption; more than half now come from China, with India the next biggest source.

A further measure will be needed to make sure that all adoptions from abroad measure up to the stringent standards that apply to home adoptions. The UK is finally on course to ratify the Hague convention on intercountry adoption next year.

Under the convention, couples wanting to adopt a child will have to apply to a central authority here, who will send a report on the would- be parents' suitability to the corresponding authority in the child's country. The adoption will go ahead there only if the natural parents have consented, the central authorities in both countries agree, and the child has been cleared by the Home Office to settle in the UK.

Levy, who has appeared in many adoption cases and written a book on the subject, points out that couples have felt compelled to look abroad not just because of the shortage of young babies to adopt in this country but because social services departments have been so restrictive in their adoption policies. "One of the reasons people were driven to go abroad to countries like China, Ecuador, El Salvador and the USA is that they found social services were not approving them as adopters because they were too old at 35 or 40. Or they were thought to be too middle class or the wrong ethnic origin, or they smoked too much or were overweight. I'm amazed there hasn't been a case that has challenged social services departments on the basis that they were fettering their discretion by taking such narrow views of people who were probably admirable adopters."

The government agrees that many local councils applied too restrictive a policy in the past, allowing too many children to languish in care. The tiny number of babies given up for adoption at birth means that most of the children adopted in the UK come from care, and the government wants more of them to be found permanent homes more quickly. The adoption and children bill, now going through parliament, was originally pencilled in for the government's second term; its fast-tracking is another legacy of the internet twins drama.

"It's horrific how many placements in care some children have," says Levy. "But adoption in this country in the main means older children, and children who have had a bad start in life and who've got physical or psychological problems. The startling statistic is that one adoption in five of children in care breaks down, and for children aged nine or over the failure rate, amazingly, is 40%. So it's not a primrose path by any means. But I think the government is right to try to speed up and centralise the process because it's far too late. There also needs to be much more post-adoption support for families, and much more galvanising into action of particular councils. The disparities between the numbers of adoptions in different authorities and between the length of time different authorities take to find permanent homes for children is disturbing."

But while he welcomes most of the bill, he takes issue with one of its reforms, which he thinks may breach human rights laws. One clause replaces the current provision under which a court may override a natural parent's refusal to consent to adoption, if the parent is deemed to be "unreasonably" withholding agreement. That provision requires the court to weigh up what a reasonable parent would do in the circumstances, and provides some safeguard for the biological parent. The new clause would simply allow the court to override the parent's refusal if the child's welfare warranted it.

"I think there's a real danger of social engineering," says Levy. "It's not a sufficient safeguard to protect the natural parent. At first blush, what's wrong with the welfare of the child being paramount? But I think there's a great temptation for the court to say 'Well, I think that child would have a better future with the adoptive parents' - and that is pure social engineering - rather than having to say that there is no way this child's welfare can be properly protected by the natural parent and so the court is compelled to make an adoption order.

"I anticipate that this will be an area which will be subject to considerable discussion and opposition. I feel very uneasy about it. I think lawyers and others will make their views very firmly known to parliament - at least I hope they do."

fields.headline: Marcel Berlins
fields.standfirst: John Kamara: a story we should all feel ashamed of
fields.trailText: John Kamara: a story we should all feel ashamed of
fields.body:
 We've become accustomed to headlines announcing the release of an innocent from years of unjustified imprisonment following the belated discovery of yet another miscarriage of justice. Most of the stories quickly disappear from public attention. These aren't high-profile cases in the Birmingham Six or Guildford Four league; they're about unspectacular murders for which unknown people wrongly went to prison. But what happens to them when they're released from what's been their only home for 10, maybe 20 or more, years? In a terrific documentary on BBC1 this evening the Rough Justice programme follows one miscarriage victim, John Kamara, from the appeal court's quashing his conviction and setting him free after 17 years of incarceration.

It's a disgraceful story, as shameful in its way as the original wrongfulness of the conviction. Quite simply, Kamara was totally abandoned by the system. On release, he was given £46. That's it. Full stop. He had no home to go to, no friends, no access to any other money, not a word of advice or help from the authorities. He was dumped in the middle of London, a city that he didn't know. If he'd committed the murder for which he'd been convicted, there would have been back-up services available. But as he hadn't done it, he no longer had a status within the system. The probation service couldn't help, because they only deal with the guilty. The social services and the benefits people couldn't help, because he didn't exist for them.

Kamara was lucky that Paddy Hill of the Birmingham Six took him in and put him up (Hill has now started a small organisation to deal with such cases) but it was weeks before he could get any money at all through the system. It's true that Kamara is eligible for compensation - he's received an interim payment - and seems to have settled down with a good woman. Others have not been so lucky. The point is that the help - financial, psychological, practical - is needed by people when they emerge from imprisonment, not weeks, months or years later. Watch this programme and feel ashamed.

 The annual batch of new QCs has been named, accompanied by the customary controversy over the legitimacy and fairness of the process. This time, though, I believe the debate will have to be taken seriously and changes may be in the air. One factor has been the Office of Fair Trading's recent

critical report, given at least tentative approval by the government. Just as importantly, I'm finding growing numbers of thinking judges and barristers questioning the system, and finding it wanting.

It is legitimate to argue that there should be some hallmark or title distinguishing ordinary practitioners from those in a higher category of ability or expertise. But in every other profession such a title is awarded to those who have done something in addition to their normal work in order to be eligible - in medicine, for instance, sitting further examinations and acquiring further specialist experience. Only barristers can convert their status from ordinary to elite without doing anything whatsoever to show added value justifying the dramatically higher fees.

Secondly, what reason is there (other than "It's the way it's always been") for giving the power to grant the QC label to a government minister? Should it not be for the profession itself to reward its more able members with what amount to its certificates of excellence? But behind those procedural issues is the one which really matters: do we need QCs at all? That's what I hope the main debate will be about.

 The Bar Council is sensibly calling for greater security in courtrooms, following the recent attack on Judge Ann Goddard by an accused at the Old Bailey. Apart from any criminal charges that might lie, it is a contempt of court to offer violence to a judge, punishable by - let us be clear about this - the immediate amputation of the offender's right hand. This happened in Salisbury in 1631 to a felon who, annoyed at the judge, "ject un brickbat a le dit justice, que narrowly mist", whereupon the prisoner immediately had "son dexter manus ampute". The language, incidentally, is one of the last examples of Norman-based law-French used in reports of English cases. A leading legal historian, Professor John Baker of Cambridge University, was unable to find any reference to the abolition of the punishment of amputation for such conduct, so it is still presumably the law.

But I suppose, if a judge tries to impose it, the Human Rights Act will step in and rule it contrary to the European Convention. Spoilsport.

webTitle: Mallorca put in mouth to go fourth

fields.headline: Mallorca put in mouth to go fourth
fields.standfirst: Sid Lowe catches up with the Luis Aragonés roadshow and anticipates imminent disintegration at Barcelona as the Spanish season reaches a climax.
fields.trailText: Primera Liga: Sid Lowe catches up with the Luis Aragonés roadshow and anticipates imminent disintegration at Barcelona as the Spanish season reaches a climax.
fields.body:
There really is only one Luis Aragonés. The Mallorca manager - who's kept us entertained all season with punch-ups, "gestures" and the best press conferences in the world ever! - has done it yet again.

As usual, the stage was the San Moix. Mallorca were 1-0 up against Las Palmas and Josico had just wasted an excellent chance to equalise when Canal Plus trained its camera on the veteran boss who was, just for a change, doing his nut.

Blink and you'd have missed it (hooray for videos), but there it was: as another profanity slipped from Aragonés's mouth, so did his teeth. Well, the whole top row of his dentures to be more precise. Unfortunately, he belied his age and reacted swiftly to clamp his jaw shut before the offending item managed to fall clean away. Checking no one was watching, he quickly and surreptitiously chewed his teeth back into place.

Desperately waiting for the break and the chance for a discreet application of Fixadent, Aragonés played safe and kept quiet for a while. Luckily, Guayre's equaliser came right on the stroke of half-time, thereby giving the Wise (Mad) Man of Hortaleza licence to rant away happily in the privacy of the dressing room.

Glue applied, Aragonés was back to his mentalist best in the second half, barking out orders as his side struggled to get the better of Las Palmas, until Carlos grabbed a late - and slightly fortunate - winner.

There was real cause to celebrate too, and not just because the glue seemed to have done the trick - Mallorca's victory lifted them into fourth place and Champions League qualification after Barcelona drew 4-4 for the second week running, this time against Zaragoza in the Nou Camp.

Serra Ferrer's side again had to rely on an injury-time equaliser after being 3-1 and then 4-2 down, with Rivaldo getting his nineteenth of the season to become the league's top scorer.

It all capped a traumatic week for the Catalan giants in which it was announced that some big names could be leaving the club.

Club official Josep María Orobit revealed that Barça would this week negotiate the transfer of Rivaldo to "an important English club" (wonder who that could be?), while Kluivert - not on the best of terms with Serra Ferrer - might, uh-oh, be on his way to the Bernabéu. On top of all that, Gerard has been attracting attention from Milan.

But the biggest shock, of course, has been the announcement that Pep Guardiola will leave in the summer to play out the rest of his career abroad. Guardiola, as he put it himself, came without a hair on his chest and leaves as a father. As the last survivor of Johan Cruyff's Dream Team, captain at the Nou Camp and a champion of Catalanisme (Catalan literacy crusades and the campaign for a Catalan national side) Pep will be sorely missed in Barcelona.

Guti excels himself

As if things Catalan weren't bad enough, Real Madrid took another step towards the title this weekend, with a 4-0 win over Villarreal. Guti was the man of the moment with a performance he described as "the best of my whole life". He hit a sensational volley from 25 yards for his first, and completed a hat-trick with two tap-ins, superbly set up by Steve McManaman and Savio. Roberto Carlos got the other with a great free-kick.

A few weeks ago, McManaman's sensational volley against Oviedo was voted Goal of the Season in a poll on the Marca website (I had nothing to do with it!). Now, much as it pains me to say it, Macca might not be there for much longer.

It may have turned out even better for the Man in the Moustache's side had Deportivo not scored a late winner to finally see-off relegation-threatened Osasuna 2-1 at the Riazor.

Javier Irureta's side remain 8-points behind Madrid, and now turn their attention to Leeds. Midfielder Emerson, the man who single-handedly rescued Soul-Glow during his Middlesborough days, claimed Depor can turn things around when he claimed earlier in the week that "scoring four goals is easier than you think". Emerson was talking about Leeds, but - in view of Barça's last two performances - he might be better telling that to Gerard Houllier.

Osasuna's defeat against Depor leaves them second bottom, level on points with Numancia and two below Racing Santander and Real Sociedad. Numancia came from 3-1 down against la Real to secure a 3-3 draw, and could even have ended up with a win but for the intervention - three times - of the post.

The gloves come off

Down at the bottom no one is giving up and Numancia's battling qualities certainly aren't unique. Real Sociedad have improved since Toshack's arrival, and Racing Santander are also pulling out all the stops - they stunned form side Celta de Vigo 3-0 on Sunday, with Espina, Mazzoni and Regueiro the men on target.

The result of all this is that the relegation three-from-four of a couple of weeks back might now be three-from-five (or possibly even three-from-eight).

After losing 1-0 to Valladolid, Oviedo lay only two points clear of Real Sociedad and Racing. Vallodolid keeper Bizzarri (the man that finally saw john Benjamin get his marching orders at the Bernabéu) was on inspired form and helped the club ease three points clear of Radi Antic's side - not safe, but breathing a little easier.

Level on points with Valladolid, and nervously looking down, are Las Palmas and Athletic Bilbao, who lost 1-0 at home to yet another Raúl Tamudo goal for Espanyol. Either side of them are Málaga and Rayo Vallecano, who drew 1-1 on Sunday.

Now, there are those games that lend themselves to match reports with more puns than a dyslexic bakery. And Saturday night's clash between Valencia and Alavés was one of them. But it was Easter, so forget that Alavés boss, Mané might be Vicente Del Bosque's twin brother, or that having brilliantly guided his side to the Uefa Cup semi (and probably the final) he'll almost certainly be at the helm at Valencia next year. Or even that Alavés won 2-1.

fields.bodyText: There really is only one Luis Aragonés. The Mallorca manager - who's kept us entertained all season with punch-ups, "gestures" and the best press conferences in the world ever! - has done it yet again. As usual, the stage was the San Moix. Mallorca were 1-0 up against Las Palmas and Josico had just wasted an excellent chance to equalise when Canal Plus trained its camera on the veteran boss who was, just for a change, doing his nut. Blink and you'd have missed it (hooray for videos), but there it was: as another profanity slipped from Aragonés's mouth, so did his teeth. Well, the whole top row of his dentures to be more precise. Unfortunately, he belied his age and reacted swiftly to clamp his jaw shut before the offending item managed to fall clean away. Checking no one was watching, he quickly and surreptitiously chewed his teeth back into place. Desperately waiting for the break and the chance for a discreet application of Fixadent, Aragonés played safe and kept quiet for a while. Luckily, Guayre's equaliser came right on the stroke of half-time, thereby giving the Wise (Mad) Man of Hortaleza licence to rant away happily in the privacy of the dressing room. Glue applied, Aragonés was back to his mentalist best in the second half, barking out orders as his side struggled to get the better of Las Palmas, until Carlos grabbed a late - and slightly fortunate - winner. There was real cause to celebrate too, and not just because the glue seemed to have done the trick - Mallorca's victory lifted them into fourth place and Champions League qualification after Barcelona drew 4-4 for the second week running, this time against Zaragoza in the Nou Camp. On top of all that, Gerard has been attracting attention from Milan. But the biggest shock, of course, has been the announcement that Pep Guardiola will leave in the summer to play out the rest of his career abroad. Guardiola, as he put it himself, came without a hair on his chest and leaves as a father. As the last survivor of Johan Cruyff's Dream Team, captain at the Nou Camp and a champion of Catalanisme (Catalan literacy crusades and the campaign for a Catalan national side) Pep will be sorely missed in Barcelona. Guti was the man of the moment with a performance he described as "the best of my whole life". He hit a sensational volley from 25 yards for his first, and completed a hat-trick with two tap-ins, superbly set up by Steve McManaman and Savio. Roberto Carlos got the other with a great free-kick. A few weeks ago, McManaman's sensational volley against Oviedo was voted Goal of the Season in a poll on the Marca website (I had nothing to do with it!). Now, much as it pains me to say it, Macca might not be there for much longer. webTitle: Leader: Politics is the only response to the bombing

fields.headline: Politics is the answer
fields.standfirst:
It is the only response to the bombing

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The weary wisdom of hindsight says it was inevitable. Of course, the so-called Real IRA were not going to let Easter pass without marking the occasion. Of course, they would choose London as their venue, guaranteeing maximum exposure.
fields.body:
The weary wisdom of hindsight says it was inevitable. Of course, the so-called Real IRA were not going to let Easter pass without marking the occasion. Of course, they would choose London as their venue, guaranteeing maximum exposure. And, of course, they would pick a site rich in what Professor Paul Wilkinson, calls "crude symbolism": a sorting office handpicked to echo republican rebels' capture of the Dublin General Post Office during the 1916 Easter Rising.

Equally predictable are the qualifying words and caveats. We still do not know for certain that Saturday's blast in Hendon was the work of the Real IRA. Nor are we likely to: that is not that organisation's style. They have not admitted responsibility for any one of the explosions linked to them since June 1 last year: not the detonation of Hammersmith Bridge last summer, nor the blast outside BBC Television Centre six weeks ago. Nevertheless, the police are not looking any further than the rejectionists of peace who form the Real IRA. After all, the usual tell-tale signs were there: the callous failure to give any advance warning, the choice of a busy area which could have caused bloodshed on a horrific scale. The Real IRA seem determined to stage a "spectacular" eventually, and each one of these events is designed to show they have the means to do it.

So what should be the response? The reflex reaction is to demand a security crackdown that might take three forms: stepping up the pressure on the IRA to disarm, halting any plans for a scaling down of the British security presence in Northern Ireland and hunting down the wicked men who lead the Real IRA. The latter objective is the only one with credibility, with the recent arrest of a suspected leader of "dissident republicanism" a clear step in the right direction. Nevertheless, mainstream republicans - the sworn enemies of the Real IRA - have doubts over that course. They fear locking up the rejectionist leadership will turn them into heroes and martyrs: just look at the propaganda use the Provisional IRA made of its own prisoners.

As to the other two, reflex reactions they do not withstand serious scrutiny. Saturday's bomb exposes once again the futility of demanding IRA disarmament. The Provos could give back their guns and reduce the terrorist threat not one jot: for the hardmen of the Real IRA would still have weapons - and the determination to use them. As for the British security presence in the province, Saturday's events show the limits of its effectiveness, if not its outright impotence. The watchtowers in South Armagh could not prevent Omagh or Hammersmith or White City or Hendon.

Those towers are worse than useless, because they continue to antagonise the nationalist communities who live under their futile gaze. And this is the rub. For the way to truly eliminate the Real IRA is to make them irrelevant, to deny them a constituency. While the peace process is stalled, they can keep arguing that republicans have been "conned" and "suckered" by the peace process. As long as those watchtowers stand, as long as only a diluted version of the Patten report on policing is implemented and as long as Sinn Fein ministers are barred from meeting their Dublin counterparts in the cross-border council, then the Real IRA can keep casting Sinn Fein and the IRA as dupes. Mainstream republicanism has gambled everything on a strategy of politics and negotiation; rejectionist republicanism insists only violence works. It is surely up to unionism and the British government to prove the former right - and the latter wrong.

webTitle: Hollywood rushes movies to beat deadline for strike

fields.headline: Hollywood rushes movies to beat deadline for strike
fields.trailText: The scene is a familiar one: mighty lorries parked around the block and wardrobe mistresses wheeling clothesracks across the street; a policeman keeping an eye on proceedings from behind his shades in the Venice area of Los Angeles.
fields.body:
The scene is a familiar one: mighty lorries parked around the block and wardrobe mistresses wheeling clothesracks across the street; a policeman keeping an eye on proceedings from behind his shades in the Venice area of Los Angeles.

Just another day's filming in LA. But it could be one of the last for weeks. Today representatives of the Writers Guild of America and the movie studios are due to hold a final round of talks about new contract terms. If there is no agreement, a screenwriters' strike is due to start on May 2.

On May 10, the actors' unions are scheduled to start their talks with the studios. If the writers are already on strike, the prediction is that the actors will follow by the end of June.

Film production is racing ahead to finish as much as possible before the possible strike deadline. The studios have stockpiled enough movies to see them through to 2002 and possibly into 2003.

If the strikes go ahead, an army of people who service the film business will also be affected, including agents, make-up artists and drivers. Already some agencies have been laying off staff. Disney has just laid off 4,000 people and AOL Time Warner, 2,400.

The dispute is about the new contracts due to be signed by the writers' and actors' unions.

At issue is how these two groups of people should be paid for the use of their work on videos, the internet, in foreign markets, on cable television and in the largely imponderable world of future communications. The unions say they are seeking only a fair share of the future profits. The studios say their demands are too costly.

With the economy worsening, there is a suspicion that some on the studio side would welcome a strike to slim down the industry.

Writers also believe that the increase in "reality" television from Survivor and Big Brother to Boot Camp and Temptation Island is no coincidence: the TV industry is creating "stars" who cost next to nothing and need no script writers.

The outgoing mayor, Richard Riordan, has now stepped into the fray. Aware of the potential damage to the economy of Los Angeles, where 250,000 people work in the entertainment industry, he has commissioned a study of the potential damage strikes could inflict.

"This is not just a game played between the studios and the other side," he said recently. "It affects the whole city."

The Writers' Guild, which represents 11,000 members, has been filling its war chests. More than $10m (£6.25m) has been set aside for loans to needy members in the event of a strike. The guild's last strike was in 1988; it lasted for 22 weeks and $3.2m was loaned to writers facing hardship.

The median annual income of a screenwriter is currently $84,000. The producers, represented by Disney's Robert Iger and Jeffrey Katzenberg of Dreamworks, say that the demands being made by the writers would amount to $1.6bn over three years in additional costs. The writers say the true figure is closer to $450m.

"If you listen to the guild characterise the issues, it's 'we're being raped'," Steve Bochco, the creator of NYPD Blue, told Variety magazine. "If you listen to the producers, it's 'we're barely surviving'."
